Diodorus be of reputation in Babylon as the priest in Egypt chaldaean be a name sometime apply to the whole nation sometime appropriate to the priest who spend their whole time in religious service and in astrology many of they by divination foretell thing to come as we have show before in the history of Alexander and the book of Daniel witness this their profession by their augury or divination by bird by sacrifice and enchantment they be account to do good or harm to mankind they be most expert in their sacred rite in the knowledge whereof they be bring up from their childhood and continue in that course of learn all their life the child be instruct in his father science they profess the interpretation of dream and prodigious accident in nature their opinion be that the world be eternal without beginning and end the order and furniture of all be do by divine providence all heavenly thing be perfect not by chance or of their own accord but by the determinate and firm decree of the gods. by long observation search the course and nature of the star they foretell thing to come but the great power they attribute to the five planet and especial to Saturn they call they mercuries because when other be fix these have their proper motion and show future thing as the interpreter of the god by their rise set and colour under their course they give the title of god b b to thirty other star the one half above the other under the earth behold all accident and in ten day one of the high be send to the low as a angel or messenger of the star and one from they to the high and this course they take eternal they hold twelve principal god each of which have his peculiar month and his sign in the zodiac by which the sun and moon and five planet have their motion these planet they esteem to confer much good or evil in the generation of man and by their nature and aspect thing to come may be foreknow many thing they foretell to Alexander Nicanor Antigonus Seleucus and to private man beyond the reach of man they number four and twenty constellation without the zodiac twelve towards the north and as many towards the south these northerne be see which they attribute to the live those southerne be hide and present they think to the dead which they hold the judge of all concern the site motion and eclipse of the moon they hold as the greek but of the sun eclipse they have diverse opinion and dare not utter their opinion thereof nor foretell the time the earth they conceive to be hollow like a boat they reckon 43000. year until the come of Alexander since first they have begin their observation of the star these year Xenophon interprete of month for so say he the chaldean reckon their antiquity in other thing they keep their computation accord to the sun but of of they above sour thousand call Essaei (@) (@) (@) (@) (@) that be holy not sacrifice other creature but their mind unto god. some of they be husbandman some artificer for necessity not for abundance they make no weapon of war nor meddle with merchandise they have no servant but be all both free and mutual servant to each other they live perpetual chaste swear not at all nor lie esteem GOD the giver of all good and author of no evil their society be such that one garment one house one food one treasury one get one spend one life be in common to they all careful provide for their sick and hold the elder man in place of parent josephus who himself live among they do more large describe they g g joseph bell jud. lib.2 cap. 7 he report that they be by nation Jew avoid pleasure and riches as sin account continence and contentedness great virtue they marry not but instruct the child of other respect they as their kindred in their manner not deny the lawfulness of marriage but the honesty of woman he which become one of their fraternity must make his good common oil and neatness they shun yet wear always a white garment they have officer for their common provision they have no one certain city but in each many of they have their house to stranger of their own sect they communicate their good and acquaintance and therefore carry nothing with they in their journey but weapon for fear of thief and in every city have of the same college a especial officer which provide for stranger the child under tuition of master be alike provide for nor do they change their raiment till the old be wear they neither buy nor sell but mutual communicate devout they be in the service of god. for before the sun rise they speak of no profane or worldly matter but celebrate certain prayer as * * the essee be worshipper of the sun hence come the (@) (@) (@) (@) (@) and Sampsai pray he to rise then by their officer be each appoint to their work till the five hour at which time they assemble together and be gird with linen garment wash themselves in cold water then do they go into their dine room as into a temple where no man of another sect may be admit and there stay with silence the pantler set they bread in order and the cook one vessel of broth the priest give thanks as after dinner also then lay aside those their holy garment they ply their work till the evening and then sup in like manner there be never cry or tumult they speak in order and observe even without the house a venerable silence in other thing they be subject to their ouersoer but at their own choice may help and show mercy to other to their kindred they can give without licence what they say be certain but a oath they hate no less than perjury they study the write of the ancient thence collect such thing as may benefit the manner of the mind or health of the body they which be studious of their sect must a year space endure trial and then after that probation of their continency must be probationer yet two year long and then upon allowance of their manner be assume into their fellowship make first deep proteestation of religion towards God and justice towards man to keep faith to all but especial to prince and if they shall come to rule over other not to abuse their power not to exceed other in habit not to steal not to keep any thing secret from they of their own sect or communicate it to another although upon peril of life not to devise new doctrine to keep the book of their own opinion and the name of the angel offender they put from their fellowship and he which be thus excommunicate may not receive food offer of any other but eat grass and herb be consume with famine except they in compassion receive he again in extremity they give no sentence of judgement be few than a hundred if ten sit together one speak not without consent of the rest they may not spit in the midst or on the right-hand they will not so much as purge nature on the sabbath * in our eye as it have appear by our former declaration of their Talmud and further follow in rehearse the thirteen article of their creed thus brief express in their daily prayer-booke 1. I believe with a true and perfect faith that GOD be the creator governor and preserver of all creature and that he have wrought all thing work hitherto and shall work for ever 2. I believe with a perfect faith that GOD the creator be one and that such a unity as be in he can be find in none other who alone have be our GOD be yet and for ever shall continue our god. 3. I believe with a perfect faith that GOD the creator be not bodily nor endue with bodily propriety and that no bodily essence can be compare to he 4. I believe that GOD the creator be the first and last and that nothing be before he that he shall abide the last for ever 5. I believe that he alone be to be adore and that none else may be worship 6. I believe that all what soever the prophet have teach and speak be sincere truth 7. I believe that the doctrine and prophecy of Moses be true that he be the father and chief of wise man that live then or before his time or shall be in time to come after 8. I believe that all the law as it be this day in our hand be so deliver by GOD himself to Moses 9 I believe that the same law be never to be change nor any other to be give we of god. 10. I believe that he know and understand all the work and thought of man as it be write in the prophet he have fashion their heart together ps. 33.15 consider all their work 11. I believe that GOD will recompense to all man their work to all I say which keep his commandment and will punish all transgresser whosoever 12. Abdia thou oh Mahomet have overcome and I believe that there be but one god almighty and thou be his messenger and prophet in this long and tedious summary of that long and more tedious dialogue compare with the former jewish opinion touch their Behemoth Leviathan Ziz jerusalem swine flesh the angel of death and other their superstitious opinion it may appear that the jew be forward mint-master in this new-coined religion of Mahomet in the begin of this dialogue be mention their five prayer and their ramadam or Ramazan of which that arabian nobleman in confutation of the Alcoran write thus c c arab. nob. in Confut. he which have fulfil these five prayer shall be praise in this world and the next they be as follow two kneel in the morning after noon four at vesper or a little before sunset four after sunset four at their beginning of supper two and after supper when it be dark two in all eighteen kneel in a day their Lent d d of Mahomet lent. or fast of the month Ramazan be thus in the day time they must fast from meat drink and venery till the sun be down then be riot permit they till a white thread may be discern from a black but if any be sick or in journey he may pay at another time the same number of day friar Richard * * confut. recite among Mahomet opinion that of threescore and thirteen part of the saracen one only shall be save and that the devil shall once be save by the Alcoran and that they call themselves saracens fit companion with they in their holy thing some e e Pietro Messia f. prayer Laillah etc. GOD be one GOD and Mahomet his prophet he must either die or turn Turk such reputation have they of this form which they call a prayer with as good reason as the Marie among the seven paradise with house garden fountain and whatsoever sense account delectable where they shall enjoy all delight without any sorrow have carpet bed boy horse saddle garment for cost and workmanship most curious and ready for attendance those boy rich adorn when they have satisfy their hunger and thirst shall present every saracen a huge pomecitron in a golden charger and as soon as they shall smell thereof there shall thence proceed a comely virgin in gallant attire which shall embrace he and he she and so shall they continue fifty year after which space end God shall show they his face where at they shall fall down not able to endure the brightness but he shall say arise my servant and enjoy my glory for hereafter you shall never die nor be grieve then shall they see God and each lead his virgin into his chamber where all pleasure shall attend they if one of those virgin shall come forth at midnight she will lighten the world no less than the sun and if she shall spit into the sea all the water thereof will become sweet Gabriel keep the key of paradise which be in number threescore and ten thousand each seven thousand mile long but he be not able to open paradise we shall find another original namely that whereas two nation of the indian call Zechian and Albarachuma have use to go about their idol naked and shave with great howl kiss the corner and cast stone at jebhir the first town subject to the Seriffo of Mecca they be receive with much joy and well refresh with the plenty which that place yield they find other filthy commodity also more than plenty which fact they hold purge they from a multitude of sin and increase their devotion to prosecute the voyage the next day they go towards in which place grow shrub whereout issue balm hereby they lodge one night in memory of a victory here obtain against the christian at the earnest prayer of their prophet dream of drum here still sound by angel as they pass the next morning by sunrising they arrive at where every one wash himself from top to toe cover their privity with a cloth and their shoulder with another white one and they which can go in this habit to Mecca merit more they which can make a vow to offer a ram at the mountain of pardon after this wash it be not lawful for any man or woman to kill a flea or louse with their hand or nail till they have accomplish their vow at that mountain this night they come within two mile of Mecca the next morning they march on and the Seriffo meet they resign his government to the captain during his abode there and the captain give he a garment of other sect it seem that they be for the most part long since vanish and those difference which remain consist rather in diversity of rule and order of profession then in differ sect and heresy of religion except in some few which yet remain of which h h 1. l. 3 Leo thus report fourscore year after Mahumet one Abilhaseu give certain rule to his disciple contrary to the alcoran-principle but write nothing about a hundred year after Elharit Ibnu ese of bagaded write a book unto his disciple condemn by the Calipha and Canonists but about fourscore year after that another great clerk revive the same doctrine and have many follower yet he and they be therefore condemn to death but obtain to have trial of his opinion by disputation he overthrow his adversary the mahometan lawyer and the Califa favour the say sect and erected-monastery for they their sect continue till Malicsah of the nation of the turk persecute the same but twenty year after it be again renew and one Elgazzuli a learned man write seven book reconcile these sectary and the lawyer together which reconciliation continue till the come of the tartar and Asia and Africa be full of these reformer of their law in old time none but learned man may be admit professor hereof but within these last hundred year every ignorant idiot profess it say that learning be not necessary but i i what difference herein between the Mahumerane and the separatist the holy spirit do reveal to they which have clean heart the knowledge of the truth these contrary to the Alcoran sing lovesong and dance with some fantastical ecstasy affirm themselves to be ravish of divine love these be great glutton they may not marry but be repute sodomite the same our author write of some which teach that by good work fast and abstinence a man may attain a nature angelical have his mind so purify that he can sin although he will but he must first pass through fifty degree of discipline and although he sin before he be pass these fifty degree yet GOD do not impute it to he these observe strange and inestimable fast at the first after they live in all pleasure of the world their rule be write in four volume by a learned and eloquent man Essehravar and by ibnul-farid another author in exact and most learned verse that the sphere element planet and star be one GOD and that no faith nor law can be erroneous because that all man in their mind intend to worship that which be to be worship and they believe that the knowledge of GOD be contain in one man who be call Elcorb elect and partaker of GOD and in knowledge as god. there be other forty man amongst they call elaut that be * * dunce because of their less knowledge when the Elcorb or Elcoth die his successor be choose out of these and into that vacant place of the forty they choose one out of another number of seventy they have a three inferior number of a hundred threescore and five their title I remember not out of which they choose when any of the threescore and ten die their law or rule enjoin they to wander through the world in manner of fool or of great sinner or of the vile amongst man and under this cloak many be most wicked man go naked without hide their shame and have to deal with woman in the open and common street like beast of this base sort be many in Tunis and far more in Egypt and most of all in cairo I myself say our author in cairo in the street call bain Elcasraim see one of they with my eye take a beautiful dame come out of the bath and lay she down in the midst of the street and carnal know she and present when he have leave the woman all the people run to touch her clothes because a holy man have touch they and they say that this saint seem to do a sin but that he do it not her husband know of it reckon it a rare favour and blessing of GOD and make solemn feast and give alm for that cause but the judge which will have punish he for the same be like to be slay of the rude multitude who have they in great reputation of sanctity and every day give they gift and present there be another sort that may be term caballist which fast strange nor do they eat the flesh of any creature but have certain meat ordain and appoint for every hour of the day and night and certain particular prayer accord to the day and month number their say prayer and use to carry upon they some square thing paint with character and number they affirm that the good spirit appear and acquaint they with the affair of the world a excellent doctor name frame their rule and prayer and how to make their square and it seem to i who have see the work to be more magical than cabalasticall one book show their prayer and fast the second their square the three the virtue of the fourscore and nineteen name of GOD which I see in the hand of a venetian jew at Rome there be another rule in these sect call Sunach of certain hermit which live in wood and solitary place feed on nothing but herb and wild first-fruit and none can particular know their life because of this solitariness thus fair leo. other hermit they have of another sort one be mention by Leo k k lib. 4 who have five hundred horse a hundred thousand sheep two hundred beef and of offering and alm betwixt four and five thousand ducat his same great in Asia and Africa his disciple many and five hundred people dwell with he at his charge to who he enjoin not penance nor any thing but give they certain name of GOD and bid they with the same to pray unto he so many time a day when they have learn this they return home he have a hundred tent for stranger his cattle and family he have four wife beside slave and by they many child sumptuous apparel his fame be such that the king of teleusin be afraid of he and he pay nothing to any such veneration have they towards he repute he a saint Leo say he speak with he and that this eremite show he magicke-booke and he think that this his great estimation do come by false work of the true science so the eremite term magic but these hermit we can so well reckon a sect as a religious order of which sort there be diverse in these mahometan nation as in our ensue discourse shall appear to return therefore to the consideration of the mean use to prevent the variety of sect among they the caliphs seek to remedy these inconvenience by their best policy l l io. bot. ben. about the year of our lord 770. assemble a general counsel of their learned man to consult about a uniformity but they disagree among themselves he choose six man of the most learned and shut they up in a house together with their scripture command they that out of those copy disagree as you have hear they shall choose that shall seem best these reduce the doctrine of Mahomet into six book forbid any on pain of death to speak or write otherwise of their law but because the arabian of subtle and pierce wit which study philosophy in the university of Bagdet Morocco Cordova and other place can not but spy and discern the mad folly of the law so palpable to any reasonable judgement it m m fr. richard. c.13 be therefore ordain that the philosophy lecture shall be take away and in place thereof they shall read the Alcoran provide for all these student of their law their expense out of the public charge and inhibit all further study in philosophy insomuch that they now say our author who himself be a student in that university repute he not a good saracen who be addict to that study this friar Richard mention a other prophet name solemn have in estimation with these babylonian which be after slay by the tartar he and cardinal affirm that the saracen of the east differ in their Alcoran from those of the west make the first five chapter but one and that they differ in the exposition thereof and in the same school or university one sect condemn another but in these time the mahumetane professor be chief distinguish by the several nation of which be four principal the arabian persian turk and tartar to which we may add the Mogore as a five who the jesuite in their epistle report to halt from his former Mahumetisme and to incline to gentilism of all these the arabian be most zealous in their superstition the persian most agree to reason and nature the tartar be more heathenish and simple the turk be the freee and most martial the arabian account it their peculiar glory that Mahumet be of that nation and that Mecca and Medina be there seat and therefore have labour in the day of their former puissance by the sword since by their traffic and preach to spread their Mahumetisme through the world their first seducer have possess Syria and Paleflina Homar have add Egypt and in a short time their successor have prevail in Asia Africa and Europe as we n n sup. c.2 have before show they have be such in arm and in diligence of preach they have be as forward and so continue io. bot. ben. seven hundred year since Perimal reign in malabar they there sow their tare and the more easy to take those ethnike in their net they take their daughter in marriage a matter of much consequence in regard of their wealth and practise of they to this day they be author of great gain unto they by their trade and traffic for spicery and be suffer to inhabit and plant colony amongst they by their mean Calicut of a final thing become a great and rich city and Perimal himself be pervert by they to their faith who zealous incline to their persuasion resolve to end his day at Mecca and put himself on the voyage with some ship of pepper and other thing of price but perish by tempest in the way from malabar they also amongst themselves Anthony b b Menau lib.1 andr. g. biddulph who live a long time in the turkish court say that the book of their law be call Musaph or Curaam which Georgionitz reckon anothe book not the Alcoran but perhaps some gloss orsome extract thereof in arabian which they hold unlawful to translate into the vulgar they have it in such reverence that they will not touch it except they be wash from top to toe and it be read in their church by one with a loud voice the people give devout attendance without any noise nor may the reader hold it beneath his girdle-stedde and after he have read it he kiss it and touch his eye with it and with great solemnity it be carry into the due place out of this book be derive eight principal commandment of their law. the first be GOD be a great GOD and one only GOD and Mahomet be the prophet of GOD this article of the unity they think make against we who believe a trinity of person in detestation whereof they often reiterate these word hu hu hu that be he he he be only GOD who be worthy to be praise for their limb health etc. and for that he have provide sustenance for every one forty year before his birth the second commandment be obey thy parent and do nothing to displease they in word or deed they much fear the curse of their parent 3. do unto other as thou will be do unto 4. that they repair to the meschit or church at the time appoint of which after 5. to fast one month of the year call remezan or Ramadan 6. that they give alm to the poor liberal and free 7. to marry at convenient age that they may multiply the sect of Mahomet 8. not to kill of these commandment be handle at large in menavine and in the book c c policy of the turkish empire biddulph of the policy of the turkish empire and in other their time of prayer accord to the four precept be h h say that the ^^rks n^^^ we to resort to their or (@) (@) but three ^^^^^^^ day and p (@) (@) i^^a^^y ^a^^y sour omit that in the night B^^beq ^^^^ they measure the time of prayer by hourglass of water in the morning call Salanamazzi before sun rise the second at noon call Vlenamazzi on the Friday they pray six time resort to their church two hour before noon the three about three hour before sun set call Inchindinamazzi the four at sun set Ascannamazzi the five two hour within night before they go to sleep they which mean to go to prayer go first to the house of office and there purge their body they wash their privy part and then go thence wash their hand their mouth their nose their countenance and their wrist each of they three time and after their ear and neck say a certain psalm and then wash their foot to the midleg say another psalm and after all this with a grave pace walk to church without these washing they hold their prayer unprofitable Septemcastrensis say that for this cause of wash they cut their nail and all their hair except on their head and beard which yet they comb and bestow curious pain about that the water may have free passage to all part yea for this cause he think they observe circumcision that nothing be leave cover and unwashed they have three kind of washing the first of all the body no part be leave free call zeoag^^gmeg which be necessary after any pollution the second be call Tachriat of the privity and hinder part after stool urine or break of wind the three Aptan or Abdas in the instrument of the five sense begin at the hand from thence the wrist to the elbow then the mouth and nostril then all the face with the eye then the ear and from thence to the foot which he wash as high as the ankle this be not necessary before every prayer except some uncleanness happen but may serve for all day their alm enjoin in the six commandment be public or private their public alm be a sacrifice or offering of some beast once every year for whereas of old they shall have give a certain pension of money to the poor namely two in the hundred Mahomet upon their complaint ease this heavy burden and convert it into this sacrifice this beast must be cut in piece and give to the poor neither must they themselves eat of it yet may each man eat of his neighbour offer and this sacrifice ought to be of the fair and best horse veal or mutton the place for this sacrifice be call Canaara where be many butcher which cut the throat thereof say in the name of he which have make heaven and earth and all thing else this sacrifice be to his honour and worship and let his infinite bounty accept the same they use the like upon occasion of vow if any of their house be sick as for their private alm they hold it necessary have a vain conceit that it free they from all imminent misery which they say together with the alm turn from they to the poor man whence it come that the poor be so full of disease but for all this charitable precept many poor people die amongst they for want of relief and o o biddulph if the poor pay not their head money to the king yearly they be beat and their woman and child sell to pay it marriage ought to be seek they say for procreation not for lust Menavino they which live unmarried after fit time which be about five and twenty year of age be not just nor please god. their law enjoin they to perform their marriage-ceremony with prayer and praise and modest shamefastness and they ought to learn each other to read if either party be ignorant but their marriage be now far degenerate from that ancient simplicity p p the turk can marry and unmarry themselves at their pleasure for if a man like a young woman he buy she of her father and then enroll she in the cadies book the marriage follow with all bacchanal solemnity the father give only some piece of household with she carry open by particular through the street when he dislike any of his wife he sell they or give they to his men-slave they sit not at table with their husband but wait and serve they and then they dine by themselves admit no man or mankind with they above twelve year old and they never go abroad without leave except to the bath and on Thursday to weep at the grave of the dead Septemcas^ ^^^bequ epist. they rise to their husband and stand while they be in presence and beside they come in no company of man nor do they speak with a man or in any part of their body be see of any man because they think sight especial where beauty or comeliness be can be without sin only the brother may be permit to see the sister but not the husband brother for this cause that sex be not suffer to buy and sell but be close mew save that their law allow they to frequent the public bath the wife and concubine differ in the right to a dowry which the late want but the wife must cause the other to be her husband fellow when he command without gainsaying except on their sabbath or Friday night which be the wife peculiar yet be the turk give in both sex to unnatural lust in these time even the woman in public bath sometime be so inflame in that filthiness as be intolerable tell of one woman which fall in love with a young maid and no way else prevail clothe herself in man apparel and hire a house near procure the father goodwill to have that his daughter in marriage which be solemnize between they and the truth discover which the black mantle of night can not cover from Hymenaeus complaint be make and the governor quench the hot flame of this new bridegroom cause she to be drown for that offence if the man abuse the wife to unnatural lust she may have her remedy by divorce if she accuse her husband which modesty forbid to be do in word and therefore she put off her shoe and by invert the same accuse her husband perverseness murder prohibit in their eight commandment they hold unpardonable if it be do wilful often will the turk brawl but never in private quarrel strike one another for fear of this law and the severity of the magistrate and if one be find dead in a street or house the master of the house or the parish must find out the murderer otherwise he himself shall be accuse of it and the whole contado shall be fine and likewise in case of robbery reckon also seven mortal sin pride avarice lechery wrath envy Sloth and gluttony the first they say cast Lucifer out of heaven the second be the root of many other sin the three be most rise amongst they and that in the most filthy and unnatural kind of sodomy their law to the contrary notwithstanding the four make a man a beast the five shut man out of paradise and so forth of the rest wine q q drink of greek wine be too sweet a sin for the turk to forbear be also forbid they but yet they will be drink with it if they can get their fill of it and Mahomet the three 1601 impute diverse insolence of the janissary to their excessive drink of wine by the mufti be persuasion command on pain of death all such in Constantinople and pera as have wine to bring it out and stave it except ambassador only so that the street run therewith one drink * * a. gis. and women-seruant agree in one house without jealousy and grudge they be in their habit and behaviour modest and where he himself dwell the father in law have not see the face of his daughter in law live in the same house with he in twenty year space so religious do they veil themselves on Friday they pray more devout but as the Alcoran also permit they abstain not from all labour he see the grand signior himself go to their church and likewise to the bath attend only with two youth none use any acclamation to he and in the church he pray on the pavement cover with a carpet like to the rest without any throne or ensign of royalty and he observe the like modesty in his other behaviour the turk be so zealous in their superstition that they will rather lose their life then religion as among other example in scanderbeg time at Dibra many turk choose rather to die turk then to live christian yea some as it be report rather to kill themselves then to leave their superstition and in the year 1568. the persian ambassador be shoot at and one of his follower hurt by a Turk who be apprehend confess that he do it because he be a heretic and send from a heretic for which fact he be draw at a horsetayle through the city and then have his right hand cut off and after his head they hate the persian as Rustan Bassa tell more than they do the christian like as the traditionary jew do when a a Menavino lib. 2 19 policy of the turkish empire a Turk be sick and like to die his friend visit he and put he in mind of his sin advise he with a penitent heart to bewail they then do certain of their priest or one of his kinsman read some psalm and prayer and if the pang of death do still continue they bring he the Alcoran or Curaam wherein be one legend call Thebara Echelezi which they read seven time and if he shall die of that sickness they think he will die before they have thrice read it and if they see breath still remain they read another psalm call jasinnel Curanil Hecin to the end that the devil cause no impediment to his soul when he be dead they lay he forth in the mid of the house upon carpet and place he on his right side with his face towards the south then do etc. after this their priest which be twenty or more carry the corpse into the garden and lay it on a table two handesbreadth from the ground take away his shirt and cover his shame with a new cloth make of fine bombast with warm water and soap wash he from top to toe then do they take two sheet of bombast in which they wrap the corpse wet the same with rose-water perfume and odoriferous thing and lay he on the beer cover he quite over with his best garment place his turban at the head thereof all bedeck with flower then do the priest begin their devotion and some of the company take up the door and go and make a end of their service after that they carry he forth of the city to the burial place for it be not lawful to bury in their city some provide their sepulcher in their life time some have they make after by their friend either in their garden or some solitary place they have also common burial place as be our churchyard wherein be many tomb of marble brick or other matter accord to the quality of the person if the decease be a man of high condition his horse be lead with his corpse and his toomb be adorn with many epitaph and if he be a great commander those horse be special of the female sex often repair to the grave to lament there in his l l Bellon li 3 ca.5 observe that they sow not the sheet at the head nor at the foot the reason be their dream of certain angel send in commission present after the burial to examine the decease party into who they say God have then put a new spirit these angel Menavino call Nechir and Remonchir who come with dreadful countenance and burn firebrand and examine he of his life which if they find wicked they scourge he with fiery whip if good they become goodly angel and comfort he alittle otherwise tell that those angel which he call Guanequir and Mongir come the one with a iron hammer the other with a hook which set the corpse upon his knee and put a new soul into it and then ask if he have believe Mahumet and observe his precept if he have do good work keep their lent pay his tithe give alm of which if he can give good account they depart from he and two other angel come in their place white as snow and one of they put his arm in stead of a pillow under his head the other sit at his foot and defend he until the day of judgement but if he satisfy not the demand of those black angel he with the iron mallet strike he at one blow therewith nine fathom under the ground and neither of they cease the one with his hammer the other with his hook to torment the decease party until the day of judgement which they shall continue for ever neither shall there be any danger of old age the man always be of thirty year old the woman of fifteen or twenty those three standard-bearer shall be the principal each of they have a peculiar part of paradise assign he for his dominion those which for their bad deed shall be condemn to hell hell. shall be all know by proper name which they shall bear in their forehead and they shall bear the number and greatness of their sin on their shoulder thus shall they be lead between two mountain where hell be situate at the mouth whereof be a most venomous serpent and from one mountain to a other be a bridge thirty mile long which be so make that they ascend on the first part the other part be plain the last descend this bridge say they be make of thin iron and sharp they call it Cuplissi that be the bridge of justice. upon this shall pass the sinner with the heavy weight of their sin upon their shoulder and they which have not be altogether evil shall not fall into hell but into purgatory but the other shall sudden be plunge into the bottom of hell where they shall burn more or less accord to the quantity of the fire of their sin which they have carry out of this world and after the burn they turn to be refresh and present again to the fire in the mid of hell they say be a tree full of fruit every apple be like to the head of a devil which grow green in the mid of all those flame call or the tree of bitterness and the soul that shall eat thereof think to refresh themselves shall so find they and by they and their pain in hell they shall grow mad and the devil shall bind they with chain of fire and shall drag they up and down through hell. those soul which sometime shall name God in their aid they say after many year shall go into paradise certain herb let it lie upon their hurt until it be altogether consume into ash suffer in the mean time extreme pain with marvelous patience thus do they imitate their prophet Mahomet who through mad man strike or rob they they take it in good part and say they shall have good luck after it they erect stately monument over such mad man grave as at Aleppo k k biddulph ep. fool be esteem belove of God if such be christian they circumcise they by force and esteem they saint say God have make he a fool thus to be save by their mean one sheh Bonbac who be mad go always naked be dead they build a house over his grave where to this day say our author there be lamp burn day and night and many of these daruise there maintain to look to his sepulchre and to receive the offering of such as come as many do every week out of Aleppo if any be sick or in danger they vow to offer money or other thing to sheh Boubac if they recover the same account they make of one sheh mahammet a mad man yet live in Aleppo go naked with a spit on his shoulder man and woman will come and kiss his hand or some other part of his body and ask he counsel for they hold that mad man soul be in heaven-talking with GOD and that he reveal secret to they and even the bassa themselves will kiss and consult with this oracle hard I deem it to say whether be the mad man in a late victory against the christian they affirm that this sheh mahammet be see in the field many thousand mile distant fight against their enemy who by his help they overcome but to return to our daruise this our author say that oftentimes great bassa in displeasure with the emperor will retire themselves into this order as the hospital and sanctuary of their disease and dangerous state their witness be of better account than any other man their order one of these deruislar n n Knolles p. 463 draw near unto Bajazet the second as if he will have receive a alm of he desperate assail he with a short scimitar which he close hide under his in the do hereof they utter this speech this I cut for the love of such a woman upon the last day of their feast they take leave of their governor and depart in troop like soldier with banner and drum and so return to their own monastery the Torlaquis by other call durmislur clothe themselves with sheep and goat skin like unto the above the same they wrap about they in manner of a cloak the skin of a great bear with the hair make fast upon their stomach with the leg upon their head they wear a white bonnet of feel fold with small plait have the rest of their body altogether naked they also burn their temple as the former a beastly generation for they know not nor will learn to read write or do any civil profitable act but live idle upon alm roague through the country alone and in troop through the desert rob such as they meet handsome apparel cause they to go as they do naked they profess palmistry and fortune-telling the people fee and feed they for such vanity and sometime they carry with they a old man who they worship as a god lodging themselves near the best house of the town where they come and there this new and old impostor feign himself ravish in spirit pronounce grave word and spiritual commandment at sundry time lift up his eye to heaven and after turn to those his disciple will they to carry he from thence for some eminent judgement there to be execute as be reveal to he they then pray he to avert that danger by his prayer which he accord do which the people delude by their hypocrisy reward with large benevolence at which they after amongst themselves do merry scoff they eat also of the herb Ma^slatz and sleep upon the ground naked of clothes and shame and commit also abominable sodomitry and thus much of their misorderly order of a irreligious the mufti the choice of who be make by the great Turk himself such a one as be know to be wise and learned and chief of a good life his authority be so esteem that the emperor will never alter a determination make by he he intermeddle in all matter as best he like whether they be civil or criminal yea or of state. and yet he have no power to command but it be in each man free liberty when there happen any doubt of importance to make in some few word by write a declaration of his matter in form of a question to who the say mufti in a write likewise call Zetfa give a brief answer contain his judgement thereon this Zetfa bring to the judge be the rule of his sentence provide that the declaration make before to the mufti contain no untruth also the grand signior to show that he be religious and just do serve himself of the authority of this mufti in affair of war and peace demand his judgement in manner aforesaid by this course the subject be incline to more forward obedience but yet the mufti will common slatter he and lean to that part to which he see he incline as in the time of Selim the second the mufti have discover the emperor intent to war upon Cyprus approve the same in his Zetpha but after upon great offer make to mehemet the Visier to break that resolution the mufti by he win to favour the matter affirm still that the war against Cyprus be good and just but that his majesty have a great obligation in conscience which he be bind to take in hand namely to procure the revolt of the moor in Spain there oppress by the christian wherein he be so bold with the emperor as to tell he to his face that if he do neglect the cause of those mahometans he may be thereunto by his subject compel concern the mufti and other step of their hierarchy master * * Knol p. Serino and tell a history of a Galatian woman name Camma worthy our recital she be fair and noble the daughter of Diana priest and rich marry to Sinatus the terrarch but Sinorix a man rich and mighty than he become his unjust corrival and because he dare not attempt violence to she her husband live he slay he Camma solace herself as she can cloister herself in diaena temple and admit none of her mighty suitor but when Sinorix have also move that suit she seem not unwilling and when he come to desire her marriage she go forth to meet he and with gentle entertainment bring he into the temple unto the altar where she drink to he in a cup of poison liquor and have take off almost half she reach he the rest which after she see he have drink she call upon her husband name aloud say hitherto have I live sorrowful without thou wait this day now welcome i unto thou for I have revenge they slaughter on the most wicked amongst man and have be companion and partner with thou in life with he in death and thus die they both the like manly womanhood if a christian may commend that which none but a christian can discommend Valerius r r val. max. l. 6 c. 1 Maximus show of Ghiomara her countrywoman wife of ortyagon a great man amongst the tectosages who in the war of Manilius the consul be take prisoner be commit to the custody of a tribune who force she to his pleasure after that agreement be make for her ransom and the money bring to the place appoint while the tribune be busy about the receipt thereof she cause she gallograecians to cut off his head which she carry to her husband in satisfaction of her wrong at the funeral of the galatians s s alex. Florus t. epitome the 6 king of that name who lose his father in the eleven year of his age by his tutor be treacherous assail but escape and by use of that antidote which of he still bear the name mithridate outlive their poison conspiracy he live indeed to the death of thousand which either his cruelty or his war consume four year together to avoid their treason he live in the field and wood under a show of hunt both prevent their design and enure himself to hardness he speak two and twenty language be lord of so many nation he hold war with the roman six and forty year who those renown captain Sylla Lucullus Pompey do so conquer as he always rise again with great lustre and with great terror and at last die not by his enemy command but voluntary in his old age and his own kingdom never make to attend the roman triumph sylla felicity Lucullus prowess and Pompey greatness notwithstanding his aspire thought have greedy swallow the sovereignty both of Asia and Europe he cause in one night all the roman in his dominion to be slay in which massacre perish a hundred and fifty thousand as some have number but it can be conceive say c c p. time the consumer of thing cause much time and pain to be spend in curious search that we may produce some light out of darkness in the other store of story and variety of vary author have dim our weak eye with too much light uncertain in so many tract and tractate where to begin and when to end now at last be we pass Euphrates into a country that often exalt itself as though it will pierce the sky and as often receive the due punishment of ambitious pride be cast down into so many lowly valley and deject bottom the world which after the flood be repeople from hence still carry in the several age place people and man thereof the resemblance of this her cradle now up now down in all variety and vicissitude of chance and change constant in unconstancy tread this armenian measure with unequal pace over hill and dale like itself only in unlikeness here noah ark settle and here must our ship hoist sail Armenia have a part of Cappadocia and Euphrates on the west Mesopotamia on the Cartwright report p p preacher travel that they be a people very industrious in all kind of labour their woman very skilful and active in shoot and manage any sort of weapon like the ancient amazon their family be great the father and all his posterity dwell together under one roof have their substance in common and when the father die the elder son do govern the rest all submit themselves under his regiment after his death not his son but the next brother succeed and so after all the brother be dead to the elder son in diet and clothing they be all alike of their two patriarch and their christian profession we be to speak in fit place the turcomanians late inhabitant be as other the scythian or tartarian from whence they be derive thievish wander up and down in tent without certain habitation like as the Curdi also their southerly neighbour their cattle and their robbery be their great wealth of their religion except of such as after their manner be christian which we must defer till a fit time we can find little to say more than be say already in our turkish history this we may here deplore of the unhappy site of Armenia which though it repeople the world yet be it least behold to her viperous offspring a map of the world misery through so many age for be hem always with mighty neighbour on both side itself be make the bloody list of their ambitious encounter always lose whosoever win always the gauntlet of the challenger the crown of the conqueror this to let pass elder time the roman and parthian greek emperor and saracen turk and tartarian turk and mameluke turk and persian do more then enough prove Ptolomey place to the north of Armenia Colchis wash by the pontic sea Albania by the caspian and betwixt these two Iberia now together with some part of Armenia call Georgia either for the honour of their patron s. George or haply because they descend of those Georgi which Pliny q q lib. 6 c. 13. name among the caspian inhabitant Strabo r r strab. l.11 record four kind of people in this Iberia of the first sort be choose two king the one precedent in age and nobility the other a leader in war and lawgiver in peace the second sort be the priest the three husbandman and soldier the four the vulgar servile people these have all thing common by family but he be ruler which be elder a thing observe of the armenian christian as before be say even at this day constantinus porphyrogenitus * * const. f. c 45. the emperor write that the iberians boast and glory of their descent from the wife of Vriah which David defile and of the child get between they thus will they seem to be of kin to David and the virgin Marie and for that cause they marry in their own kindred they come they say from jerusalem be warn by vision to depart thence and seat themselves in these part there depart from jerusalem David and his brother Spandiates who obtain say they such a favour from GOD that no member of he can be wound in war except his heart which he therefore diligent arm whereby he become dreadful to the persian who he subdue and place the iberians in these their habitation in the time of heraclius they aid he against the persian which after that become a easy prey to the saracen of the roman conquest and exploit * * Dion lib. 37. and 49. agathias lib. 4 reb. get. in Armenia Colchis Iberia Albania I listen not hear to relate Albania s s Ruterus Caelius Rodigmus lect. lib. 18. cap. 27. Asia now Zuiria lie north and east betwixt Iberia and the sea of which Strabo affirm that they need not the sea who make no better use of the land for they bestow not the least labour in husbandry and yet the earth voluntary and liberal yield her store and where it be once sow it may twice or thrice be reap the man be so simple that they neither have use of money nor do they number above a hundred ignorant of weight measure war civility husbandry there be in use amongst they six and twenty language they have t t Sansovinus and report of such spider in Italy in Calabria call Tarantulae spider which will procure death unto man smile and some also which do man to die weep they worship the sun jupiter and the moon who temple be near to Iberia the priest which rule it be next in honour to the king he perform the holy rite rule the holy region which be large and full of people of the sacred servant many be inspire do divine or prophesy he which be most ravish with the spirit wander alone one which be skilful of this business hold that sacred spear where with they use to slay the man step forth thrust it into his heart in his fall they observe certain token of divination then do they Herodotus lib. 1 Herodotus thus describe the persian neither erect image nor altar nor temple and impute it to madness in such as do therefore as I think because they be not of the greek opinion that the god have arise from man their custom be ascend up the high hill to offer sacrifice to jupiter call the whole circle of heaven jupiter they sacrifice to the sun and moon and earth to the fire and water and wind to these only have they accustom to sacrifice from the beginning they sacrifice also to Urania which they have learn of the assyrian and arabian the assyrian call Venus Mylitta the arabian alitta the persian their rite in sacrifice be these be to sacrifice they neither set up altar nor kindle fire nor use vestment pipe cake or libament but he which intend to sacrifice place the sacrifice in a clean place call upon that god wear their Tiara d d the attire of the head among the persian as the turban among the turk gird about with myrtle the sacrificer pray not for himself alone but general for all persian and especial for the king. and after that the sacrifice be cut into small piece he strew under the sodden flesh small herb chief trifoly and set the flesh in order thereon the Magus stand by sing e e some hymn of the generation of the god which they hold to be a most effectual enchantment without one of their magi no sacrifice be account lawful after all this the sacrificer use the flesh at his pleasure of all day every man account his own birthday to be most solemn observe and then make great cheer the rich sort than set whole beef camel horse ass bake in a oven or furnace on the table the poor small beast the persian be small eater but in their drink consult of the weighty affair of which they deliberate fast but pronounce sentence after they be well in drink to vomit or make water open be unlawful to they those that be equal salute when they meet each other with a mutual kiss which be fasten on the cheek only if they be of unequal degree they hold themselves the best of all man their neighbour so much better how much near they they dwell they be much addict to venery with both sex next unto martial valour they repute excellent the procreation of many child the king allow annual present to he who have beget most child and therefore they use many woman the child come not in his father sight till he be five year old but live with the woman that if he die before his father shall thence conceive no grief from that time till he be twenty he learn three thing to ride to shoot to speak truth for to lie be with they the most shameful thing the second to be in debt for one fault only no man ought to be punish whatsoever be not mere to be do ought not to be speak a leprous person if he be a citizen may not enter into the city nor have any society with man for this disease be send say they for some offence against the sun if he be a forrenner they banish he out of their region and for the same cause carry into that region white pigeon in a river they neither spit nor make water nor wash but have they in very religious veneration these thing say Herodotus I can affirm of the persian out of my own knowledge that which follow I do not so well know that they bury not their dead body before they be tear of some fowl or dog but I well know that their magi do wrap they up in wax and then bury they these magi differ both from other man and from the egyptian priest in this that these pollute themselves with the death of nothing but their sacrifice but the magi with their own hand kill any thing except a man and a dog yea they esteem it some great exploit if they have kill very many aunt or serpent or other thing which creep or fly thus far Herodotus Strabo e e libr. 11 name Anaitis amanus and Anandatus god of the persian when the persian emperor have overthrow the f f these Goropius with dutch etymology and interpretation bring from the cimmerian and saxon see his Saxonica p.606 sacae they encompass report of the persian the persian have neither image nor altar they sacrifice in a high place they think heaven to be jupiter they worship the sun who they call Mithra the moon also and Venus and the fire and the earth and the wind and the water they sacrifice in a clean place and present their sacrifice crown and when as Magus the ruler of this business have divide the flesh in piece to every one they go their way leave no part thereof to the god who say they be satisfy with the soul of their sacrifice some as it be report lie a part of the numble on the fire they sacrifice especial to the fire and to the water lay on the fire dry stick the bark pull off and lay thereon fat tallow and pour on the same oil they kindle the same not blow with their breath but fan or otherwise enforce the wind thereto if any blow the fire or cast any dead thing or dirt therein he be punish with death they perform their water-ceremony in this sort come to a lake or river or fountain they make a ditch and there slay a sacrifice with great heed that none of the next water be touch with the blood after lay the flesh on myrtle and laurel the magi burn the same with small twig and make certain prayer sprinkle oil mix with milk and honey not in the fire or water but on the earth they be a long while mutter their prayer hold a bundle of small tamarisketwigge in Cappadocia where be very great store of the magi which of the fire be call Pyrethi and many temple of the persian god they slay not the sacrifice with a knife but a club or mallet wherewith they beat it the Pyretheia be great enclose place in the midst whereof there be a altar thereon the magi keep much ash and a fire continual burn whither they every day resort and make their prayer about a hour space hold a bundle of twig before the fire have their head cover with a kind of labeled mitre hang down on both side that the string cover their lip these thing be do in the temple of Anaitis and amanus for there be their temple and there the image of amanus be carry in procession these thing we have see it seem that whereas Herodotus report they have no temple altar nor image and Strabo so often mention their temple and here the altar and image of amanus that in Herodotus day they have none which grow afterward in use as a foreign rite bring in amongst the persian after the macedonian have conquer they or else that there be differ sect among their magi some as these in Cappadocia embrace altar image and temple some refuse some or all of these for otherwise Strabo disagree not only from Herodotus but from himself before the lake of van in which be a city of christian armenians where he abide four year in the house of a armenian priest be then about thirteen year old who use he courteous and instruct he in the rudiment of christian religion a year after he go from Arminig to Chillan where he keep with a goldsmith his father friend in this time he have intelligence by mutual writing with his friend at Ardovil and with this goldsmith have gather together eighteen or twenty man of their sect secret to take a strong castle call Maumutaga and hide in ambush two hundred horseman of his friend in Ardovil sudden slay the guard and possess himself of the castle he enter a town not far from the castle kill the inhabitant and carry the spoil to the castle this castle be very rich because it be a principal haven of the caspian sea and so strong that when Alumut have news hereof he be dissuade from send any power thither to besiege he two day journey from hence be Sumachi which with his power now increase he also take and divide the spoil every where to his soldier which with fame of this liberality come from all part unto he he send also into three or four day journey from thence which be then govern by seven great lord three of which Alexander Sbec Gorgurambec and Mirzambec with many promise of present spoil and future exemption from tribute he win to his side receive from each of they three thousand horse so that he be now grow fifteen or sixteen thousand strong Alumut with thirty thousand valiant soldier go to meet he between Tauris and Sumachia and have pass a great river over which be two bridge he present cause they to be break Ishmael arrive there the next day with great diligence find a passage through the stream and with his whole force in front in the break of the day assail alumut his army little suspect such a good morrow that alumut with a few companion hardly escape the pavilion horse and other booty Ishmael bestow on his soldier and then haste to Tauris where enter without resistance he make great slaughter kill all the race of jacob open his sepulchre and the grave of other nobleman which have be at the battle of darbent against his father and burn their bone 300 harlot he cause to be cut asunder in the middle he kill all the dog in Tauris and because his mother have marry to one of those noble which be in the battle of Darbent he cause her head to be strike off in his presence in this while many town city castle and lord submit themselves to he and wear his red-coloured turban but the castle Alangiachana whereto be subject eighteen village of christian which use yearly to send to Rome two man from the patriarch to the pope of who faith they be speak armonian have some book but quite lose the use of the italian language this castle I say hold out for alumut until his death while Ishmael be sultan in Tauris the sultan in Bagadet murat can son of jacob with a army of 30000. march against he and in a plain meeting with Ishmael be there overthrow not 70. person escape to Bagadet with murat can the place bear witness of the slaughter bury under many new hill of bone all these thing be do 1499. and while I be in Tauris Ishmael after this war and win upon the Zagatai tartars and other adjacent nation that he leave unto his successor a very great estate Knol Turk hist. reach from the caspian sea to the persian and between the lake jocco and Tigris the river and the kingdom of Cambaya more than twenty degree from east to west and eighteen from north to south he ordain a new liturgy and form of prayer differ from the ancient such be his authority that they will swear by the head of Ishmael and bless in his name say Ishmael grant the thy desire upon his coin on the one side be write and on the other ismaill halife jullahe that be Ishmael the vicar of god. Asdec 2.l ^0 c.6 there be one sect amongst they call which subject all thing to chance and to the star not to divine providence there be other call Emozaidi which reject many thing in the Alcoran and follow the doctrine of Zaidi the nephew of second son of Ali these inhabit on the confine of Prester John and in Melinde but to come to the common persian and to observe out of barrius the diversity of opinion betwixt they and the arabian their doctor reduce these difference into seventeen conclusion the persian say that GOD be the author and worker of every good and that evil come from the * * devil doe-evill or devil of Di@bolo@ a accuser or caviller devil the arabian say that will bring in two god one of good the other of evil the persian say that GOD be eternal and that the law and creation of man have a beginning the arabian answer that all the word of the law be praise of the work of GOD and therefore eternal like himself the persian say that the soul of the bless in the other world can see the essence of GOD because he be a spirit of divinity only they shall see his greatness mercy pity and all other good thing which he work in the creature the arabian answer that they shall see he with their eye even as he be the persian say that when Mahomet receive the law his soul be carry by the angel Gabriel into the presence of GOD the arabian affirm it of his body also the persian say that the child of Ali or awl and Fatema and their twelve nephew have pre-eminence above all prophet the arabian grant it above all other man but not above the prophet the persian say that it be sufficient to pray thrice a day unto GOD in the morning when the sun rise which be call sob the second Dor at noon the three Magareb before sunset because these three contain all the part of the day the arabian require twice beside accord to their law call hacer and assa. the rest of their seventeen article of difference my author have not express these be sufficient to show that they not only differ about the successor of Mahomet as affirm but about dogmatic point also in their ridiculous theology and interpretation of their law. these difference have continue of old and long continuance what have in late time accrue hereunto by the sophian addition of guine and his follower be in part touch in the former chapter let we now take view thereof as the same at this present Attalia where they execute the chief magistrate and be persuade by these new master they swear never to forsake their captain or refuse any labour for their most holy religion vow their soul and body that he say he shall be victorious and break his enemy force as he have break those dish whereupon he command he to be keep till his return and find the event accord he use he honourable when the sultan ride through the field he be set on a mule and his hand bind before he because he be sometime accustom to do some dangerous folly at his foot there attend on he many of their religious person call daruise these mad trick he use accord to the course of the moon sometime in two or three day not eat any thing busy in such foolery that they be fain to bind he he have great allowance for his expense one of those holy man there be which go naked like to the beast preach their faith and have obtain great reputation he cause himself to be immure in a wall forty day there to abide without any sustenance but when this time be expire and some wonder one more nosewise than the rest smell the send of flesh the sultan hear it commit he and his disciple to the Cadilasher who by torment cause they to confess the cousinage for through a hole which be make in the wall by a cave he have broth convey to he and therefore they be both put to death in the year 1478. Chozamirech a armenian be in his shop in Tauris a Azi or saint of they come to he and will he to deny his christian faith he answer he courteous and pray he not to trouble he but when he persist he offer he money the saint will not have the money but importune his first suit Chozumirech say he will not deny his christian faith whereupon the other pluck a sword out of a man scabbard which stand by and with a wound which he give the armenian in the head kill he and run away but the armenian son complain to the sultan procure his apprehension ^^ two day journey from Tauris and be bring before he he with a knife kill he with his own hand and cause he to be cast on a dunghill for the dog to eat say be this the way to increase the faith of Mahomet but when some of the more zealous people go to one which be in guard of the sepulchre of Assambei the former sultan and as it be prior of the hospital and request of he obtain the body to bury it the sultan hear it send for he and say to he dare thou countermand my command away and kill he which be sudden dispatch he further to be revenge of the people commit the town to the sack which for the space of three or four hour be do and then he forbid further spoil and fine the town in a great sum of gold last he cause the armenian son to come before he and with many kind word comfort he this long history I have insert to show the extremity of blind zeal and religious fury in the secular and votary of these persian if instire shall not withstand their rage before be mention the commemoration of their dead which be thus perform and custom he thus report they have no limitation of land nor tillage nor house but always wander through place not inhabit feed their herd and flock they carry their wife and child with they on cart which also be cover with hide they use for house no offence be more heinous amongst they then theft gold and silver they as much contemn as other desire milk and honey be their food their clothes skin of beast for the use of wool they know not they have three time seek the empire of Asia never conquer of other they chase Darius the persian king out of their coast they slay Cyrus with all his army o Herod lib.4 in history Asiae confute this tale report that they send to Delos virgin with sacrifice to Lucina bind up in wheat-straw through so many nation inhabit between of the issedones be report that when one die his kindred bring thither beast which they kill and cut and dress and eat together with the flesh of the dead man who skull also they keep and gild use it as a idol to which they perform yearly ceremony mese exequy do the son there perform to his dead father general of the scythian religion thus of the god they worship first Vesta who they call in their language tabit next of all jupiter in their speech Papeus and the earth suppose she to be the wife of jupiter and call she apia in the next place they worship Apollo and Venus by the name of oetosyrus and Artimpasa and Mars and Hercules some of they sacrifice also to Neptune or Thamimasades image altar and temple they think ought not to be make except to Mars their manner of sacrifice be general this the sacrifice be present with the fore-feet bind the sacrificer at his back have lay aside his holy vestment wound the same and while it fall call upon that god to who he sacrifice and then put a halter about the neck and strangle it without kindle any fire or vow or other ceremony and flay it the flesh pluck from the bone he cast into a great cauldron the bone he use for fuel to seethe the same for wood the country do not yield and if they have not any such vessel they put all the flesh with water into the paunch and so the beast do seethe itself after it be boil he which sacrifice offer the libament or offering of the flesh and and innards their sacrifice be beside other beast especial of horse their temple to Mars they build on this manner scythian temple they heap together bundle of twig three furlong in length and breadth and above on they be make a square plain three side thereof be upright the four be make slope and bending-wise thereby to get up thither they bring every year a hundred and fifty wane of twig to supply the waste of they underneath this work be erect a old iron sword and this be their image of Mars to which they offer yearly sacrifice both of other cattle and of horse and more to this blade then to other god of their captive they offer one of a hundred but after another manner for after they have offer wine on their head they kill they by a certain vessel and after lift they upon that their heap or temple they imbrue the sword-god with the blood this they do above beneath in the temple they cut off all the right shoulder of the slay man and hurl they up in the air together with the hand wheresoever the hand shall fall there it lie and the dead body apart when they have perform all their solemnity they depart swine be so odious to they that they will have none of they nourish in their country there be among they diviner who rite be these scythian divination they bring great bundle of willow twig which they lie on the ground and untie and lay they asunder one by one divine some of they practice divination with the leaf of the teil-tree which they fold and unfold in their hand the king when at any time he fall sick send for three choice man of those diviner who for the most part name some man unto he which have forswear himself have swear by the king throne a oath use of the scythian present the man be bring forth who if he deny what their art have accuse he of the king send for twice the number of diviner or if they by new practice of their art find he guilty his head be cut off and the first diviner share his good but if they shall absolve he more diviner be send for and if the most of they do absolve he than those three first be thus do to death they lade a wain with twig and bind the diviner hand and foot and stop their mouth cast they into the wane and set all on fire burn ox wain and man together unless some of the ox by the burn of their harness escape this punishment inflict they on their false prophet they make their league with other nation in this sort they pour wine into a great bowl mix therewith the blood of they which join in league cut some part of the body with a knife or sword and then dip in that bowl or mazer a sword arrow a axe a dart and after curse themselves with many word last of all drink the wine their king be bury amongst the Gerrh^ with many ceremony carry the dead body through all the country over which he reign which cut and shave themselves and with he be bury his best belove paramour his cupbearer cook master of his horse waiter messenger horse and the first first-fruit of all other thing and also golden cup and then cast on earth make a very great hill when the year be go about they take fifty of his principal attendant which be not slave but freeborn scythian and strangle they with so many horse of the best and fasten the dead man on the dead horse with much solemnity but to relate all the particular hereof and their burial also of private man who dead body be carry Rome lib. 2 call he Zitzischan Cyngis who begin to be a mighty hunter before the lord for he learn to steal man he range into other country take as many captive as he can and join they unto himself also he allure the man of his own country unto he who follow he as their ringleader to do mischief then begin he to war upon the Sumongols or tartar and slay their captain and after many conflicts-subdued they to himself and bring they all into bondage afterwards he use their help against the merkat who also he vanquish in battle proceed from thence he fight against the metrite and vanquish they also the Naiman^ hear that Cyngis be thus exalt great disdain thereat for they have a great and mighty emperor unto who all the foresay nation pay tribute who son when he be dead succeed he in his empire howbeit be young and foolish they know not how to govern the people but be divide and fall at variance among themselves these invade Cyngis his country put the inhabitant to the sword but be after overthrow by the Mongols and either slay or make captive some e e g. forsake their former habitation and depart thence far off into the north deny further tribute unto Vncam after they have there continue a certain time they choose to their king about the year 1162 one which be call Cingis can who rule they with such modesty and justice that they love and fear he as a god his fame reduce all the other tartar in other part under his obedience he thus strengthen weary of those desert command they to arm themselves with bow and other weapon and begin to invade and conquer city and province to his subjection the principal inhabitant whereof he carry with he kind entertain they leave such discreet governor in the same that the people be secure in their person and good when he have thus subdue about nine province he send his ambassador to * * Vncam subdue Vncam to demand his daughter in marriage which vncam with much indignation and many threaten deny Cingis assemble his force march against he and by the way inquire of his astrologer and diviner touch his success they take a green reed cle^t it asunder place the part thereof a good distance one from another and write upon the one the name of Vncam and Cingis on the other tell the king that while they be read their conjure charm these reed will fight together and the victory shall remain with he who reed get the better which accord come to pass in the sight of the army Cingis his reed overcome the other as after Cingis himself do Vncam who he slay in the field and possess his daughter and state wherein he continue six year conquer city and kingdom and at last be wound at a castle call thaigin
