Haithon or Anthony the armenian have write of the tartarian beginning this our author be royal descend in Armenia where he live about three hundred year since and at the request of pope Clement the 5 write the history of the tartar from Cingis or Cangius till Mango can take out of the tartarian history the rest he partly see with his eye and partly learned of his uncle a eyewitness of the same who have attend on Haython the armenian king in the great cha^^s court. the country where the tartar first dwell say i i the tartar legend of Cangius Hait Armen Haithon be beyond the mount belgian where they live like beast have neither letter nor faith nor habitation nor souldiourie nor reputation among their neighbor-nation there be of they diverse nation call by one common name Mogli which be divide into seven principal tribe who name be Tatar tangut cunat Talair Sonich monghi Tebeth these all be subject to their neighbour a poor old man be a smith who as they believe be engender of the sunbeam see in his sleep a arm man on a white horse which say unto he oh Cangius the will of the immortal GOD be that thou be the governor of the tartarian and ruler of the seven nation to free they from their bondage and tribute this his vision when he report to other they will not believe he until that the night follow the chief man amongst themselves see the same man with command from the immortal GOD to yield obedience unto Cangius this they perform with all reverence and spread in the midst of they a black felt with a seat thereon on which the seven prince or chief man place Cangius call he can that be emperor and kneel before he this happy be then the most sumptuous throne * * a feel the tartarian throne in their coronation their state can afford but continue in the royal investiture of their succeed sovereign their exceed riches and conquest notwithstanding at two of which solemnity say our author I myself have be present Cangius thus enthronize on his felt command they many thing first to believe the immortal GOD and from thence forward the tartar begin to call upon the name of the immortal GOD seek for his aid in all their enterprise second he command to make a general view of all such as be able to bear arm appoint captain over ten over thousand and over ten thousand which make a full regiment he command also those seven principal head of their tribe to bereave themselves of their dignity and for further trial of their obedience each of they to bring thither his elder son and to cut off his head each with his own hand which they refuse not to do in reverence to that divine ordinance whereby he be make their sovereign Cangius have thus make trial of their fidelity subdue many nation and one day have his horse slay in battle under he be forsake of his tartar despair his recovery after they see he fall and may easy have be slay have not his enemy through ignorance neglect he to pursue the rest which Cangius perceive convey himself into a thicket of shrub and when his enemy return to despoil the dead a owl come and sit on the shrub under which Cangius be hide which cause they not to suspect any to lurk there and so they depart he the next night flee to his people who see he and hear the order of his escape give thanks to the immortal GOD who by mean of that bird have preserve he they also have after this that * * the owl observe foul in such reverence that it be account a happy thing to wear one of her feather on their head Cangius afterward assault his enemy bring under both they and all the country on that side of belgian the exact time of these thing Haithon can not learn notwithstanding his much inquiry which he impute to their want of letter at that time these country thus conquer the arm man appear to he the second time and command he in the name of the immortal GOD to pass the mountain belgian and go towards the west where he shall conquer kingdom seignory and land and that thou may be assure that this be the will of GOD arise and go with thy people towards the mountain to that part which join on the sea there thou shall dismount and turn thou towards the east and kneel down nine time shall worship the immortal GOD and he which be almighty shall show thou the way by which thou may commodious pass Cangius present command his people with their wife and family to accompany he in this enterprise and when they be come to the sea forget not with his follower to perform those nine worship and stay there that night in his prayer the next day he see that the sea have go nine foot back from the mountain and leave a spacious way by which they with all their substance pass westward hence it be that the tartar ascribe some happiness to the number of nine and he that will offer a present to any tartarian signior must offer nine thing * * the number of nine which custom they use in their tribute unto this day as master jenkinson find by experience to his cost Cangius after many adventure and many law which of he be call jasack Cangis can have first persuade his twelve son wherein I think his nephew be also reckon to concord bid each of they to bring he a arrow which together none of they asunder the least of they may easy break he die this history of Cingis or Cangius I have thus full relate for knowledge both of the beginning of their state and religion and if these vision seem fabulous yet may Cingis in his subtlety deal with they as Mahomet with his arabian or Numa with the roman the one make Gabriel the other Aegeria author of their policy and what he in part pretend may by fame and time be augment although I see not but that this history of Cingis may as well be credit as that of Alexander in josephus to who appear one in the habit of the jewish high priest command Paul.l.2 be a eyewitness of the tartarian proceed who affirm that this cublas exceed in power not his predecessor only but all the kingdom of christian and saracen although they be join in one before he obtain the sovereignty he show himself a valiant soldier but after he be emperor he never fight field but once against naians his uncle who be able out of the province wherein he govern to bring together four hundred thousand horse to who Caidu shall have add a hundred thousand horse more these both conspire against their master and lord Cublai but before their force be join Cublai stop the passage that none may pass to carry news sudden assemble within ten day journey of Cambalu three hundred and threescore thousand horse and a hundred thousand footman an. 1286. with this power ride day and night he come sudden on his enemy and have first consult with his diviner after their manner give the onset and take Naiam prisoner who he strangle betwixt two carpet lest the earth shall drink or the sun shall see the blood of that imperial family Naiam have be secret baptize and now also have the cross for his banner which occasion the jew and Saracen to scoff at the christian but Cublai understand hereof call they all before he and say that the cross will not help such wicked man as Naiam who be a traitor to his lord say you not therefore that the GOD of the christian be unjust to forsake his follower for he be the chief bounty and justice. Emanuel a jesuite date at malaca in januarie 1599 be contain the transcript of Jerome Xaverius his letter from Lahor the city royal of the great Mogor date August 1598. wherein the jesuite relate that while he be in conference with the prince there enter into the palace a old man of Mahomet religion threescore year of age who affirm to the prince that he have come from Xatai by the way of Mecca present some which know he affirm that he have distribute in alm a hundred thousand piece of gold at Mecca the prince ask if it be so he affirm that he do it because he be old and can not long live nor carry those thing away with he be demand of the state of Xatai he answer that he have there live thirteen year in the city royal Xambalu the king whereof be very mighty and have in his empire a thousand and fifty city some of they very populous he say he have often see the king with who no man speak but by a supplication nor be answer but by a eunuch be ask how he have access thither he answer that he sustain the person as well of the ambassador of the king of caygar as of a merchant and be detain in the first city by the magistrate he show his commission and post be present send to the king who return in a month ride 90. or 100 mile a day with change of horse bring he letter of admission no man be troublesome to he in the way they punish thief severe which also be observe of the cathayans in josapha Barbaro and in Marcus Paulus aforesaid the people he affirm be white comely long-beareded and very personable in religion he say they be isavite or christian professor of JESUS and some among they mussavite or jew and many mahometans who hope to draw the king be a Christian to their Sect. the jesuite add that he far confer with he another day about their religion who tell he that they have many church and some very great many image both paint and carve especial of the crucifix which they religious worship every church have his priest much reucrence the priest live single and keep school wherein they instruct the youth which shall after take order they have also one among the priest supereminent and be all maintain at the king cost as be the church also both build and repair they wear black clothes and on holiday red with cap much like the jesuite but great he add that he have often see the king go to church that there be many of both sex which in cloister live a monastical life some observe also a single life in their own house this agree with vertomans report he report that the country be rich and have in it many mine of silver the king have four hundred elephant which they say be bring from malaca and from pegu also he say that merchant resort thither which voyage be half a year it seem through the sea between China and japan Xaverius add that while he be at Caximir he hear of many christian in a kingdom adjoin to Xatai who have church priest and bishop to who he have write three way in the Portugal and the persian tongue the great objection against this history that distinguish cathay from China be the report of jacob Pantogia l l jacob Pantogia a jesuite in a letter date from Panquin the seat royal of China in march 1602 in which he blame a double error of our map both for make China large than it be and for adjoin to the same this question kingdom of cathay whereas say he China or sina be cathay and this Panquin where now we live be Cambalu this he prove by the incredible riches which he here see agree to that which be common report of cathay and by the testimony of certain moor and mahumetan who he find in Panquin which usual every five year resort hither under show of a embassage and pay of tribute indeed for gain by way of traffic their tribute meanwhile obtain sufficient retribution out of the king coffer who sustain they and they all the time of their abode in China at his own cost beside other gift of these merchant which resort hither out of Persia and the country of the Mogores the jesuit by enquiry learned that this country of China be call cathay and have no other name in Persia and among the Mogores nor do they know any other country so call and ask further how they call the city Panquin they answer Cambalu whereupon the jesuite conclude without all scruple as be say and again in the chinian epistle date 1607 be report that m m Bened. go Benedictus go send six year after of the jesuite by the way of Mogor to find out cathay remain in the border of China in the province of Xanti from whence he write an. 1606. that he can find no other Catay then the kingdom of China this report further pantogia opinion but if it be not sufficient to oppose the former report of Xamer to these of Pantogia and go and the different quality of the chinians and cathayans as in their proper place shall Paulus and josafa Barbaco from the relation of eye-witness affirm that in Cambalu be such sudden and rigorous execution of justice that one take a jar of milk from a woman head and beginning to drink upon the woman outcry be apprehend and present with a sword cut in funder that the blood and milk issue together a tartarian ambassador affirm both this and that he have see the like execution upon another for take a piece of bay from a woman so chap in twain but the relation of the chinian and cathayan differ rite will further clear this point as for the name of cathay ascribe to China by the moor I answer that William q q will de rubr. Hak. ^^ 1 plano thus write of their religion they believe that there be one GOD the maker of all thing visible and invisible the author of good thing and punishment yet do they not worship he with prayer praise or any certain rite they have also idol of felt in the fashion of a man and the same they set on both side of their tent-doore and under they they put a thing of felt fashion like a dug these they account the keeper of their cattle author of their milk and yongstore other they make of silk and do they much honour some place they in a fair chariot cover before the door of their flation and whosoever steal any thing out of that chariot be slay without all pity their captain have one always in the midst of their tent. to these idol they offer the first first-fruit of their milk and the first morsel of their meat and first draught of their drink at meal and when they kill a beast they offer the heart to their idol leave it before he till the morning and then they take and eat it they make a idol also to their chief emperor and offer thereunto with great solemnity as well other creature as horse which none after dare ride on till death they break not a bone of the beast which they kill for meat but burn they with fire they bend themselves to this idol towards the south as to god. they worship the sun light and fire water also and the earth offer thereunto the first of their meat and drink and in the morning before they eat or drink they have no set rite prescribe by law nor do they compel any to deny their religion simple although in some of their custom they be very rigorous thus they martyr Michael duke of Russia because he refuse to do reverence to the image of Cingis can which have be their first emperor and compel they young brother of Andrew duke of Saruogle in Russia to marry his say brother wife accord to their custom after that they have slay her former husband they have certain tradition accord to which they reckon these thing follow to be sin their sin to thrust a knife into the fire or any way to touch the fire with a knife or with their knife to take flesh out of the cauldron or to hew with a hatchet near to the fire for they think that they shall so cut away the head of the fire they account it sin also to lean on the whip wherewith they beat their horse for they ride not with spur also to touch arrow with a whip to take or kill young bird to strike a horse with the rain of their bridle and to break one bone against another likewise to pour out meat milk or any kind of drink upon the ground or to make water within their tabernacle which whosoever do willing be slay but otherwise he must pay a great sum of money to the enchanter to be purify who cause the tabernacle with all thing therein to pass between two fire beside if any have a morsel give he which he be not able to swallow and for that cause cast it out of his mouth there be a hole make under his tabernacle by which he be draw forth and slay without all compassion likewise whosoever tread upon the threshold of any of the duke tabernacle he be put to death thus be these gnattes strain when as hostile invasion murder and such other camel be easy amongst they swallow they think that after death they shall live in another world and there multiply there cattle eat drink and do other action of life at a new moon or a full moon they begin all new enterprise they call she the great emperor and bow their knee and pray thereto the sun they say be the moon mother because she have thence her light their sorcery they be give to divination augury sooth-saying witchcraft enchantment and when they receive answer from the devil they attribute the same unto God who they call Itoga and the comanians call he cham that be emperor who they marvellous fear and reverence offer to he many oblation and the first first-fruit of their meat and drink accord to his answer they dispose all thing they believe that all thing be purge by fire therefore when any ambassador prince or other personage whatsoever come unto they they and their gift must pass between two fire to be purify lest peradventure they have practise some witchcraft or have bring some poison or other mischief with they and if fire fall from heaven upon man or beast which there often happen or if they think themselves any way defile or unclean they thus be purify by their enchanter if any be sick a spear be set up in his tent with black feel welt about it and from thenceforth no stranger enter therein their sickness and funeral for none of they which be present at his death may enter the hoard of any duke or emperor till a new moon when he be dead if he be a chief man he be bury in the field where please he and he be bury with his tent sit in the midst thereof with a table set before he and a platter full of meat and a cup of mare milk there be also bury with he * * vin. l.30.c.86 a mare and colt a horse with bridle and saddle and they eat another horse who bone the woman burn for the soul of the dead stuff his hide with straw set it aloft on two or four pole that he may have in the other world a tabernacle and other thing fit for his use they bury his gold and silver with he the chariot or cart in which he be carry forth be break his tent be destroy neither be it lawful to name his name till the three generation they observe also other funeral rite too long to rehearse they lament their dead thirty day more or less their parent and those of their family be thus cleanse they make two fire and pitch near thereunto two spear with a line from the top of the one to the other fasten on the same line some piece of buckram under which and betwixt the fire pass the man beast and tent there stand also two woman one on this side the other on that cast water and repeat certain charm if any thing fall or be break the enchanter have it and if any be slay of thunder the man in the tent must thus be cleanse and all thing in the tent be otherwise report unclean and not to be touch their condition no man be more obedient to their lord then the tartar they seldom contend in word never in deed they be reasonable courteous one to another their woman be chaste adultery be seldom hear off and theft be rare both punish by death drunkenness common but without brall among themselves or discredit among other they be proud greedy deceitful they eat dog wolf fox horse and in necessity man flesh mouse and other filth and that in as filthy a manner without clothes and napkin their boot and the grass can serve to wipe their greasy hand they have no bread herb wine meat or beer nor do they wash their dish it be a great sin amongst they to suffer any of their food to be lose and therefore they will not bestow a bone on a dog till they have eat the marrow Yvo Paris b b mat. Paris an. 1243. report the confession of a english man which be take with other tartar by the christian he say that they call by the name of god the ancient founder and father of their tribe and at set time do solemnize feast unto they many of they be particular and but four only general they think that all thing be create for themselves alone they be hardy and strong in the breast lean and pale-faced rough and huf-shouldred have flat and short nose long and sharp chin their upper jaw low and decline their tooth long and thin their kickshaw extend from their forehead down to their nose their eye inconstant and black their thigh thick and leg short yet equal to we in stature they be excellent archer vanquish they ask no favour and vanquish they show no compassion they all persist as one man in their purpose of subdue the whole world their proud swell title appear in the copy of those letter of duke baiothnoy and cuin can express by c c Vincent rel. Spec. hist. l.ult.c.51 and 52. vincentius one of they begin thus by the precept of the live GOD Cingischam son of the sweet and worshipful GOD say that GOD be high above all the immort all GOD and upon earth Cingischam only lord etc. these letter of the emperor the tartar call the letter of God and so begin duke baiothnoy to the pope who have send friar Ascelline with Alexander Albericus and Simon thither in embassage the word of baiothnoy send by the divine disposition of cham know this oh pope etc. friar John d d jo. de P.C. say he style himself the power of GOD and emperor of all man and have in his scale engrave word of like effect as be already show mandevill e e c. 37 sir io. mand. have the same report will. f f w. de Rubr. say that they have divide Scythia amongst they from Danubius to the sunrising every captain know the bound of his pasture which they feed in the winter descend southwards ascend in the summer northwards their house be movable remove on great cart which contain twenty foot between the wheel their house on each side overreach five foot draw by above twenty oxen. when they take they down they turn the door always to the south over the master head be a image of felt call the master brother and another over the head of the good wife or mistress call her brother fasten to the wall and betwixt both of they be a little lean one which be the keeper of the whole house shee have also at her bed foot a kid skin fill with wool and a little image look towards the maiden and woman next to the door on the woman side which be the east as the man side be on the west there be a image with a cow udder for the woman who office it be to milk the cow on the other side another with a mare udder for the man when they make merry they sprinkle their drink upon these image in order begin at the master then go a servant out of the house with a cup full of drink sprinkle thrice towards the south and bow the knee at every time and this be do for the honour of the fire then perform he the like superstition towards the east for the honour of the air next to the west for the honour of the water and last to the north in the behalf of the dead when the master hold a cup in his hand to drink before he taste thereof he pour his part upon the ground if he drink sit on horseback he first pour part thereof on the mane of the horse after the servant aforesaid have discharge his cup to the four quarter of the world he return to the house and two other servant stand ready with two cup and two bason to carry drink unto their master and that wife which lie with he the last night sit together on a bed their soothsayers or enchanter be their priest m. Paulus thus report of their religion they say g g l. 1.c.46 that there be a god on high in heaven of who lift up their hand and smite their tooth three time together every day with censer and incense they desire health h h l. 2.c.26 and understanding they place a table aloft in the wall of their house in the which be write a name that represent this god. they have another which they call Natigay or Itogay of feel or other stuff in every house they make he a wife and child and set his wife on the left hand his child before he which seem to do he reverence this they call the god of earthly thing which keep their child beast and corn and when they eat they anoint his mouth with the fat and the mouth of his wife and child and then cast out the broth out of the door unto other spirit and when their God have have his part they take they of this Natigay they with like ceremony of lift up their hand and smite of their tooth desire temperature of the air first-fruit of the earth l. 2.c.26 child and such like their wife be exceed chaste and observant and though they be many yet can Rachel and Leah yea ten or twenty of they agree with a marvelous union intent unto their household and other business whereby they be gainful and not chargeable to their husband when they marry i i w. rub. in this sort the husband covenant with the father of the maid who have give he power to take she wheresoever he shall find she he seek she among some of her friend where she have then of purpose hide herself and by a kind of force carry she away they marry with any except their own mother and sister their widow seldom marry because of their service to their former husband in a other world except the son marry his father wife or the brother his brother because they can there in the next world be content to resign they to their former husband again the woman buy sell and provide all necessary into the house the man intend nothing but their arm hunt and hawk if one have bury a male-child and another a female the parent contract a marriage betwixt those two and paint in paper servant horse clothes and household and make write for the confirmation of the dower burn these thing in the fire by the smoke whereof they in their smoky conceit imagine all these thing to be carry and confirm to their child in the other world and the parent of the two dead party claim kindred each of other as if they indeed have marry their child while they live in Xaindu do Cublai can build a stately palace encompass sixteen mile of plain ground with a wall wherein be sertile meadow pleasant spring delightful stream and all sort of beast of chase and game and in the midst thereof a sumptuous house of pleasure which may be remove from place to place here he do abide in the month of june july and August on the eight and twentieth day where of he depart thence to another place to do sacrifice on this manner he have a herd or drive of horse and mare about ten thousand as white as snow of the milk whereof none may taste except he be of the blood of Cingis can. yea the tartar do these beast great reverence nor dare any cross their way or go before they accord to the direction of his astrologer or magician he on the eight and twentieth of August aforesaid spend and pour forth with his own hand the milk of these mare in the air and on the earth to give drink to the spirit and idol which they worship that they may preserve the man woman beast bird corn and other thing grow on the earth their sect and order these astrologer or necromancer be in their art marvelous when the sky be cloudy and threaten raive they will ascend the roof of the palace of the grand can and cause the rain and tempest to fall round about without touch the say palace these which thus do be call Tebeth and Chesmir Tebeth and Chesmir two fort of idolater which delude the people with opinion of their sanctity impute these work to their dissemble holiness and for this cause they go in filthy and beastly manner not care who see they with dirt on their face never wash nor comb themselves and if any be condemn to death they take dress and eat he which they do not if any die natural they be also call Bachsi that be of such a religion or order as if one shall say a friar preacher or Minor and be exceed expert in their devilish art. they cause that the bottle in the hall of the great can do fill the bolle of their own accord which also without man help pass ten pace through the air into the hand of the say can and when he have drink in like sort return to their place these Bachsi sometime resort unto the officer and threaten plague or other misfortune from their idol which to prevent they desire so many mutton with black head and so many pound of incense and aloe to perform their due sacrifice which they accord receive and offer on their feast day sprinkle broth before their idol there be of these great monastery which seem like a small city in some whereof be two thousand monk which shave their head and beard and wear a religious habit and hallow their idol feast with great solemnity of hymn and light some of these may be marry otherthere be call a order which observe great abstinence and strictness of life in all their life eat nothing but bran which they put in hot water and let it stand till all the white of the meal be take away and then eat it be thus wash these worship the fire and be condemn of the other for heretic because they worship not their idol and will not marry in any case they be shave and wear hempen-garment of black or bright yellow and although they be silk yet will they not alter the colour they sleep on great mat and live the austere life in the world of their astrologer in Cambalu be not few than five thousand christians catayans and saracen maintain with food and raiment at the great can charge these by their astrolabe foretell of the change of weather mortality war disease etc. and if any enterprise any great work he resort unto they and tell the hour of his nativity by their art be inform of the success they hold the soul to be immortal and accord to every man merit in his life to pass into a more noble creature till it be deify or ignoble as to a peasant and then to a dog and so by degree to the vile they show much reverence to their parent to who if any be ungrateful in their necessity there be a office and officer appoint to try and punish the offence in the emperor hall none dare spit but for that purpose carry a little vessel to spit in nor dare any there make any noise or loud talk the tartar be at first very uncharitable to the poor and will curse they say that if God have love they he will have provide for they but after the idolatrous Bachsi have commend alm for a good work there be great provision make for they and every day at least twenty thousand dish of rice mill and Panike by certain officer distribute amongst they and for this liberality they adore he as a god. amongst his first law enact as say vincentius the punishment of Vincent bel. Spec. histor.lib 30 ca. 70. death to be inflict upon offender in those three vice which before time have be most rife amongst they namely lie adultery and theft of which yet towards other man that be not tartars they make no conscience they be great usurer take ten in the hundred for a month beside use upon ca. 75 use insomuch that a soldier in Georgia which have borrow five hundred piece of coin call Yperpera retain the same five year be constrain to repay seven thousand and a tartarian lady for seven year use of fifty sheep demand seven thousand they be so covetous that though they abound in cattle they will scarce allow any to their own expense while it be find and good but if it die or be sick they be addict to sodomy or buggery ca. 76. they eat sometime for necessity man flesh sometime to delight themselves and sometime to terrify other reckon it a great glory to have slay many and that by variety of cruelty ca. 77. their head they shave from ear to ear in manner of a horse-shoe wear long lock at their ear and neck there be some of the tartar which when they see their father grow old and disease they give they fat meat which may choke they and when they be thus dead they burn their body reserve the ash as a precious jewel sprinkle their meat with that powder ca. 86. but if any think not this enough which I be afraid the most will deem too much let he resort to the large Chaldea Aslyria they leave their own and learn the rite and religion of these mahometans chap. 12 of the festival solemnity and of the magnificence of the grand can. we have already speak of the solemn sacrifice observe on the eight and twenty day of August we read in our author a a Marcus Paulus Marcus Paulus a eyewitness of these his relation of other the grand can grand solemnity of which two be principal one on his birth day which in Cublai time be the eight and twentieth of September on which himself be royal clothe in cloth of gold and twenty thousand of his baron and soldier be all apparel in one colour and like except the price to himself every one have a girdle wrought of gold and silver and a pair of shoe some of their garment rich set with pearl and jewel which they wear on the thirteen solemnity accord to the thirteen moon of the year on this day all the tartar and several prince subject present he with rich gift and all sect of religion pray unto their god for his health and long life but their chief feast be on the first day of their year which they begin in February celebrate by the grand can and all the country subject to he in which they be all array in white a colour in their estimation portend good luck and then he be present with many clothes and horse of white colour and other rich present in the same religious observe the number of nine as nine time nine horse if they be able and so of piece of gold cloth and the rest then also the elephant which be about five thousand be bring forth in sumptuous furniture and camel cover with silk and in the morning they present themselves in the hall as many as can the rest stand without in their due order first those of the imperial progeny next the king duke and other in their due place then come forth a great man or prelate which cry out with a loud voice bow down yourselves and worship which they present do with their face to the earth this prelate add God save and preserve our lord long to live with joy and gladness they all answer God grant it the prelate again God increase his dominion and preserve in peace all his subject and prosper all thing in all his country whereunto they answer as before thus they do worship four time after this the say prelate go to a altar there rich adorn on which be a red table with the name of the great can write in it and a censer with incense which he incense in stead of they all with great reverence perform unto the table this do they return to their place and present their gift and after be feast when cublas have overthrow Naiam his uncle as before be say understand that the christian observe their yearly solemnity of easter he cause they all to come unto he and to bring the book of the four gospel which he incense often with great ceremony devout kiss it and cause his baron to do the like and this he observe always in the principal feast of the christian as Christmas and Easter the like he do in the chief feast of the saracen jew and idolater the cause he say be because of those four prophet to which all the world do reverence JESUS of the christian Mahomet of the saracen Moses of the jew and Sogemambar can the first idol before the conquest of cathay they observe not any day at all with festival solemnity Cublai can be of mean stature of countenance white red and beautiful he have four wife which keep several court the least of which contain at least ten thousand person he have many concubine every second year have a new choice of the fair maiden in the province of vngut most fertile belike of that commodity which pass a second election at the court and the fair and fit of they be commit to lady to prove and to instruct they their parent hold it a great grace so to have bestow their child and if any of they prove not they impute it to their disastrous planet they hold it for a great beauty to have their nose flat between the eye in December january and February he abide at Cambalu in the north-east part of the province of cathay in a palace near to the city build on this manner there be a circuit wall in four square each square contain eight mile have about they a deep ditch and in the middle a gate a mile inward be a other wall the grand can palace which have six mile in each square and in the south side three gate and as many on the north. betwixt those wall be soldier in every corner of this wall and in the midst be a stately palace eight in all wherein be keep his munition there be a three wall within this contain four mile square each square take up one mile have six gate and eight palace as the former in which be keep the grand can provision and between these two wall be many fair tree and meadow store with many beast within this be the grand can palace the great that ever be scene confine with the wall abovesaid on the north and south the matter and form thereof be of such cost and art with such appurtenance of pleasure and state as be too long here to recite he for a superstitious fear suggest by his astrologer of a rebellion which sometime shall be raise against he in Cambalu build a new city near thereunto call Taidu c c Odoricus call it caide four and twenty mile in compass and yet not able to receive the inhabitant of the old city whence he remove such as may move suspicion hither this city be build by line in four square each whereof contain six mile and three gate so straight that upon the wall of one gate one may see the gate right against it in the midst of the city be a great bell which be ring in the night to warn man to keep within door the great can have twelve thousand horseman under four captain to his guard he keep leopard wolf and lion to hunt with and with they to take wild ass bear heart etc. and one sort of eagle able to catch wolf the two master of his hunt game have ten thousand man under each of they the one part clothe in red the other in skie-colour and when the emperor hunt one of these captain go with his man and dog Precop desert Zagathay caz ^^ and morgat divide they into five principal sort which may likewise be subdivide into many inferior branch or horde the first of these he call or the less which be in Europe betwixt Boristhenes and Tanais comprehend taurica chersonesus inhabit by the precopite tartars or as Broniovius b b mart. Bronie Tartary term they Perecopensis of Perecopia a town and castle in taurica they be call also ossovense and crim of two town bear those name these be now subject to the Turk both in state and religion have some town and mahumetane temple and monastery and turkish garrison and a few temple and person christian of the armenian grecian and western profession they live in their homely cottage in the winter but in the summer wander in their cart as the other tartar than who they be somewhat more civil they pay three hundred christian yearly to the Turk for tribute of who their can since the time of Zelim receive a banner and his approbation to the empire give his child or brother in hostage they elect also a heir apparent to their empire who they call Galga and if the can will prefer his son to that dignity he kill all his brother as the turk also deal with they it shall seem that they derive their pedigree from Cingis descend if I may conjecture where certain history fail of some of the son of bathy the great conqueror in those part of the world Lochton can be the first which rule in taurica long since bathy time they use the chaldean and arabian letter they have their cady to administer religion and justice as have the turk of these european tartar c c l Chalcond lib. 3 Bronionius and other have write a discourse to who I refer such as desire to know further of their affair they count the don or river Tanais holy in respect of the commodity which it yield they these tartar d d a Guag sarmat Sigism Herberst petr. in tab. auton pass through the confine of Polonia and Podolia to help the Turk in the war of Hungary the way be secure and defend with the garrison they use a new stratagem to make way by drive a multitude of bull before they which contrary to their expectation affright with the ordnance recoil upon their driver tread they down and scatter they the Chan when st. bathor king of Poland be dead send his ambassador to be elect their king affirm that their pope shall be he their Luther his also and for dainty horseflesh will content he his suit be reject with laughter the second part in this division be attribute to Tartary so call of the desert gentile and the cheremize half gentile half tartar and Mangat or Nagay mahometan tartar which in the year 1558. be through civil war famine and pestilence destroy to the number of above a hundred thousand these nagayans have their diverse hoard subject to their several duke who they call murze have no use of money corn or Arts. they in the time of their distress will for one loaf of bread worth six penny have sell son or daughter to master jenk if he will have buy a thousand although otherwhiles they deride the christian as live on the top of weed so they call our corn this our author and countryman travel down the river Volga to Astracan which river after it have run above two thousand english mile have threescore and ten mouth or fall into the Caspiansea through this sea he pass to manguslaue a other part of the desert Tartary the prince whereof Soltan he find and salute in a f f little round house not have town or castle make of reed cover without with felt within with carpet accompany with the great metropolitan of their country esteem of amongst that field-people as the bishop of Rome be in most part of Europe and have he not present himself to he with the great duke letter he have be spoil of all that he have they pass thence with a caravan of merchant twenty day not find water but as they draw out of old deep well brackish and salt and pass sometime two or three day without the same after that they come to a gulf of the caspian sea again where the water be fresh and sweet not so the people for the customer of the king of turkeman toll of every five and twenty one and seven ninth for the say king and his brother into this gulf the river oxus do sometime fall but be now intercept by the river Ardock which run towards the north and as it be loath to view so cold a clime and barbarous inhabitant after he have run with a swift race a thousand mile as it be in flight he hide himself under ground for the space of five hundred mile and then look up and see little amendment drown himself in the lake of Kithay thence they have three day journey to sellizure where find Azim can to who he present a nine he receive there the like festival entertainment as before with that be the g g con flesh of a wild horse and mare milk without bread he and his brother rule all from the caspian sea to urgence and have continual war with the persian and be call turkeman for the other horde of that huge tartarian desert the Kirgessen Melgomazan Scibanski Thumen which still be say to remain under the obedience of the grand can heselit harsh name of harsh people in those most harsh and horrid desert will hasten my pen and your ear to some more please subject the thumen and their neighbour be great enchanter and by their art they say raise tempest and overthrow their enemy the Kirgessen observe these stink holy their h h Ortelius priest mix blood milk and cowdung together with earth and put they in a vessel therewith climb a tree and after his devout exhortation to the people he besprinckle they with this sacred mixture which they account divine when any of they die they hang he on a tree instead of burial the tartar in turkeman use to catch wild horse with hawk tame to that purpose which seize on the neck of the horse with his beat and the horse chase tire he and make he a easy prey to his master who always ride with his bow arrow and sword they eat their meat and say their prayer sit on the ground crosslegged spend the time very idle as master jenkinson with his company travel from hence towards Boghar they be assail with forty thief of who they have intelligence somewhat before and therefore certain holy man for so they account such as have be at Mecca cause the caravan to stay while they make their prayer and divination touch their success they take certain sheep and kill they and take the blade-bone of the same which they first sod and then burn mingle the blood of the say sheep with this powder of their bone swith which blood they write certain character use many other ceremony and word and thereby divine that they shall meet with enemy which after much trouble they shall overcome which accord prove true of the faithfulness of these holy man he have good proof both here and elsewhere they refuse not to expose themselves to danger and to forswear themselves rather then betray he and the christian to their thievish countryman for these robber will have dismiss the bussarmans so they call their catholic if they will have deliver the caphar that be infidel as they esteem the christian unto their power one of their holy man which the enemy have surprise by no torment will confess any thing to the prejudice of his fellow but at last they be force to agree and give the thief twenty ninth that be twenty time nine several thing and a camel to carry the same away this country of turkeman or Turchestan be the first habitation of the turk and the people be call by that name both in haithons time while he yet live appoint two wise counsellor Odmar and aly to assist he he be well instruct in the arabian learning and a lover of learned man nature have set in his eye such ray of majesty and beauty that man can scarce endure to look on they he wear long hair contrary to the tartarian custom pretend that his mother come of the race of Samson he be strong and have a fair leg whereas Leunclavius say he be call Tamurleng of his lameness his first war be against the Muscovite who he overcome the second against the king of China with like success I mention not his battle in civil war the three against Bajazet the Turk who he captive pass thither by the way of Persia where guines author of the sophian sect a great ginger and account a holy man encourage he with prophecy of his good success this war he make against Bajazet in behalf of the greek emperor and other who the Turk oppress he go private to Constantinople and have sight of the city with all kindness from the emperor he invade Syria and Egypt overthrow the sultan and win cairo destroy Damascus visit and honour jerusalem and the holy sepulchre and grant great privilege thereunto the prince of Lybia and Barbary by their embassage in Egypt acknowledge his sovereignty in his return by Persia he be encounter by guines who bring with he a infinite number of sundry kind of beast which he make tame and by which he teach man as soon as he see Tamerlan he make his prayer towards the heaven for his health and for the religion of the prophet excommunicate the ottoman as enemy to the faithful believer Tamerlan give he fifteen or sixteen thousand r r some say 30000. of his prisoner which he instruct in his opinion and after conquer Persia and so return to samarcand where he have vow to erect a church and hospital with all sumptuous magnificence thence he go to mount Althay to bury his uncle and father in law the great cham in who state he succeed he enrich samarcand with the spoil get in his war and call the temple which he there build the temple of Solomon wherein he hang up trophy and monument of his victory and cause all his battle therein to be engrave thereby say he to acknowledge the goodness of god. his religion be not pure Mahumetisme for he think GOD be delight with variety of worship yet he hate polytheisme and idol only one GOD he acknowledge and that with much devotion after his manner thus he beat down all the idol in China but honour the christian with great admiration at the strict life of some votary when aly his counsellor be dead he build a stately tomb for he at samarcand and cause prayer to be say three day for his soul be near his end he bless his two son lay his hand on the head of Sautochio the elder and press it down but lift up the chin of Letrochio the young as it Barbaro z z l. 1 ram. a venetian which live amongst the tartar about the year 1437 say that they embrace not the faith of Mahomet general but as every man like until about that time in the day of Hedighi a captain under sidahame can who first compel they thereunto be before free unto their idolatry if they please and of the other tartar near the zagathayans he say that many of they be idolater and carry idol in the cart yea some of they use to worship beast they first meet with after they go abroad in the morning their neighbour the moxij at a certain time in the year take a horse which they set in the field with his four leg tie to four post and his head to another post fasten in the ground this do one of they stand in a convenient distance shoot he to the heart afterward they flay he and observe certain ceremony about the flesh eat the same the skin they fill with chaff and in each of his leg thrust a straight stick that he may stand upright as if he be alive last they go to a great tree and lop therefrom as many bough as they think good and make a room or sollar in that tree where they set this horse on this foot and worship he offer unto his fox and diverse beast which bear rich fur of which offering the tree hang full master jenkinson mention a nation live among the tartar call king which be also gentile as be also the Kirgessen of who we have speak and the colmacke which worship the sun as they do also a red cloth fasten to the top of a pole and eat serpent worm and other filth near to which he place in his map of Russia certain statue or pillar of stone which sometime be hoard of man and beast feed transform by divine power if it be not human error into this stony substance retain their pristine shape these nation be either tartar or in manner of life like unto they and may therefore pass under that general appellation and this may suffice touch the tartarian nation and religion which in the west and south part of their abode be mahumetane in the more northerly and easterly partly heathenish partly jewish or moorish or mix or as may best advantage they and most please they wander in opinion in like sort as in their habitation but I have show myself no tartarian while I dwell so long on this tartarian discourse happy herein as tedious to the reader as stay in one place will be to the bohemian-tartar a thing to he so abominable as in anger he wish it as a curse will GOD thou may abide in one place as the christian till thou smell thine own dung indeed this history not thorough handle before by any one draw i along and I hope will purchase pardon to this prolixity chap. 14 of the nation which live in or near to those part now possess by the tartar and their religion and custom from those country inhabit by the persian and zagathayan tartar eastward we can see with m. Paulus his eye the best guide we can get for this way any religion but the saracen till we come to a province somewhat bend to the south the people whereof be idolater and magician cruel and deceitful live on flesh and rice seven day journey from hence be chesmur wicked cunning in their devilish art by which they cause the dumb idol to speak the day to grow dark and other marvelous thing be the wellspring of idol and idolatry in those part they have Heremits after their law which abide in their monastery be very abstinent in eat and drink contain their body in strait chastity and be very careful to abstain from such sin wherewith they think their idol offend and live long there be of they many monastery they be observe of the people with great reverence the people of that nation shed no blood nor kill any flesh but if they will eat any they get the saracen which live amongst they to kill it for they northeastward from hence be Vochan a saracenicall nation and after many day journey over mountain so high that no kind of bird be see thereon be Beloro inhabit with idolater Cascar the next country be mahumetane beyond which be many nestorian christian in Carchan there be also moores or mahumetan which have defile with like superstition the country of Cotam and Peym where the woman may marry new husband if the former be absent above twenty day a a this marriage admit no nonresidence and the man likewise and of Ciarcian and lop. from lordship they cross a desert which ask thirty day and must carry their victual with they here they say spirit call man by their name and cause they to stray from their company and perish with famine when they be pass this desert they enter into Sachion the first city of Tanguth a idolatrous province subject to the great can there be also some nestorian and saracen where they have have the art of print these thousand year they have monastery replenish with idol of diverse sort to which they sacrifice and when they have a male child bear they commend it to some idol in who honour they nourish a ram in their house that year and after on their idol festival they bring it together with their son before the idol and sacrifice the ram and dress the flesh let it stand till they have finish their prayer for their child health in which space they say their idol have suck out the principal substance of the meat which they then carry home to their house and assemble their kinsfolk eat it with great reverence and rejoice save the bone in goodly vessel the priest have for their fee the head foot innards skin and some part of the flesh. when any of great place die they b b funeral observance in Sachion assemble the astrologer and tell the hour of his nativity that they may by their art find a planet fit to the burn of the corpse which sometime in this respect attend this fiery constellation a week a month or half a year in all which time they set before the corpse a table furnish with bread wine and other viand leave they there so long as one may convenient eat they the spirit there present in their opinion refresh himself with the odour of this provision if any evil happen to any of the house the astrologer ascribe it to the angry soul for neglect of his due hour agree to that of his nativity they make many stay by the way wherein they present this depart soul with such cates to hearten it against the body burn they paint many paper make of the bark of tree with picture of man woman horse camel money and raiment which they burn together with the body that the dead may have to serve he in the next world and all this while of burn be the music of the city present play Chamul the next province be idolatrous or heathenish for so we distinguish they from saracens jew and christian which I will be not as guilty of idolatry as the former in so many their forbid rite although these have all and the other part of the scripture whereof those heathen and idolater be utter ignorant here they not only permit but account it a great honour to have their wife and sister at the pleasure of such stranger as they entertain themselves depart the while and suffer all thing to be at their guest will for so be their idol serve who therefore for this hospitality they think will prosper all that they have and when as mangu can forbid they this beastly practice they abstain three year but then send a pitiful embassage to he with request that they may continue their former custom for since they leave it they can not thrive who overcome by their fond importunity grant their request which they with joy accept and do still observe in the same province of Tanguth be Succuir who mountain be clothe with rheubarbe from whence it be by merchant convey through the world Campion be the mother city of the country inhabit by idolater with some of the arabian and christian nation the christian have there in the time of m. polo three fair church the idolater have many monastery abound with idol of wood earth and stone cover with gold and artificial make some great ten pace in length lie along with other little one about they which seem as their disciple to do they reverence their religious person live in their opinion more honest than other idolater although their honesty be such as that they think it no sin to lie with a woman which shall seek it at their hand but if the man first make love it be sinful they have also their fasting-day three four or five in a month in which they shed no blood nor eat flesh they have many wife of which the first-married have the first place and pre-eminence here m. Paul live about a year touch the religion and custom in Tanguth the report c c ramusius of Caggi Memet in ramusius who of late year be in Campion be not much different he say that their temple be make like the christian capable of four or five thousand person in they be two image of a man and woman lie in length forty foot all of one piece or stone for which use they have cart with forty wheel draw of five or six hundred horse and mule two or three month journey they have also little image with six or seven head and ten hand hold in each of they several thing as a serpent bird flower etc. they have monastery wherein be man of holy life never come forth but have food carry they thither daily their gate be wall up and there be infinite of friar-like companion pass to and fro in the city when any of their kindred die they mourn in white they have print not much unlike to that which be use in Europe and artillery on their wall very thick as have the turk all the catayans and idolater be forbid to depart out of their native country they have three science limia and the first alchemy the second to make enamour the three juggle or magic Succuir also be accord to his report great and fair beautify with many temple their rheubarbe they will not bestow the pain to gather but for the merchant which from China Persia and other place fetch it from they at a cheap price nor do they in Tanguth use it for physic as we here but with other ingredient make perfume thereof for their idol and in some place they burn it in stead of other fire and give it their horse to eat they set more price by a herb which they call Mambroni medicinable for the eye and another call Chiai Catai grow in Catay at Cacianfu admirable against very many disease a ounce whereof they esteem as good as a sack of rheubarbe who description you may see at large accord to the relation and picture of the say Chaggi in ramusius for to add that also they have many painter and one country inhabit only by they these tanguthians be beard as man in these part especial some time of the year northwards from Tanguth be the plain d d m. paul. of Bargu in custom and manner like to the first tartars confine with the scythian ocean fourscore day journey from Ezina in the north part of Tanguth and situate under the north star eastward of Tanguth somewhat incline to the south be the kingdom of erginul addict likewise to ethnic superstition wherein yet be some both nestorian and Mahumetans here be certain wild bull as big as elephant with mane of white and fine hair like silk of which some they tame and betwixt they and their tame cow engender a race of strong and laborious oxen. here be find a beast also as big as a goat of exquisite shape which every full moon have a apostemation or swell under the belly which the hunter at that time chase the say beast do cut off and dry against the sun and it prove the best musk in the world the next easterly country be Egrigaia idolatrous and have some christian of the sect of Nestorius but Tenduc next adjoin be at that time govern by king George a christian and a priest of the posterity of presbyter John subject to the grand can. and the grand can give common their daughter in marriage to this generation and stock of presbyter John the most part of the inhabitant be christian some idolater and mahometans be there also there be also that be call descend of ethnike and moor the wise and proper man in those part all the people from hence to cathay be Christian mahometan and gentile as themselves like best in Thebet the next country the people that drink out of they in the midst of their jollity they may not forget their progenitor they have much gold but hold it a high offence to imprison it as some do with we in chest or treasury and therefore have satisfy his necessity they lie up the rest in the earth fear otherwise to offend god. Cambalu be in the north-east part of cathay and forty mile westward from hence all which way be enrich with palace vineyard and fruitful field be Gouza a fair city and great with many idoll-monastery here the way part lead westward into cathay and south-eastward unto Mangi or China Tanifu and Cacianfu be province which trend westward from hence inhabit with idolatrous nation and here and there some of the arabian and christian profession full of city Cunchin and Sindinfu be ethnike as be Thebeth where they have a brutish custom f f livert report the like custom in Calicut not to take a wife that be a virgin and therefore when merchant pass that way the mother offer unto they their daughter much strive which of they may be the most effectual bawd to her child they take to their pleasure such as they like gratify they with some jewel or other present which on her marriage-day she wear and she which have most of such present bring the most accept dowry to her husband as testimony of the great favour of their idol this Thebeth contain sometime eight kingdom with many city but be now desolate by the tartarian there be great necromancer which by their infernal skill cause thunder and tempest they have dog as big as ass with which they catch wild ox and all sort of beast Caindu be a heathenish nation where in honour of their idol they prostitute their wife sister and daughter to the lust of traveller which be entertain in the house the good man depart and the woman set some token over the door which there remain as long as this stallion-stranger for a sign to her husband not to return till the guest be as well go from her house as honesty from her heart and wit from his head they make money of salt as in cathay of paper in Caraian also a large province adjoin there be some christian and saracen but the most ethnike which be not discontent that other man shall lie with their wife if the woman be willing Carazan be of like ir-religion their soul captivate to the old serpent and their body endanger to mighty huge body of g g the serpent of Carazan serpent ten pace long and ten span thick which that country yield they keep in their den in the day and in the night prey upon lion wolf and other beast which when they have devour they resort to some water to drink and by their weight leave so deep impression in the sand that hereby man know their haunt do underset this their Tract with sharp stake head with iron cover the same again with sand by this mean prey on the spoiler and devour the devourer esteem nothing more savoury than the flesh nor more medicinable than the gall of this serpent more serpentine than this diet be that custom which they use when any proper and personable gentleman of valorous spirit and goodly presence lodge in any house amongst they in the night they kill he not for the spoil but that his soul furnish with such part of body and mind may remain in that house much hope of future happiness to that house do they repose in so unhappy attempt but the great can kill this serpent also overthrow this custom in the conquest of that province Cardandan confine on the western limit of Carazan they make black lift in their flesh rase the skin and put therein some black tincture which ever remain h h naked pride account it a great ornament when a woman be deliver of a child the man lie in and keep his bed with visitation of gossip the space of forty day they worship the ancient person of the house ascribe to he all their good in this province and in Caindu vocian and they have no physician but when any be sick they send for their witch or sorcerer and acquaint they with their malady they cause minstrel to play while they dance and sing in honour of their idol not cease till the devil enter into one of they of who those sorcerer demand the cause i i infernal physic of the party sickness and mean of recovery the Demoniake answer for some offence to such or such a god. they pray that god of pardon vow that when he be whole he shall offer he a sacrifice of his own blood if the devil see he unlikely to recover he answer that his offence be so grievous that no sacrifice can expiate but if there be likelihood of recovery he enjoin they a sacrifice of so many ram with black head to be offer by these sorcerer assemble together with their wife and then will that god be reconcile this be present do by the kinsman of the sick the sheep kill their blood hurl up towards heaven the sorcerer and sorceress make great light and incense all this visit house make a smoke of aloe and cast into the air the water wherein the sacrifice flesh be sodden with some spice drink laugh sing dance in honour of that god. after all this revel-rout they demand again of the Demoniake if the God be appease if so they fall to those spice drink and sacrifice flesh with great mirth and be well apay return home if not they at his bid renew their superstition ascribe the recovery if it happen to that idol and if he die notwithstanding they shift it off to the want of their full due fleece or taste the same before to the idol defraud thus they do in all Catay and Mangi thus much out of the large report of Paulus tell the like of Cailar and Caracoram where he have be in these catayan province concern their Christopher or giantlike idol and idol temple in one of which he see a man with a cross draw with ink on his read soft to themselves nor can our author enter amongst they by any mean break this their silence they have wheresoever they go a string about they full of nutshell like the popish bead-roll always they be utter these word GOD thou know expect so many reward as they make such memorial of god. they have a churchyard and a church-porch with a long pole on it as it be a steeple adjoin to their temple in those porch they use to sit and confer they wear certain ornament of paper on their head their writing be downward and so from the left hand to the right which the tartar receive from they they use magical character hang their temple full of they they burn their dead and lay up the ash in the top of a pyramid they believe there be one GOD that he be a spirit and their image they make not to represent GOD but in memorial of the rich after their death as they profess to the priest beside their saffron-iackets button close before wear on their left shoulder a cloak descend before and behind under their right arm like to a deacon carry the houselboxe in lent. they worship towards the north clap their hand together and prostrate themselves on their knee upon the earth hold also their forehead in their hand they extend their temple east and west in length upon the north-side they build as it be a vestry on the south a porch the door of their temple be always open to the south a certain nestorian priest tell he of so huge a idol that may be see two day before a man come at it within the quire which be on the north side of the temple they place a chest long and broad like a Hak. to.1 follow the samoyed about the bank of Pechere be in subjection to the Muscovite and when they will remove from one place to another than they will make sacrifice in manner follow every kindred do sacrifice in their own tent and he that be most ancient be their priest. and first the priest do begin to play upon a thing like to a great five with a skin on the one end like a drum his drumme-sticke be about a span long and one end be round like a ball cover with the skin of a hart. also the priest have as it be a white garland on his head and his face be cover with a piece of a shirt of male with many small rib and tooth of fish and wild beast hang thereon then he sing as we use here in England to hollow whoop or shout at hound and the rest of the company answer he with this oute Igha Igha Igha to which the priest with his voice repli and they answer he with the selfsame word so many time till in the end he become as it be mad fall down as he be dead have nothing on he but a shirt and lie on his back I perceive he yet to breath and ask why he lie so they answer now do our GOD tell he what we shall do and whither we shall go and when he have lie still a little while they cry thus three time together Oghao Oghao Oghao and as they use these three call he rise with his head and lie down again and then he rise up and sing with like voice as he do before with the like answer Igha Igha Igha then he command they to kill five Ollens or great deer and continue sing still both he and they as before then he take a sword of a cubit and a span long I do mete it myself and put it into his belly half way and sometime less but no wound be to be see they continue their sweet song still then he put the sword into the fire till it be warm and so thrust it into the slit of his shirt and thrust it through his body as I think in at his navel and out at his fundament the point be out of his shirt behind I lay my finger upon it then he pull out the sword and sit down this be do they set a kettle of water over the fire to heat and when the water do seethe the priest begin to sing again they answer he for so long as the water be in seethe they sit and sing not then they make a thing be four square and in height and squareness of a chair and cover with a gown very close the forepart thereof for the hinderpart stand to the tent side their tent be round and be call Chome in their language the water still seethe on the fire and this square seat be ready the priest put off his shirt and the thing like a garland which be on his head with those thing which cover his face and he have on yet all this while a pair of hose of deere-skinne with the hair on which come up to his buttock so he go into the square seat and sit down like a tailor and sing with a strong voice or hollow then they take a small line make of deere-skinne of four fathom long and with a small knot the priest make it fast about his neck and under his left arm and give it to two man stand on each side of he which hold the end together then the kettle of hot water be set before he in the square seat which seat they now cover with a gown of broad-cloath without line such as the Russ use to wear then the two man which do hold the end of the line still stand there begin to draw and draw till they have draw the end of the line stiff and together and then I hear a thing fall into the kettle of water which be before he in the tent I ask what it be and they answer his head shoulder and leave arm which the line have cut off I mean the knot which I see afterward draw hard together then I rise up and will have look whether it be so or not but they lay hold on i and say that if they shall see he with their bodily eye they shall live no long and the most part of they can speak the russian tongue to be understand and they take i to be a russian then they begin to hallow with these word oghaoo oghaoo oghaoo many time together in the mean while I see a thing like a finger of a man two time together thrust through the gown from the priest. I ask they that sit near to i what it be that I see and they say not his finger for he be yet dead and that which I see appear through the gown be a beast but what beast they know not nor will not tell and I look upon the gown and there be no hole to be see at last the priest lift up his head with his shoulder and arm and all his body and come out to the fire thus far of their service which I see during the space of certain hour but how they do worship their idol that I see not for they put up their stuff to remove from that place where they lay and I go to he that serve their priest and ask he what their GOD say to he when he lay as dead he answer that his own people do not know neither be it for they to know for they must do as he command the hollander in the year 1594. scent to have then build Quinsay anew thirty mile circuit but let we listen to Pantogia these city of China want that elegance and magnificence which stately temple and sumptuous building do afford unto our city of Europe their house be low without the ornament of porch gallery window and prospect into the street in the winter m m ant. dal. meida they have store of ice and snow even about Nanquin they have abundance of all thing necessary to the life of man first-fruit flesh and fish with price correspondent they have two and some where three harvest in the year few mountain but plain of a hundred league wine they make of Rice they eat thrice a day but spare their drink be it water or wine they drink hot and eat with two stick of ivory ebony or like matter nor touch their meat with their hand and therefore little naperie serve they their warm drink and abstinence from first-fruit be great preservative of their health which for the most part they enjoy the chinians n n description of the Chinois have thin beard not above twenty hair short nose small black eye long garment and if they will resemble a deform man they paint he with short habit great eye and beard and a long nose they be white but not so much as in Europe they have artificer of all trade and in idleness none may live the impotent be well provide for in hospital they have no gentleman but every man be a plebeian until his merit raise he preferment be achieve only by learning this make they general studious their letter be not reduce into alphabetical order nor be proper letter but character whereof they have forty thousand and therefore in that they frame not difference of syllable but of sense in diverse language yea in japon their writing be understand not their speak their paper be like a thin transparent parchment and bear ink but on one side their writing be downward not sideways as we they have in ordinary and daily use eight or ten thousand of those character their word be monosyllable rhetoric be the only science which they aim at for he obtain place of honour which can most fit place his word and most eloquent write of the subject propound they have not public school but in the city be public trial or commencement every three year whither these probationer resort and be examine and be accord prefer they have three degree o o descrip. mac. graduate of the first degree be call Siusai of the second Quiugin of the three Chinzu every city yield trial for the first degree for the second only the metropolitan city of the province whereunto they of the first degree do resort every three year and in a public house do the second time make a oration of some obscure theme than the former there be such multitude of they that some be sometime kill in the entrance of that their commencement-house for the three degree they be examine only at the court the three year after and out of this order be take their mandarine or magistrate after some study in the law of the land. while they be write their probationary theme they be shut up with one to attend they four and twenty hour with pen ink paper and candle and have subscribe their name certain register copy the say oration without set to the author name and then seal up their first pattern those nameless copy be by appoint officer examine and those choose which they approve for best the name and author be know by compare these copy with the principal in the first degree they obtain certain immunity to themselves and their family provide that he proceed in his study or else they will degrade he he that have obtain the three degree of p p Loytia or Loutea Loytia as they term it or as we may style it doctor write it up over his door that all man may honour his house and this be the high nobility whereto they can ascend to the elder brother of these fellow-commencers be a triumphal arch erect beside other solemnity they have book write by certain wiseman or philosopher two thousand year since or more of political and moral philosophy the author whereof they honour for saint especial one to who the mandarine do therefore once in the year offer sacrifice and the king do honour his posterity unto this day and he alone in the pith and weight of his sentence may be compare to Plato or Seneca though far short of their elegant and eloquent phrase their print be somewhat differ from we not join the letter but for every leaf make a table with letter or character on both side they print also white letter in black more atificial than we poetry paint and music be amongst they commendable quality their learning be not so exceed as the first chinian relation report in the mathematics and other liberal science the principal mandarine admire the jesuite in these thing who esteem the great learning of the Chinois after their valuation to be nothing superior to that of the roman in the day of Cicero although it can be deny that Rome even then approach near her high top of human science
