Vanlia the present king be the son of a concubine as his apparent heir also be these woman be so strait keep that they be neither suffer to go abroad nor to speak unto their kinsfolk which likewise receive no increase of honour or authority by their kinswomens advancement his courtier be eunuch who their poor parent have geld in their youth in hope of this court-preferment where after they be admit by that Manderine appoint to this office they be train up under elder eunuch to be make serviceable of this dross of mankind be suppose to be in the court a hundred and threescore thousand this king be esteem more tyrannical than his predecessor neither do he ever come abroad as they be wont once in the year to sacrifice in the temple sacred to heaven and earth his palace be far more spacious but not equal in workmanship to those in Europe it be compass with a triple wall the first whereof may environ a large town herein beside the many lodging of the eunuch be hill grove stream and other thing of pleasure the jesuite t t our author say that he pass eight huge palace before he come to the lodging of those eunuch which be appoint to learn how to order their clock or watch wherewith they have present the king and there be as many beyond and ascend up a tower he see tree garden house exceed all that ever he have see in Europe who yet have be in many the most sumptuous building therein within the three wall be the king with his woman child and such servant as be thither admit when the heir apparent be proclaim all his other son be send away soon after and confine to certain city where they nothing participate in affair of state otherwise be honour as the king kindred live in pleasure in their pallaceprison unto the three and four generation the king title be lord of the world and son of heaven the mandarine have their habit both in attire and language in their judicial proceed peculiar of these mandarine to omit they which be officer in each city there be three principal in each province the first have to deal in case criminal and be call Ganchasu the second be the king fosterer or treasurer and be call puchinsn the lieutenant for the war name Chumpin these all be in subjection unto the Tutan or viceroy of the province all these magistrate bear office three year together choose always out of other province to avoid corruption they have a annual officer call chaien who make inquisition of all crime both of private person and magistrate themselves none may execute the sentence of death but by especial commission from the king. and therefore the malefactor be consume in the prison but they have authority with certain cane to bear man on the leg in such terrible cruelty that a few blow may either lame or kill the party and therefore no king be more fear than these mandarine who go or be carry rather on man shoulder in sumptuous chair such be their fashion attend with fifty or threescore sergeant go before they two and two in a rank arm and furnish with halberd mace battleax chain and these cane some cry to give way wherewith and the noise of those chain and cane both man and dog with mute silence give place in the midst of their city be palace of the king for these officer to reside in in Panquin and Nanquin the multitude of these magistrate be incredible one of these city contain more than two thousand and five hundred as many as somewhere be of citizen these all twice a day hear cause and execute justice in Panquin be six mandarine precedent of so many several counsel the first of these be call the heavenly mandarin for that his most ample power which entreat with the king for the preferment degradation or correction of all the mandarine in the kingdom for not one of they be there who office be not by his majesty confirm or abrogate the second be master of the ceremony both in human magnificence and divine saricfice the three be head of the council of war the four be chief treasurer the five be surveyor and Longobard. on the say holiday of the new and full moon a little before sun rise in all the city of this vast kingdom and in all the street thereof at one and the same hour they make publication and proclamation of six precept first obey thy father and mother second reverence they elder and superior three keep peace with thy neighbour four teach thy child and posterity the five enjoin every one to discharge his office and calling the last prohibit crime as murder adultery theft and such like these thing do their mandarine cause to be observe otherwise atheist not have reason or reason of the immortality of the soul and future reward which yet some of their book and picture of their Pao or God resemble those infernal torment may learn they both manderine and other have many image in their house to which they sacrifice but n n reg. sin. if they obtain not their request they will whip and beat these god and then set they again in their place and with new incense seek their reconcilement renew their prayer and their stripe also if their prayer be reject and in a word the manderine be the god or devil rather who the people most fear as dread blow from they which themselves at pleasure can and do inflict on the other this god-beating they use with lot o o l. 6 disc. of China for when any be to undertake a journey or any matter of weight as buy lend marry etc. they have two stick flat on the one side otherwise round as big as a walnut tie together with a small thread which after many sweet orison they hurl before the idol if one or both of they fall with the flat side upward they revile the image with the most opprobrious term and then have thus disgorge their choler they again crave pardon with many fawn promise but if at the second cast they find no better fortune they pass form word to blow the deaf God be hurl on the earth into the water or fire till at last with his vicissitude of sweet and sour handle and their importunate reiteration of their cast he must needs at last relent and be therefore feast with hen music and if it be of very great moment which they consult about with a hog head boil dress with herb and flower and a pot of their wine they cut off the the kindred come together and assemble as many priest as they can which on musical instrument and with their voice tune their mournful ditty the place whither the corpse be carry be adorn with diverse image the coffin be very large the provide of which they commit not to their heir but themselves in their life take order for the same bestow great care and cost for the best wood and workmanship which they be able to procure wherein spend sometime seventy eighty or a hundred ducat they hold it unfortunate to die before they have provide the same they be no less curious for the place of their burial think that hereon depend the fortune of their posterity and therefore sometime spend a whole year in consultation whether it shall be towards the north or some other region their sepulcher be in the field where they fortify they and oft time resort thither to perform their obsequy to be bury within the wall be a thing most miserable never to be forget and for some time after they will eat no flesh in regard of that passage of soul before speak of this opinion be of more authority and credit with they than that of hell or heaven although as be say their book and picture depaint terrible king but one of they be Paramount it b b discourse of China p. 381 abound with gold silver aloe porcelain and silk they be idolater and pagan and c c gi. bot. ben. have have some devotion to the some miracle their religion seem little to differ from that of the Chinois nigh unto this kingdom be Champa the name of a kingdom and chief city thereof of great traffic especial of aloe which grow there in the mountain prize at the weight in silver which they use in bath and in the funeral of great prince in religion they be as the former Camboia lie southward from thence a great and populous country full of elephant and abada this beast be the rhinoceros here also they begin to honour the cross as friar Silvester a man as they say much reverence by the king and honour of the people have teach they when the king die d d pop. his woman be burn and his noble do voluntary sacrifice themselves in the same fire the woman be general burn with their husband at their death the camboyans deal treacherous e e jac. cornel. Nicolai with the hollander an. 1602. who they invite to the shore with promise of certain buff and then cruel slay they they detain the admiral on shore to be redeem with some of their ordinance when they intend a journey they use divination with the foot of a hen to know whether it will be lucky or no and as the wizard shall answer they dispose of themselves either to go or stay on this side of Camboia be f f magin ben. siam mother-city of a kingdom bear the same name in which be reckon thirty thousand family of moor beside the natural in these part be huge wood harbour of lion tiger ounce and mariche which have maiden face and scorpion tail here run Menan out of that huge lake Chiamay which yield this and other river of like nature to Nilus in Egypt they have amongst they many religious g g discourse of China p. 390 man which lead a austere life and therefore have in great reputation of holiness these live in common they may not marry nor speak to a woman which fault be punish with death they go always barefoot in poor array eat nothing but rice and green herb which they beg from door to door they crave it not nor take it with their hand but go with a wallet at their back always with their eye modest fix on the ground and call or knock stand still till they receive answer or some thing be put in their wallet many time they set themselves naked in the heat of the sun notwithstanding that himself with such direct beam together with his fry whole army of gnat do their utmost malice upon they they rise at midnight to pray unto their idol which they do in quire as the friar do they may not buy sell or take any rent which if they shall do will bring on they the imputation of heretic some merchant of siam be at Canton and hear that friar Martin Ignacio and his companion be there imprison for ^^^ that chinian kingdom without licence they visit they and see their poor friar weed they beside other alm offer to pay their ransom if money will do it the siamite h h g. bot. B^^ l.2.part.3 common hold that GOD create all thing reward the good punish the bad that man have two spirit one good to keep and the other evil to tempt continual attend he they build many and fair temple and place in they many image of saint which sometime live virtuous and now be in heaven they have one statue fifty pace long which be sacred to the father of man for they think that he be send from above and that of he be bear certain person that suffer martyrdom for the love of god. their priest be clothe in yellow long garment this colour be esteem holy and every yellow thing for the resemblance which it have with gold and with the sun be hallow to god. beside that which be before say of their strict order they may not nourish hen because of their female sex to drink wine be punish in their priest with stone they have many fast in the year but one especial in which the people frequent the temple and their sermon they have their canonical hour by day and night for their holy thing they hold that the world shall last eight thousand year whereof six thousand be pass and then it shall be consume with fire at which time shall be open in heaven seven eye of the sun which shall dry up the water and burn up the earth in the ash shall remain two egg whence shall come forth one man and one woman which shall renew the world. but there shall be no more salt but fresh river and lake which shall cause the earth without man labour to abound in plenty of good thing the siamite be the sink of the superstition which they derive to many nation the inhabitant of this kingdom be much give to pleasure and riot they refuse the use of manual art but addict themselves to husbandry they have i i ben. public school where they teach law and religion in the vulgar language other science they learn in a more learned tongue they worship innumerable idol but especial the four element accord to which his sect each man make choice of his burial they which worship the earth be therein bury the fire burn the dead carcase of they which observe it in the air be hang to feast that ayrie-winged people with their flesh those which adore the air be alive the water drown those which have alive be drown in that watery religion every king at his first entrance to the crown erect a temple which he adorn with high steeple and innumerable idol in the city of Socotay be one of mettle fourscore span high the kingdom of siam comprehend that aurea chersonesus of Ptolomey describe by arrianus in his periplus the map whereof Ortelius set forth 1597 which tremellius and junius and yet have not prevail if treason have not more further his design then force the gate be one night set open and the Peguans enter which when the siamite perceive he poison himself leave his child and kingdom a prey to the conqueror who triumphal return Frederick then in Pegu behold since that time the king of siam have be tributary to Pegu. after this peguan have reign seven and thirty year he leave his kingdom but not his fortune to his son who take displeasure against the siamite his vassal send for he to come to he which he refuse and thereupon he enter into his country with nine hundred thousand man and besiege he in his chief city which he seek politic delay make semblance still to deliver until in the three month after which be march the river overflow the country six score mile about after his yearly custom and partly drown partly commit to the siamite attend in boat for this booty to be slaughter that huge army of which scarce threescore and ten thousand return to Martavan Frith before they take order go to school till they be twenty year old or more then they come before a tallipoie appoint for that purpose who they call Rowli he as chief and most learned examine they many time whether they will leave their friend and the company of all woman and take upon they the habit of a talipoy if he be content than he ride upon a horse about the street very rich apparel with drum and pipe to show that he leave the riches of the world to be a tallipoie in few day after he be carry upon a thing like a horslitter which they call a serion upon ten or twelve man shoulder in apparel of a tallipoy with pipe and drum and many tallipoy with he and all his friend which accompany he to his house stand without the town and there leave he every one of they have his house which be very little set upon six or eight post to which they ascend on a ladder of twelve or fourteen step these house be common by the highway side and among the tree and in the wood they go stange apparel with one Camboline or thin cloth next to their body of a brown colour another of yellow double many time upon their shoulder these two be gird to they with a broad girdle and they have a skin of leather hang on a string about their neck whereon they sit bareheaded and barefooted with their right arm bare and a broad Sombrero or shadow in their hand to defend they in summer from the sun and in winter from the rain they go with a great pot make of wood or fine earth and conered tie with a broad girdle upon their shoulder which come under their arm wherewith they go to beg their victual which they eat which be Rice fish and herb they demand nothing but come to the door and the people present do give they one thing or other they put altogether in their pot they keep their feast by the moon and at a new moon be their most solemn feast and then the people send Rice and other thing to that kiack or church of which they be and there all the tallipoy of that church meet and eat that which be send they they preach against all abuse and many resort unto they when they enter into their kiack at the door there be a great jar of water with a cock or a ladle in it and there they wash their foot and then enter in lift up their hand to their head first to their preacher and then to the sun and so sit down when the tallipoy preach many of the people carry they gift into the pulpit where they sit and preach and there be one which sit by they to take that which the people bring which be divide among they they have none other ceremony nor service that I can see but only preach Boterus f f g. b.b.l.part 3 Arthus pag. 319. say that they hold a innumerable multitude of world successive one after another and also innumerable number of god but not all at once they imagine that five have govern this present world whereof four be pass above two hundred year ago now they be without a god and expect the five many age hereafter after who death they conceive that the world shall perish by fire and then another world shall follow and other god to rule it they reckon likewise in the number of their god certain man which yet have first pass into fish beast and bird of all sort after death they believe three place one of pleasure like the mahumetane paradise another of torment the three of annihilation which they call Niba the soul after their fantasy abide in the two former place whence they return so often into this life till at last they be hold worthy that Niba he add that they have covent or college of priest which live three hundred together or more in one place have no use of woman be harbourer of stranger and live some of alm some of rent they have like nunnery also for the woman there be suppose to be in one idol-sanctuarie whereof they have many 120000. idol they fast thirty day in the year in which they eat nothing till night they be of opinion that he which in this world rob another man shall in the next world be his servant for recompense they other thing and so set forth the same to sea set that theatre or pagcant on fire in one of the ship be talapoy which sing till they think the body consume to ash then do they make a mass or lump of these ash and milk and commit the same to sea in the haven of sirian at a ebb water the bone which remain they carry to a other place and there erect a chapel do bury the same therein after this they these be his executioner who in the presence of the king cut off his head hand and foot and add pepper and salt eat his flesh raw he be call the king of and be of great power have many ship much pepper and be a swear enemy to the portugall work all the evil he can to malacca if the father know the son to be guilty or the son the father of some grievous crime he may slay he but must after give arrecaes and other first-fruit and with great dance and rejoice they offer to the devil and say they give the devil to eat and drive he out and to this end in their dance they cry and hollow very loud likewise when they be sick a tallipoy or two every night do sit by they and sing to please the devil that he shall not hurt they when one be dead he be carry upon a great frame make like a tower with cut off and be thence forward narrow look to that they keep not each other company the portugal have here Porto and Porto Pequino but without fort and government every man live after his own lust and his snout tooth flesh blood claw and whatsoever he have without and within his body be good against poison and be much account of throughout all India the skin d d Linschot c. 47 upon the upper part pray which make all holy they have one idol call ada with four hand and claw on certain great carve stone also they pour water rice wheat etc. they have a great place like a well with step to go down wherein the water stand foul and stink by reason of those many flower which they continual throw thereinto many people be always therein with imagination of pardon for their sin because God as they blaspheme wash himself therein they gather up the sand in the bottom as a holy relic they pray not but in the water and wash themselves over head lade up water with both their hand and turn themselves about and then drink a little of the water three time after which they go to their god in their house some of they will wash a place which be their length and then will pray upon the earth with their arm and leg at length out and will rise up and lie down and kiss the ground twenty or thirty time but will not stir their right foot some use fifteen or sixteen pot little and great ring a bell while they make their mixture ten or twelve time and make a circle of water about their pot and pray other sit by one of which reach they their pot they say over these pot diverse thing many time which do they go to their god and strew their sacrifice which they think be very holy and mark many of they which sit by in the forehead esteem as a great gift there come fifty and sometime a hundred together to this well and to these idol about their idol in some house sit one in warm weather to blow the wind with a fan upon they and when they see any company come they ring a little bell and many give they their alm none of these idol have a good face some be black and have claw of brass and some ride on peacock or other fowl one there be always attend with his fan to make wind which they say give they all thing both food and raiment here some be burn to ash some scorch in the fire and throw into the water when they be dead the fox present eat they the wife do burn with their husband when they die if they will not their head be shave and never any account be make of they after if a man or woman be sick and like to die they will lay he before their idol all night and that shall mend or end he and if he do not mend that night his friend will come and fit a little with he and cry and after will carry he to the water side and set he upon a little raft make of reed and so let he go down the river the chief idol be very evill-favoured their mouth monstrous their ear gild and full of jewel their tooth and eye of gold silver glass colour black with lamp continual burn before they into their house or temple you may not enter with your shoe on when the scorch indian be throw into Ganges the man swim with their face downward the woman with their face upward which I have think they have by up their hand to the sun and to kiss the earth with their arm and leg stretch out along their right leg be always before the left every time they lie down they score it with their finger to know when accustom himself to poison that no day pass wherein he take not some for else he himself have die say Barbosa as it fare with amsian or opium the use whereof kill such as never take it and the disuse such as have and beyond that which we read of Mithrodates in the like practice his nature be transform into so venomous a habit that if he do mean to put any of his noble to death he will cause they to be set naked before he and chew certain fruit in his mouth which they call Chofolos and with lime make of shell by spit upon he in one half hour deprive he of life if a fly sit upon his hand it will present fall off dead neither be e e ^d Barbosa his love to be prefer to his hatred or with woman be his deal less deadly for he have four thousand concubine of who none live to see a second sun Mamudius the successor of king machamut be a great enemy to the portugall Badurius succeed in state and affection and exceed in greatness and ambition he invade g g Moff l. 11 Mandao and Sanga where he besiege citor then govern by a warlike woman which not able to hold out long against he flee and leave the people in forlorn plight who in a desperate resolution like Sardanapalus heap up their treasure set fire thereto and then cast themselves therein this fire continue three day and consume threescore and ten thousand person hence Badurius triumphant march against the Mogor who Maffaens call it seem to be echebar grandfather who some h h rel. reg Mog call Baburxa famous for his indian victory with a army of a hundred and fifty thousand horse whereof thirty thousand be bard and five hundred thousand footman of great brazen ordinance a thousand whereof four basilisk be draw such be their weight by so many hundred yoke of ox with shot and powder he lade five hundred wane and as many with gold and silver to pay his soldier these force with this provision may rend the air with thunder may make the earth to shake with terror may dry and drink up river of water may frame another fiery element of art invention but can not either terrify the Mogor or save Badurius from a double overthrow first at next at Mandoa where the lose his tent and treasure and shave his beard flee disguise to Diu in which that the portugall may be engage in the same war he give they leave to erect a fortress a thing of such moment unto they that John Botelius confine before unto India for crime object think by be the first messenger thereof in Portugal to purchase his liberty whereof he may well be repute worthy who in a little vessel scarce eighteen foot long and six wide with undaunted courage contemn that wide long and tempestuous ocean arrive with his small company great news and great admiration at Lisbon Badurius after alteriug his mind and therein entertain a treacherous project against the portugall colour the same with kindness and he which fear all i i cicer. offic. man no less than he be fear as guilty to his own tyranny which sometime make dionisin of a king a I go one day say Pinnerus to the public hospital which the citizen of Cambaia have found for all kind of bird to cure they in their sickness some peacock be there incurable and therefore may have be expel the hospital but alack for pity of so rueful a accident a hawk have be admit thither for the cure of his lame leg which be whole he inhospital slay many of these co-hospitall weak fowl and be therefore expel this bird-colledge by the master thereof for man they have not a hospital that be thus hospital to fowl they have certain religious person call Verteas a a the religious in Cambaia which live in a college together and when I go to their house they be about fifty in number they wear white cloth be bareheaded and shave if that word may be apply to they who pull off their hair on their head and face leave only a little on their crown they live on alm nor receive they but the surplusage of the daily food of he that give they they be wifeless the order of their sect be write in a book of the guzarate write they drink their water hot not for physic but devotion suppose that the water have a soul which they shall slay if they drink the same unsodden for the same cause they bear in their hand certain little brush with which they sweep the floor before they sit down or walk lest they shall kill the soul of some worm or other small creature I see their prior thus do the general of this order be say to have a hundred thousand man under his canonical obedience and be new choose every year I see amongst they little boy of eight or nine year old resemble the countenance of Europe rather than of India by their parent consecrate to this order they have all in their mouth a cloth four finger broad let through both their ear in a hole and bring back again through their ear they will not show i the cause but I perceive it be lest some gnat or fly shall enter thither and so be slay they teach that the world be make many hundred thousand year ago and that GOD do then send three and twenty apostle and now have send the four and twenty in this three age two thousand year since from which time they have have write which before they have not the same b b em. pinner author in another epistle say that the most of the inhabitant of Cambaia be Bramenes they eat no flesh nor kill any thing yea they redeem beast and bird maim or sick and carry they to their hospital to be cure in guzzarat he have see many gioghi a religious order of monk which yield to none in penance and poverty they go naked in cold weather they sleep on dunghill upon a heap of ash with which they cover their head and face I see the place where one of these gioghi keep in the midst of the city Amadeba to who in conceit of holiness resort more number of people then to the shore of Lisbon at the return of the indian Fleet. this gioghi be send for by the prince sultan Morad son of the Mogor and refuse to come c c one report the like of the gymnosophist bid that the prince shall come to he it be enough that I be holy or a saint to this end whereupon the prince cause he to be apprehend and be sound whip to be banish this people kill not their kine but nourish they as their mother I see at Amadeba when a cow be ready to die they offer her fresh grasle and drive the fly from she and some of they give this attendance two or three day after till she be dead a league and a half from this city I see a certain or burying-place than which I have never see a fair sight wherein have be bury one Cazis the master of a king of Guzarat who have erect this fabric and three other be bury in another chapel the whole work and pavement be of marble contain three isle in one whereof I tell four hundred and forty pillar with their chapiter and base of corinthian work very royal and admirable on one side be a lake great than the Rozzio at Lisbon and that build be curious frame with fair window to look into the lake Linschoten d d Linsch c.37 Andrea affirm the same thing of their Pythagorean error and add that they sometime buy fowl or other beast of the portugal which mean to have dress they and let they flee or run away in the highway also and wood they set pot with water and cast corn or other grain upon the ground to feed the bird and beast and to omit their charitable hospital before mention if they take a flea or a louse they will not kill it but put it in some hole or corner in the wall and so let it go and you can do they no great injury then to kill it in their presence which with all entreaty they will resist as be a heinous sin to take away the life of that to which GOD have impart both soul and body and where word will not prevail they will offer money they eat no radish onion garlic or any kind of herb that have red colour in it nor egg for they think there be blood in they they drink not wine nor use vinegar but only water they will rather starve then eat with any but their countryman as it happen when I sail from Goa to cochin with they in a Portugal ship when they have spend all their store the time fall out long than they make account of they will not once touch our meat they wash themselves every time they eat or ease themselves or make water under their hair they have a star upon their forehead which they rub every morning with a little white sander temper with water and three or four grain of rice among it which the Bramenes also do as a superstitious ceremony of their law they sit on the ground in their house upon mat or carpet and so they eat leave their staff which be pike and hook at the door for which cause the heel of their shoe be seldom pull up to save labour of undo they the moor e e od. Barbosa amongst they will sometime abuse the superstition of these cambayans to their own covetousness bring some worm rat or sparrow and threaten to kill the same so to provoke they to redeem the life thereof at some high price and likewise if a malefactor be condemn to death they will purchase his life of the magistrate and sell he for a slave the moor will sometime make semblance as if they will kill themselves that these foolish guzzarate may see they in like sort they will go out of the path if they light on a anthill lest they may happy tread on some of they they sup by daylight lest their candlelight shall occasion the death of some gnat or fly and when they must needs use a candle they keep it in a lantern for that cause if louse do much annoy they they call to they certain religious and holy man after their account and these obseruant f f the like lousy trick be report in the legend of s. Francis and in the life of Ignatius of one of the first jesuitical pillar by Maffaeus will take upon they all those louse which the other can find and put they on their head there to nourish they but yet for all this lousy scruple they stick not at cousinage by false weight measure and coin nor at usury and lie some be say g g n. di cont. to be zealous in their idol-service as to sacrifice their life in their honour by a divine cut off their head the priest meanwhile mutter his damn holiness for which they be account saint chap. 8 of the indian nation betwixt Cambaia and malabar and their religion the mighty river of Indus and Ganges pay their fine to the Ledi^ of water the ocean almost under the very tropic of cancer do as it be betwixt their watery arm present into that their mother bosom this large Chersonesiu a country full of kingdom riches people and our du task superstitious custom as Italy be divide by the apennine so be this by the hill which they call gate quite thorough to the cape which not only have enter league with many in-lets of the sea to divide the soil into many signory and kingdom but with the air and nature high officer to dispense with the ordinary order and establish statute of nature a a gi. bot. ben. maff. lib. 1. Linsch i 1 c.34 at the same time under the same elevation of the sun divide to summer and winter their season and possession for whereas cold be banish out of these country except on the top of some hill and altogether prohibit to approach so near the court and presence of the sun and therefore their winter and summer be not reckon by heat and cold but by the fairness and foulensse of weather which in those part divide the year by equal proportion at the same time when on the west-part of this Peninsula between that rig of mountain and the sea it be after their appellation summer which be from September till April in which time it be always clear sky without once or very little rain on the other side the hill which they call the coast of Choromandell it be their winter every day and night yield abundance of reins beside those terrible thunder which both begin and end their winter and from April till September in a contrary vicissitude on the western part be winter and on the eastern summer in so much that in little more than twenty league journey in some place as where they cross the hill to saint Thoma^ on the one side of the hill you ascend with a fair summer on the other you descend attend with a stormy winter the like say Linschoten happen at the cape Rosalgate in Arabia and in many other place of the east their winter also be more fierce than we every man provide against the same as if he have a voyage of so many month to pass by sea their ship be bring into harbour their house can scarce harbour the inhabitant against the violent storm which choke the river with Sands and make the sea unnavigable I leave the cause of these thing to the further scan of philosopher the effect and affect thereof be strange the sea roar with a dreadful noise the wind blow with a certain course from thence the people have a melancholic season which they pass away with play in the summer the wind blow from the land begin at midnight and continue till noon never blow above ten league into the sea and present after one of the clock until midnight the contrary wind blow keep their set-time whereby they make the land temperate the heat otherwise will be unmeasurable but this change common cause disease flux fever vomiting in dangerous and to very many in deadly manner as appear at Goa where in the king hospital which be only for white man there die five hundred in a year here you may see both the north and south star and little difference or none be find in the length of day and night throughout the year de be the next kingdom to Cambaia now not the next but the same the mountain which before divide it not prohibit the mogor force to annex it to his crown of it be speak before in the chapter of Cambaya as also of Decan which lie along the coast betwixt the river bate and Aliga two hundred and fifty mile here b b gio-r^t ben. Garcias ^ 2.c.28 Linschot etc. be as be say sometime a Moor king who lead a voluptuous and idle life by his captain be dispossess of his state the one of these be call Idalcan who seat royal be Visapore who in the year 1572. encamp before Goa which the portugal have take from he with a army of seventy thousand foot and five and thirty thousand horse two thousand elephant and two hundred and fifty piece of artillery the other be Nizzamalucco which reside in Danaget and besiege Chau with not much less force against a captain of the venazary which be a people that live on spoil as the in Cambaia the Belemi in del Canara or Concam seem to have be a part of Decan but be possess by the king of Narsinga who state be on the east side of the mountain it have in it the coast-towne of onor Batticalla Mayander and mangalor c c Linscho lib.1.cap.27 famous for traffic but eclipse by the portugal neighbourhood in these part sometime reign a Bengalan prince which divide his state among his captain which original for the most part be slave that he may ease himself of the care of government and as he impart to they great place so do he likewise honourable name d d cap.7 call one Idalcam which signify the king of justice another Nisamalucco that be the spear of the kingdom another Cotamalucco the strength of the kingdom another Imademalucco the pillar of the kingdom another melique Verido the keeper of the kingdom etc. but he that shall have be the keeper of the kingdom be make the keeper of the king who these his slave and officer by joint conspiracy have take prisoner at bider his ch^fe town the country of Decan fall to those two which be before name and the rest to the rest Goa e e of Goa read Arthus histor. Ind.c. 25. and Linschot be the seat of the viceroy and of the archbishop and of the king counsel for the indies and the staple of all indian commodity it stand in a little island call Tizz^arin nine mile long and three broad bard on the north and Salzette be both in like subjection to the portugal the king let they to farm and employ the rent to the payment of the archbishop cloister priest viceroy and other his officer there dwell in this town of all nation and religion the government be as in Portugal only public use of foreign religion be forbid they but in their house private or on the main land they may practice the same the portugall many of they be marry with indian woman and their posterity be call mestic^s and in the three degree differ nothing in colour and fashion from natural indian of the portugall they reckon two sort marry man and soldier which be a general name to all bachelor although they be at their own command of these be many knight and be call Canalhiero Pidalgo for if a man do any thing worth reckon present his captain impart this honour to he whereof they much boast themselves albeit that this knighthood have descend to cook boy many of the portugall live only by their slave they use great ceremony or pride which you will call it in their behaviour the particular whereof let Linschoten f f Linschot lib. 1 cap.28 29. 30. 31. 32. that there live amongst they teach you beside both abassine and armenian christian jew and moor here be many heathen the moor eat all thing but swine flesh and die be bury like the jew the heathen as de^anijns guzarate and canarijn be burn to ash and some woman alive be bury with the gentleman or Bramenes their husband some will eat nothing that have life some all but the flesh of cow or buffle most of they pray to the sun and moon yet all acknowledge a GOD that make all thing and rule they after this life render to all accord to their work but they have pagode which be image cut and frame most ugly and like monstrous devil to who they pray and offer and to saint which here have live holy and be now intercessor for they the devil often answer they out of those image to who also they offer that he shall not hurt they they present their pagode when a marriage be to be solemnize with the bride maidenhead two of her near kinswoman force she upon the ivory pin leave the blood there for monument of that devilish idol the husband herein applaud his happiness they have for the most part a custom to pray unto the first thing they meet withal in the morning and all that day after they pray unto it be it hog or any other thing but if they first meet with a crow whereof there be great store they will not for any thing stir out again that day after so unlucky a sign they pray likewise to the new moon salute her first appearance on their knee they have jogos or hermit repute very holy many juggler also and witch which show devilish tricke^ they never go forth without pray every hill cliff hole or den have his pagode in it with their furnace hard by they and their cistern always full of water with which every one that pass by wash his foot and then worship and offer Rice egg or what else their devotion will afford which the Bramen^ eat when they be to go to sea they will feast their pagode with trumpet fire and hang fourteen day before they set forth to obtain a good voyage and as long after their return which they use to do in all their feast marriage childbirth and their harvest and seed-season chap. 9 of the indian Bramenes the indian heathen have a custom that no man may change his father trade but must succeed in the same and marry a wife also of the same tribe the Brachmanui or as they be at this day call the Bramenes who have their shop as well as other merchant throughout the city be of best reputation and wear in sign of their profession from the shoulder cross under the arm upon their naked body down to the girdle three string like seal thread which for their life they will not nor may by their vow put off they be naked save that about their middle they have a cloth bind to hide their privity and sometime when they go abroad they cast a thin gown over they upon their head they wear a white cloth wound twice or thrice about therewith to hide their hair which they never cut off but wear it long and turn up as the woman do they have common hang at their ear goldrings they be very subtle in writing and account make other simple indian believe what they will whatsoever they meet first with in the street they pray to all day after when the Bramenes die a a ceremony at the death of a Bramene all their friend assemble together and make a hole in the ground in which they throw much sweet wood spice rice corn and oil then lay they therein the dead body his wife follow with music and many of her near friend sing praise in commendation of her husband life encourage she to follow he which accord she do for part her jewel among her friend with a cheerful countenance she leap into the fire and be present cover with wood and oil whereby she be quick dead and with her husband body burn to ash and if it chance which be seldom that any woman resu^eth this fiery conjunction they cut the hair clean off from her head neither may she after that wear jewel but be account a dishonest woman this custom be as may appear very ancient and suppose to have be ordain because of the libidinous disposition of the indian woman which for their lust will often poison their husband the Bramenes observe fasting-dai with so great abstinence that they eat nothing that day and sometime not in three or four day together they tell many miracle of their pagode they hold the immortality of the soul both of beast and man and that so often mention Pythagorean succession and renew of man soul in beast and contrariwise they by the direction of the devil the author of their miracle frame such deform statue to their idol the indian woman in Goa when they go forth have but one cloth about their body which cover their head and hang down to the knee otherwise naked they have ring through their nose about their leg toe neck and arm and seven or eight bracelet upon their hand accord to their ability of glass or other mettle when the woman be seven year old and the man nine they marry but come not together till the woman be able to bear child master fitch mention b b r. fitch the solemnity of these marriage and the cause to be the burn of the mother when the father be dead that they may have a father-in-law to bring they up to leave Goa with this island the Canaras and Decanijns wear their beard and hair long without cut as the Bramenes they except from food cow hog and buffle they account the ox cow or buffle to be holy which they have common in the house with they and they besmear stroke and handle they with all friendship in the world feed they with the same meat they eat themselves and when the beast ease themselves they hold under their hand and throw the dung away they sleep with they in their house hereby think to do GOD service in other thing they be as the Bramenes for those be the Laity these be the spiritualty when they take their oath they be set within a circle of ash on the pavement and lay a few ash on their head the other on their breast swear by their pagode to tell the truth the canarij^s and the corumbijn be the rustic and countrey-husbandman the most miserable people of all India their religion be much as the other they cover only their privity and eat all thing except cow ox buffle hog and hen flesh their woman bind a cloth about their navel which reach halfway the thigh they be deliver alone by themselves without other help their child be bring up naked till they be seven or eight year old without any trouble about they except wash they in a little cold water and live to be a hundred year old without headache or loss of tooth they nourish a tough of hair on their crown cut the rest when the man be dead the wife break her glasse-iewel and cut off her hair his body be burn they eat so little as if they live by the air and for a penny will endure whip in Salsette be two temple or hole rather of pagode renown in all India one of which be cut from under a hill of hard stone and be of compass within about the bigness of a village of four hundred house with many gallery or chamber of these deform shape one high than another cut out of the hard rock there be in all three hundred of these gallery the other be in another place of like matter and form it will make a man hair stand upright to enter amongst they in a little island call pory there stand a high hill on the top whereof be a hole that go down into the hill dig and carve out of the hard rock within as large as a great cloister round beset with shape of elephant tiger amazon and other like workmanly cut suppose to be the Chinois handiwork but the portugall have now overthrow these idoll-temple will GOD they have not set new idol in the room with like practice of offering and pilgrimage as do these to their pagode I once c c Linschoten go into a temple of stone in a village and find nothing in it but a great table that hang in the middle of the church with the image of a pagode thereon paint hellish disfigure with many horn long tooth out of the mouth down to the knee and beneath his navel with such another tusked and horn face upon the head stand a triple crown not much unlike the pope it hang before a wall which make a partition from another chamber like a quire close without any light in the middle whereof be a little door and on each side of it a furnace within the wall with certain hole thereby to let the smoke or savour of the fire to enter into that place when any offering shall be make whereof we find there some Rice corn fruit hen and such like there issue thence such a filthy smoke and stink that it make the place black and almost choke such as enter we desire the Bramene to open the door which with much entreaty he do offer first to throw ash on our forehead which we refuse so that before he will open we the door we be force to promise he not to enter beyond the door it show within like a lime-kill be close vault without hole of window neither have the church itself any light but the door within the say cell hang a hundred burn lamp and in the middle stand a little altar cover with cotton cloth and over that with gold under which as the Bramene tell we sit the pagode all of gold of the bigness of a puppet hard by the church without the great door stand within the earth a great foursquare cistern hew out of free stone with stair on each side to go down into it full of green filthy and stink water wherein they wash themselves when they mean to enter into the church to pray in the evening they carry their pagode on procession first ring a bell wherewith the people assemble and take the pagode out of his cell with great reverence and set it in a Palamkin which be bear by the chief man of the town the rest follow with great devotion with their usual noise and sound of trumpet and other instrument and have carry he a pretty circuit bring he to the stone-cisterne wash he and place he again in his cell make a foul smoke and stink and every man leave his offering behind he intend to the pagode but consume by the Bramene and his family as we go along by the way we find many such shape under certain coverture with a small cistern of water hard by and half a indian nut hang thereby to take up water withal for the traveller to wash and pray by the say pagode do stand common a calf of stone and two little furnace before which they present their offering my fellow leap on one of those calf in the church the Bramene call out and the people come run but we stay their fury by gentle persuasion of the Bramene before and thus much of these deform form and misshape shape with their worship and worshipper suitable like lip like lettuce vain rite stink sink and smoke ugly idol conspire with internal darkness of the mind and external darkness of their temple to bring a eternal darkness to the follower be then call Abduti as the illuminate elder of the familist pollute themselves in all filthiness the Bramenes f f od. Barbosa have image of the trinity and have in religious estimation the number of three they acknowledge and pray to the trinity in unity but affirm many demigod which be his deputy in govern the world they honour the portugall image also as approach to their own superstition they marry but one wife and admit no second succeed marriage the Bramenes must descend of the Bramene tribe and other can aspire to that priesthood but some be of high account than other for some serve for messenger which in time of war and among thief may pass safe and be call father they will not put a Bramene to death for any crime when they be seven year old g g od. Barbosa they put about their neck a string two finger broad make of the skin of a beast call Cressuamengan like a wild asle together with the hair which he wear till he be four year old all which time he may not eat h h Betelle a leaf Betelle that time expire the say string be take away and another of three thread put on in sign that he be become a bramen which he wear all his life they have a principal amongst they which be their bishop which correct they if they do amiss they marry but once as be say and that not all but only the elder of the brother to continu^ the succession who be also heir of the father substance and keep his wife strait kill she if he find she adulterous with poison the young brother lie with other man wife which account the same as a singular honour do unto they they have great revenue belong to their church beside offering and at set hour of the day resort thither to sing and do other their holy rite twice in the day and as often in the night their pagode be take out of the altar and set on the Bramenes head look backward and be carry in procession three time about the church the Bramenes wife carry light burn every time they come to the principal door of the church which be on the west side thereof some church have two door beside they set it down on their offering-stone and worship it twice a day they bring it to eat of their sod rice as often it seem as the Bramene be hungry when they wash they which be often they lie a little ash on their head forehead and breast say that they shall return into ash when the Bramenes wife be with child as soon as he know it he cleanse his tooth and abstain from Betelle and observe fast till she be deliver the king of malabar will scarce eat meat but of their dress i i Sumario di pop orient they be of imperial title unto his nephew of Calicut who only enjoy the title of or emperor and have prerogative of stamp come some exempt from this empire and allegiance both Coulam the papal sea of the high Bramene and Cananor and some have since by their own force exempt themselves this perimal die in his holy voyage and the indian of malabar reckon from this division their computation of year as we do from the bless nativity of our lord he leave say Castaneda to himself but twelve league of his country which lie near to the shore where he mean to embark himself never before inhabit this he give to he command not to coin money but only the king of Calacut for Calcutta be therefore here build and the moor for the embark take such devotion to the place that they will no more frequent the port of Coulan as before which therefore grow to ruin but make Calicut the staple of their merchandise Calicut the first in order with they shall be so with we the city be not wall nor fair build the ground the palace with great music and other jollity ^ Ba^bosa reckon eighteen sect that have no mutual conversation nor may marry but in their own rank or order next to the king and Bramenes he place the Nayros which be gentleman and soldier and be not profess Nairos notwithstanding their-bloud till they be by their lord or by the king make knight or soldier and then he must never from that time go without his weapon which common be a rapier and a target and sometime piece or bow they never marry but lie with such of the Nairos woman or daughter as like they leat^^ng his weapon meanwhile at the door which forbid any man else although it be the goodman himself to enter till he have end his business and be go and if one of the common people once touch a Nairo it be lawful for the Nairo to kill he and he be also unclean and must be purify by certain washing and for this cause they cry as they go in the street Po Po that the base raskallity may give place they have a pit of stand water at their door hallow by the Bramenes wherein every morning they wash themselves although it be green and stink imagine thus to be cleanse of their sin they be bring up altogether to foate of arm and actituitie from their childhood admirable able to wind and turn themselves and be very resolute and desperate bind themselves by oath to live and die with their king or lord. no Nairo's woman may enter into Calicut but one night in the year when the city be full of light and they go with the Nairos to behold and gaze their fill they intend nothing but their lust and think that if they die virgin they shall never enter into paradise the Biabari be another sort and be merchant gentile and enjoy great privilege the king can put they to death but by sentence of the principal of themselves they be the only merchant before the moor trade there and still enjoy many possession these marry one wife and their child inherit and they may touch the Nairo's the be a sect of the Nairo's have a law and idol by themselves which they may never alter they make tile to cover the temple and the king palace the Nairo's may lie with their woman but must wash themselves before they go home another sect be call mananta^^ar which be launderer nor may they or their posterity be of other function nor may they mingle themselves with any other generation they have idol-ceremony and temple by themselves the Nairos may use their wife or woman rather their brother or nephew be their heir the calien be weaver and have a distinct idolatrous sect otherwise be as the former beside these of better condition there be of base sort eleven sect which may not marry nor meddle with other the first of these be call Tiberi husbandman the second Moger and be mariner both have their proper superstition and use their woman in common the three be astrologer who they call Caniun great man ask their counsel but may not touch their person the Aggeri be mason and worker in metal the Muchoa or Mechoe be fisher dwell in village by themselves the man thief the woman harlot with who they please the Betua be salt-maker the paerun be juggler enchanter and physician if such damnable devilish practice may deserve so honourable name which when any be sick and require their help use conjuration to cause the devil to enter into some of they and then by his suggestion declare the event of the disease and what sacrifice or other thing be to be perform they may not touch or be touch of other man the revolet be a base sort of gentile which carry wood into the city to sell and herb the pule be as excommunicate person and live in desert place where the Nairos have no occasion to pass and when they go near any these Nairos or any of the better sort they cry as loud as they can as i i l^u gate with guard of soldier here he observe their rite in burn the woman so often mention the woman d d the solemnity of burn of the wife after her husband death take two or three month respite after her husband death the day be come she go early out of her house mount on a horse or elephant or else on a stage carry by eight man apparel like to a bride adorn with jewel and her hair about her shoulder hold in her left hand a lookingglass in the right a arrow and sing as she pass through the city say that she go to sleep with her husband shee be accompany with her friend until it be one or two of the clock in the afternoon then they go out of the city pass by the river side to the burning-place where be prepare a great square cave full of wood here be make a great banquet the woman eat with joy as if it be her wedding-day and after they sing and dance till the woman bid to kindle the fire in the cave then she leave the feast and take her husband near kinsman by the hand and go with he to the bank of the river where she strip she of her clothes and jewel bestow they at her pleasure and cover herself with a cloth throw herself into the river say oh wretch wash away your sin come out of the water she roll herself into a yellow cloth and again take her husband kinsman by the hand go to the say cave by which be erect a little pinnacle on which she mount and there recommend her child and kindred to the people after this another woman take a pot with oil and sprinkle it over her head and therewith annoynt all her body and then throw it into the furnace the woman go together with the same present after the woman the people throw great piece of wood into the cave so that with those blow and the fire she be quick dead and their great mirth be on a sudden turn into great lamentation and howl when a great man die both his wife and slave with who he have have carnal copulation burn themselves together with he among the base sort I have see say master Fredrick the dead man carry to the place of burial and there set upright the wife immure with her dead husband the woman come before he on her knee cast her arm about his neck while a mason make a wall round about they and when the wall be as high as their neck one come behind the woman strangle she the workman present finish the wall over they and this be their burial Vertomannus f f lud. vert. li.6 relate the same Odoricus m m Odoricus tell of a strange and uncouth idol as big as saint Christopher or pure gold with a new band about the neck full of precious stone some one whereof be of value if he value just more than a whole kingdom the roof pavement and seel of the wall within and without the temple be all gold the indian go thither on pilgrimage some with halter about their neck some with their hand bind behind they some with knife stick on their arm and leg and if after their pilgrimage the wound flesh sefter they esteem that limb holy and a sign of their god favour near to the temple be a lake whereinto he pilgrim cast gold silver and gem for honour of the idol and reparation of his temple at every yearly feast the king and queen with the pilgrim and people assemble place the say idol in a rich chariot and with a solemn procession of virgin two and two in a rank sing before he and with musical instrument carry he forth many pilgrim put themselves under the charriot-wheel where they be crush in piece more than five hundred person use thus to do who carcase be burn and ash keep for holy relic otherwise also they will themselves to such a martyrdom in this manner the parent and friend assemble and make a feast to this votary and after that hang five sharp knife about his neck and so carry he before the idol where he take one of his knife and cry for the worship of my god I cut this my flesh and cut a piece cast it at the face of the idol and so proceed at the last say now do I yield myself to death in the behalf of my god and be dead be burn as before our countryman n n s. John man ^^^ sir John Mandevile report the same history of their idol procession and the ash of those voluntary martyr which they keep to defend they against tempest and misfortune he also say that some pilgrim in all their peregrination not once lift up their eyelid some at every three or four pace fall down on their knee to worship some whip other wound themselves yea and kill themselves as be before say Nicholas conti o o Nic^ conti. report the same in his time neither be this bloody custom yet lest as Linscboten p p Linschat libr. 1.c2.44 affirm by report of one of his chamber-fellow that have see it they have say he a waggon or cart so heavy that three or four elephant can hardly draw it which be bring forth at fair feast and procession at this cart hang many cable or rope whereat all the people hale and pull of devotion in the upper part of the cart stand a tabernacle and therein the idol under it sit the king wife play on instrument and while the procession pass some cut piece of their flesh and throw at the pagode some lay themselves under the wheel of the cart with such event as you have hear balby relate the same and add that the priest which have care of this idol and certain woman be conscrate to these devotion from their cradle by their zeale-blinde parent q q balhy ca. 28. and Arthus dan. hist. ind. o^. c.1 and the woman prostitute their body to gain for the idol whatsoever they can get over and above their own maintenance this fill the city with strumpet there be of this sacred you may interpret it curse crew four hundred in one place of the city these have their place in the idol-procession some of they in the chariot which be draw by man every one account himself happy that can touch or draw the same this he say be at Negapaton he further affirm that not far from the city of saint Thomas be the town Casta where the wife be not burn as at Negapatan but a great grave be make for the decease husband they place the live wife by the dead corpse and their near kindred cast earth upon they both and stamp thereon they which marry wed in their own degree as a smith to smith daughter and they pour out their prayer at the image of some cow or a serpent call Bittia their ^burne cowes-doung and if they intend any war with other nation they anoint their nose and forehead with those ash not wash themselves till the evening they which have sacrifice themselves to the pagode when they have wal^^^ arrow and diverse mangle themselves at last cut their own throat so sacrifice themselves to the pagode there be also certain people call Amouchi otherwise Chiavi which perceive the end of their life to r r ociperate die approach lay hold on their weapon which they call chisse and go forth kill every man they meet with till some body by kill they make a end of their kill they be loath it seem to come into the devil presence empty-handed or to go to hell alone some of they worship GOD in the likeness of a man some in the image of cow and scrpent some invoke the sun and moon other some tree or river among many feast which they celebrate in the year one in autumn be most solemn in which they take some great tree and fasten it in the ground have first fashion it like a mast of a ship with a crosse-yard whereon they hang two hook of iron and when any one by sickness or other misery have make a vow to their idol or pagode he come thither and be first admonish by the priest to offer his sacrifice they lift he with those hook by both the shoulder and there hold he to the idol till he have 3 time salute the same with clap his fold hand to his breast and have make some sport thereto with weapon which he have in his hand after this he be let down and the blood which issue from his shoulder be sprinkle on the tree in testimony of his devotion then they draw he up again by the middle to give thanks to the idol and then give he leave to heal himself if he can they which be in great misery or seek some great matter at the hand of their idol do this they have a other feast celebrate in the night continue eight night in which many candle be see burn through the city three or four run from one end of the street to the other and hurl rice and other meat after they say they offer it to the devil which follow they not dare to look behind lest he shall slay they in other place also they have those idoll-chariot like unto tower to the draw whereof many thousand of devout person put their helping-hand Francis s s f. Fernandes epist. 1598. Fernandes say that Cidambaran be the mother-city of their pagan-rite wherein be many stately temple and the revenue of the Bramenes amount to thirty thousand ducat but now they be pay but twelve thousand yearly here happen a strange accident the same day the jesuite depart which be this there be in this city a temple of Perimal wherein they worship a ape call Hanimant who they report to have be a GOD and for I know not what together with many thousand of other god to have remain there be all transform into ape now when this principal ape be force to pass into the island Zeilan and want a ship he leap and at every leap leave a island or heap of land behind he so make way for his apish train to Zeilan the tooth of this ape be keep for a great relic in that island with great resort of pilgrim thereunto and in the year t t Linschot c. 44. 1554. be by the portugall who make a road thither in hope of great booty take away the indian prince offer the viceroy three hundred thousand or as Linschoten tell seven hundred thousand ducat for the ransom of this ape tooth but the archbishop dissuade the viceroy who thereupon burn the same before those indian ambassador and throw the ash into the sea. not long after a Benian^ of Cambaia persuade the indian that he by divine power have take away that holy tooth be invisible present and have leave another in the room which be burn superstition be credulous and the king of Bisnagar give he a great sum of gold for that ape tooth wherewith he thus apish have bite and mock they which be after hold in like veneration as the former but to return to our cidambaran history they u u f. fernand. tell that a holy man in great penance have many year hold his foot pierce through with a piece of iron and when he be often by GOD command to leave that selfe-rigour he flat refuse unless that he may see GOD dance about he which also he condescend unto and with the sun moon and star which play the musician he appear dance and as he dance a chain of gold fall from his foot whereof this town take name for Cidambaran signify a golden chain now at this time * * 1598. there be a great contention whether the sign of Perimal shall be erect in the temple of Cidambacham this sign be a gild mast with a ape at the foot thereof many ambassador be there about this quarrel someurge some resist this deed but the prince call the Naicho of Gingi will have it set up not withstand the priest great unwillingness the priest therefore both regular which be the jogue and secular Bramenes ascend up the roof of the church and thence threaten to hurl down themselves which twenty of the jogue do and the rest threaten to follow but the Naicho cause gun to be discharge at they which slay two and cause the rest to retire and break their covenant rather than their neck with their fellow a woman also of this faction cut she own throat for zeal of this new superstition the swell style of this king of Bisnagar I think worthy to be here insert which be this 10 10 the title of the king of Bisnagar the husband of good fortune the god of great province king of the great king and God of king the lord of horseman the master of they which can not distribute the water of Ganges out of certain vessel cover with soul and filthy clothes which yet the people for devotion kiss these jogue with admirable patience endure the sun heat and one among the rest enclose himself in a iron cage with his head and foot only out of the cage that he can neither sit nor lie down at any time and on the cage be hang a hundred lamp which four other jogue his companion light at certain time and thus walk he in this his perpetual prison as a light unto the world in his vainglorious opinion they reason with certain Bramenes some of which hold the sun for God and yet sometime to have be a man and for his merit so promote some deny a multitude of god only allow that privilege to Pyrama Vidhun and vnitir one of which make a other keep the three destroy all mention some a elephant be weary haste home his keeper after much entreaty not prevail tell he it be for the king of Portugall service which he will have he do the beast answer ho ho which in the malabar language signify I will I will as acosta interprete fulfil his request the same elephant want his meat his master say it be because his kettle wherein he use to boil it be break and therefore will he to carry it to the tinker which he do and bring it again but ill-mended whereupon he be send again and the tinker to try he amend it worse the elephant carry it to the river which run by to see if it will hold water and find it to run come back with great noise and anger the tinker entreat pardon and at the three time do it well which yet the elephant will not believe till by trial he see it hold water and then show it to the stander by that it will hold carry it home a soldier hurl a coco-shell at a elephant which because he can not then repay it put the shell in his mouth and a few day after see he in the street at cochin he hurl the same out of his mouth at the soldier again another soldier injure the keeper of a elephant which will have revenge the wrong but be forbid by his say keeper but after espy the soldier when his keeper be absent he take he up in his trunk and duck he diverse time in the water and then set he down where he have take he up they be very ambitious one be upbraid of lazine by his keeper when as his burden be too heavy for he to draw and therefore they have bring another elephant to help he disdain a companion thrust he away and draw himself dead in the place another in like case fall on his foreleg and weep at his keeper chide and although he admit a companion till the great difficulty be overcome yet feel it then in his own power to draw he put away the other elephant with his head and tooth to recover his credit of the admirable capacity gratitude and other quality of this beast be tedious to recite a ample testimony this sort be the indian figtree if it may may be call a tree which be not above a man height and within like to a reed without any woody substance it have leave a fathom long and three span broad which open and spread abroad on the top of it it yield the fruit in fashion of the cluster of grape and bear but one bunch at once contain some two hundred fig at least which be ripe they cut the whole tree down to the ground leave only the root out of which present grow another and within a month after bear fruit and so continue all the year long they be the great sustenance of the country and be of very good taste and smell and in those part man believe that Adam first transgress with this fruit but of great admiration be the o o of this beside Linschoten see Garcias Hort^ with clusius note lib. 7.c.26 coquo-tree be the most profitable tree in the world of which in the land of they make and furnish whole ship so that save the man themselves there be nothing of the ship or in the ship neither tackle merchandise or aught else but what this tree yield the tree grow high and slender the wood be of a spongy substance easy to be sow when they make vessel thereof with cord make of Cocus for this nut which be as big as a ostrich egg have two sort of husk as our walnut whereof the uppermost be hairy like hemp whereof they make Occam and cordage of the other shell they make drinking-cuppe the fruit when it be almost ripe be full of water within which by degree change into a white hard substance as it ripen the liquor be very sweet but with the ripen grow sour the liquor extract out of the tree be medicinable and if it stand one hour in the sun it be very good vinegar which be distil yield excellent aquavitae and wine of it also they make by set it in the sun sugar of the meat of the nut dry they make oil of the pith or heart of the tree be make paper for book and evidence of the leaf they make cover for their house mat tent etc. their apparel their fire and the rest of the commodity which this tree more plentiful in the indies than willow in the low-countries yield will be too tedious to recite they will keep the tree from bear fruit cut away the blossom and then will hang some vessel thereat which receive from thence that liquor of which you have hear it be the canarijn live and they will climb up these tree which yet have no bough but on the top like they can endure much hardship a infant new bear in the cold of winter be present carry to the river to be wash their education be hard yet be they neat they use fork as the Chinois or stick not touch the meat with their finger and therefore need no naperie they sit on carpet and enter the room unshod their table be a hand high some eighteen inch square curious wrought to each guest one and change at every new service or change of meat Quabacondonus against a solemn and festival entertainment of his father prepare a hundred and thirty thousand of these tablet their house be most of wood because of often earthquake and some of stone temple and monastery they have for both sex and more have till Nubunanga destroy they their language be one and yet exceed diversify according as they differ in state or sex or as they speak in praise or dispraise use a diverse idiom they use character in writing and print as in China their sword be of a most excellent temper their custom differ in many thing from other man e e custom in thing indifferent be comely or uncomely black be a festival colour white a funeral their meat drink perfume be as dissonant to we their tooth be colour with black as beauty livery borrow of art which we by art will avoid they mount on the right side of the horse they sit as we rise to entertain a friend they give to the sick person salt thing sharp and raw never let blood we contrary as in other rite either to other ridiculous all their noble be call Toni amongst who be diverse degree all of they hold their all in to find so many soldier to the war at their own cost geneneral the whole nation be witty poverty be a disgrace to no man reproach theft perjury diceplay be hateful very ambitious they be in all thing respective to their credit full of courtesy each to other never brawl no not at home with their houshould the inconstancy of that state learn they by use to prepare for and to welcome every state. they be exceed subtle hypopocriticall and double-dealing they be also of cruel disposition not to their enemy alone but sometime will assay the goodness of their blade and strength of their arm on some innocent body and in case of distress they esteem it a credit to prevent the sentence of law by bloody execution do on themselves which they usual do in rip up their breast a cross a servant or friend attend to smite off his head and if it be a man of any sort his friend and follower in like manner with their own hand pluck out their bowel to testify their love the governor have absolute rule over their inferior yea in every private family the authority extend to life or death all ^apon sometime obey one prince call or Dairi who at length addict himself to his private delight and put off the burden of rule to his officer grow in Frois a few year since the first which in these many late age take the title of a king which together with the crown he receive of the king of China ordain before his death that his body shall not be burn after the wont manner but close in a chest and in a sumptuous temple for that purpose build k k al. his image shall be enshrine and worship with the title of Scinfaciman or new Faciman the name of their Mars or warlike God which be also do thus he which in his youth have use to cut wood and carry it into the market to sell for his daily fustenance for his valour promote in military honour at last become the great monarch that japon have see in eight hundred year and not content with human greatness will aspire to that divine whereof he himself have be a derider in other his name before be Faxiba call after Quabacondonus the high title next to the Dairi and signify the chief of the treasure next borrow a kingly style from China will mad folly on his deathbed bequeath godhead to a man and immortality to a carcase when he can no long hold out his pride cruelty and other wicked course which make his presence dreadful his memory detestable Nabumanga be his predecessor in his state and impiety arrogate divine honour to himself l l l. black hat and so wander from place to place give notice of their come by a little bell. another sect call Genguis dwell on some high hill black of complexion and as be suppose horn marry wife of their
