Galuano black people call Ospapuas man-eater and sorcerer among who devil walk familiar as companion if these wicked spirit find one alone they kill he and therefore they always use company their idol they adorn with ostrich feather they use to let themselves blood with a certain herb lay to the member and lick with the tongue with which they can draw out all the blood in their body when as Magellan first of all man by the west discover these eastern land in the land of Buthoan and Caleghan he can learn no other religion observe amongst they but that lift up their hand close together and their face towards heaven they call on their god by the name of Abha in Zubut in token of friendship he and the king do let themselves blood on the right arm for so be their wont to confirm league of amity the king have his skin paint with a hot iron pensile he and his people at magellan persuasion be baptize and burn their idol which be make of hollow wood with great face and four tooth like borestuske in their mouth paint they be all over but have only a forepart and nothing behind they wear in their yard a nail of gold they have many wife but one principal they observe many ceremony in kill a hog in sacrifice as it seem to the sun after the sound of their cimball and certain cates set down in platter two old woman come forth with trumpet or pipe of reed and do reverence to the sun and then clothe themselves with sacred vestment one of they put about her forehead a hairlace with two horn hold another hairlace or scarce in her hand and so begin to sound dance and call upon the sun wherein she be follow by the other both of they in this manner dance about th^ Hogge which be there fast tie l l a. Pigasetta ^^^ the horn beldame still mutter certain word to the sun and the other answer she then do she take a cup of wine and after some ceremony pour it on the hog and after that with a lance after dance and flourish she kill the hog all this while a little torch be burn which at last she take into her mouth and bit it and the other woman wash the pipe with the swine blood and with her finger imbrue with blood mark the forehead of her husband first and then of the rest then do they untire themselves and only with woman associate ^ate the cheer in the platter and after sing the hog and eat he from hence Magellan go to Mathan where in a battle with the islander he be slay in Puladan they keep cock for the game but eat not of their flesh forbid by their superstition in Ciumbubon they find a tree which have leaf like those of the mulberry have beside on each side of the leaf as it be two foot with which as if it have be move and sensible it will stir and go up and down Pigafetta keep one eight day in a platter and when he rouch it present it will ^lee from he and move up and down he think it live of the air in Burneo the people be partly moores and partly gentile and accord to their religion have two king and two royal city situate in salt-water the moor when they kill a hen or a goat use first certain word to the sun the gentile m m mas. Transil worship the sun and moon esteem the one male and the other female he the father this the mother of the star who also they reckon in the catalogue of their demigod they salute the sun in his morning-approch with certain verse and adoration which they also perform to the moon and demand of they child riches and other their necessary after death they expect no future state the spaniard hear of great pearl as big as egg which the king of Burneo have and if you believe they they take a oyster themselves who fishie substance weigh seven and forty pound the mooreking in Burneo be serve in his palace and attend only by woman and maiden in Gilolo n n Pigafetta they be likewise some of the arabian sect the other gentile the moor have two king of their law each of which have six hundred child the gentile use to worship the first thing they encounter in the morning all the day follow they o o got. pag. 396 be sometime man-eater some of the islander be by the portugall convert but the king be poison by a mahometan they decline yet one noble man name John first kill his wife and child with his own hand leave they shall apostatise and then offer himself to endure any torment the molucco be usual reckon as before be say but many other land be subject to they and by some author call also by that name the king of ternate be say p p sir fr. Drah^ to have seventy land under his subjection and in his port represent great majesty both here and in Banda the mahometan superstition have set foot and prevail as in the other adjoin land the moor be as zealous to win proselyte as to enrich themselves none of these land be above six league in compass enrich with clove but of other first-fruit barren and poor one q q mass. libr. 5. tree they have which out of the cut branch yield a white wholesome and savoury liquor for drink they call it Tuaca and the pith thereof afford they meat call Sagu taste in the mouth like sour curd melt like sugar whereof they make certain cake which will endure good for food ten year the clove-tree not only suck up all the moisture of the earth where they grow disdain any other plant shall grow near they like our incloser sudden drink up all the heaven liberality in shower but with their thirsty appetite intercept the run water that descend from the mountain before they can betake they to their mother lap the ocean refuge in this island r r Galuan^ be man have ankle with spur like to cock here be hog with horn a river store with fish and yet so hot that it flaicth of^ the skin of any creature which enter it there be oyster so large that they christian in the shell crab so strong that with their claw they will break the iron of a pickeaxe stone which grow like fish whereof they make lime in ternate s s jac. ^^^ be a mountain which as it be angry with nature for be fasten to the earth do not only lift up his high head above the airy region of cloud but endeavour also to conjoin itself with the fiery element where with it seem to hold some intercourse with dreadful thunder belch out light flame mix with a dark smoke like proud greatness waste itself with it own flame and fill the neighboring-valley with ash it be not much above a hundred year since first the sect of Mahumet enter the Moluccas but now t t lud. fernand. la. 1599 when the moon be eclipse about eight of the clock at night they every way by cry out by strange gesture pray and beat their bason and drum express a lamentable passion of grief for the fear aforesaid and the eclipse be past when they see that neither the king nor any other be dead they observe the next day solemn festival with public procession of old and young of all sort they esteem it also one bell but without a clapper all come at that peal or sound with their weapon arm the moluccians z z Navig in part ind. orient bry. be better proportion then other indian have more beard which the elder man nourish and wear long for their great authority brown of colour and mean of stature for valour they have not their like in all India especial those of ternate choose rather to die then flee and esteem it a great credit to fight against great multitude their shield be of wood two span broad and four foot long they be exceed addict to sloth and ease none work in any handicraft their house be of timber and reed without one nail in they which their slave build and do also their other labour they have no money and the silver which they have be employ to vessel of plate their riches be their clove wherewith they provide they of other necessity they never see their wife till they be marry nor the wife they Makian and Moher be now subject to the king of ternate Tidore and Batian five dutch mile they say it be inhabit of devil and whosoever must pass by make all possible haste to be go much affright either by selfe-fancy or devilish imposture banta be four and twenty dutch mile from Amboyna^ and divide into three part which comprehend five mile the chief city be Nera in this island be more store of nutmeg then elsewhere in the Moluccas for which cause they resort hither from java China and malacca they profess Mahumetisme so devout that they never go to their watch before they have pray in the whereinto they enter be first wash after the mahumetane manner but pray so loud that they may be hear a great distance their word of prayer be Stofferolla Stofferolla Ascehad a Ascehad a y^lla Ascehad a ill lolla ill lolla mahume die Rosulla at the pronounce of which last word they strike their hand over their face in which gesture they think be much holiness other prayer they mutter over very soft with little move their lip they stand upon mat and lift up their eye twice or thrice to heaven after which they kneel down bow their head twice or thrice to the earth thus they do often every day both at home and in the street they have their public meeting and banquet in their temple very often every one bring his part of the cheer which sometime they do in the wood a hundred in a company at these time they consult of public affair they have civil war and hold together against three other town two little island Pollerviin and Poelvuay take part with and when occasion require come thither with their boat to consultation where they be entertain in public feast the manner whereof be that they sit down in order in stead of a table every one have a piece of a leaf of the bonanas tree then be set before each a piece of Sagu bread after that a dish make of the leaf of another tree with a little sodden rice and flesh-pottage which they hurl by handful into their mouth devour rather then eat the same in the mean while the gentleman arise with their weapon and exercise themselves in martial game with dance the quarrel betwixt these islander grow about the cut of certain tree from whence it be come to cut and kill one another with cruel butchery they exercise sea-fight in their or galeot with great dexterity with great shout and cry the gentleman dance on the hatch very active they be very bloody and barbarous yet bury the head of their enemy with sweet odour if any of their friend die the woman make a shrill and loud cry to call he again which not effect they provide a great feast whereunto all the kindred and friend be invite they bury they almost after our fashion in a white sheet the corpse be carry on man shoulder the man first and woman after follow a censer be there leave fume all the day and night and in the night they keep a light burn in a little house which they have set over the grave in the morning and evening all of all sort come and say their prayer a long while together at the grave and be ask wherefore they say that the dead shall not arise again they have a play with the ball exercise by many of they not as amongst we with the hand but with their foot toss the same up into the air and take it one of another with admirable sleight before we leave these Moluccas and their dependent island we may conclude with a tragedy wherein blind superstition and beastly cruelty be principal actor when Menesius c c art. Arthus Isacius and ^^^ say that their ancestor come from China which country they forsake because of the tyranuie where with they be oppress and in great multitude people this island they wear their hair and their nail long they be dutiful to their superior the great man stir^e not forth without a great troop of follower they be seldom idle much busy about their scabbard and weapon which they use to poison they be not without their weapon night or day which they will not suffer another man to touch they be so eager of revenge that they will press on their adversary weapon draw it through their own body to kill he that have wound they they have mahumetane temple where they do their devotion with great silence they acknowledge JESUS Mahomet David and Moses four prophet they observe their hour and two fast or lent the great man wife never go out of the door to be see their city be Ballambua and Panarucan a little from whence be a burn hill which first break forth 1586 and oppress infinite number of man and cast great stone into the city for three day space make one continue night of darkness Passarua the king whereof marry the king of Ballambuas daughter and the second night after he have lie with she slay she and her attendant because she will not turn mahometan Surrabaia Tuban be also royal city as be daunia Taggal Charabaon and many other but Bantam be of most traffic frequent by portugall dutch and english in which every day be three several market here merchant when they come may buy a woman for their fleshly and worldly business you may add the devil too to make up the number which at their departure they fall again public affair be treat and handle by night at which time the counsellor of state meet and ascend some tree or the roof of the house view the heaven till the moon arise and then go into the senate-house not far from Bantam m m io. Candish Hak. 10 3.pag.822 be mention make of a javan king call Raia Balombam very age which have a hundred wife and his son have fifty their custom be that when the king die they burn the body and preserve the ash five day after the wife of the dead king go to a place appoint and there she which be dear in his favour throw a ball from she and where that ball rest thither they go all and turn their face eastward stab themselves with a Crise or dagger to the heart they be very resolute people and dread no attempt which the king shall enjoin they be it never so dangerous all the race of this king Ballamboam be raze and utter destroy by the Passarvan after a long siege which war be begin in the blood of the king of ballamboams daughter who he slay as be before say and add this drunkenness unto his thirst or q q N^nig Oliver Noort contain about a thousand household the inhabitant be ethnike and have their temple in wood to which they resort to say and do their holy at noon before their deform devill-formed Pagodes in this city dwell the chief pope or highpriest of that superstition who authority be great in all those part he be a hundred and twenty year old and have many wife which nourish he with their milk be not able to take other sustenance a deadly enemy to the christian who the king do yet with some privilege favour chap. 17 of Samatra and Zeilan SAmatra be esteem by some a a gi. bot. ben. mass. l.4 o. Paul k k m. paul. lib. 3 his report think to have comprehend three thousand six hundred mile in circuit since much impair by his over-mightie neighbour the sea which have now leave not above two hundred and fifty mile in length and a hundred and forty of breadth unto it I I Barbosa the indian call it Tenarisim or the delicious land and some be of opinion that this be paradise so just be the judgement of the high that when as man wander from he cause he also to wander from himself and from his habitation yea the place itself have also wander in man wander conceit over the world yea and out of our habitable world altogether as before be show man now seek it as vain as before they lose it it be in fashion m m lib. 1. resemble a egg by a shallow channel separate from the cape the heaven with their dew the air with a pleasant holesomenesse and fragrant freshness the water in their many river and fountain the earth diversify in aspire hill jow^^^ vale equal and indifferent plain fill in her inward chamber with metal and jewel in her outward court and upper face store with whole wood of the best cinnamon that the sun see beside fruit orange leimon etc. surmount those of Spain fowl and beast both tame and wild among which be their elephant n n Linschot an. Corsali honour by a acknowledgement of excellence of all other elephant in the world these all have conspire and join in common league to present unto Zeilan the chief of worldly treasure and pleasure with a long and healthful life in the inhabitant to enjoy they no marvel then if sense and sensuality have here stumble on a paradise there woody hill as a natural amphitheatre do encompass a large plain and one of they as not content his beetle-brow with that only prospect disdain also the fellowship of the neighbour mountain lift o o maff. 1.3 up his steep head seven league in height and have in the top a plain in the midst whereof be a stone of two cubit erect in manner of a table hold in it the print of ^ man foot who they say come from Deli thither to teach they religion the jogue and other devout pilgrim resort thither from place a thousand league distant with great difficulty of passage both hither and here for they be force to mount up this hill by the help of nail and chain fasten thereto nature have prohibit other passage Maffoeus and Boterus can persuade themselves that this foot-steppe be a relic and memory of the aethiopian eunuch other will have it far fetch and father it on Adam the first father of mankind of who the hill also be name Pico de Adam the moor p p od. Barbosa call it Adam Baba and say that from thence Adam ascend into heaven the pilgrim be clad in their pal^ners-weed with iron chain and skin of lion and other wild beast upon their arm and leg they wear button with sharp point that cut the flesh and draw blood which they say they do in God service before they come at the mountain they pass by a fenny valley full of water wherein they wade up to the waste with knife in their hand to scrape from their leg the bloud-leeche which else will end their pilgrimage and life before the time for this dirty and watery passage continue eighteen mile before they come at the hill who proud top will disdain climb if art do not captive nature and bind the hill with chain of iron as be say when they be mount they wash they in a lake or pool of clear spring water near to that foote-stone and make their prayer do thus account themselves clean from all their sin this holy journey be general perform by the islander say Vertomannus once a year he add q q vert. ^^ 3.c.4 that a Moor tell he that his foot-print be two span long and that Adam here a long time bewail his sin and find pardon but Odoricus affirm that they report this mourn to have be for Abel and to have last three hundred year and of the tear of Abel and Eve this purify water to have proceed which Odoricus r r Odoricus prove to be a tale because he see the water spring continual and it run thence into the sea he say that this water have in it many precious stone and the king give leave at certain time of the year to poor man to take they that they may pray for his soul which they can not do but first anoint with lemon because of the horseleech in that water Adam hill be suppose to be seven league in height in Candy s s her. leo. l 1. they be mahometan and have be about these nine hundred year past from the time of Hucba the inhabitant of the city differ much from the mountainer and rude rustics for they be studious especial in matter of their law as in time past they be also in philosophy and the mathematics but these last five hundred year their prince and doctor have prohibit many science as astrology and philosophy accord to the mahometan custom they use much wash and resort to the temple they be very faithful in their promise and exceed jealous they go through the world as merchant and in many place be entertain as reader and master in diverse science and be well esteem in Egypt Ethiopia Arabia Persia India Turkey the young sort yield much reverence to their elder and parent and will not hold discourse of love or sing lovesong in their presence but these citizen be very proud and revengeful the lord esteem more of their beast then of the common-people the the countrypeople in the field and mountain live hardly in labour and want they be beastly thievish ignorant unfaithful their woman before they be marry may live as wanton as they listen yea the father make hateful love to the daughter and the brother be unlovely love to the sister the numidian be traitor homicide thief and for reward will do any thing such also be the libyan without any kind of letter faith or law without heaven or can no long endure the success of this barbarian but mad to see the christian unchristian madness and unwilling to submit his proud wave to the base thraldom of this base Turk swell with indignation conspire with the neighbour element which pretend equal quarrel for so often darken his light and poison his breath with those hellish smoke and for usurp those thunder which have wont to be the airy privilege of his middle region these both agree in their disagree with tempestuous fury to spoil the spoiler the wind from the Acroceraunian hill and the sea on the dalmatian shore so gird in the turk Fez. it seem that nature and art have play the wanton and have bring forth this city the fruit of their dalliance or else they may seem corrival both by all kind office seek to win her love so do the earth seem to dance in little hillock and pretty valley diversify the soil so do the river disperse itself into manifold channel no soon enter the city but it be divide into two arm where with it embrace this lovely nymph and these subdivide as it be into many finger in variety of watercourse insinuate itself unto every street and member thereof and not content thus in public to testify affection find mean of secret intelligence with his love by conduit-pipe close visit every temple college inn hospital the special chamber of his spouse yea and almost every private house from whence till a hour and half within night they teach aswell moral philosophy as the law of Mahomet private man read the sommerlecture only great clerk may read the other which have therefore a large stipend and book and candle be give they the priest of this temple be tie to nothing but his Mumpsimus or service also he take charge of the money and good which be offer in the temple for orphan and dispense the revenue that be leave for the poor every holy day he deal to the poor of the city money and corn accord as their necessity be more or less the treasurer of this church be allow a ducat a day he have under he eight notary each of which have six ducat a month other six clerk gather the rent of house and shop which belong to the church retain the twenty part thereof for their wage moreover there be twenty bailiff of the husbandry that oversee the labourer not far from the city be twenty lyme-kills and as many brick-kills serve for the reparation of the temple and the house thereto principal and most stately college of scholar adorn with Mosaikes and carve work pave with marble and stone of Maiorica in each of they be many chamber in some college be a hundred in some more and in some less they be all build by diverse king of the marin family one be most beautiful found by king Abu Henon it be adorn with a goodly fountain of marble and a stream continual run there be three cloister or gallery of incredible beauty support with eight square pillar of diverse colour the arch adorn with of gold and fine azure the roof be of carve work about the wall be inscription in verse express the year of the foundation and praise of the founder the gate of the college be of brass fair wrought and the door of the chamber carve in the great hall where they say their prayer be a pulpit that have 9 stair to it all of ivory and ebony this college cost the founder 480000. ducat all the other college in Fez hold some resemblance with this and in every of they be reader or professor in diverse science provide for by the founder in old time the student be wont to have their diet and raiment allow for 7. year but now they be allow only their chamber for the b b Bellona enemy to the Mu^ war of Satrid consume their possession so that now there remain but little wherewith they maintain their reader and of they some have 200. ducat some 100 yearly and some less and there abide in the say college only a few stranger maintain by the alm of the citizen when they will read one of the auditor read a text and the reader than read his comment and bring some exposition of his own and explane the difficulty and sometime in his presence the student dispute of that argument which he handle there be many hospital in Fez not inferior in building to the college aforesaid in they stranger be entertain three day at the common charge but in the time of satrids war the king sell their revenue now only learned man and gentleman receive entertainment and poor person relief there be a other hospital for disease stranger which have their diet but no physic allow they here also mad man be provide for in this hospital Leo in his youth have be a notary there be in Fez a hundred bathstove well build with four hall in each and certain gallery without in which they put off their clothes the most part of they pertain to the temple and college yield they a great rent they have a yearly festival wherein all the servant of the bath with trumpet and great solemnity go forth of the town and gather a wild onion which they put in a brazen vessel and bring it solemn to the hothouse door and there hang it up in token of goodluck this Leo think to be some sacrifice observe by the ancient moor yet remain every african town have sometime their peculiat feast which the christian abolish inn here be almost two hundred build three story high and have a hundred and twenty chamber a piece with gallery afore all the door but here be no provision of bed or board for stranger the innkeeper of Fez be all of one family call Elcheva and be attire like woman shave their beard become womanish in their speech yea degenerate even to the wheel and spindle they be so c c infamous inn keeper odious except to base villain that resort thither that the better sort of people will not speak to they and may not enter the temple burse or bath nor into those inn next the great temple where merchant be entertain there be thousand of mill all almost pertain to the temple and college revenue each trade in Fez have a peculiar place allot thereto the principal whereof be next the great temple as scrivener bookseller etc. every trade by themselves the christian captive rest only upon friday and eight other day in the year festival to the moor there be six hundred fountain wall about the water whereof be convey by conduit to the temple or other place because the river be sometime dry they have in Fez a judge for criminal cause and a other for question of religion a three that deal in matrimonial case from these there lie a appeal to the high advocate the judge of Mahomet law in matter of conscience have no allowance for the same their marriage be thus when the father of the maid have espouse she to her d d the man never see his bride before marriage but send his mother or some other woman to see she and upon that report agree with the father lover they go with their friend to church and have with they two notary which draw the covenant agree betwixt they into writing the father bestow a dowry or portion of money apparel and such like seldom of land when the bridegroom fetch she home she be set in a cabinet cover with silk and carry by porter accompany with her kins-folk and much minstrelsy and the bridegroom friend go before with torch and her kinsman after towards the great church then he haste home expect his bride in his chamber who her father brother and uncle bring and deliver to his mother and he set his foot on she shut the chamber door at which a woman stand and receive of he a napkin stain which she show to the assembly as a testimony of the bride virginity but if she be not find a maid she be return to her friend with shame and the guest go home without their feast they hold great feast also at the circumcision of their male-children which be the seven day after they be bear the barber or circumciser be present with gift of all the invite guest then follow mirth and jollity they use dance but the woman apart by themselves without man there be a remainder of holy day institute by the christian which themselves understand not on Christmas even they eat a salad make of diverse herb and see all kind of pulse which they feed upon on new-year day the child go with mask on their face to the house of gentleman and have first-fruit give they for sing certain song on the feast of s. John Baptist they use to make bonfire they make a feast call Dentilla when their child tooth begin to grow unto other child when a man die the woman put on sackcloth and defile their face with dirt they call to they those wicked man in woman attire which have four square drum to the sound whereof they sing mournful ditty in praise of the dead party at the end of every verse the woman utter most hideous shriek and outcry tear their hair and beat their breast and cheek till they be all imbrue with blood and thus they continue seven day and then intermit their mourn forty day after which space they resume the same for three day as before but the better sort behave themselves more modest at this time all the widow friend come about she to comfort she and send her diverse kind of meat for in the mourn house they may dress no meat at all till the dead be carry out the woman which lose her father brother or husband never go forth with the funeral at some festival the youth of one street will fight with club against the boy of a other street and sometime betake they to other weapon and kill one a other sometime they use these bloody fray without the city the officer force they to better order there be many poet which pen amorous sonnet and on Mahomet birthday make verse in his commendation resort early to the palace and there ascend the tribunal read their verse to the people and he who verse be best be pronounce that year prince of the poet the marin king on that day use to entertain the learned man and to reward the best poet with a hundred ducat a horse a woman-slave and the king robe which he wear that day in Fez be two hundred grammar school build like great hall every day they learn one lesson of the Alcoran they read and write not in book but in great e e these table be board like horn book when one lesson be learn that be wipe out and a other write and so throughout the Alcoran till all be learned table in seven seven year they learn the whole Koran by heart and then the father invite his son schoolfellow to a banquet and his son ride through the street in costly apparel both which be lend by the governor the other boy ride and sing song in praise of GOD and Mahumet on mahumets birthday every boy must carry a torch to school curious wrought some weigh thirty pound which they light before day and let they burn till sunrising sing all the while the praise of Mahumet the schoolmaster have the remnant of the wax which sometime they sell for a hundred ducat they be free school ancient build in the school and also in the college they have two day of recreation every week wherein they neither teach nor study there be three kind of fortune-teller or diviner one of which use geomanticall figure other pour a drop of oil into a glass of water which become clear as a see glass in which they say they see strange sight rank of devil like army some travel some pass over a river etc. when the divine seethe they quiet he demand such question of they as he will and the devil with gesture return answer the three sort be women-witche which make the people believe that they be acquaint with devil of diverse sort red white black and when they will tell any man fortune they presume themselves with certain odour whereby as they say the devil enter into they and their voice be present alter as if the devil speak within they and then they that come to inquire ask their question and so have leave their present for the devil depart these f f female fifthinesse woman use unlawful lust between themselves in mutual filthiness and if fair woman come to they they will demand the devil fee that they may have such deal with they yea some addict themselves to these abominable practice will feign themselves sick and send to one of these witch which will affirm that she be possess with a devil and can be cure except she become one of their society the foolish husband believe consent and make a sumptuous feast at that her devilish admission other will conjure this devil with a cudgel out of their wife other feign themselves to be possess with a devil will deceive the witch as they have deceive their wife there be exorcist or diviner call Mubazzimi which cast out devil or if they can they excuse themselves and say it be a airy spirit they write character and frame circle on a ash-heape or some other place then they make certain sign on the hand or forehead of the possess party and perfume he after a strange manner then they make their enchantment and demand of the spirit which way he enter what he be and his name and then command he to come forth other there be that work by a cabalistical rule call Zairagia and be very hard for he that do this must be a perfect ginger and cabalist myself it be Leo report have see a whole day spend in describe one figure only it be too tedious here to express the manner howbeit Mahomet law forbid all divination and therefore the mahometan inquisitor imprison the professor thereof there be also in Fez some learned man which give themselves the surname of wiseman and moral philosopher which observe law not prescribe by Mahumet some account they catholic other not but the vulgar hold they for saint the law forbid lovesong which they say may be use they have many rule and order all which have their defender and doctor this sect spring up fourscore year after Mahumet the first author thereof be Elhesen Abilbasen who give rule to his disciple but leave nothing in writing about a hundred year after come Elbarit Ibun ese from Bagadet who leave volume of write unto his disciple but by the lawyer be condemn fourscore year after under a other famous professor that law revive who have many disciple and preach open but by the patriarch and lawyer they be all condemn to loose their head the giddy receptacle of such fantastical devotion but he obtain leave of their caliph or Patriarch that he may try his assertion by disputation with the lawyer who he put to silence and therefore the sentence be revoke and many college build for his follower a hundred year after Malicsach the Turk destroy all the maintainer thereof some flee into cairo some into Arabia not long after elgazzul a learned man compound the controversy so reconcile these and the lawyer that the one shall be call conseruer the other reformer of the law. after the tartar have sack Bagdat in the year of the Hegeira 656. these sectary swarm all over Asia and Africa they will admit none into their society but such as be learn and can defend their opinion but now they admit all affirm g g anabaptistical fancy in Fez. learning to be needless for the holy teach they that have a clean heart therefore they addict themselves to nothing but pleasure feast and sing sometime they will rend their garment say they be then ravish with a fit of divine love I think rather superfluity of belly-cheer be the cause for one of they will eat as much as will serve three or else it be through wicked lust for sometime one of the principal with all his disciple be invite to some marriage feast at the beginning whereof they will rehearse their devout orison and song but after they be rise from table the elder begin a dance and tear their garment and if through immoderate drink any catch a fall one of the youth present take he up and wanton kiss he whereupon arise the proverb the hermit banquet signify that the scholar become his master minion for none of they may marry and be call hermit among these sect in Fez be some rule esteem heretical of both fort of doctor some hold that a man by good work fast and abstinence may attain to the nature of a angel the understanding and heart be thereby so purify say they that a man can sin though he will but to this height be ascend by fifty step of discipline and though they fall into sin before they be come to the fifty degree yet will not God impute it they use strange and incredible fast in the beginning but after take all the pleasure of the world they have a severe form of live set down in four book by a certain learned man call Essehravar de Sehranard in Corasan likewise a other of their author call ibnul Farid write all his learning in witty verse full of allegory seem to treat of love. wherefore one Elfargano comment on the same and thence gather the rule and the degree aforesaid in three hundred year none have write more elegant verse which therefore they use in all their banquet they hold that the heaven element planet and star be one God and that no religion be erroneous because every one take that which he worship for god. they think that all knowledge of God be contain in one man call Elcorb elect by God and wife as he forty among they be call elant which signify block of these be or Elcorb elect when the former be dead threescore and ten elector make the choice there be seven hundred and threescore and five other out of who those threescore and ten elector be choose the rule of their order bind they to range unknown through the world either in manner of fool or of great sinner or of they the vile man that be thus some wicked person of they go up and down naked shameful show their shame and like brute beast will sometime have carnal deal with woman in the open street repute nevertheless by the common people for saint h h vide. l.3.c.7 as we have show elsewhere there be a other sort call caballist which fast strange eat not the flesh of any live creature but have certain meat and habit appoint for every hour of the day and of the night and certain set prayer accord to the day and month strict observe the number of they and carry square table with character and number engrave in they they say that good spirit appear to they and talk with they instruct they in the knowledge of all thing there be amongst they a famous doctor call which compose their rule and order who book I have see seem to favour more of magic than the cabala their notable work be eight the first call demonstration of light contain fast and prayer the second their square table the three fourscore and nineteen virtue in the name of GOD contain etc. they have a other rule among these sect call S^uach the rule of hermit the professor whereof inhabit wood and solitary place without any other sustenance than those desert afford none can describe their life because they be estrange from all human society he that will see more of these thing let he read the book of one Elefacni who write at large of the mahometan sect whereof be threescore and twelve principal each maintain his own for truth and the way to salvation two be most predominant in these day that of Leshari in Africa Egypt Syria Arabia and Turkey and the other of Imamia in Persia and Corasan more late broach although I have speak before of the saracen sect yet can I not but follow Leo in his report of they here as for these i i gold-finder and alchemist conjurer which by art magic profess to find gold which indeed loose gold to find it and the alchemist which seek to turn other metal into gold turn their gold into other metal and the book that both these have of their science likewise the snake-charmer and other base people I pass over in the suburb of Fez be a hundred and fifty cave hew out of excellent marble the least of which will hold a thousand measure of corn this be the sink of Fez where every one may be a vintner and a bawd another suburb have two hundred family of leper which be there provide for and all of that quality force to keep there in new Fez the jew have a street wherein they have their house shop and synagogue and be meruailous increase since they be drive out of Spain they be goldsmith for the mahometans may not be of that trade because they say it be usury to sell thing make of gold or silver for more than their weight which yet be permit to the jew they live in exceed contempt not be permit to wear shoe but in steed thereof use sock make of rush they wear a black turban and if any will wear a cap he must fasten a red cloth thereunto they pay to the king of Fez monthly in Leo time one thousand and four hundred duckat the mahometan temporal lord be not by their law to hold any other revenue then of every subject which possess a hundred duckat two and a half for tribute and of corn the ten measure yearly yea this be to be pay into the patriarch or calif hand who shall bestow that which remain over and above the prince necessity on the common profit as for the poor and maintenance of war but now the prince have tyrannize further especial in Africa where they have not leave the people sufficient for their needment and therefore courtier be odious no less than the publican sometime among the jew no man of credit vouchsafe to invite they to their table or receive gift from they esteem all their good theft and bribery nor may any mahometan prince wear a diadem which yet it seem be now break in Gualili a town of mount Zarhon be idris of who before be speak bury all Barbary religious visit his sepulchre Pharaoh be the name of a town by the vulgar suppose the work of Pharaoh which fond conceit grow from a book entitle the book of the word of Mahomet take out of a author call Elcalbi which say with Mahomet testimony that there be four king which rule all the world two faithful and two unfaithful the two former Solomon and Alexander Magnus the two late Nimrod and Pharaoh the latin inscription there see show it be the work of the roman in Pietra Rossa a town by the lion be so tame that they will gather up bone in the street the people not fear they the like lion Tame lion be in where one may drive they away with a staff at Agla the lion be so fearful that they will flee at the voice of a child whence a coward braggart be proverbial call a lion of Agla shame be the name of a castle so call of their shameful covetousness which when they once request the king then entertain amongst they to change he consent but the next morning when they have bring he vessel of milk half fill up with water hope the king will not perceive it he say that none can alter nature and so leave they and their name to they we have now pass two province of the kingdom of Fez the three be name azgar which have the river buragrag on the west Bunasar on the south the ocean on the north and eastward the mountain here stand Caesar Elcabir which king Mansor give to a poor fisher who have give he kind entertainment in his cottage one night when he have lose his company in hunt in it be many temple one college of student and a stately hospital the four province or shire I be acquaint say Leo with a age fire in this city repute a saint and enrich exceed with the people offering from Fez do the people resort to visit he with their offering which be fifty mile he seem to i to be a deceiver in mount beni jesseten be many iron mine and the woman in great bravery wear iron ring on their finger and ear Ham Lisnan be build by the african and borrow the name from the fountain of a idol who temple be near the town to which at certain time in the year resort man and woman in the night where after sacrifice the candle be put out and each man lie with the woman he first touch those woman be forbid to lie with any other for a year after the child beget in this adultery be bring up by priest of the temple the moor destroy this holy-stewe and the town not leave any mention thereof in mount Centopozzi be ancient building and near thereto a spacious hole or dry pit with many room therein they let man down into the same by rope with light which if they go out they perish in the pit therein be many bat which strike out their light in the mountain of Ziz there be serpent so tame that at dinner time they will come like dog and cat and gather up the crumb not offer to hurt any thus much of the kingdom of Fez out of Leo a learned citizen of Fez and great traveller both in the place and author of Africa who Ortelius Boterus follow commend by m m Bodin method c. ^ ant. pess hist. Apparat. l. 16 ser. 7 c. 2 and other as the most exact writer of those part and translate into english by mr. porie from who if I swerve in diverse thing impute it to the italian copy of ramusius which differ not a little especial in these thing I have here set down from the english. I think good here also to add out of other some such custom and rite as they observe in Fez and other part of this kingdom n n history of Barbary ro. c. their circumcision be use in their private house woman may not enter the Moschee for their often uncleanness and because Eve first sinue the eight day after a child be bear the parent send for a jalby or priest and some old man and woman where after a few prayer say the woman wash the child all over with water and give the name make a banker but sometime the circumcision be defer diverse year after this ceremony as the father think meet their fast they observe very strict not so much as taste water till the star appear yea diverse have be see by their rigour in this superstition to faint and some to die a certain more in the time of their lent which continue thirty day in the company of a english gentleman be thirsty with heat and travel go to a conduit in Morocco where the same religion be profess as in Fez and there drink be so revile of the people that in a desperate anguish he slay himself with his dagger yet do their law allow a exchange some day of this lent with other day in the year follow if travel then hinder their feast and fast be at the same time and in the same manner that the turk observe of which be before speak their easter they call Rumedan their Whitsuntide Lidhiber their Michaelmas Lashour their Candlemas Lidshemaw if it be lawful thus to parallel those vain superstition with christian observation in this last feast which seem to be the same that Leo call Mahomet birthday every one must have a candle for himself and for every son in his house the king have that day candle carry to he some like maypole other like castle six or eight man carry one of they so artificial compose that some be in make six month that night the king do hear all the law read the like be do in all other church the talby that can read all their law in a night be hold insufficient for his place they go say my author six time in four and twenty hour which be once often than be write of the turk except on their sabbath to their prayer first wash themselves as they do also after the office of nature and after company with their wife think thereby to be wash from their sin their time of prayer be two hour afore day the first when the Monde^ or sexton cry in the steeple as you may read in our turkish relation and then may no man touch his wife but prepare himself to pray with wash or other devotion either in his own house or at church after their public prayer the talby sit down and spend half a hour in resolve the doubt of such as shall move any question in matter of their law the second time of prayer be two hour after when it be day the three at noon the four at four of the clock in the afternoon the five at the twilight the last two hour after in the first of these they pray for the day in the second they give thank for it in the three time they give thank for that it be half pass in the four they desire the sun may well set on they at twilight they give thank after their daily labour the lasttime they desire a good night they think it unseemly to eat meat with their left hand and hold it unclean and do all with their right hand their sabbath or Friday be not exempt from work only they be then more devout in go to church their church be not so fair general as in Christendom nor have seat in they ornament or bell only the floor be mat they be also poor for the most part as be their churchman their liturgy be very short not so long as the and creed other set form they have not but every one pray after his own pleasure although the Moor may have four wife and as many concubine as he can purchase yet few marry four because the wife friend will have a sufficient bill of dowry for her maintenance which none but rich man can perform and again the wife challenge his night company and that in course if any be neglect she complain to the magistrate and he force the husband to his duty or else to send she home with her dower and a bill of divorce the concubine be embrace with more steal pleasure that bill of dower hold the husband in awe which else will make a slave of his wife or still change for young flesh the bride be bed before her husband see she and if he find she not a virgin he may turn she home and keep her portion by law for their funeral rite when one be dead they present wash he and speedy put he into ground the heat so require and after that the woman at convenient time have a custom to meet and make memorial of their decease friend with remembrance of their virtue which they think cause man to have more respect to their good name their other obsequy be before declare the king use to sit in judgement on friday in the afternoon and the musti sit with he at other time in judgement but on the Friday he sit alone by himself of these mufti be three one at Morocco a other at Fez the three at taradant in Sus a other part of this Seriffian kingdom other judge sit all the year long two hour before noon and as many after before these every man plead his own cause and if the witness can be prove to be infamous of life or not to say their prayer six time a day their testimony be disable the scrivanos be talbies which assist the judge and in his absence supply his place the foker or saint Leo before call they hermit dwell in the best place of the country keep great hospitality for all traveller whither any man may come for a night and be go in the morning they give great example of moral live and alm to the needy comprimise matter of difference betwixt party and repress disorder they be much love and respect and their house be hold sanctuary who privilege the king will not break but upon weighty reason chap. 11 of the kingdom of Morocco with a discourse of the king thereof and of the seriff xarif or jarif and his posterity now begin in Barbary this kingdom be situate a a part i between Atlas and the atlantike ocean bear name of the chief city thereof fruitful of corn oil grape sugar honey and cattle they make fine cloth of goat hair and of their hide that leather b b Cordovan jether of Morocco which hence be call marocchine this kingdom be divide into seven province through which we intend our next perambulation take Leo c c leo. part. 2. for our guide beginning at Hea which on the north and west have the ocean Atlas on the south and the river esisnual on the east the people feed on cake of barley and on a pap or hasty-pudding of barley meal which be set in a platter all the family compass about and rude with nature spoon claw forth those dainty nappery they use none a mat lay on the ground serve for table and cloth and stool too cap be the privilege of age and learning linen shirt be almost banish their country and so be art liberal and mechanical except some simple lawyer which can make some shift to read and a surgeon to circumcise their child their physic be cauterize as man deal with beast they be always in mutual war one with a other yet will not they injury a stranger who if he will travel amongst they must take some harlot or wife or religious man of the adverse part with he at tedn one of their city such respect be have to stranger that if a merchant come thither and have no acquaintance the gentleman of the city cast lot who shall be his host and they use he kind look only for some present at his departure in token of thankfulness and if he be a mean person he may choose his host without any recompense at all in the midst of the city be a great and ancient temple with many priest attend their devotion beside other mean oratory this city have since be ruin and desolate in tecule be 1000 household four hospital one beautiful temple and a house of religious person Paris have write of John king of England about these time and in his own day he send say he Thomas Herdinton and Radulph Fitz Nicholas knight and Robert of London clerk to admiral Murnselius king of Morocco Africa and Spain who they common call miramumelius to make offer unto he of his vassalage and that he will not only hold the land of he with payment of tribute but will also change his religion and accept the mahometan the ambassador have declare their message the king or Emire Elmumenin to call he right shut up the book whereon they find he read and after a little deliberation thus answer I be now read a greek book of a certain wise man and a christian call Paul who word and deed well please i this only I like not that he forsake the religion wherein he be bear and unconstant embrace another and the same I say of your master GOD almighty know that if I be without the law and now to choose this above all other shall be my choice and then by diverse question inform himself better of the state of the kingdom and of the king he grow into great passion and indignation against the king protest that he think he unworthy to be his confederate and command the ambassador never more to see his face the author hear Robert of London one of those which be send relate these thing but to return to our marocchian building in it be a great castle in the mid whereof be a fair temple and thereon a goodly tower and on the top of the same a iron brooch with three golden globe weigh a hundred and thirty thousand Barbary ducat in form like those before mention diverse king have go about to take down the same but always some strange misfortune have befall they whereby they have be force to leave their attempt insomuch that it be hold a sign of ill luck to take they from theuce the vulgar conceit be that some influence of the planet be cause hereof and also that she that set they there by art magic enchant certain spirit to a perpetual station there for to guard they the people indeed be the spirit which in our time keep the king finger from they who else will have adventure all those phantasy danger to have possess himself of the gold for his war against the portugal the wife of king Mansor be report to have set they there as a monument of her memory have sell her jewel to purchase they adrianus l l in Theatt Romanus say that the talofi numidian and all Barbary come to Morocco to study and learn grammar poetry astrology and the law there be also in the say castle a college for the receipt of student which have thirty chamber and beneath a spacious hall where in old time lecture be read and all the student have their expense allow they and raiment once a year and the reader for their stipend have some a hundred ducat some two hundred accord to the quality of their profession no man may be admit into that college which be not well instruct in the principle of art the excellency of the matter and workmanship may well detain we long in the view thereof but that it be now rather become a sepulchre of science than a theatre there be not above five student under a senseless professor leave in Leo time as the ghost of those sometime renown number of scholar there be build also by Mansor twelve stately palace in the say castle for his guard officers armoury and other purpose fit both Mars and Venus there be also goodly and spacious garden and also a park with many kind of wild beast as lion elephant etc. there be a leopard make of marble the spot not borrow but nature handiwork but alas devour time that swallow his own offspring be not content to have inglut his insatiable paunch with the flesh of those beast and man brand with nature stamp of mortality but even those curious and costly stone be now become gravestone to themselves provoke and sarra otherwise call Numidia and Libya we have now I suppose weary you with so long discourse of that part of Africa on this side Atlas but such be the difference of the mind weariness from that of the body that this be weary with one long journey if the same be continue with a second it be more than tire the other after a tedious and irksome way when another of another nature present itself be thereby refresh and the former wearinsse be with this variety abate yea although it be as this be from a better to a worse even the mount up this cold hill and thence to view the atlantike ocean on the west southward and eastward the desert will neither make the soul breathless with the steep ascent nor faint with so wild prospect of manifold wilderness this of barren earth and that of ba^^ water a three seem to be mix of both a sea without water and earth without solidity a sand not to hazard ship with her privy ambushment but with open violence swallow man and disdain to hold a foot-print as a testimony of subjection a wind not breathe air but sometime the high element in fiery heat and sometime the low in sandy shower once a nature mock nature a order without order a constant inconstancy where it be nature pastime to do and undo to make mountain and valley and mountain of valley at pleasure strange be the composition of these place but stranger be that of the mind which feed itself with the cruel hunger and thirst with the insatiable thirstiness of these desert and whereas the body fear to be drown even there where it as much fear to want water in this sandy journey the soul model of divinity life of humanity fear no such accident to itself but in a sweetness of variety delight to survey all that her first and ancient inheritance howsoever since by sin mortgage and confiscate and be sequester from all society of man can here discourse with GOD and nature in the desert hither now after so long a preamble we bring you and at first present unto your bore through the gristle of the camel nose serve they for a bridle mat make of rush be their bed and wool grow on their date-tree yield matter for their tent their food be oftentime patience with a empty belly which when they fill bread or meat after any sort be absent only they have their camel milk whereof they drink a dish-full next their heart and certain dry flesh sod in butter and milk every one with his hand rake out his share of these dainty and after drink the broth and then drink up a cup of milk and supper be do while milk last they care not for water especial in the springtime all which soason some never wash hand or face because they never go to the place where they may have water and the camel have join with their master in this neatness not regard water while they may feed on grass all their life or that space rather before they die not worthy the name of life be spend in hunt and rob their enemy not stay above three or four day in a place as long as the grass will serve their camel they have over every tribe one in manner of a king who they honour and obey very rare be a judge find amongst they and to he such as be litigious ride sometime five or six day journey he will they amply-reward with a thousand ducat more or less by the year as for letter art virtue they dwell not in these desert they be very jealous which be the death of many yet be they liberal after their manner to stranger as I myself it be Leo report can testify for go over the desert with a caravan of merchant the prince of Zanaga encounter we with five hundred man on camel and cause we to pay our custom and then invite we to his tent there do he kill many camel to feast we both young and old and as many gelt and ostrich which they have take in the way and when the merchant show themselves loath that he shall make such slaughter of they he say that it be shame to entertain they with small cattle only be stranger so we have roast and boil and bread of Panike very fine and date great plenty he honour our company with his presence but he eat together with his noble separate from we and have with he certain religious and learned man to sit with he which all the meale-time touch no bread but only flesh and milk the reason the prince give we because they be bear in the desert where no corn grow only they eat bread on certain solemn feast as at their easter and day of sacrifice thus do this liberal prince spend on we ten time the value of his custom after this manner also live the african call Soava the tract of Numidia f f lib. 6. most in name be these dara which gold for or else leave altogether this seem hard to believe but many of the arabian and Azanhagi testify it to our author for truth the merchant of affirm to i that their prince have once by a plot cure their disease whence happy that deformity proceed they renew that traffic to leave these far within land and come to the k k barrius dec. 1 lib. 3 cap. 8 and Maffaeus hist. ind. lib. 1 say that on the one side the inhabitant be well proportion very black and the soil very fertile on the other side the inhabitant meager small swart and the ground barren the people that dwell on the bank of Niger be call Gilofi the king name in my time which be l l 1455. almost a hundred and threescore year since be Zuchali he have thirty wife when Richard m m Hak. to 2 Rainolds be there 1591. the king name be Amar melik all that region betwixt Sanaga and Gambea be call by one general name Gia lof of which Maffeus n n maff. l. 1 bar. dec. 1 l.3 c. 6,7,8 and barrius write that in a accident of civil war bemoin come to the king of Portugal for aid and be there royal entertain and baptize with his follower of which some be of such admirable dexterity and nimbleness of body that they will leap upon a horse as he gallop and will stand upright in the saddle when he run fast and turn themselves about and sudden sit down and in the same race will take up stone lay in order on the ground and leap down and up at pleasure this bemoin be shameful murder by Peter Vaz the Portugal general and the hope of christianity in those part disappoint this be 1489. from thence o o al. Cadamosto go to Budomel the prince whereof be have in great respect by his people which when they come into his presence kneel on both their knee and bow their head to the ground cast sand over their shoulder and on their head with both hand and then go towards he on their knee and when they speak to he cast sand over their shoulder still with their head bow down the prince scarce deign they a look or word for every light offence he will sell their wife and child he suffer our author to go into his Moschee where his arabian chaplain after their manner mumble their matin ten or twelve time in half a hour all the company rise and fall again to the earth and kiss it he also hear he willing confute the mahumetane and prove the christian faith but say he think it be hard for a Christian to be save then a negro because GOD be a just GOD and lord who have give to we many good thing in this world to they nothing in comparison who shall therefore in the other world have their paradise which here they want easy may he have be turn to christianity but for fear of lose his state. his wife provide he his diet as it be usual among the negro and none but his priest and some principal man eat with he which be after a beastly sort lie on the ground the dish set in the midst and all take out the meat with their hand they eat little at once but eat often four or five time a day from October to june it rain not there they have great serpent and many which they use to charm and the prince when he will poison his weapon do as be report make a great circle and enchant by his charm all the serpent thereabouts thereinto and then kill that which seem to he most venomous let the rest go with the blood thereof and the seed of a certain tree he temper a poison for that purpose with which a weapon infect draw never so little blood do kill in a quarter of a hour they have great store of parrot which be instruct by a marvelous natural cunning to prevent the serpent which will else destroy their nest they build therefore on high tree and on the end of some tender bough thereof they fasten a bulrush which hang down two span thereunto weave and work their nest in such sort that the serpent for fear of fall dare not adventure to deal therewith the negro come about Cadamosto with wonder to see his apparel and the whiteness of his colour never before have they see any Christian and some of they with spittle rub his skin to see whither his whiteness be natural or no which perceive to be no tincture they be out of measure astonish they will then give nine or sometime fourteen slave for a horse furnish and when they buy a horse they will bring some of their enchanter which make a fire of herb and set the horse over the smoke utter certain word and after that anoint he with a thin ointment and shut he up twenty day that none may see he hang certain trumpery about his neck think that hereby they be more secure in battle gun seem to they for their hideous noise to be of the devil bagpipe they think to be a live creature that thus sing in variable accent but when they be suffer to handle they they think they to be some heavenly thing that GOD have make with his own hand to sound so sweet they behold the ship with great curiosity and eye that be carve in the prow of the ship they take to be eye indeed by which it see how to direct the course at sea. they say the christian that can thus make voyage by sea be great enchanter and comparable to the devil themselves have enough to do to travel by land. see a candle burn in the night they which know not to make any light but their fire esteem it wonderful honey they have which they suck out of the comb but the wax they hurl away till they be instruct how to make candle thereof Senega Boterus say come from the lake a hundred and fifty league from the mouth it have certain Falls or cataract as Nilus have that man may pass under the fall of the stream without wet Cadamosto double the promontory call cape Verde or the green cape because of the green tree which the portugall who have first discover it in the year before find there grow in abundance as o o likewise cape Sierra Liona be so call of the lion-like terror thereof always cover on the top with cloud which yield dreadful thunder and lightning it seem to be the same that Ptolomey and hann. call the chariot of the gods. g. ^ot ben. cape blanco or the white cape be so call of the white sand there the inhabitant they find be of two sort Barbacini and they have no prince they be great idolater and have no law but be very cruel they poison their arrow with which and the situation of their country they have preserve themselves from the king of Senega in Gambia they be some idolater of diverse sort some mahumetan they be also great enchanter their live as at Senega save that they eat dogges-flesh here the prince hunt a elephant and give they to eat the flesh be strong and unsavoury the elephant delight in mire like swine they hunt they in the wood for in the plain a elephant will without run soon take and kill the swift man who yet they hurt not except they be first provoke here be a kind of fish Cadamosto p p Cadamosto 47. call it cavallo and his latin interpreter Caballinus I take it for the Hippopotamus or river-horse which be say he as big as a cow his leg short with tusk like to a boar but so great that I have seeve one of two span and long clovenfooted and head like a horse he live on both element sometime in the water otherwhiles on the land. the woman upon their breast neck and arm have certain work do Nauig. 1599 in Guinea a little from thence they find man who use as great bravery in their ear which they bore full of hole and wear therein ring of gold in row or rank they wear one great ring in a other hole bore through their nose like to buffle in Italy which when they eat their meat they take away the man and woman of sort wear such ring also in their lip in like sort as in their ear a ensign of their nobility and greatness which they put in and out at pleasure beyond the river of palm they find other thus beringe and for great gallantry wear about their neck certain chain of tooth seem to be the tooth of man they take a negro who they carry into Portugal who affirm if a woman which only can understand he do interpret he right that in his country be unicorn on this coast the portugal erect a castle call mina for their better trade and these country have since be seek to s s the guineans esteem well of the french ill of the flemish and not well of the portugall Arthus hist. ind. or. c.9 by french flemish and many of our english merchant in the year 1553. t t tho. he cause a pot of wine of palm or Coco which they draw forth of tree as we have elsewhere observe but their ceremony in drink be thus first they bring forth their pot of drink and then make a hole in the ground and put some of the drink into it and after that cast in the earth again and thereon set their pot and with a little thing make of a gourd take out of the same drink and put it upon the ground in three place and in diverse place they have certain bunch of the pill of palmtree set in the ground before they and there they put in some drink do great reverence in all place to the same palmtree all these ceremony do the king take a cup of gold in which they put wine and while he drink all the people cry Abaan Abaan with certain other word and then they give drink to every one the like ceremony they use in all the country in benin y y james welsh the people go naked till they be marry and then be clothe from the waste to the knee their bread be a kind of root call Inamia which when it be well sodden may be prefer before we they have here great spout of water fall out of the air which if they light on a ship do endanger the same they fall like the pillar of church as for India c. 9 ind. orient part. 6. bry. observe circumcision and other mahumetical superstition they cut or raze the skin with three line draw to their navel esteem it necessary to salvation they will not easy do injury to any especial a stranger they have bird in such respect that it be deadly to any that shall hurt they and some be appoint to have a peculiar care of they and to provide they soode which they do in high mountain where they lay meat for they which they come and eat the inhabitant of Guinea c c get. art. c. 10.11,12,13 give religious respect also unto certain tree and in the year 1598. certain hollander cut they and not cease at the persuasion of the negro who superstition in that case they deride it pass from word to blow betwixt they and the dutchman be force to get they to their ship one of their company be slay in the chase but the murderer be offer to the hollander to be punish which they refuse his countryman cut off his head and quarter his body bestow the one as a monument of revenge over the slay party grave the other on the fowl unbury their nose be flat not natural but by press they down in their infancy esteem it a great part of beauty their hot stomach can digest raw flesh and therefore d d alex. problem l. 1. and 2. cael. l. 16 c 15. Alexander Aphrodisieus and coelius that think their natural heat extract to the outward part to be the cause of their blackness be deceive they eat their enemy which be slay in the war which be very rise amongst those nation and those which be take be everlasting prisoner and in some more important war which they undertake they will burn their dwelling before they go lest either the enemy may possess they by conquest or themselves become too mindful of a return in these war they provide themselves of some light armour wear at such time no other apparel some man of great sort have a white confection wherewith they white their face and body their woman be unfaithful secretary in nature most hide secret use in the sight of man woman boy and girl to be deliver of their child who after they circumcise whether they be of the male or female sex their they celebrate with much sing and solemnity they believe that man when they die go into another world where they shall have like need of many thing as here they have and therefore use to put with the dead corpse some part of household and if they lose any thing they think that some of their friend which in the other world have need thereof come thence and steal it of b b the religion of the guineans GOD be ask they say he be black and evil and do they much harm their good they have by their own labour and not by his goodness circumcision they use and some other turkish rite they hold it unmeet and irreligious to spit on the ground they have no letter nor book they observe a sabbath herein agree and yet disagree with Turk jew and Christian for they observe Tuesday rest from their fish and husbandry the wine of the palmtree which be that day gather may not be sell but be offer to the king who bestow it on his courtier to drink at night in the midst of the marketplace this be in the river and the hollander the reporter they have a table stand on four pillar two elnes high who flat cover be make of straw and reed weave together hereon be set many strawen ring call fetissos or god and therein wheat with water and oil for their god which they think eat the same their priest they call Fetissero who every festival day place a seat on that table and sit thereon preach to the people which do the woman offer he their infant and he sprinkle they with water in which a newt do swim and then besprinkle the table aforesaid with the same water and so utter certain word very loud he dismiss his devout assembly many wear such ring of straw next their body as preservative from those danger which else their angry god may inflict on they in honour of the same deity or devil as it seem they conceive he to be they bechalke themselves with a kind of chalkey earth and this be unto they in stead of their morning matin the first bit at meal and first draught be consecrate to their idol and therefore they besprinkle therewith those ring which I say they wear on their body if fisher can speed at sea they give a piece of gold to the Fetissero to reconcile their frown saint he therefore with his wife walk a kind of procession through the city smite his breast and clap his hand with a mighty noise till he come at the shore and there they cut down certain bough from the tree and hang they on their neck and play on a timbrel then do the Fetissero turn to his wife and expostulate with they and withal hurl into the sea wheat and other thing as a offering to Fetisso to appease his displeasure towards the fisherman when the king will sacrifice to Fetisso he command the Fetissero to inquire of a tree whereto he ascribe divinity what he will demand he with his wife come to the tree and in a heap of ash there provide prick in a branch pluck off the tree and drink water out of a basin spout it out on the branch and then daubeth his face with the ash which do he declare the king question and the devil out of the tree make answer the noble also adore certain tree and esteem they oracle and the devil sometime appear unto they in the same in form of a black dog and otherwhiles answer without any visible apparition there be which worship a certain bird which be spot and paint as it be with star and resemble the low of a bull in her voice to hear this bird low in their journey be a lucky bode say Fetisso make they good promise and therefore set he in that place where they hear it a vessel of water and wheat and as the earth and air yield they deity so the sea be not behind in this liberality but yield certain fish to their canonisation in this respect they take not the tunie at all and the swordfish they take but eat not till his sword be cut off which be dry and hold in great veneration the mountain will bend their sullen brow if they shall not have some red letter in their calendar to which their top aspire threaten to scale heaven or overwhelm the earth if this Fetissan portion do not pacify their angry mood by daily present of meat and drink set thereon neither can nature alone usurp this praviledge but art in other thing her emulous corrival and far unequal competitor in this matter of god-making common get the upper hand and therefore they with their ceremonious art can make they fetisso or god at pleasure principal in their funeral they observe it for when one be dead they make a new Fetisso or funeral rite ring of straw and pray it to bear the dead party company and protect he in his journey into the other world the friend and kinsfolk assemble prepare a hen and then set themselves in a corner of the dead man house they place all his fetisso on a row the great in the midst adorn the same with garland of pease and beanes like to the popish praying-beade then they sprinkle the same with the blood of the hen and hang a chain or garland of herb about their neck after this the woman set the hen now sodden in the midst of the fetisso and the Fetissero take water in his mouth which amidst his exorcism and charm he spout on those fetisso and take two or three herb from his neck he roll the same in form of a ball which after certain ceremony he lay down and so do till all his hearbe-garland be spend and then make they all into one great ball and therewith besmear his face and thus be it make a Fetisso and the party decease be now at rest in the mean time the dear of his wife fill all the house with mourn the neighbour and friend with song and music such as they have and dance and at last they take up the corpse and carry it to the grave which be dig four foot deep and cover it with stake that nothing may fall therein the woman creep about the sepulchre expostulate with he why he will leave they then do they hurl on earth so that none can get into the corpse for he have with he his household armour and whatsoever he use in his life time wine also if before he love it to drink in the other world last they cover the sepulchre with a roof to defend all from rain if the king die not only great solemnity be use but the noble think it necessary for so great a personage to have attendant they offer unto he one a servant another a wife a three his son or daughter till there be many of both sex in that other life to attend he all which be sudden slay at unaware and their bloody carcase bury together with the king. yea the king wife which love he best refuse not this last and everlasting service as they suppose but yield themselves to die that they may live with he the head of all these thus slay be set upon pole round about the sepulchre meat drink raiment arm and other utensil be add for their use and bury with they they in uncertainty of criminal accusation as of adultery murder and such like have a certain water offer they to drink by the Fetissero make of those herb whereof their ball be make and in effect like the curse water num. 5. none dare to drink for fear of sudden death thereby if he be guilty and now leave the coast of Guinea benin Melegete and other region of the negro adjoin to the sea we
