great ape as big as weathers their forepart hairy like lion which go not less than two or three hundred in a company they will climb any rock they dig the earth that it seem as it have be till in the country of the e e ca. 50 as they travel they cross a certain brook or river that come down from the mountain and find a pleasant place shade with the sallowe there they repose themselves at noon the water of the brook be not sufficient to drive a mill. and while the company stand some on one side the brook some on the other they hear a thunder which seem a far off but see no likelihood of rain or wind when the thunder be do they put their stuff in order to be go and have take up the tent in which they dine when one of the company go by the brook about his business sudden cry out look to yourselves whereupon turn about they see the water come down a spear depth with great fury which carry away part of their stuff and have they not by good hap take up their tent they together with it have be carry away with the stream many of they be force to climb up the sallowe such be the noise of the water and the rattle of the stone which come tumble down the mountain together that the earth tremble and the sky seem to threaten a down fall sudden it come and sudden it pass for the same day they pass over and see very many and great stone join to those which they have see there before in and h h Abuna be their patt-arch Abunas other use wine make of raisins steep ten day in water and sirain which be cordial and strong they have plenty and want of metal gold silver etc. the soil yield but they have not art to take it they have no coin of gold or silver salt be the most current money sugar cane they have but want skill to use they the mountain and wood be full of basil and other odoriserous plant they have store of bee and honey but their hive be place in chamber where make a little hole in the wall the bee go in and out there be some place very cold the commons be miserable oppress by their superior no man may kill a ox though it be his own without licence from the governor there be no shambles but at the court. the common people seldom speak truth no not upon a oath except they be compel to swear by the head of the king they exceed sere excommunication their oath be in this fort the party to be depose go with two priest carry with they fire and and incense to the church-door whereon he lay his hand then the priest adiure he say if thou shall swear false as the lion devour the beast of the forest so let the devil devour thy soul and as corn be grow under the millstone so let he grind thy bone and as the fire burn up the wood so letthy sou'e burn in hell the party answer to every to these clause amen but if thou speak truth let thy life be prolong with honour and thy soul enter into paradise with the bless amen then do he give his testimony they have book write in parchment some i i f. Milone be the rule of my faith to friar and jesuite in their relation in natural and moral history which serve not to the build of Babylon tower I receive they with attention with thanks and if need be with admiration in some thing but when they come with slime instead of mortar and will get Rome a name I remember their vow and profession and yield no further attendance that Claudius which be then emperor and his successor Adamas be of schismatical and tyrannical quality as other historian affirm friar Lewis not only deny but extoll their good part he which now be emperor be elect an. 1606 and call himself zaraschaureat asprout or bud of the lineage of David assister of s. Peter and s. paul. he be a man haughty and valorous and be therefore choose because the turkish empire be so full of sedition and the sophi have send his ambassador to they to choose a fit warrior that they may with joint force assault the ottoman there be in all the city of Aethiopia two school or college for the instruction of youth one for the male sex the other for the female each divide into three part the first for the gentleman child the second for citizen the three for the base vulgar with their several instructer and without communion meddle or converse of the one with the other the seminary of college of boy be a quarter of a league without the city the other within there be they teach letter and religion all even the king themselves be bind to send their child thither to be instruct and the priest resort theither for confession and minister the sacrament to they they may resort home at festival time otherwise they be there detain the virgin from ten to twenty the other from ten to sixteen year of their age they have not only this order in their well-ordered school but in their disorder misorderly stew the devil worke-house and suburb of hell which yet in Rome and place of that religion be permit and admit the city and his holiness self be not a little enrich with that which GOD prohibit f f Deut. 23.18 the price of the dog and of the whore. the aethiopian permit not any to be strange woman but stranger of other country which may not enter into their city nor may the noble enter into the common house which belong to the citizen or these to those of the plebeian nor any but to those peculiar design their state under pain of death as adulterer to be cast to the lion these woman be hire by certain officer at a common price and be not to take any thing of particular man they go in pale-coloured garment and if they distaste and forsake that beastly trade they send they to some place subject unto the portugall not admit they to converse with their woman for fear of infection but to leave these beast the aethiopian give great respect to their physician which be only of their gentry and that not all that will but only such as certain officer shall choose of every city to be send to their general university of which there be seven in Aethiopia there to be teach natural philosophy logic and other art they know not together with physic and the art of the apothecary and chirurgeon they be there maintain at the public charge of the city that send they when the doctor and instructer see they sit to be graduate they go with they to the monk of hallelujah and of who with a monk cowl of hood and other doctoral ensign do invest and inaugurate they in that degree they be great herbarist they make g g make of mummy mummia otherwise then in other part where it be either make of body bury in the sand or take out of ancient sepulcher where they have be lay be embalm with spice for they take a captive Moor of the best complexion and after long diet and medicine of he cut off his head in his sleep and gash his body full of wound put therein all the best spice and then wrap he up in hay be before cover with a scarecloth after which they bury he in a moist place cover the body with earth five day be pass they take he up again and remove the cerecloth and hay hang he up in the sun whereby the body resolve and drop a substance like pure balm which liquor be of great price the fragrant scent be such while it hang in the sun that it may be smell he say a league off the privilege of physician be that they be free from the common custom of give one in three of their son for the emperor war that they may ride on elephant in the city which be allow only to the emperor prelate and priest that be virgin they may also wear miniver-hood and be free from subsidy and payment theology and the Chaldee tongue be teach only among their priest and ecclesiastical person in their church and monastery they read divinity in their native tongue the text be the four first general counsel the scripture they read in Chaldee which be with they as latin with we they handle not question as the schoolman in logical disputation and argue but copious and eloquent interpret the scripture because we have mention their city Saba and Zambra let we take some briese view of they and so leave this Spaniard who discourse have I hope not without some delight and profit thus long hold you beside these two city none have above three thousand house in they but these be populous and magnificent with tower temple triumphant arch obelisk pyramid and the like token of industry antiquity and majesty Saba be found by that queen which visit Solomon and be the mother-city of the empire it have five thousand house great and sumptuous the street spacious with portal or penthouse that man may walk safe from the sun violence it have four chief gate all of alabaster and jasper wrought with antique-worke the gate-dore of cedar curious carve the way that lead to these gate for the space of two league be set with palm plane orange cedar cypress and other tree on both side for shade and fruit the four high street go through the city across and where they meet be a arch or vault erect on high pillar fair wrought and gild with the brazen image of s. Lopez tell that certain moor relate unto they of the riches of those mine that ship from Mecca and use to trade there and that yearly there be take forth of the mine two million of mittigall every mittigall be a ducat of gold and a three part that the war in those country at that time have cease the traffic and that they have book and ancient write which testify that these be the mine whence Solomon in his three year voyage fetch his gold and that the queen of Saba be natural of the part of India as for India you have 10 10 cap. sup. even now read that it be a name give to many nation and among the rest to Aethiopia and if a man consider the small skill which that age of the world have in marine affair still as much as may be hold their course within fight of land he can scarce think that long navigation can then be perform barrius account all Sofala to the empire of Benomotapa of which we shall speak anon we have now mention the same by reason of the isle which be subject to the portugall these beside gold here have great trade for ivory of which barrius say that in Benomotapa be yearly slay four or five thousand and of water-horse who tooth be account ivory also all the great river in Africa be full these feed sometime on the meadow where the mariner have chase they as Lopez y y th. Lopez report and after long chase by land they have take the water where in revenge they have assault the mariner in their boat and bite chip of the same be by the thickness of their hide arm against their pike and have make they afraid that they will overwhelm the boat. within the land behind these part be the kingdom of Monoemugi which be rich in gold their unfortunate war with Monomotapa have make they know Nilus be their western border and Abassia on the north. they have little read ball make of a kind of clay in Cambaya and resemble glass which they wear for ornament and use for money this king war with the Benomotapa and have terrible soldier call Giacqui or Agab or agog who inhabit between the lake whence Nilus and Zaire take their beginning which live a wander life like the nomads in cottage which they make in the field they be of stature tall and of countenance terrible make line upon their cheek with certain iron instrument and turn their eyelid backward eat their enemy these not long since as z z od. champain compass with mountain ninety mile in circuit the place where the gold be appear and be know by the dryness and barrenness of the soil as if nature itself can not hoard up gold in her spacious chest but she must needs prove bare and barren of her wont good work and how much less unnatural and degenerate mankind the province be call Matuca the people botonghi which although they be between the line and the tropic yet in winter have such snow in the mountain that if any abide there they die freeze in they and in summertime the air in the top of those hill be so clear and pure that some of our man which be then there see the new moon the same day that she have kiss her bright and bountiful brother and who can now charge the bright eye of the world with the obscure darkness of this people hue which so cold winter nor pure summer can lessen or lighten yea even in the cold country near the cape of good-hope the aethiopian have no hope or hap of better colour whereas the hot country of Libya and in manner all America notwithstanding the sun straight look and nearness not allow they a shadow to attend they in the great height of his bounty know not this black tincture in the natural thereof but to return and who will not return to the mine there be other mine in the province of Boro and in which and in the river be find gold not so pure the people be careless and ancient or late the people be rude and dwell in cottage of timber all the people of this region be of curl hair and more ingenious than those which be against Mosambique Quiloa and mclinde among who be many that eat man flesh and let their kine blood to satisfy their thirst these seem prone to receive the faith for they believe in one GOD who they call moz^^o and have no idol not worship other thing they punish nothing more severe than witchcraft whereunto other negro be exceed addict no such person escape death the like detestation they conceive against adultery and theft every one may have as many wife as they will but the first be principal the other serve she and her child be heir a woman be not marriageable with they till her natural purgation testify for her ability to conception and therefore they entertain the first flux thereof with a great feast in two thing they be religious in observation of day and rite concern their dead of day they observe the first day of the moon the 6 the seven the eleven the sixteenth the seventeen the twenty and the eight and twenty because in that day their king be bear the religion be in the first 6 and seven all the rest be repetition above ten when any be dead after his body be eat his near kindred or his wife which have have most child by he keep the bone with some sign whereby to know who they be and every seven day they observe exequy in the same place where they be keep they spread many clothes and set thereon table furnish with bread and sodden flesh which they offer to the dead with prayer and supplication and the principal thing they request of they be the good success of their king affair these prayer they make be clothe in white garment after which the goodman and his family eat their offering the Benomotapa must wear clothes of the same country for fear of infection other may wear foreign cloth he be serve on the knee and when he drink or cough all they which be about he make a shout that all the town may know none may cough in his presence also every one must sit in token of reverence to stand be a sign of dignity which he afford the portugal and moor and be the chief honour can be yield any the second honour be to sit on a cloth in his house the three that a man may have a door in his house which be the dignity of great lord for mean person they need not fear to have any thing steal out of their open house seel the severity of justice do secure they door be not for necessity but for honour their house be of pyramidal or steeple form all the timber meet in the midst at the top cover with earth and straw some of they be make of timber as long and big as a great ship mast the great they be the more honourable the Benomotapa have music whither so ever he go with singer and more than five hundred jester which have their captain or master of misrule the royal ensign be a little ploughshare with a ivory point which he carry always at his girdle by which be signify peace and husband of the ground he bear likewise one or two d d porta ^^ due zagaie Bot^^^^ say Zapoa ^^ due a mattock and two dart sword in token of justice and defence of his people the country be free and give he no other payment but present when they come to speak with he and certain day service no inferior come before his superior without some present in token of obedience and courtesy the captain of war with all they bestow seven day in thirty in his husbandry or other business he must confirm all sentence of judgement in his own person there need no prison for matter be present dispatch accord to the allegation and testimony that be bring and if there be not sufficient testimony than the matter be try by oath in this manner they beat the bark of a certain tree and cast the powder thereof in water e e of such like water see the next chapter which the party drink and if he do not vomit he be clear if he vomit he be condemn and if the accuser when the accuse party vomit not will drink of the same and do not vomit he be then acquit and the matter dispatch if any sue to he he speed not but by mediation of a three person which also set down the sum that the king must have sometime at so dear rate that the suitor rather refuse the king grant they have no horse and therefore war on foot the spoil be general share amongst all when he march in the place where he be to lodge they make a new house of wood and therein must continual fire be keep without ever go out say that in the ash may be wrought some witchery to the indamagement of his person and when they go to the war they never wash their hand nor face till they have obtain victory they have their wife with they which be so love and respect that if the king son meet with one of they in the street he give her way Benomotapa have more than a thousand woman but the first be principal although she be inferior in blood and her son succeed and in seedtime and harvest the queen go to the field and over-seeth those which live near Mosambique and those especial more within the land they be black as pitch with flat nose thick lip some have hole both above and under in their lip and as it be other mouth in their cheek wherein they thrust small bone to beautify themselves for which cause they raze and sear their body with iron if they will make a devilish form and picture they represent a white man in his apparel as think nothing more ugly some also file their tooth as sharp as needle they have village wherein they dwell together and in every village a lord or king to who they be subject religion and faith be unknown to they they use mutual war and some eat man flesh when they take prisoner in war or kill their enemy they observe a more than beastly testimony of their great valour which be after this manner they cut off their privy member to deprive they of all hope of generation and then dry they well for preservation after which they come before the king with great reverence in the presence of the principal man of the village and there take these member so dry one by one in their mouth and spit they on the ground at the king foot which the king with great thanks accept and the more to honour they cause they all to be take up and give to they again which be from thenceforth a ensign of their knighthood for they take all those member and tie they on a string like a bracelet or chain and at all solemn meeting as when they marry or go to a wedding or feast the bride or wife of these knight do wear that chain about their neck be say our author among they as great a honour as the golden fleece or the renown garter with we and their wife as proud as if some crown or sceptre have befall they chap. 9 of the kingdom of congo and the other kingdom and nation adjoin the Panlo Dias to who the king Sebastian have give the government of these part with licence to conquer three and thirty league alongst the coast to he and his heir to revenge himself for this despite do to his people arm such portugal as he have and with two galley and other vessel which he keep in the river Coanza he go on both side the river conquer and subdue many lord unto he the king of angola raise a mighty army of a million of man e e p. diaz as some report send a present to Spain of two butt of negro nose which be slay a.b. as be suppose for they use to leave none at home that be fit to carry a weapon and make no preparation for victual but such as have any carry it upon the shoulder of their servant and therefore no marvel if their food be soon consume their camp be soon dissolve small likewise be their provision of armour for offence and for defence much less diaz send to the king of congo for aid who send he sixty thousand man with which and his own nation he make his party good against the confuse rabble of the Angolans the trade of angola be yet continue and from thence the portugal buy and carry to brasil and other part yearly a world of slave which be buy within the land and be captive take in their war one Thomas f f thom. governor under the king of Spain at his city of saint Paul and with he go far into the country of angola their army be eight hundred portugal and fifty thousand natural this Andrew battle tell that they be all heathen in angola they have their idol of wood in the midst of their town fashion like a negro and at the foot thereof be a great heap of elephant tooth contain three or four ton of they these be pile in the earth and upon they be set the skull of deadman which they have slay in the watre in monument of their victory the idol they call Mokisso and some of they have house build over they if any be sick he account it mokisso hand and send to appease his angry god with pour wine which they have of the palmtree at his foot they have proper name of distinction for their mokissos as Kissung^ Kal^kete etc. and use to swear by they kissungowy that be by Kissango they have another more solemn oath intriall of controversy h h this trial be call Motamba for which purpose they lay a kind of hatchet which they have in the fire and the ganga-mokisso or mokissos priest take the same red hot and draw it near to the skin of the accuse party and if there be two he cause their leg to be set near together and draw this hot iron without touch between they if it burn that party be condemn as guilty otherwise he be free for the ceremony about the dead they first wash he then paint he three apparel he in new clothes and then bring he to his grave which be make like a vault after it be dig a little way down undermine and make spacious within and there set he on a seat of earth with his bead which they use in chain and bracelet for ornament and the most part of his good with he in his last home they kill goat and shed the blood in the grave and pour wine there in memorial of the dead they be much give i i od. Lopez to divination by bird if a bird fly on their left hand or cry in some manner which they interpret ominous and unlucky they will cease from the enterprise which they have in hand their priest be k k gi. bot. the world. it follow in the course of our discovery to set you on shore in Loango the northerly neighbour of congo right under the line a a Lopez l. i c.5 who country stretch two hundred mile within land. the people be call Bramas the king mani Loango sometime as report go subject to the king of congo they be circumcise after the manner of the hebrew like as also the rest of the nation of those country use to be they have abundance of elephant and wear clothes of the palm Andrew b b Andrew bat. battle live amongst they two year and a half they be say he heathen and observe many superstition they have their mokisso or image to which they offer accord to the proportion of their sort and suit the fisher offer fish when he sue for his help in his fish the countryman wheat the weaver alibungo piece of cloth other bring bottle of wine all want that they will have and bring what they want furnish their Mokisso with those thing whereof they complain themselves to be disfurnish their ceremony for the dead be diverse they bring goat and let they bleed at the mokisso foot which they after consume in a feast memorial of the decease party which be continue four or five day together and that four or five several time in the year by all of his friend and kindred the day be know and though they dwell twenty mile thence yet they will resort to these memoriall-exequy and beginning in the night will sing doleful and funeral song till day and then kill as aforesaid and make merry the hope of this make such as have store of friend to contemn death and the want of friend to bewail he make a man conceive a more dreadful apprehension of death their conceit be so ravish with superstition that many die of none other death kin be the name of unlawful and prohibit meat which accord to each kindred devotion to some family be some kind of fish to another a hen to another a buff and so of the rest in which they observe their vow abstinence so strict that if any shall though at unaware eat of his kin he will die of conceit always present to his accuse conscience the breach of his vow and the anger of Mokisso he have know diverse thus to have die and sometime will when some of they have eat with he make they believe that they have eat of their kin till have sport himself with their superstitious agony he will affirm the contrary they use to set in their field and place where corn or fruit grow a basket with goates-horne parrot feather and other trash this be the mokisso ensign or token that it be commend to his custody and therefore the people very much addict to theft dare not meddle or take any thing likewise if a man weary with his burden lay it down in the high way and knit a knot of grass and lay thereon or leave any other note know to they to testify that he have leave it there in the name of his idol it be secure from the lime-singer of any passenger conceit will kill the man that shall transgress in this kind in the Banza or chief city the chief idol be name chekoke every day they have there a market and the chekoke be bring forth by the Ganga or priest to keep good rule and be set in the market place to prevent steal moreover the king have a bell c c recovery of steal good the stroke whereof find such terror into the heart of the fearful thief that none dare keep any steal good after the sound of that bell. our author inhabit in a little reed house after the Lcango manner and have hang by the wall in a cloth case his piece wherewith he use to shoot fowl for the king which more for love of the cloth then for the piece be steal upon complaint this bell in form like a cow-bell be carry about and ring with proclamation to make restitution and he have his piece the next morning set at his door the like another find in a bag of bead of a hundred pound weight steal from he and recover by the sound of this bell. they have a dreadful and deadly kind of trial in controversy after this manner d d trial of suspect person there be a little tree or shrub with a small root it be call Imbunda about the bigness of one thumb half a foot long like a white carrot now when any list to accuse a man or family or whole street of the death of any of his friend say that such a man bewitch he the Ganga assemble the accuse party and scrape that root the scrape whereof he mix with water which make it as bitter as gall he taste of it one root will serve for the trial of hundred man the Ganga brew the same together in gourd and with plantain stalk hit every one after they have drink with certain word those that have receive the drink walk by till they can make urine and then they be thereby free other abide till either urine free they or dizziness take they which the people no soon perceive but they cry Vndoke Vndoke that be naughty witch and he be no soon fall by his dizziness but they knock he on the head and drag he away hurl he over the cliff in every liberty they have such trial which they make in case of theft and death of any person every week it fall out that some or other undergo this trial which cosume multitude of people there be certain person call which be bear of negro-parent and yet be by some unknown cause white they be very rare and when such happen to be bear they be bring to the king and become great witch they be his councillor and advise he of lucky and unlucky day for execution of his enterprise when the king go any whither the dundas go with he and beat the ground round about with certain exorcism before the king sit down and then sit down by he they will take any thing in the market none dare to contradict they be the land place of Loanga they have there a idol call Gumbiri and a holy house call keep and inhabit by a old woman where once a year be a solemn feast which they celebrate with drum dance and palme-wine and then they say he speak under the ground the people call he Mokissa Cola or a strong Mokisso and say that he come to stay with chekoke the idol of the Banza that chekoke be a negro-image make sit on a stool a little house be there make he they anoint he with Toccola which be a red colour make of a certain wood e e this seem to be red sander a. bat. say it be Log^ood ground on a stone and mix with water wherewith they daily paint themselves from the waste upward esteem it great beauty otherwise they account not themselves ready it be for like purpose carry from hence to angola sometime it fall out that some man or boy be take with some sudden enthusiasm or ravishment become mad and make a whoop and great clamour they call they mokisso-moquat that be take of the they clothe they very handsome and whatsoever they bid in that fit for it last not very long they execute as the mokissos charge Morumba be thirty league northwards from hence in the mani-loango's dominion where he live nine month there be a house and in it a great basket proportion like to a hive wherein be a image call Morumba who religion extend far they be swear to this religion at ten or twelve year old but for probation be first put in a house where they have hard diet and must be mute for nine or ten day any provocation to speak notwithstanding then do they bring he before Morumba and prescribe he his kin or perpetual abstinence from some certain meat they make a cut in his shoulder like to a half moon and sprinkle the blood at foot and swear he to that religion in the wound they put a certain white powder in token of his late admission which so long as it continue do privilege he to take his meat and drink with whosoever he please none deny he the same at free cost they also have their fatal trial before this image where the accuse party kneel down and clasp the hive say Mene bamba Morumba signify that he come thither to make trial of his innocence and if he be guilty he fall down dead be free he be free Andrew battle say he know six or seven in his be there that make this trial beyond the country of Loango be the anzigne f f od. Lopez l.1 ^5 the cruel cannibal which the sun look on for in other place they eat their enemy or their dead but here they take and eat their kinsfolk and countryfolk they keep shambles of man flesh as with we of beef and mutton they eat their enemy their slave if cut out they will yield they more in the several joint or piece then to be sell alive they kill though it be but to save a halfpenny some of they for weariness of life and some oh cruelty of vainglory even for valour of courage in contempt of death and esteem it a honourable proof of their fidelity and manhood will offer themselves to the butchery as faithful subject unto their prince of they to be consume and eat that with their death and after their death they may do they service these Anzichi stretch from Zaire to Nubia they have many mine of copper and great quantity of sanders red and gray wherewith mix with the oil of palmtree they anoint themselves the portugall temper it with vinegar for the heal of the french poke by the smoke thereof they drive away the headache it be incredible or at least will so seem to we which Lopez report that they carry their arrow which be short and slender of a very hard wood in the bow hand will shoot off eight and twenty so many they hold at once before the first of they fall to ground and with a short hatchet with a sudden whirl themselves about break the force of the enemy arrow and then hang this hatchet on their shoulder discharge their own arrow they be of great simplicity loyalty and fidelity and the portugall more trust they then any other slave they be yet savage and beastly and there be no converse with they but they bring slave of their own nation and out of Nubi^^o congo to sell for which they recarrie salt and shell which they use for Mon^ silk linen glass and such like they g g all the heathen nation in these part of Africa be circumcise circumcise themselves and beside that both man and woman both of the nobility and commonalty from their childhood mark their face with sundry slash make with a knife I ask say h h cap. 10 Lopez of their religion and it be tell i that they be gentile which be all I can learn of they they worship the sun for the great God as though it be a man and the moon next as though it be a woman otherwise every man choose to himself his own idol and worship it after his own pleasure the Anzichi i i ben. part. 1.l.3 have one king principal which have many prince under he of Ambus and northern region little beside the name be know Biafar be inhabit with people much addict to enchantment witchcraft and all abominable sorcery of the Giacchi we have make often mention and of their incursion into congo these in their own language be call agag as Lopez k k Lopez l.1.13 and l. 2.c.9 testify and live on both side of Nilus in the border of the empire of Mohenhe-Muge they use to mark themselves about the lip upon their cheek with certain line which they make with iron instrument and with fire moreover they have a custom to turn their eyelid backward so that their black skin white eye and cauterize mark seem to conspire a dreadful and ghastly deformity in their face they hold war with the l l these amazon be as we have observe doubt of in other place and andr. battle which travel near to those part deny this report of Lopez as untrue amazon and of late year have invade the neighbour nation their weapon be dart their food human flesh without all humanity devour Andrew battle m m andr. battle live by occasion of the portugall treachery with the lagge a long time than ever any christian or white man have do and serve they with his musket in their war neither can Lopez say he have true intelligence whence they come for the christian at that time have but uncertain conjecture of they neither after have the portugall any converse but by way of commerce but he be betray flee to they for his life and after by stealth escape from they the only european that ever live in their camp live amongst they sixteen month he say they be call jag by the Portugal by themselves Imbangolas and come from Sierra Liona this either be not the former nation but so call of like condition in manner and invasion of country or else these report agree not howsoever he affirm that they be exceed devourer of man flesh for which they refuse beef and goat whereof they take plenty they have no settle habitation but wander in a unsettle course they rise in harvest and invade some country there stay as long as they find the palm or other sufficient mean of maintenance and then seek new adventure for they neither plant nor sow nor breed up cattle and which be more strange they nourish up none of their own child although they have ten or twenty wife a man of the proper and comely slave they can take but when they be in travail they dig a hole in the earth which present receive in that dark prison of death the newborn creature not yet make happy with the light of life their reason be that they will not be trouble with education nor in their flit wander be trouble with such cumbersome burden once a secret providence both punish the father wickedness and prevent a viperous generation if that may be a prevention where there be a succession without generation and as Pliny n n plin l. 5.c.17 say of the Esseni gens aelerna in for of the conquer nation they preserve the boy from ten to twenty year of age and bring they up as the hope of their succession like negro-azimogli o o Azimogli be the child of christian ta^^^^ from the parent by the Turk the spawn of their janissary with education fit their design these wear a collar about their neck in token of slavery until they bring a enemy head slay in battle and then be they uncollare free and dignify with the title of soldier if one of they run away he be kill and eat so that hem in betwixt hope and fear they grow very resolute and adventurous their collar breed shame disdain and desperate fury till they redeem their freedom as you have hear the great jagge bring with he twelve thousand of these cruel monster from Sierra Liona and after much mischief and spoil settle himself in benguele twelve degree from the line southwards and there breed and grow into a nation but Kelandula sometime his page proceed in that beastly life before mention and the people of Elembe by great troop run to he and follow his camp in hope of spoil they have no fetisso or idol the great jagge or prince be master of all their ceremony and be a great witch I have see this Kelandula say our author continue a sacrifice from sun to sun the rite where of be these himself sit on a stool in great pomp with a cap adorn with peacock feather which fowl in one country call Shelambanza be find wild and in one place empale about the grave of the king be fifty keep and feed by a old woman and be call Ingilla Mokisso that be bird of Mokisso now about he thus set attend forty or fifty woman each of they wear continual a Zebras tail in their hand there be also certain gangas priest or witch behind they be many with drum and pipe and Pungas certain instrument make of elephant tooth make hollow a yard and half and with a hole like a flute which yield a loud and harsh sound that may be hear a mile off these strike and sound and sing and the woman weave as be say till the sun be almost down then they bring forth a pot which be set on the fire with leave and root and water therein and with a kind of white powder the witch or gangas spot themselves one on the one cheek the other on the other and likewise their forehead temple breast shoulder and belly use many enchant term which be hold to be prayer for victory at sunset a Ganga bring his Kissengula or warre-hatchet to the prince this weapon they use to wear at their girdle and put the same in his hand bid he be strong their god go with he and he shall have victory after this they bring he four or five negro of which with a terrible countenance the great jagge with his hatchet kill two and other two be kill without the fort. likewise five cow be slay within and other five without the fort and as many goat and as many dog after the same manner this be their sacrifice at the end whereof all the flesh be in a feast consume Andrew battle be command to depart when the slaughter begin for their devil or Mokisso as they say will then appear and speak to they this sacrifice be call Kissembula which they solemnize when they attempt any great enterprise there be few leave of the natural jag but of this unnatural brood the present succession be raise now that we have thus discourse John Castro g g joh. di Castro afterward viceroy of India sail to the bottom of the straight as far as suez and much labour to find the cause why it shall be call the h h the scripture often mention this sea but call it as Tremel and jun. translate or after Vatablus Carectosum of the weed plentiful grow therein exod. 10.18 etc. red sea. he in his map of these part say that he see therein many such red space of water but take up the water in a vessel out of the sea it seem clear and more crystalline than that without the straits he cause also some to dive which do bring he out of the sandy bottom a red matter branch like coral and some like orange in other place where be green spot in the sea be take out green branch and where the sea be white the sand there-und be very white and though the depth in some place amount to twenty fathom yet the purity of the crystalline water cause this transparent colour near to Suachen he find most of those spot and from thence to Alcocer the space of four hundred mile but near the bottom towards suez in a great space he see none further without the straight he see such red i i Lewis de Vrreta say that the sand on the shore and that the mountain be red which the sun shine on and by reflection of the beam cause that redness hist. Eth^op l. 1.c.11 spot or vein of water at cape Fartach as if ox have be slay there yet the water take up in a vessel seem clear and he suppose that this redness proceed of the whale bring forth their young barrius mislike that conjecture and those other of antiquity in search the cause of this name of red and be of opinion that the violent current of the tide assist with some tempestuous wind raise up from the bottom that red floor whereof we have speak and cause by the motion of the same under the water that redness in the upper face thereof which be in more spacious quantity near the straits where there be great force of the tide and the thread or strain of this redness be less in the great and more spacious sea-room the Portugal pilot first thought that the wind bring out red dust from the dry soil of Arabia which no man experience have confirm Andrea k k a. exceed drink they first sleep and after boil it to that end in some place they first cause it to be champ with maid in some place with old woman and then make a leaven thereof which they boil and make this inebriate drink the cane and leave serve for their mole to eat they boil and drink it also for pain in the back the bud of mays serve in flee of butter and oil in some part they make bread of a great root call Yuca which they name they first cut and strain it in a press for the juice be deadly poison the cake dry be sleep in water before they can eat they another kind there be of this Yuca or jucca the juice whereof be not poison it will keep long like biscuit they use this bread most in hispaniola Cuba and jamaica where wheat and mays will not grow but so unequal that at one some be in the grass other in the grain they use in some place another root call Papas like to ground nut for bread which they call Chuno of other their root and first-fruit I be loath to write lest I weary the Zeni gather out of their letter by Francisco Marcolino they be relate by m. hakluyt in his 3. vol part. 121 in the year 1380 master Nicolo zeno be wealthy and of a haughty spirit desire to see the fashion of the world build and furnish a ship at his own charge and pass the straits of Gibraltar hold on his course northwards with intent to see England and Flanders but a violent tempest assail he at sea he be carry he know not whither till at last his ship be cast away upon the isle of Friesland where the man and most part of the good be save in vain seem that delivery that deliver up present to another executioner the islander like Neptune hungry groom or base and black guard set upon the man who the sea have spare but here also they find a second escape by mean of a prince name prince of that and many land thereabouts who be near hand with his army come at the outcry and chase away the people take they into protection this have the year before give the overthrow to the king of Norway and be a great adventurer in feat of arm he speak to they in latin and place they in his navy wherewith he win diverse land Nicole behave himself so well both in save the fleet by his sea-skill and in conquest of the land by his valour that Zichmui make he knight and captain of his navy after diverse notable exploit Nicolo arm three bark with which he arrive in Engroneland where he find a monastery of friar of the preacher order and a church dedicate to saint Thomas hard by a hill that cast out fire like Vessvius and Aetna there be a fountain of hot water with which they heat the church of the monastery and the friar chamber it come also into the kitchen so boil hot that they use no other fire to dress their meat and put their bread into brass pot without any water it do bake as it be in a hot oven they have also small garden which be cover over in the winter time and be water with this water be defend from the violence of the frost and cold and bring forth flower in their due season the common people astonish with these strange effect conceive high of those friar and bring they present of flesh and other thing they with this water in the extremity of the cold heat their chamber which also as the other building of the monastery be frame of those burn stone which the mouth of the hill cast forth they cast water on some of they whereby they be dissolve and become excellent white lime and so tough that be contrive in building it last for ever the rest after the fire be out serve in stead of stone to make wall and vault and will not dissolve or break except with some iron tool their winter last nine month and yet there be a fair haven where this water fall into the sea not freeze by mean whereof there be great resort of wild fowl and fish which they take in infinite multitude the fisher boat be make like to a weaver shuttle of the skin of fish fashion with the bone of the same fish and be sow together with many double they be so strong that in foul weather they will shut themselves within the same not fear the force either of sea or wind neither can the hard-hearted rock break these yield vessel they have also as it be a sleeve in the bottom thereof by which with a subtle devise they convey the water forth that soak into they the most of these friar speak the latin tongue a little after this Nicole return and die in Friesland whither his brother Antonio have before resort to he and now succeed both in his good and honour who Zichmni employ in the expedition for Estotiland which happen upon this occasion six and twenty year before four fisher-boat be apprehend at sea by a mighty and tedious storm wherewith after many day they be bring to Estotiland above a thousand mile west from Friesland upon which one of the boat be cast away and six man that be in it be take and bring to a populous city where one that speak latin and have be cast by chance upon that island in the name of the king ask they what countryman they be and understand their case he acquaint the king therewith they dwell there five year and find it to be a island very rich be little less than Iseland but far more fruitful one of they say see latin book in the king library which they at this present do not understand they have a peculiar language and letter or character to themselves they have mine of gold and other metal and have trade with Engroneland they sow corn and make beer and ale. they build bark but know not the use of the compass and have many city and castle the king send these fisherman with twelve bark southwards to a country which they call Drogio in which voyage escape dreadful tempest at sea they encounter with cannibal at land which devour many of they these fisher show they the manner of take fish with net escape and for the present which they make of their fish to the chief man of the country be belove and honour one of these more expert it seem than the rest be hold in such account that a great lord make war with their lord to obtain he and so prevail that he and his company be send unto he and in this order be he send to five and twenty lord which have war one with another to get he in thirteen year space whereby he come to know almost all those part which he say be a great country and as it be a new world. the people be all rude and void of goodness they go naked neither have they wit to cover their body with the beast skin which they take in hunt from the vehement cold they be fierce and eat their enemy have diverse law and governor their live be by hunt further to the south-west they be more civil and have a more temperate air they have city and temple dedicate to idol where they sacrifice man and after eat they and have also some use of gold and silver he flee away secret and convey himself from one lord to another come at length to Drogio where he dwell three year after this time find there certain boat of Estotiland he go thither with they and grow there very rich furnish a bark of his own and return into Friesland where he make report unto his lord of that wealthy country Zichumi prepare to send thither but three day before they set forth this fisherman die yet take some of the mariner which come with he in his stead they prosecute the voyage and encounter after many day a island where tenene man of diverse language be bring unto they of which they can understand none but one of Iseland he tell they that the island be call icaria and the king thereof call descend of the ancient pedigree of Dedalus king of scot who conquer that island leave his son there for king and leave they those law which to that present they retain and that they may keep their law inviolate they will receive no stranger only they be content to receive one of our man in regard of the language as they have do those ten interpreter Zichumi sail hence in four day descry land where they find abundance of fowl and bird egg for their refresh the haven they call cape trin. there be a hill which burn cast out smoke where be a spring from which issue a certain water like pitch which run into the sea. the people of small stature wild and fearful hide themselves in cave Zichumi build there a city and determine to inhabit send Antonio back again with the most of his people to Friesland this history I have thus insert at large which perhaps not without cause in some thing may seem fabulous not in the Zeni which thus write but in the relation which they receive from other howsoever the best geographer d d Abrah ortel ch^rt 6. George best all which at large the reader may find in m. hackluyt laborious discovery of discovery to speak brief what may best befit we in our pilgrimage sir Martin Frobisher sail from Blackwall june the fifteen and the eleven of july * * 1576. have sight of Friesland but can not get on shore for the abundance of ice which be also accompany with a extreme fog as double guard to that island uncertain whether to fortify or to imprison they the twenty of july he have sight of a high land which he name q q queen foreland and opposite thereto halls isle in 62. degree 50. min. Elizabeth foreland here be he much trouble with ice but sail more northerly descry another foreland with a great gut bay or passage which he enter call it frobishers straits suppose it to be the division of Asia and America have enter threescore league he go on shore and be encounter with mighty deer which run at he with danger of his life here have he sight of the savage which row to his ship in boat of seal skin with a keel of wood within they like a spanish shallop save only they be flat in the bottom and sharp at both end they eat raw flesh and fish or rather devo^ red the same ^^^ have long black hair broad face flat nose tawny of colour or like a olive which neither sun or wind but nature itself imprint on they as appear by their infant and seem to be the general livery of America their apparel be seal skin their woman be paint or mark down the cheek and about the eye with blue streeke these savage intercept five of our man and the boat we also take one of they which they bring into England where they arrive the second of October r r Gaspar l. 2 hist. ind. because the ice be fresh and the sun melt the top cause rill of fresh water to run down which meet together make a pretty stream or river and with the summer sun be loose and break out of their natural prison offer themselves to all outrage whereto the swift current and cold wind will conduct they strange it be to see their greatness some not less than half a mile about and fourscore fathom westward the people resemble much the tartar or rather the samoed in apparel and manner of live it be cold here in 62. then 9 or 10. degree more northerly towards the north-east which it seem come to pass by the wind east and north-east which from the ice bring so intolerable a cold the people be excellent archer a thing general throughout America beside seal skin they use the skin of deer bear fox and hare for apparel and the case also of fowl sow together they wear in summer the hairy outward in winter inward or else go naked they shoot at the fish with their dart they kindle fire with rub one stick against another they use great black dog like wolf to draw their sled and a less kind to eat they have very thin beard in the best of summer they have hail and snow sometime a foot deep which freeze as it fall and the ground freeze three fathom deep they have great store of fowl whereof our man kill in one day fifteen hundred they have thick skin and be thick of down and feather then seem they feed on the grass by their dung which be like to horse-dung they hear dog howl on the shore which be tame they kill one with a collar about his neck he have a bone in his pisle these it seem be use to the sled for they find two sled the next year he make his second voyage wherein he find the savage people tractable they be great idolater and witch they have many image which they wear about they and in their boat they find a grave wherein be many bury cover with seales skin and a cross lay over they one of they make a fire of turf kindle with the motion of a stick in a piece of a board which have a hole half through into which he put many thing with diverse word and strange gesture our man suppose it to be a sacrifice they will have have one of the english to stand in the smoke which themselves be bid to do and will not by any mean whereupon one of they be thrust in and the fire put out by our man they be very thievish they catraw fish grass and ice and drink salt water here they see a whirlwind take up the water in great quantity furious mount it up into the air three hour together with little intermission they find in 63. deg. 8. min. a strange quantity of ice in one entire mass so big that they know not the limit thereof very high in form of land with bay and cape like high-cliffe land they send their pinnace to discover it which return with information that it be only ice this be the seventeen of july 1586. and they coast it till the thirty of july in 66. deg. 33. min. they find it very hot and be much trouble with a sting fly call jaq. car. 2. cap 10. cartier in one which they call Cudruaigni who say they often speak to they and tele they what weather will follow whether good or bad moreover when he be angry with they he cast dust into their eye they believe that when they die they go into the star and thence by little and little descend down into the horizon even as the star do after which they go into certain green field full of goodly fair and precious tree flower and first-fruit the frenchman tell they Cudruaigni be a devil and acquaint they with some mystery of the christian religion whereupon they condescend and desire baptism the french excuse and promise after to bring priest for that purpose they live in common together and of such commodity as their country yield they be well store they wed two or three wife a man which their husband be dead never marry again but for their widow livery wear a black weed all the day of their life besmear their face with coaldust and grease mingle together as thick as the back of a knife they have a filthy and detestable use in marry their maiden first put they be once of lawful age to marry in a common place as harlot free for every man that will have to do with they until such time as they find a match I have see house as full of such prostitute as the school in France be full of child they there use much misrule riot and wantonness they dig their ground with certain piece of wood as big as half a sword where they sow their maiz. the man also do much use tobacco the woman labour more than the man in fish and husbandry they be more hardy than the beast and will come to our ship stark naked go upon snow and ice in which season they take great store of beast stag bear Marterns hare and fox who flesh they eat raw have first dry it in the sun or smoke and so they do their fish they have also otter weasils beavers badgers coney foul and fish great variety and one fish call Adhothuis who body and head be like to a greyhound white as snow their great jewel be chain of Esurgny which be shellfish exceed white which they take on this manner when a captive or other man be condemn to death they kill he and then cut flash in his most fleshy part and hurl he into the river Cornibots whence after twelve hour they draw he find in those cut these Esurgny whereof they make bead and chain they be excellent for staunch of blood thus much out of cartier Champlein have of late make the same voyage discourse with certain savage yet live of who he learn touch their religion that they believe in one GOD who have create all thing that after GOD have make all thing he take a number of arrow and do stick they into the ground from whence man and woman spring up which have multiply ever since touch the trinity be ask a sagamo or governor answer z z the answer of a sagamo in case of religion there be one only GOD one SONNI one mother and the sun which be four notwithstanding a a this somewhat agree with the manichean and pythagorcan error that GOD be over and above all the son be good and the sun also but the mother be naught and do eat they and that the father be not very good be ask if they or their ancestor have hear that GOD be come into the world he say that he have not see he but that ancient there be five man who travel towards the set of the sun meet with GOD who demand of they whither go you they answer we go to seek for our live GOD say you shall find it here but they not regard pass further and then GOD with a stone touch two of they who be turn into stone and he say a gain to the three other whither go you they answer and he reply as at first they yet pass further he take two staff and touch therewith the two foremost and transform they into staff ask the three man whither he go he say to seek his live whereupon he bid he tarry and he do so and GOD give he meat and he do eat and after he have make good cheer he return among the other savage and tell they all this tale this sagamo also tell that at another time there be a man which have store of tobacco and GOD come and ask he for his pipe which the man give he and he drink much of it and then break the pipe the man be offend hereat believe he have no more pipe but GOD give he one and bid he carry it to his sagamo with warning to keep it well and then he shall want nothing nor any of he since the say sagamo lose the pipe and find famine and other distress this seem to be the cause why they say GOD be not very good be demand what ceremony they use in pray to their god he say that they use no ceremony but every one do pray in his heart as he will they have among they some savage who they call Pilotova who speak visible to the devil and he tell they what they must do as well for war as for other thing and if he shall command they to put any enterprise in execution or to kill a man they will do it immediate they because also that all their dream be true so far Champlein in the year 1604. de Monts accord to a patent grant he the year before for the both in stone and wood as well as the workman in these part they as be say ascribe not divine worship to any thing but yet acknowledge some spiritual and invisible power I know not by what divine justice and injustice of the devil it come to pass that God have give some man up so far unto the devil tyranny that he have banish out of their heart the knowledge and worship of the true God and yet the nature of man can be without apprehension of some great and more excellent nature and rather than want all religion they will have a religious-irreligious commerce with the devil yea the more all knowledge of God be banish the base service do man in do and suffer yield to the devil as to leave other part to their own place it fall out in these region the prince and great commander of man among they seem by this mean to be the devil vicegerent and by wisardly and devilish practice to up-hold his own greatness so it be with sagamo Memberton if any body be sick he be send for he make invocation on the devil he blow upon the party grieve make incision suck the blood from it a practice use in very many country of the continent and land of America if it be a wound he heal it after the same manner apply a round slice of beavers stone some present be therefore make to he of venison or skin if it be a question to have news of thing absent have first question with his spirit he render his oracle common doubtful very often false and sometime true he render a true oracle of the come of poutrincourt to Pont say his devil have tell he so when the savage be hungry they consult with memberton oracle and he tell they the place whither they shall go and if there be no game find the excuse be that the beast have wander and change place but very often they find and he make they believe that the devil be a god and know none other although they yield he no adoration when these aoutmoin so they call these wizard consult with the devil they fix a staff in a pit to which they tie a cord and put their head into the pit make invocation or conjuration in a language unknown to the other that be about and this with beat and howl until they sweat with pain when this devil be come the master Aoutmoin make they believe that he hold he tie by his cord and hold fast against he force he to give he a answer before he let he go that do he begin to sing something in the praise as it seem of the devil that have discover some game unto they and the other savage that be there make answer with some concordance of music among they then they dance with song in another not vulgar language after which they make a fire and leap over it and put half a pole out of the top of the cabin where they be with some thing tie thereto which the devil carry away Memberton carry at his neck the mark of his profession which be a purse trianglewise cover with their embroider work within which there be somewhat as big as a nut which he say be his devil call this function be successive and by tradition they teach their elder son the mystery of this iniquity every * * sagamo signify a king or ruler sagamo either be or have his aoutmoin the man and woman wear their black hair long hang loose over the shoulder wherein the man stick a feather the woman a bodkin they be much trouble with a sting fly for prevention where ^^ they rub themselves with certain kind of grease and oil they paint their face with blue or red but not their body for their marriage they be contract with the consent of parent who will not give their daughter in marriage to any except he be a good hunter the woman be say to be chaste and the contrary seldom find and though the husband have many wife yet be there no jealousy among they the widow here if their husband be kill will not marry again nor eat flesh till their death be revenge otherwise they make no great difficulty which cartier report of canada to marry again if they find a fit match sometime the savage have many wife will give one to their friend if he like she so to disburden themselves the woman eat not with the man in their meeting but apart when they make feast they end they with dance all in a round to which one sing at the end of every song all make a loud and long exclamation and to be the more nimble they strip themselves stark naked if they have any of their enemy head or arm they will carry they as a jewel about their neck while they dance sometime bite the same after their feast they will diet themselves live sometime eight day more or less with the smoke of tobacco they be in nothing laborious but in hunt they sow but so much as will serve they for six month and that very hardly during the winter they retire three or four month space into the wood and there live on acorn fish and venison they wash not themselves at meal except they be monstrous foul and then wipe on their own or their dog hair their entertainment be with small compliment the guest sit down by his host if it be the king take tobacco and then give the pipe to he that he think the worthy person in the company they be dutiful to their parent obey their commandment and nourish their person in age they use humanity to the wife and child of their conquer enemy but the man of defence they kill their chief hunt be in winter they carry always tinderbox with they to strike fire when hunt be do or night take they for they follow the game sometime three day together their dog be like fox which spend not never give over and have racket tie under their foot the better to run on the snow they see the flesh in a tub of wood by put stone heat red hot therein the woman duty be to flay the beast and bring it home the ellan door stag and bear be their game they take also with their hand bever which be of a chest-nut colour short legged his forefoot have open claw the hinder fin like a goose the tail scale almost of the form of a solefish it be the delicate part of the beast the head be short and round with two rank of jaw at the side and before four great tooth two above and two beneath with which he cut down small tree he build on the brink of a lake cut his wood there with raise a vault and because the water sometime rise he have a upper story to betake himself to in such case he build it pyramide-wise sometime eight foot high and daub it with mud he keep his tail still in the water they take he with their hand in a frost one fray he on the ice while a other seize on his neck when one die they mourn for he long every cabin his day by course after that they burn all his good and bury the body in a grave where when they have place he every one make a present of the best thing he have as skin to cover he bow knife or the like the scurvy or scorbuch much consume the french in these part a disease that usual attend evil diet and much salt meat which and want of exercise convenient be the harbinger of this sickness ol. mag. l.16 cap. 51 in long siege and navigation Cartiers company be in a little time after come to five principal navigable river the mountain be of diverse composition some like millstone some of marble and many piece of crystal they find throw down by the water which also wash from swine a tail like a rat as big as a cat and have under her belly a bag wherein she carry her young their dog bark not their wolf be not much big than our fox their fox be like our siluer-haired coney and smell not like we they have eagle hawk wild turkey and other fowl and fish which here to repeat will to some nice fastidious stomach breed a fullness they be a people o o though hariot clothe with be most monstrous their woman embroider their leg hand etc. with diverse work as of serpent and such like with black spot in the flesh their house be make of small pole make fast at the top in round form as be use in many arbour with we cover with bark or mat twice as long as they be broad chap. 5 of the religion and rite of the virginian now for the manner and rite of the people thus have master hariot a a tho. hariot Hak. 10.3.p.277 report they believe that there be many god which they call Mantoac but of different sort and degree one only chief and great God which have be from all eternity who as they affirm when he purpose to make the world make first other god of a principal order to be as mean and instrument to be use in the creation and government to follow and after the sun moon and star as petty god and the instrument of the other order more principal first they say be make water out of which by the god be make all diversity of creature that be visible or invisible for mankind they say a woman be make first which by the work of one of the god conceive and bring forth child and in such sort they say they have their beginning but how many year or age have pass since they say they can make no relation have no letter nor other mean to keep record of time past but only tradition from father to son they think that all the god be of human shape and therefore they represent they by image in the form of man which they call kewasowok one alone be call Kewas they they place in house or temple which they call Machicomuck where they worship pray sing and make many time offering unto they in some Machicomuck we have see but one Kewas in some two in other three they believe the immortality of the soul that after this life as soon as the soul be depart from the body accord to the work it have do it be either carry to haeven the habitacle of god there to enjoy perpetual bliss and happiness or else to a great pit or hole which they think to be in the further part of their part of the world towards the sunset there to burn continual this place they call Popogusso for the confirmation of this opinion they tell tale of man dead and revive again much like to the popish legend thus they tell of one who grave the next day after his burial be see to move and his body be therefore take up again who report that his soul have be very near the enter into Popogusso have not one of the god save he and give he leave to return again and teach his friend how to avoid that terrible place they tell of a other which be take up in that manner relate that his soul be alive while his body be in the grave and that it have travail far in a long broad way on both side whereof grow most delicate pleasant tree bear more rare and excellent first-fruit then ever he have see before or be able to express and at length come to most brave and fair house near which he meet his father that have be dead before who give he great charge to go back again and show his friend what good they be to do to enjoy the pleasure of that place which when he have do he shall after come again what subtlety soever be in their Wiroances b b Wiroance be a chief lord or petty king which sometime have but one town and none that we have deal with have above eighteen town under he and priest the vulgar be hereby very respective to their governor and careful of their manner although they have also in criminal case punishment inflict accord to the quality of the offence this I learn by special familiarity with some of their priest wherein they be not so sure ground but that they lend open ear to we with doubt of their own the c c tho. bry. in pictur priest in Secota have their hair on the crown like a comb the rest be cut from it only a foretop on the forehead be leave and that comb they have a garment of skin peculiar to their function they be great wizard our artificial work firework gun write and such like they esteem the work of god rather than of man or at least teach we by the gods. they bear much respect to our bible when the wiroan be sick he send to we to pray for he some be of opinion that we be not mortal nor bear of woman but that we be man of a old generation many year past then rise again to immortality some will likewise seem to prophesy that there be more of our generation yet to come to kill they and take their place which be now in the air invisible and without body and that they by our entreaty do make man to die which have wrong we they have d d first voyage to Virginia Hak. tom.3.249 their idol in the inner-most room of their house of who they tell incredible thing they carry it with they when they go to the war and ask counsel thereof as the roman do of their oracle they sing song as they march towards the battle in stead do more hurt then while we be alive they use to solemnize certain moneths-minde in their savage manner for any great personage dead james f f james rosier rosier from the relation of Owen Griffin a eyewitness thus tell of their ceremony one among they the elder as he judge rise right up the other sit still and look about sudden cry with a loud voice baugh waugh then the woman fall down and lie upon the ground and the man all together answer the same fall a stamp round about the fire with both foot as hard as they can make the ground shake with sundry out-cry and change of voice and sound many take the fire-sticks and thrust they into the earth and then rest a while of a sudden they begin as before and continue so stamp till the young sort fetch from the shore many stone of which every man take one and first beat upon they with their fire-sticks then with the stone beat the earth with all their strength and in this manner they continue above two hour after this end they which have wife take they apart and withdraw themselves several into the wood this seem to be their evening devotion when they g g theod. de bry Icone 17.18 and seq. have obtain some great deliverance from danger or return from war they observe a public and solemn rejoice by make a great fire encompass with the man and woman promiscuous all of they with rattle in their hand make a great noise they hold one time in the year festival and then they meet together out of many village every one have a certain mark or character on his back whereby it may be discern who subject he be the place where they meet be spacious and round about be set post carve with the resemblance of a nun head in the midd be three of the fair virgin love embrace and clasp each other about this live centre and artificial circle they dance in their savage manner their idol call Kiwasa be make of wood four foot high the face resemble the inhabitant of Florida paint with flesh colour the breast white the other part black except the leg which be spot with white he have chain or string of bead about his neck this idol be in Socota as it be the keeper of the dead body of their king in their temple be house of public three grain of wheat and after they have thus lay down six or seven hundred in one circle account their song by grain as the papist their orison by bead they make two or three other circle in like manner and put at the end of every song betwixt every two or three or five grain a little stick the high priest disguise with a great skin his head hang round with little skin of weasils and other the swine which be offend with they the chief God they worship be the devil which they call oak they have conference with he and fashion themselves unto his shape in their temple they have his image ill-savoured make paint adorn with chain copper and bead and cover with a skin by he be common the sepulchre of their king who body be first bowel then dry on a hurdle and have about the joint chain of copper bead and other like trash then lap in white skin and roll in mat and orderly entomb in arch make of mat the remnant of their wealth be set at their foot these temple and body be keep by their priest for their ordinary burial they dig a deep hole in the earth with sharp stake and the corpse be wrap in skin and mat with their jewel they lay they upon stick in the ground and cover they with earth the burial end the woman have their face paint with black coal and oil sit four and twenty hour in the house mourn and lament by turn with yell and howl every territory of a Weroance have their temple and priest their principal temple be at Vttamussack in pamaunk where powhatan have a house upon the top of certain sandy hill in the wood there be three great house fill with image of their king and devil and tomb of their predecessor those house be near threescore foot long build after their fashion arbour-wise this place be in such estimation of holiness that none but the priest and king dare enter yea the savage dare not pass by in boat without cast copper bead or somewhat into the river here be common resident seven priest the chief differ from the rest in his ornament the other can hardly be know from the common people but that they have not so many hole at their ear to hang their jewel at the high-priest head-tire be thus make they take a great many snake skin stuff with moss as also of weasils and other vermin skin which they tie by their tail so that all the tail meet on the top of the head like a great tassel the face of their priest be paint as ugly as they can devise in their hand they have rattell some base some treble their devotion be most in song which the chief priest begin the rest follow sometime he make invocation with break sentence by start and strange passion and at every pause the other give a short groan it can be perceive that they have any set holy day only in some great distress of want fear of enemy time of triumph and of gather their first-fruit the whole country man woman and child assemble to their solemnity the manner of their devotion be sometime to make a great fire all sing and dance about the same with rattle and shout four or five hour sometime they set a man in the midst and dance and sing about he he all the while clap his hand as if he will keep time after this they go to their feast they have certain altar-stone which they call pawcorance stand from their temple some by their house other in the wood and wilderness upon which they offer blood deer-suet and tobacco this they do when they return from the war from their hunt and on other occasion when the water be rough in storm their conjurer run to the water side or pass in their boat and after many hellish out-cry and invocation cast tobacco copper Pocones or such trash into the water to pacify that GOD who they think to be very angry in those storm before their dinner and supper the better sort will take the first bit and cast it into the fire which be all the grace they be know to use in some part of the country they have yearly a sacrifice of child such a one be perform at Quiyonghcohanock some ten mile from james-towne in this manner fifteen of the proper young boy between ten and fifteen year of age they paint white have bring they forth the people spend the forenoon in dance and sing about they with rattle in the afternoon they put these child to the root of a tree all the man stand to guard they each with a bastinado of reed bind together in his hand then do they make a lane between they all along through which there be appoint five young man to fetch these child each of these fetch a child the guard lay on with their bassinadoe while they with their naked body defend the child to their great smart all this time the woman weep and cry out very passionate provide mosle skin mat and dry wood as thing fit the child funeral when the child be in this manner fetch away the guard tear down tree branch and bough make wreath for their head or bedeck their hair with the leaf what else be do with the child be not see but they be all cast on a heap in a valley as dead where be make a great feast for all the company the Werowance be demand the meaning of this sacrifice answer that the child be not all dead but that the oak or devil do suck the blood from their left breast who chance to be his by lot till they be dead but the rest be keep in the wilderness by the young man till nine moon be expire during which time they must not converse with any and of these be make their priest and conjurer this sacrifice they hold to be so necessary that if they shall omit it their oak or devil and their other quiyoughcosughe or god will let they have no dear turkey corn or fish and will beside make a great slaughter amongst they they think that their werowance and priest which they also esteem quiyoughcosughe when they be dead do go beyond the mountain towards the set of the sun and ever remain there in form of their oak have their head paint with oil and Pocones m m Pocones be a small root which dry and beat into powder turn red they use it for swell ache and paint fine trim with feather and shall have bead hatchet copper and tobacco never cease to dance and sing with their predecessor the common people they suppose shall not live after death some seek to convert they from these superstition
