S.A.T.W.R.N.P.W.P.R.W.R.P.etc when our man pray accord to their daily custom and sing a psalm they much wonder and after begin in most passionate manner to hold up their hand to the sun with a song then embrace the captain they begin to adore he in like manner and so proceed notwithstanding his rebuke they till their song be end which do one with a most strange action and uncomely voice begin a oration of their love that end with a great paint bear skin they cover the captain another hang about his neck a chain of white bead other lay eighteen mantle at his foot with many other ceremony to create he their governor that he may defend they against the massa-womekes their enemy as these be very great so the wighcocomocoe be very little I may also here insert the ridiculous conceit which some virginian hold concern their first original as I have hear from the relation of a english p p cap. Argoles boy his name be Henry Spilman youth which live long amongst the savage that a hare come into their country and make the first man and after preserve they from a great serpent and when two other hare come thither that hare for their entertainment kill a dear which be then the only dear that be and strew the hair of that dee hide every hair prove a dear he say they worship towards a certain hoop or sphere double across which be set upon a heap of stone in their house they have a house without the town for the woman in the time of their natural sickness to keep in where no man may come the virginian q q cap. smith m.s. be bear white their hair black few have beard the woman with two shell be their barber they be strong nimble and hardy inconstant timorous quick of apprehension cautelous covetous of copper and bead they seldom forget a injury and seldom steal from each other lest the conjurer shall bewray they which it be sufficient that these think they can do they have their land and garden in proper and most of they live of their labour in each ear common they have three great hole whereat they hang chain bracelet or copper some wear in those hole a small snake colour green and yellow near half a yard long which crawl about his neck offer to kiss his lip other wear a dead rat tie by the tail their name be give they accord to the humour of the parent their woman they say be easy deliver they wash in the river their young infant to make they hardy the woman and child do the household and field-worke the man disdain the same and only delight in fish hunt war and such manlike exercise the woman plant reap bear burden pound their corn make basket pot their bread and do their cookery and other business powhatan have above thirty commander or wirrowance under he all which be not in peace only but serviceable in captain smith presidency to the english and still as I have be tell by some that have since be there they do affect he and will ask of he powhatan have three brother and two sister to who the inheritance belong successive and not to his or their son till after their death and then the elder sister son inherit he have his treasure of skin copper pearl bead and such like keep in a house for that purpose and there store against the time of his burial this house be fifty or threescore yard long frequent only by priest at the four corner of this house stand four image as sentinel one of a dragon a other of a bear a three of a leopard and the four of a giant he have as many woman as he will which when he be weary of he bestow on who he best like his will and custom be the law he execute civil punishment on malefactor as broil to death be encompass with fire and other torture the other wirowance or commander so the word signify have power of life and death and have some twenty man some forty some a hundred some many more under their command some be send to inquire for those which be leave of sir Walter rawleighs the city where watchman always be set for defence their house be round their apparel nakedness except a beast skin or some ornament of moss about their secret part they paint and raze their skin with great cunning the smart make they sick seven or eight day after they rub over those raze work with a certain herb which colour the fame so as it can be do away they paint their face and their skin cunning this Morgues a painter be judge even to admiration they let the nail on their toe and finger grow long they be tall nimble comely they war q q laudonniere always one country upon another and kill all the man they can take the woman and child they bring up they cut off the hair of the head together with the skin and dry it to reserve the same as a monument of their valour after their return from the war if they be victorious they make a solemn feast which last three day with dance and song to the honour of the sun for the sun and moon be their deity their priest be magician also and physician with they they have many hermaphrodite which be put to great drudgery and make to bear all their carriage in necessity they will eat coal and put sand in their pottage three month in the year they forsake their house and live in the wood against this time they have make their provision of victual dry the same in the smoke they meet in consultation every morning in a great common house whither the king resort and his senator which after salutation sit down in a round they consult with the jawas or priest. and after this they drink cassine which be very hot make of the leaf of a certain tree which none may taste that bath not before make his valour evident in the war it set they in a sweat and take away hunger and thirst four and twenty hour after when a king die they bury he very solemn and upon his grave they set the cup wherein he be wont to drink and round about the grave they stick many arrow weep and fast three day together without cease all the king which be his friend make the like mourn and in token of their love cut off half their hair which they otherwise wear long knit up behind both man and woman during the space of six moon so they reckon their month there be certain woman appoint which bewail his death cry with a loud voice thrice a day at morning noon and evening all the good of this king be put into his house which afterward they set on fire the like be do with the good of the priest who be bury in their house and then both house and good burn the woman r r Morgues icon. 18 19 that have lose their husband in the war present themselves before the king sit on their heel with great lamentation sue for revenge and they with other widow spend some day in mourn at their husband grave and carry thither the cup wherein he have wont to drink they cut also their hair near the ear strew the same in the sepulchre there they cast also their weapon they may not marry again till their hair be grow that it may cover their shoulder when any be sick they lay he flat on a form and with a sharp shell rase off the skin of his forehead suck out the blood with their mouth spit it out into some vessel the woman that give suck or be great with child come to drink the same especial if it be of a lusty young man that their milk may be better and the child thereby nourish may be strong ribault s s icon. 8 at his first be there have fix a in the mid they dry the arm and leg and crown of their enemy which they have slay to make solemn triumph at their return which they do fasten they on pole pitch in the ground the man and woman sit round about and the magician with a image in his hand mumble curse against the enemy over against he be three man kneel one of which beat a stone with a club and answer the magician at every of his imprecation the other two sing and make a noise with certain rattle they sow or set their corn rather as in Virginia and have two seede-time and two harvest which they bring into a public barn or common store-house as they do the rest of their victual none fear to be beguile of his neighbour thus do these barbarian enjoy that content attend with sobriety and simplicity which we have banish together out of our coast every one distrust or defraud other while either by miserable keep or luxurious spend he which be y y malus Seneca bad to all be worst to himself to this barn they bring at a certain time of the year all the venison fish and crocodile dry before in the smoke for the better preservation which they meddle not with till need force they and then they signify the same to each other the king may take thereof as much as he will this provision be send in basket on the shoulder of their hermaphrodite which wear long hair and be their porter for all burden they hunt heart after a strange manner for they will put on a heart skin with the leg and head on so that the same shall serve they to stalk with and they will look through the eye and hole of the hide as if it be a visor thereby deceive their game which they shoot and kill especial at the place where they come to drink their crocodile they take in a strange manner they be so plague with these beast that they keep continual watch and ward against they as otherwhere against their enemy for this purpose they have a watch-house z z icon. 16 by the river side and when hunger drive the beast on shore for his prey they have great tuft of hair on their forehead and have a kind of beard under their chin and throat the male have very long tail with a great knob or flock at the end so that in some respect they the cold be so extreme that the horse and man pass over the river upon the ice they there take a town f f take of Tiguez after five and forty day siege but with much loss and little gain for the indian kill thirty horse in a night and in a other slay certain Spaniard send up into the country they can not tell whether for sacrifice or for the show and wound fifty horse they drink snow in stead some spaniard to accompany they into the region of death and wound many more both man and horse the snow continue in these part half the year Quivira be more northerly and yet more temperate the on the hill torment themselves tear their flesh from their cheek whereby it appear that they be about some sacrifice the news be further spread bring the king thither which be a man of goodly stature many tall man attend he two ambassador with a long speech of half a hour signify his come before one go before the king with a sceptre or mace whereon hang two crown with three chain the crown be of knitworke wrought artificial with diverse colour feather the chain of a bony substance the king follow clothe in conyskinne the people come after all have their face paint with white black and other colour every one bring his present even the very child also the scepter-bearer make a loud speech of half a hour take his word from a other which whisper the same unto he which with a solemn applause be end they come all down the hill in order without their weapon the scepter-bearer begin a song and dance wherein all the rest follow he the king and diverse other make several oration or supplication to the general to become their king and the king with a song do set the crown on the general head and put the chain about his neck honour he by the name of Hioh the common sort leave the king and his guard scatter themselves with their sacrifice among our people take view of all and to such as best please their fancy which be the young offer their sacrifice with weep scratch and tear their flesh with much effusion of blood the english mislike their devotion and direct they to the live God they show again their wound whereunto the other apply plaster and lotion every three day they bring their sacrifice till they perceive that they be displease and at the departure of the english they by stealth provide a sacrifice take their depart very grievous they find herd of dear feed by Vlloa and hack. vol. 3 Francis de Vlloa with a fleet for discovery in the year 1539 from acapulco which come to Santa cruz in california they sail over the gulf and come to the river of saint Peter and saint Paul where they behold on both side a goodly country I be loath to hold on with they in their voyage lest I sail from my scope and leave the offend reader behind i here they find in their course burn mountain which cast up fire ash and smoke in great quantity they encounter with a cruel storm and be almost out of hope they see as it be a candle upon the shroud of the trinity one of their ship which the mariner say be saint elmo and salute it with their song and prayer this be the darkness of popery to worship a natural light yea that which have little more than be and be a imperfect meteor be with they more perfect than human and must participate in divine worship without the gulf of california they find store of great fish which suffer themselves to be take by hand also they see weed float on the sea fifty league together round and full of gourd under they be store of fish on they store of foul they grow in fifteen or twenty fathom depth they catch with their dog a beast very fat haired like a goat otherwise resemble a dear in this neither that it have four dug like unto a cow full of milk but because they have little deal with the inhabitant I leave they and will see what Fernando p p fer. Alarchon Alarchon can show we of his discovery he be set forth by Antonio de Mendosa the viceroy in the year of our lord 1540 with two ship he come to the bottom of the bay of california and there find a mighty river which run with such surious violence that they can scarce sail against ^ here leave the ship with some of his company he pass up with some piece of ordnance and two boat and so draw the boat with hal^ers they make up the river call Guia they be encounter with the indian inhabitant who forbid they land but Alarchon hurl his weapon down and pull out certain ware to give they appease their fury and cause they also to lay down their weapon and receive of he some trifle which he give they two league high many indian come and call to he these be dec^^d after a strange manner some have paint their face all over some half way other have visard on with the shape of faces^ they have hole in their nostril whereat certain pendant hang other ware shell have their ear full of hole with bone and shell hang thereat all of they wear a girdle about their waste whereunto be fasten a bunch of feather which hang down behind like a tail they carry with they bag of tobacco their body be trace with coal their hair cut before hang down long behind the woman ware bunch of feather before and behind they there be four man in woman apparel Alarchon perceive by sign that the thing they most reverence be the sun and therefore signify unto they that he come from the sun whereat they marvel and take curious view of he with great reverence than before bring he abundance of food first fling up part of every thing into the air and after turn to he to give he the other part offer in their arm to carry he into their house and do else whatsoever he will have they and if any stranger come they will go and meet he to cause he to lay down his weapon and if he will not they will break they in piece he give the chief of they small ware they need not pray they to help draw the boat up the stream every one labour to get hold of the rope otherwise it have be impossible to have get up against the current he cause cross to be make and give they with instruction to honour they which they do with ecstasy of blind zeal kiss they and lift they up every one come for they till he have not paper and stick enough for that purpose and as he pass further he meet with one which understand his interpreter and ask of he many question to which he answer that he be send of the sun which the other doubt because the sun go in the sky he say that at his go down and rise he come near the earth and there make he in that land and send he hither to visit this river and the people and to charge they not to make further war one upon another but why say the indian do he send you no soon he answer because before he be but a child a long dialogue thus pass betwixt they the issue whereof be that the indian cry out they will all receive he for their lord see he be the child of the sun and come to do they good this use do he make of their superstitious observation of the sun which they worship because he make they warm say they and cause their crop to grow and therefore of all thing which they eat they cast a little up into the air to he they war one upon a other a thing common to all savage for small occasion the elder and most valiant guide the army for in some place they have no lord and of those which they take in the war some they burn and from some they pluck out the heart and eat they Alarchon cause a cross to be make of timber command his own people to worship it and leave it with the indian with instruction every morning at the sunne-rise to kneel before it this they take with great devotion and will not suffer it to touch the ground until they know it by question how deep they shall set it with what composition of gesture to worship it and the like curiosity of paganish christianity he be tell that this river be inhabit by three and twenty language that they marry but one woman to one man that maid before marriage converse not with man nor talk with they but keep at home and wrought adultery be death they burn the dead widow stay half a year or a whole year before they marry again every family have their several governor other ruler they have none the river use at sometime to overflow the bank these people tell Alarchon that in Cevola they have many blue stone or turquoise which they dig out of a rock of stone and when their governor die all their good be bury with they that they eat with napkin many wait at table that they kill the negro before mention because he say he have many brother to who they think he will give intelligence and therefore kill he a old man tell he the name of two hundred lord and people of those part this other be put into a coupe or cage to be fatten for another sacrifice but break prison they escape to another cacike enemy to the former where all the rest die but himself and Gonsalo Guerrer a mariner victual and jewel of gold and other curious work of feather which Cortes requite with a collar of glass and other thing of small value a woman slave give he at Potonchan understand their language and she with aguilar be his interpreter Cortes profess himself the servant of a great emperor which have send he thither who power he so high extol that Teudilli marvel think there have be no such prince in the world as his master and soucraigne the king of Mexico who vassal he be name Mutezuma to he he send the representation of these beard man and their horse apparel weapon ordinance and other rarity paint in Cotton clothes their ship and number these paint cotton he send by post which deliver they from one to another with such celerity that in a day and night the message come to Mexico which be two hundred and ten mile distant Cortes have demand whether Mutezuma have gold Tendelli affirm and Cortes reply that he and his fellow have a disease of the heart whereunto gold be the best remedy Mutezuma send he many cotton clothes of diverse colour many tuffe of feather two wheel the one of silver with the sign of the moon and the other of gold make like the sun which they hold for god and give unto they the colour of the metal most like they every wheel be two yard and a half broad these with other part of the present be esteem worth twenty thousand ducat Mutezuma also profess joy to hear of so great a prince and so strange people and promise provision of all necessary but be very unwilling that Cortes shall come to see he as he pretend yet Cortes persist in that his desire of see Mutezuma that he may further acquaint himself with the knowledge of those part the silly indian have never see such strange sight come daily to the camp to see they and when they hear the ordnance discharge they fall down flat think the heaven have fall the ship they think be the god of the air call quezalcovolt which come with the temple on his back for they daily look for he among the rest or rather aloof off from the rest be certain indian of differ habit high than the other and have the gristle of their nose slit hang over their mouth and ring of jet and amber hang thereat their neither lip also bore and in the hole ring of gold and turkesle-stone which weigh so much that their lip hang over their chin leave their tooth bare this ugliness they account gallantry and such uncouth deformity to be the only bravery and thou gallant that read and deride this madness of fashion if thine eye be not dazzle with lightness light I can call it of selfe-reflected Vanity may see garrison Cortes pass from thence to Mexico by the frontier of tlaxcallon which be enemy to Mutezuma who he may easy have overcome but reserve partly for the exercise of his subject to the war and partly for the sacrifice to his god these join a hundred and fifty thousand man against Cortes take he for mutezuma friend and yet every day send he guinney-cocke and bread partly to espy his strength and partly in a bravery lest their glory shall be obseur in the conquest of man already starve but when in many skirmish and fight they can not prevail against that handful of spaniard they think they be preserve from harm by enchantment and send he three present with this message that if he be that rigorous god which eat man flesh he shall eat those five slave which they bring he and they will bring he more if he be the meek and gentle god behold frankincense and feather if he be a mortal man take here foul bread and cherry at last they make peace with he and submit their city to he their city Tlaxcallan be great plant by a river side which issue into the South-sea it have four street each of which have their captain in the time of war the government be a aristocraty hate monarchy no less than tyranny it have eight and twenty village and in they a hundred and fifty thousand household very poor but good warrior they have one marketplace so spacious that thirty thousand person in a day come thither to buy and sell by exchange for money they have none Mutezuma have send before to Cortes and promise tribute to the emperor whatsoever shall be impose only he will not have he come to Mexico and now he send again that he shall not trust that new friendship with the beggarly nation of Tlaxcallan and they again counsel he not to adventure himself to Mutezuma Cortes hold his determination for Mexico and be accompany with many of the Tlaxcantlexas he go to Chololla a little from whence Mutezuma have prepare a army to entrap he in the way but he find the treachery it redound upon Cholollois the same day they have think to have execute the same upon he for this end they have sacrifice ten child five male and as many female three year old to Quezalcovatl their god which be their custom when they begin their war he out-going they in their own art of subtlety entrap their captain in counsel and send his army to spoil the city where be slay many thousand there be twenty gentleman and many priest which ascend up to the high tower of their temple which have a hundred and twenty step where they be burn together with their god and sanctuary this city have twenty thousand household within the wall and as many in the suburb it show outward very fair and full of tower for there be as many temple as day in the year and every one have his tower. the spaniard count four hundred tower it be the city of most devotion in all India whither they travel from many place far distant in pilgrimage their cathedral temple be the best and high in all new Spain with a hundred and twenty step up to it their chief god be Quezalcovatl god of the air who be they say founder of their city be a virgin of holy life and great penance he institute fast and draw of blood out of their ear and tongue and leave precept of sacrifice he never wear but one garment of Cotton white narrow and long and upon that a mantle beset with certain red cross they have certain green stone which be he and be keep for great relic one of they be like a ape head eight league from Chololla be the hill Popocatepec or smoake-hill which the earth seem to have erect as a fort to encounter and assault the air now with smoky mist endeavour to choke his pure breath another while with violent flame and natural firework threaten to join league with his elder and superior brother to disinherit he sometime with shower of ash and embers as it be put out the eye and sometime with terrible and dreadful thunder rend the ear of that airy element always such be the event of war hurt and waste itself to endamage the enemy the indian think it a place of purgatory whereby tyrannical and wicked officer be punish after their death and after that purgation pass into glory the spaniard adventure to see it but two only hold on their journey and have there be consume have they not by a rock be shadow from the violent eruption of the fire which then happen it chance that the earth weary it seem of the war as have spend her store and munition agree on a truce which continue ten year but in the year 1540 it break forth into more violent hostility then before quake and rent itself with unbridled passion and whereas the air have always a snowy garrison about her high top and frontier to cool and quench her fiery shower yet these do but kindle a great flame the ash whereof come to Mexico Mutezuma provide all thing necessary for the spaniard and indian that attend they even bed of flower be make in place of litter for their horse but Cortes disquiet with those thought which common attend ambition discontent in the present hope and fear of the future use the matter so that he take Mutezuma prisoner and detain he in the place appoint for the spaniard lodging with a spanish guard about he permit he otherwise to deal in all private or public affair as before hereupon Cacama lord of Tezcuco nephew to Mutezuma rebel but by treachery of his own people be present prironer to Mutezuma he after this summon a parliament where he make a oration unto his subject say that he and his predecessor be not natural of the country but his forefather come from a far country and their king return again and say he will send such as shall rule they and he have now send these spaniard say he hereupon he counsel they to yield themselves vassal to the emperor which they do at his command though with many tear on his part and they at this farewell of their liberty Mutezuma present give to Cortes in the name of tribute great quantity of gold and other jewel which amount to sixteen hundred thousand Castlins of gold beside silver Cortes have hitherto a continual victory in Mexico without any fight but news be bring he of pamphilo de Naruais who be send with eighty horse and some hundreth of spaniard by Velasques to interrupt the proceed of Cortes who leave two hundred man in Mexico with two hundred and fifty other come sudden in the night and take naruaes prisoner and return to Mexico with naruaes his company now his follower also where he find his man exceed distress by the citizen for a murder commit in the great temple at a solemn feast where in a religious dance they be slay for the rich garment and jewel they wear by the spaniard Cortes come in good time for the relief of his man and Mutezuma cause the mexicans to bridle their rage which present be renew and when Mutezuma be again by his guardian the spaniard cause to speak to the people a blow of a stone on his temple wound he whereof three day after he die Cortes have some thousand of the Tlaxoltecas to help he but be drive to flee from Mexico with all his spaniard and indian which he do close in the night but yet a alarm be raise and the bridge be break much slaughter of his people be make by the mexicans and all his treasure in manner lose they pursue after he also and have two hundred thousand in the field when it be Cortes his good hap to slay the standard-bearer whereupon the indian forsake the field this battle be fight at Otumpan at Tlazcallan he and he be kind entertain they have prepare before fifty thousand man to go to Mexico for his help and now they promise he all office of loyalty and service with their help he subdue Tepeacac and build certain brigandine or frigate which be carry many league on the back of those indian and there fasten and finish without which he can never have win Mexico in Tezcuco certain spaniard have be take sacrifice and eat which Cortes now revenge on they eight thousand man have carry the loose piece and timber of this navy conquer sometime as be the doubtful chance of war conquer Cortes have in Tezcuco ordain a new king a Christian Indian of the royal blood who much assist he in this siege the spaniard be lord of the up into the tower of Tlatelulco their chief temple and make their perfume of sweet gum in token of victory and sacrifice forty spaniard which they have take captive open their breast and pluck out their heart for offering to their idol sprinkle their blood in the air their fellow look on and not able to revenge it they slay likewise many indian and four spaniard of alvarado company who they eat in the open sight of the army the mexicans dance drink themselves drink make bonfire strike up their drum and make all solemn express of joy dread disdain and all the fury that passion or compassion can conjure up have now fill the spaniard heart and their indian partaker and Cortes that hitherto have hope to reserve some part of the city now do the utmost that rage and revenge can effect help no less within with famine and pestilence then with sword and fire without at last Mexico be raze the earth and water share betwixt they what the fire have leave and all which have sometime challenge a remnant of the like beastly man be yet find which do great hurt and will not by either cunning or force of the spaniard be reduce to any other course they seem to have learn the savage nature of the wild beast of who and with who they live by this mean it come to pass that this wild mountainous people leave the best and most fertile part of the country unpeople which certain remote nation possess who they call b b b b b Navatalcas signify wellspeaker Navatalcas for their civility these come from those northern part which now they call new Mexico the Navatalcas paint their beginning and first territory in manner of cave because of their seven tribe and man come out of they by the supputation of their book this departure be above eight hundred year since and by reduce to our account about the year of our lord 720. fourscore year they stay on the way the cause whereof they ascribe to their god which speak visible to they and bid they seek new land that have such sign as they notify thus they proceed in seek those sign and people the best part still remove their habitation as they find more fertile country leave only the age sick and weary with a few other to remain in the former and by these leisurely proceed they enter the land of Mexico about the year 902 after our account those seven nation come not all at once but first the Suchimilcos next the Chalcas and three the tepanetans four those of Tescuco after they the tlalluicans the 6 be the tlascaltecans which help the spaniard to conquer Mexico and therefore be exempt from tribute to this day these expel as their history say certain giant who in pretence of friendship they have invite to a banquet and in their drunkenness steal away their weapon and slay they neither do this seem a fable for at this day be find dead man bone of incredible bigness I see a tooth say acosta at Mexico in the year 1586 as big as the fist of a man and accord to this all the rest be proportionable three hundred and two year after the first transmigration those of the seven cave or line arrive which be the mexican nation they worship the idol Vitzliputzli and the devil speak and govern this nation he promise to make they lord over all which the other six nation possess and to give they a land plentiful in riches whereupon they go forth carry their idol with they in a coffer of reed support by four of their principal priest with who he talk and communicate his oracle and direction he likewise give they law and teach they the ceremony and sacrifice they shall observe and even as the pillar of cloud and fire conduct the israelite in their passage through the wilderness so this apish devil give they notice when to advance forward and when to stay the first thing they do wheresoever they come be to build a house or tabernacle for their Vitzliputzli which they set always in the midst of their camp and there place the ark in the midst of the altar this do they sow the land and if their god command to gather they do so and if to raise their camp they obey leave the age tick and weary to gather the first-fruit and to dwell there the chief captain who they follow be call Moxi whence come the name of their c c Mexico and mexicans city and nation their idol persuade they when some be bathe themselves in certain lake to remove the camp close and steal away their clothes whereat they which be thus forsake change their language and manner of life retain always their hatred to the mexicans they people the province Mechovacan from hence to Mexico be fifty league and upon the way be Malinalco which they say be people by a witch and her family who by the commandment of their god they leave behind close remove the army by night they stay in a place call where by stop a river they drown a plain and plant it round with willow and other tree and many like the place talk of stay there whereat their god offend threaten the priest and in the night slay those which have consult of stay their heart be find pull out and their stomach open which after that they observe in their sacrifice the mexicans by the advice of their idol proceed and by force make way through the Chalcas and send to the lord of Culhuacan who grant they the place of Ticaapan to dwell in which be full of snake and venomous beast which by the help of their god they tame he will not suffer they to stay there but command they to proceed and to seek forth a woman who they shall name the goddess of discord whereupon they send to the king of Culhuacan to demand his daughter to be queen of the mexicans and mother of their god who easy condescend and send his daughter gorgeous attire the same night she arrive by order of their god she be murder and flay and a young man be cover with her skin with her apparel thereon and be place near the idol be consecrate a goddess and mother of their god ever after worship the same make a idol which they call toccy that be our grandmother the king of Culhuacan hereupon war against they and chase they out of those part by which mean they come to the place where Mexico now be here certain old priest or sorcerer enter into a place full of water-lily they meet with a very fair and clear current of water with tree meadow fish and other thing all very white which be the sign their god have give they of their promise land. in the night follow Vitzliputzli appear in a dream to a ancient priest say that they shall go seek out a tunal in the lake which grow out of a stone upon which they shall see a eagle feed on small bird which they shall hold for the place where their city shall be build to become famous through the world hereupon the next day they all assemble and divide themselves into band make that search with great diligence and devotion in their search they meet with the former watercourse not white as it be then but read like blood divide itself into two stream one of which be a obscure azure at last they espy the eagle with wing display towards the sun compass about with many rich feather of diverse colour and hold in his talon a goodly bird at this sight they fall on their knee and worship the eagle with great demonstration of joy and thanks to Vitzliputzli for this cause they call the city which there they found d d Mexico tenoxtiltan tenoxtiltan which signify tunal on a stone and to this day carry in their arm a eagle upon a tunal with a bird in his talon the next day follow by common consent they make a hermitage adjoin to the tunal of the eagle that the ark of their god may rest there till they may have mean to build he a sumptuous temple this they make of flag and turf cover with straw afterward they consult to buy of their neighbour stone timber lime in exchange of fish fowl frog and other thing which they hunt for in the lake by which mean they procure necessary build a chapel of lime and stone and labour to fill up part of the lake with rubbish the idol command that they shall divide themselves into four principal quarter about this house and each part build therein to which he enjoin certain god of his appointment call Calpultetco which be quarter-god this be the beginning of Mexico this division seem not equal to some of the ancient who value their desert far above their allot portion who therefore separate themselves and go to Tlatedulco who practice against the mexicans cause they to choose a king to which sovereignty be choose Acamapitzli nephew to the king of Culhuacan and of the mexican blood by the father side he by embassage they demand and obtain in the name of their god with this answer from the king of Culhuacan let my grandchild go to serve your god and be his lieutenant to rule and govern his creature by who we live who be the lord of night day and wind let he go and be lord of the water and land and possess the mexican nation etc. he be solemn welcome by the mexicans welcome they art say a e e many of these oration be express in acosta seven book at large full of witty invention and which signify a snake of razor the source of acamapixtl their first king. the common people be earnest with this new king for peace with the tapanecan for the obtain whereof they will carry their god his noble they on the other side promise if he do overcome to become his tributary for before they enjoy much freedom and to labour in his field and house and to become his servant in war and peace in fine such be the valour of Tlacaellec the general that the enemy be overthrow their city sack and the remainder of they make tributary the land and good of the conquer be divide among the conqueror before they sacrifice he they give he the name of the idol to who he shall be sacrifice apparel he also with the same ornament and during the time that this representation last which be for a year in some feast six month in some in other less they worship he in the same manner as they do their god he in the mean time eat drink and make merry when he go through the street the people come forth to worship he bring their alm with child and sick folk that he may cure and bless they suffer he to do all thing at his pleasure only he be accompany with ten or twelve man lest he shall flee and he to the other side of the stair and all such as shall die go in procession to the place where they shall be sacrifice where they find the minister ready for that office six of the priest be appoint to this execution four to hold the hand and foot of he that shall be sacrifice the five to hold his head the 6 to open his stomach and pull out his heart they call they Chachalmna that be the minister of holy thing it be a high dignity wherein they succeed their progenitour the 6 which kill the sacrifice be as a high priest or bishop who name be different accord to the difference of time and solemnity their habit also differ accord to the time the name of their chief dignity be Papa and Topilzm their habit and robe be a red curtain with tassel below a crown of rich feather Greene white and yellow paint about with diverse colour and they be attire in a dalmatic robe of white wrought with black in this attire represent the devil the sovereign priest carry a great knife in his hand of a large and point that the man which be to be sacrifice be lay thereon upon his back do bend in such sort as let the knife but fall upon his stomach it open very easy in the midst then do the guard cause they to naked and cast he on his back upon this point stone where the five of they put the collar of wood about his neck and the high priest open his stomach with the knife with a strange dexterity and face and then cast away the body tumble it down the stair of the temple there be not two foot space betwixt the stone and the first step in this sort they sacrifice they all one after another their master or such as have take they take up the body and carry they away and divide they amongst they do eat they there be ever forty or fifty at the least thus sacrifice the neighbour nation do the like imitate the mexicans in this sacred butchery there be another kind of sacrifice which they make in diverse feast call racaxipe Velitzli which be as much as the flay of man because they flay the he with the congeal blood this continue till the skin do stink during which time much alm be gather which they employ in necessary for their devotion in many of these feast they make a challenge between he that do sacrifice and he that shall be sacrifice thus they tie the slave by one foot to a wheel of stone give he a sword and target in his hand to defend himself then step forth the other arm in like manner and if he that shall be sacrifice defend himself valiant against the other he be free and be repute a famous captain but if he be vanquish he be sacrifice on that stone whereto he be tie they every year give one slave to the priest to represent their idol at his first entry into the office after he have be well wash they adorn he with the idol ornament and name as before be say feather and long fringe of the same within the circuit of this court there be many chamber of religious man and other that be appoint for the priest and pope this court be so great and spacious that eight or ten thousand person do dance easy in a round hold hand which be a usual custom there howsoever it seem incredible there be four gate or entry at the east west north and south at every b b Gomara say that the four be not a causey but a street of the city of which begin a fair causey of two or three league long there be in the midst of the lake wherein Mexico be build four large causy street that go between they upon the top of these step there be a walk of thirty foot broad all plaster with chalk in the midst of which walk be a palisado artificial make of very high tree plant in rod be many skull and these rank of skull continue from the foot to the top of the tree this palisado be full of dead man skull from one end to the other which be the head of such as have be sacrifice for after the flesh be eat the head be deliver to the priest who tie they in this sort until they fall off by morsel upon the top of the temple be two stone or chapel and in they the two image of peculiar house priest god and service at every door of the great temple be a large hall and goodly building which be common armoury for the city they have other dark house full of idol of diverse great temple five thousand person which have there their meat drink and lodging the temple enjoy great revenue and diverse town for the maintenance thereof next c c accost l.5.c.13 to the temple of when any waste supply be make of other in their roome^ within this great circuit of the principal temple be two house like cloister the one opposite to the other one of man the other of woman in that of woman they be virgin only of twelve or thirteen year of age which they call the maid of penance they be as many as the man and live chaste and regular as virgin dedicate to the service of their god. their charge be to sweep and make clean the temple and every morning to prepare meat for the idol and his minister of the alm the religious gather the food they prepare for the idol be small loaf in the form of hand and foot as of marchpane and with this bread they prepare certain sauce which they cast daily before the idol and his priest do eat it these virgin have their hair cut and then let they grow for a certain time they rise at midnight to the idol matin which they daily celebrate perform the same exercise which the religious do they have their abbess who employ they to make cloth of diverse fashion for the ornament of their god and temple their ordinary habit be all white without any work or colour they do their penance at midnight sacrifice and wound themselves and pierce the top of their ear lay the blood which issue forth upon their cheek and after bathe themselves in a pool which be within the monastery if any be find dishonest they be put to death without remission say she have pollute the house of their god. they hold it for a ominous token that some religious man or woman have commit a fault when they see a rat or a mouse pass or a battin in the idol-chappell or that they have gnaw any of the veil for that they say a cat or a bat will not adventure to commit such a indignity if some of tense have not go before and then begin to make inquisition and discover the offender put he to death none be receive into this monastery but the daughter of one of the six quarter name for that purpose and this profession continue a year during which time their father and themselves have make a vow to serve the idol in this manner and from thence they go to be marry the other cloister or monastery be of youngman of eighteen or twenty year of age which they call religious their crown be shave as the friar in these part their hair a little long which fall to the midst of their ear except on the hinder part of the head where they let it grow to their shoulder and tie it up in truss these serve in the temple live poor and chaste and as the levite minister to the priest incense light and garment sweep and make clean the holy place bring wood for a continual fire to the hearth of their god which be like a lamp that still burn before the altar of their idol beside these there be other little boy that serve for manual use as to deck the temple with bough rose and reed give the priest water to wash rasour to sacrifice and to go with such as beg alm to carry it all these have their superior who have the government over they and when they come in public where woman be they carry their eye to the ground not dare to behold they they have linen garment and go into the city four or six together to ask alm in all quarter and if they get none it be lawful for they to go into the corne-field and gather that which they need none dare to contradict they there may not above fifty live in this penance they rise at midnight and sound the trumpet to awake the people every one watch by turn lest the fire before the altar shall die they give the censer with which the priest at midnight incense the idol and also in the morning at noon and at night they h h mexican votary no less strict in that threefold cord which the popish votary glory of poverty continency obedience with other will-worship yea for the time more austere be very subject and obedient to their superior and pass not any one point command and at midnight after the priest have end his cense they retire themselves apart into a secret place where they sacrifice and draw blood from the calf of their leg with sharp bodkin therewith rub their temple and under their ear present wash themselves in a pool appoint to that end these young man do not anoint their head and body with * * tobacco Petum as the priest do this austerity continue a year the priest likewise rise at midnight and retire themselves into a large place where be many light and there draw blood as the former from their leg than do they set these bodkin upon the battlement of the court stick in straw that the people may see neither may they use one bodkin twice the priest also use great fast of five or ten day together before their great feast some of they to preserve their chastity slit their member in the midst and do a hundred thing to make themselves impotent lest they shall offend their gods. they drink no wine and sleep little for that the great part of their exercise be by night they do use also that the selfe-tyrannising catholic shall not outvie merit to discipline themselves with cord full of knot wherein the people likewise come not behind in cruel procession especial on the feast of Tezcalipuca lash themselves with knot manguey-cord over the shoulder the priest fast five day before midnight all the chief officer of the temple do rise and in stead of bell they do sound a long time upon trumpet cornet and flute very heavy which be end he that do the office that week step forth attire in a white robe with a censer in his hand full of coal which he take from the hearth burn continual before the altar in the other hand he have a purse full of incense which he cast into the censer and enter the place where the idol be he incense it with great reverence then take he a cloth with the which he wipe the altar and the curtain this do they go all into a chapel and there do beat themselves and draw blood with bodkin as be say this be always do at midnight none other but the priest may intermeddle with their sacrifice and every one do employ himself accord to his dignity and degree they do likewise preach to the people at some feast they have revenue and great offering the mexican priest l l accost l.5.c.26 be thus anoint they anoint the body from the foot to the head and all the hair likewise which hang like tress or a horsemane for that they apply this unction wet and moist their hair grow so that in time it hang down to their ham insomuch that the weight make it burdensome for they never cut it until they die or be dispense with for their great age or be employ in governement or some honourable charge in the commonwealth they carry their hair in tress of six finger breadth which they die black with the fume of sapine fir or rosine they be always die with this tincture from the foot unto the head so as they be like unto shine negro this be their ordinary unction they have a other when they go to sacrifice or incense on the top of mountain or in dark cave where their idol be use also certain ceremony to take away fear and add courage this unction be make with diverse venomous beast as spider scorpion salamander and viper which the boy in the college take and gather together wherein they be so expert as they be always furnish when the priest call for they they take all these together and burn they upon the hearth of the temple which be before the altar until they be consume to ash then do they put they in mortar with much tobacco or Petum which make they loose their force mingle likewise with these ash scorpion spider and palmer alive after this they put to it a certain seed be ground which they call Ololol^chqui whereof the indian make drink to see vision for that the virtue of this herb be to deprive man of sense they do likewise grind with these ash black and hairy worm who hair only be venomous all which they mingle together with black or the fume of rosine put it in small pot which they set before their god say it be his meat and therefore call it a divine meat by mean of this ointment they become witch and do see and speak with the devil the priest be slubber with this ointment lose all fear put on a spirit of cruelty by reason whereof they do very bold kill man in their sacrifice go all alone in the night time to the mountain and into obscure cave contemn all wild beast believe that lion tiger serpent and the rest flee from they by virtue hereof this Petum do also serve to cure the sick and for child all resort to they as to their saviour to apply unto they this divine physic as they call it they use manifold other superstition to delude the people in tie small flower about their neck and string with small bone of snake command they to bathe at certain time to watch all night at the divine hearth to eat no other bread but that which have be offer to their god that they shall upon all occasion repair to their wizard who with certain grain tell fortune and divine look into keeler and pail full of water the sorcerer and m m their witch minister of the devil use much to besmear themselves there be a infinite number of these witch diviner enchanter and the like and still there remain of they but secret not dare public to exercise their superstition the mexicans n n their rite unto infant have amongst they a kind of baptism which they do with cut the ear and member of young child have some resemblance of the jewish circumcision this ceremony be do principal to the son of king and noble man present upon their birth the priest do wash they and do put a little sword in the right hand in the left a target and to the child of the vulgar sort they put the mark of their calling and to their daughter instrument to spin knit and labour the o o their marriage priest also have their office in marriage the bridegroom and the bride stand together before the priest who take they by the hand ask they if they will marry understand their will he take a corner of the veil wherewith the woman have her head cover and a corner of the man gown which he tie together on a knot and so lead they thus tie to the bridegroom house where there be a hearth kindle then he cause the wife to go seven time about the hearth and so the marry couple sit down together and thus be the marriage contract in other part of new Spain p p Gomara part. 1 pag 389. they use other marriage-rite at Tlaxcallan the bridegroom and bride poll their head to signify that from thenceforth all childish course shall be lay aside at Michuacan the bride must look direct upon the bridegroom or else the marriage be not perfect in Mixteopan they use to carry the bridegroom upon their back as if he be force and then they both join hand and knit their mantle together with a great knot the Macatecas do not come together in twenty day after marriage but abode in fast and prayer all that while sacrifice their body and anoint the mouth of the idol with their blood in Panuco the husband buy their wife for a bow two arrow and a net and afterward the father in law speak not one word to his son in law for the space of a year when he have a child he lie not with his wife in two year after lest she shall be with child again before the other be out of danger some suck twelve year and for this cause they have many wife no woman while she have her disease may touch or dress any thing adultery in Mexico be death common woman be permit but no ordinary stew the devil do many time talk with their priest and apparition they paint he in many shape it belong also to the office of the priest and religious in Mexico q q accost li. 5 c.8 to inter the dead and do their obsequy the place where they bury they be their garden and court of their own house other carry they to the place of sacrifice which be do in the mountain other burn they and after bury the ash in the temple bury with they whatsoever they have of apparel stone and jewel they do sing the funeral office like respond often lift up the dead body with many ceremony at these mortuary they do eat and drink and if it be a person of quality they give apparel to such as come when one be dead his friend come with their present and salute he as if he be live and if he be a king or lord of some town they offer some slave to be put to death with he to serve he in the other world they likewise put to death his priest or chaplain for every nobleman have a priest for his domestical holy that he may execute his office with the dead they likewise kill his cook his butler dwarf and deform man and whosoever have most serve he though he be his brother and to prevent poverty they bury with they much wealth as gold silver stone curtain and other rich piece and if they burn the dead they use the like with all his servant and ornament they give he for the other world and last bury the ash with great solemnity the obsequy continue ten day down their month name in order the indian describe they by peculiar picture common take of the principal feast therein they account their week by thirteen day they have also a week of year which be likewise thirteen they reckon by a certain wheel which contain four week that be two and fifty year in the midst of this wheel be paint the sun from which go four beam or line in cross of distinct colour green blue red and yellow and so the line betwixt these on which they note by some picture the accident that befall any year as the spaniard come mark by a man clad in red. the last night when this wheel be run about they break all their vessel and stuff put out their fire and all the light say that the world shall end at the finish of one of these wheel and it may be at that time and then what shall such thing need upon this conceit they pass the night in great fear but when they see the day begin to break they present bear many drum with much other mirth and music say that GOD do prolong the time with another age of two and fifty year and then begin another wheel the first day whereof they take from fire for which they go to the priest and make a solemn sacrifice and thanksgiving the twenty day of each month be call by several name the first Cipact^ which signify a spade and so the rest a house a dog a snake a eagle a temple and the like by this calendar they keep thing in memory above nine hundred year since the indian of Culhua do believe that the god have make the world they know not how and that since the creation four sun be pass and that the five and last be the sun which now give light unto the world the first sun forsooth perish by water and all live creature therewith the second fall from heaven and with the fall slay all live creature and then be many giant in the country the three sun be consume by fire and the four by tempest of air and wind and then mankind perish not but be turn into ape yet when that four sun perish all be turn into darkness and so continue five and twenty year and at the fifteen year God do form one man and woman who bring forth child and at the end of other ten year appear this five sun new bear which after their reckon be now in this year 1612 nine hundred and eighteen year since three day after this sun appear they hold that all the god do die and that these which since they worship be bear in process of time at the end of every twenty day the mexicans celebrate a feast call Tonalli which be the last day of every month the last day of the first month be call Tlacaxipevaliztli on which be slay a hundred captive in sacrifice and eat other put on the skin as be before show many of they will go to the staughter with joyful countenance dance and demand alm which befall to the priest when the green corn be a foot above the ground they use to go to a certain hill and there sacrifice two child a girl and a boy three year old to the honour of Tlaloc god of water that they may have rain and because these child be freeborn their heart be not pluck out but their throat be cut their body be wrap in a new mantle and bury in a grave of stone when the field of Maiz be two foot high a collection be make and therewith be buy four little slave betwixt the age of five and seven and they be sacrifice also to Tlaloc for the continuance of rain and those dead body be shut up in a cave appoint to that purpose the beginning of this butchery be by occasion of a drought which continue four year and force they to leave the country when the Maiz be ripe in the month and feast hueitozotl every man gather his handful of Maiz and bring it to the temple for a offering with a certain drink call Atuli make of the same grain they bring also Copalli a sweet gum to incense the god which cause the corn to grow at the beginning of summer they celebrate the feast Tlaxnehimcaco with rose and all sweet flower make garland thereof to set on their idol head and spend all that day in dance to celebrate the feast Tecuilhustli all the principal person of each province come to the city on the evening of the feast and apparel a woman with the attire of the god of salt who dance among a great company of her neighbour but the next day be sacrifice with much solemnity and all that day be spend in devotion burn of incense in the temple the merchant have a temple by themselves dedicate to the god of gain they make their feast upon the day call Miccailhuitl wherein be sacrifice and eat many captive which they have buy and all the day spend in dance in the feast of Vchpaniztli they sacrifice a woman who skin be put upon a indian which two day together dance with the townsman celebrate the same feast in their best attire in the day of Hatamutztli the mexicans enter into the lake with a great number of canoas and there drown a boy and a girl in a little boat which they cause to be sink in such sort that never after that boat appear again hold opinion that those child be in company with the god of the lake that day they spend in feast and anoint their idol cheek with a kind of gum call V^^ when Cortes be go out of Mexico to encounter pamphilo de narnaes and have leave alvarado in the city he in the great temple murder a great multitude of gentleman which have there assemble in the great temple to their accustom solemnity be six hundred or as some say a thousand rich attire and adorn where they use to sing and dance in honour of their god to obtain health child victory etc. in the month of May e e accost l. ^ c. 24 the mexicans make their principal feast to Vitziliputzli two day before which the religious virgin or nun mingle a quantity of beet with roast Maiz and mould it with honey make a image of that paste in bigness like to the idol of wood put in instead of eye grain of glass green blue or white and for tooth grain of maiz. then do all the noble bring it a rich garment like unto that of the idol and be clad do set it in a azured chair and in a litter the morning of the ^^st be come a hour before day all the maiden come forth attire in white with new ornament which that day be call the sister of Vitziliputzli they be crown with garland of Maiz roast and parch with chame of the same about their neck pass under their left arm their cheek be die with vermilion their arm from the elbow to the wrist be cover with red parrot feather thus attire they take the image on their shoulder carry it into the court where all the youngman be attire in red garment crown like the woman when the maiden come forth with this idol the young man draw near with much reverence take the litter wherein the idol be upon their shoulder carry it to the stair foot of the temple where all the people do humble themselves lay earth upon their head after this all the people go in procession to a mountain call chapulteper a league from Mexico and there make sacrifice from thence they go to their second station call Atlacuyavaya and from thence again to a village which be a league beyond cuyoacoan and then return to Mexico they go in this sort above four league in so many hour call this procession Vpanta Vitziliputzli be come to the foot of the temple stair they set down the litter with the idol and with great observance draw the same to the top of the temple some draw above and other help below the flute and drum cornet trumpet meanwhile increase the solemnity the people abode in the court. have mount and place it in a little lodge of rose present come the young man which straw flower of sundry kind within and without the temple this do all the virgin come out of their convent bring piece of the same past whereof the idol be make in the fashion of great bone which they deliver to the young man who carry they up and lay they at the idol foot till the place can receive no more they call these morsel of paste the flesh and bone of Vitziliputzli then come all the priest of the temple every one strict observe his place with vatle of diverse colour and work garland on their head and chain of flower above their neck after they come the god and goddess who they worship of diverse figure attire in the same livery then put themselves in order about those piece of paste they use certain ceremony with sing and dance by these mean they be bless and consecrate for the flesh and bone of the idol which be then honour in the same sort as their god. then come forth the sacrificer who begin the sacrifice of man whereof they now sacrifice more than at other time for this be their solemn festival the sacrifice be end all the young man and maid come out of the temple attire as before and be place in order and rank one direct against another they dance by drum which sound in praise of the feast and of their god. to which song all the ancient and great man do answer dance about they make a great circle as the manner be the young man and maid remain always in the midst all the city come to this spectacle and throughout the whole land on this day of Vitziliputzli his feast no man may eat any other meat but this paste with home whereof the idol be make and this shall be eat at the point of day not drink till afternoon the contrary be sacrilegious after the ceremony end it be lawful for they to eat any thing during the time of this ceremony they hide the water from their little child admonish such as have the use of reason to abstain the ceremony dance and sacrifice end they go to unclothe themselves and the priest and ancient of the temple take the image of paste and spoil it of all the ornament make many piece of it and of the consecrate roll which they give to the communion begin with the great and continue unto the rest both man woman and child who receive it with tear fear reverence and other both affect and effect of devotion say that they do eat the flesh and bone of their god. such as have sick folk demand thereof for they and carry it with great reverence and veneration all such as do communicate be bind to give the ten part of this seed whereof the idol be make the solemnity of the idol be end a old man of great authority sleep up into a high place and with a lo^de voice preach their law and attire like to the idol carry flower in his hand and a flute of earth have a very sharp sound and turn towards the east he sound it and after that to the west north and south he do the like this do he put his finger into the air and then gather up the earth h h the mexicans lend begin not with uthe but with dust which he put in his mouth eat it in sign of adoration the like do all that be present weep and fall flat to the ground invocate the darkness of the night and the wind not to forsake they or else to take away their life and free they from the labour they endure therein thief adulterer murderer and all other offender have great fear and heaviness while the flute sound so as some can not hide nor dissemble their offence by this mean they all demand no other thing of their god but to have their offence conceal pour forth many tear with great repentance and sorrow offer great store of incense to appease their gods. all the martialist and resolute spirit addict to the watre desire with great devotion of GOD the creator of the lord for who we live of the sun and of other their god that they will give they victory against their enemy and strength to take away many captive for simple till you come to six than they count six and one six and two six and three ten be a number by itself which in the ensue number be repeat as in other language till fifteen which they reckon in one term ten five and one and so the rest to twenty the mexicans t t gom. pag.38^ do believe concern the soul that it be immortal and that man receive either joy or pain accord to their desert and live in this world they hold for a assure faith that there be nine place appoint for soul and the chief place of glory to be near unto the sun where the soul of good man slay in the war and those which be sacrifice be place that the soul of wicked man abide in the earth and be divide after this sort child which be dead-borne go to one place those which die of age or other disease go to another those which die of wound or contagion to a three those which be execute by order of justice to a four but parricide which slay their parent or which slay their wife or child to a five another place be for such as slay their master or religious person u u accost l.7.c. ^ acosta seem to deny that the indian believe any punishment after death and yet set down a oration make at mutezuma election Mart. dec. 4.1 go to a city on the shore which for the greatness they call Cayro of that great city in Egypt here they find turrete house stately temple way past and fair market place the house be of stone or brick and lime very artificial compose to the square court or first habitation of their house they ascend by ten or twelve step the roof be of reed or stalk of herb the indian give the spaniard jewel of gold very fair and cunning wrought and be requite with vesture of silk and wool glasse-beade and little bell their apparel be of cotton in manifold fashion and colour they frequent their temple much to the which the better sort pave way with stone from their house they be great idolater and be circumcise but not all they live under law and traffic together with great fidelity by exchange commodity without money the spaniard see cross amongst they and demand whence they have they they say that a certain man of excellent beauty pass by that coast leave they that notable token to remember he other say a certain man bright than the sun die in the work thereof the spaniard sail thence to c c this town be take by master William Parker 1596. Campechium a town of three thousand house here they see a square stage or pulpit four cubit high partly of clammy bitumen and partly of small stone whereto the image of a man cut in marble be join two fourfooted unknown beast fasten upon he as if they will tear he in piece and by the image stand a serpent all besmear with blood devour a lion it be seven and forty foot long and as big as a ox these thing I mention as testimony of their art in these barbarous place and perhaps of their devotion also Grijalua or Grisalua see a tower far off at sea by direction thereof come to a island call Cosumel agree in private and public manner of life with they of jucatan their house temple apparel and trade of merchandise all one their house some where cover with reed and where quarry be with slate many house have marble pillar they sound ancient tower there and the ruin of such as have be break down and destroy there be one whereto they ascend by eighteen step or stair the governor who they suppose to be a priest conduct they to the tower in the top whereof they erect a spanish banner and call also the island Santa cruse in the tower they find chamber wherein be marble image and some of earth in the similitude of bear these they invoke with loud sing all in one tune and sacrifice unto they with sum and sweet odour worship they as their household gods. there they perform their divine ceremony and adoration they be also circumcise Gomara d d Gomar gen. hist. ca.54 say that here and at Xicalanco the devil use to appear visible and that these two be great in estimation for holiness every city have their temple or altar where they worship their idol amongst which be many cross of wood and brass whereby some conceive that some spaniard have recourse hither when Roderigo be defeat and Spain overrun by the saracen in both e e goma part. 1 pag. 36 these place they sacrifice man which Cortes persuade they to cease the temple in Cosumil or Acusamil be build like a square tower broad at the foot with step round about and from the midst upward very straight the top be hollow and cover with straw it have four window and porch in the hollow place be their chapel where stand their idol in a temple by the sea side be a uncouth idol great and hollow fasten in the wall with lime it be make of earth behind this idol back be the vestry where the ornament of the temple be keep the priest have a little secret door hard adjoin to the image by which they creep into his hollow paunch and thence answer the people that come thither with prayer and petition make the simple people believe it be the voice of the god which therefore they honour more than any other with many perfume and sweet smell they offer bread fruit quail blood and of other bird dog and sometime man the fame of this idol and oracle bring many pilgrim to Acusamil from many place at the foot of this temple be a plot like a churchyard well wall and garnish with pinnacle in the midst whereof stand a cross of ten foot long which they adore for the god of rain at all time when they want rain they will go thither on procession devout and offer to the cross quail sacrifice no sacrifice be so acceptable they burn sweet gum to perfume he with besprinkle the same with water and by this mean they think to obtain rain they can never know say Gomara how that god of cross come amongst they for in all those part of India there be no memory of any preach of the gospel that have be at any time what other think and what some indian answer concern it be say before Benzo f f m. Benzo libr. 2.ca.15 write that they do not eat the flesh of these man which they sacrifice and that they be first subdue by Francis Montegius who cruelty be such that alquinotep a cacique or indian lord above a hundred and ten year old and a christian tell he that when he be a youngman there be a sickness of worm that they have think all will have die they be not only eject by vomit but do eat out themselves a passage through man body and not long before the spaniard arrival they have two battle with the mexicans in which a hundred and fifty thousand man perish but all this be light in respect of that spanish burden Guatimala g g Botero libr. 5 part 1. Guatimala or saint james. come next to our consideration a province of pleasant air and fertile soil where grow abundance of their Cacao which be a fruit that serve the indian for meat drink and money the city which bear the same name be first at the foot of a Vulcano or hill which cast fire but because in the year 1542 h h Benzo and Gomara say sept 8. 1541. on the six and twenty day of December a lake hide in the bowel of that hill break forth in many place and with a terrible violence ruin the most part of the city it be remove two mile thence together with the episcopal sea and the king council but in the year 1581. there issue from another Vulcan two mile off or somewhat more such a irruption of fire as threaten to consume every thing the day follow follow such a shower of ash that it fill the valley and almost bury the city and yet be not all the throw pass of this hill monstrous travel but the year after for the space of four and twenty hour thence issue a stream of fire that drink up five stream of water burn the stone and rock rend the air with thunder and make it a wave and move sea of fire before i i gas. en. libr. 3 ca.6 that first eruption of water some indian come and tell the bishop that they have hear a uncredible noise and murmuirng at the foot of the hill but he reprove they say they shall not trouble themselves with vain and superstitious fear about two of the clock in the night follow happen that deluge which carry many house and whatsoever stand in the way in which five hundred and twenty spaniard perish and scarce any mention of the house remain it be worthy recital which Benzo k k h. Benzo libr. 2 ca. 16 Gomar bis^er gen. ca.209 and Gomara have record that Peter alvarado the governor who by licence of the pope have marry two sister the lady Frances and the lady Beatrice Culva have perish by a mischance his wife not only paint her house with sorrow black livery and abstain from meat and sleep but in a mad impiety say God can now do she no great evil yet for all this her sorrow she cause the citizen to be swear unto her government a new thing in the indies soon after this inundation happen which first of all assail the governors house and cause this impotent and impatient lady now to bethink she of devotion and betake she to her chapel with eleven of her maid where leap on the altar and clasp about a image the force of the water ruin the chapel whereas if she have stay in her bedchamber she have escape death they tell of uncouth noise and hideous apparition which then be see Benzo observe by his own experience that this country be much subject to earthquake the and long chain of iron to be let down into this fiery concavity where by the violence of the heat the kettle and part of the chain be melt he make a big and strong but return with like success and
