colour they differ as in languages^ so in religion of their religious rite thus write Gomara their priest be all marry except their confessor which hear confession and appoint penance accord to the quality of the fault they reveal not the confession they appoint the holiday which be eighteen when they sacrifice they have a knife of flint wherewith they open he that be sacrifice the priest appoint the sacrifice how many man whether they be to be woman or slave take in battle that all the people may know how to celebrate the feast what prayer and what offering to make the priest go three time about the captive sing in a doleful tune and sudden open his breast anoint his face with the blood take out his heart divide his body the heart be give to the prelate the foot and hand to the king the buttock to the taker the rest to the people the head of the sacrifice be set on tree plant there for that purpose every tree have figure in it the name of the province wherewith they have war under these tree they many time sacrifice man and child of the country and of their own people be first buy for it be lawful for the father to sell his child those which the q q pet mart. dec. 6.lib.6 and 7. king bring up of their own people with better fare then ordinary for sacrifice be make believe they shall be some canonize wight or heavenly deity and therefore take it glad they do not eat the flesh of these as they do of the captive when they eat their sacrifice captive they make great feast and the priest and religious man drink much wine and smoke their wine be of prune while the priest annoynt the cheek and mouth of the idol with the blood the other sing and the people make their prayer with great devotion and tear and after go on procession which be not do in all feast the religious have white cotton coat and other ornament which hang down from the shoulder to the leg thereby to put a difference between they and other the layman have their banner with that idol which they most esteem and bag with dust and bodkin the youngman have their bow dart arrow and the guide of all be the image of the devil set upon a lance carry by the most ancient and honourable priest. they go in order the religious sing till they come to the place of their idolatry where be arrive they spread cover on the ground or strew it with rose and flower because their idol shall not touch the ground and the banner be stick fast the sing cease and the prelate beginning all the rest follow and draw blood some from their tongue some from their ear some from their member and every man as his devotion like best and with that blood anoint the image in the mean while the youth skirmish and dance for the honour of their feast they cure the wound with the powder of herb and coal in some of these procession they hallow Mayz besprinkle the same with the blood of their privity and eat it they may have many woman but one be their lawful wife which they marry thus the priest take the bridegroom and the bride by the little finger set they in a chamber at a fire and give they certain instruction and when the fire be out they be marry if he take she for a virgin and find she otherwise he may divorce she many bring their wife to the cacique or lord to corrupt they esteem it a honour their r r pet. mart. dec. 6 temple be low dark room which they use for their treasury also and armoury before the temple be a high altar for the sacrifice whereon also the priest play the preacher first and then the butcher adulterer be beat but not slay the adulterous wife be divorce and may not marry again and her parent be dishonour their husband suffer they to lie with other in some feast of the year he that force a virgin be a slave or pay her dowry if a slave do it with his master daughter they be both bury quick they have common brothel a thief have his hair cut off and be make his slave from who he have steal until he have make satisfaction which if he defer long he be sacrifice they have no punishment for he which shall kill a cacique for they say such a thing can not happen the riches of nicaragua s s Botero consist much in a great lake three hundred mile long and into a lake of stand water where it live five and twenty year when any of the servant come to the lake and call matto motto she will come and receive meat at their hand and if any will be ferry over the lake she willing yield she back and perform this office faithful yea she have carry ten man at once sing or play a Spaniard have once wrong she by cast a dart at she and therefore after that when she be call she will plunge down again otherwise to the indian she remain officious shee will be as full of play as a monkey and will wrestle with they especial she be addict to one young man which use to feed she this proceed partly from her docible nature partly because be take young she be keep up a while at home in the king house with bread this fish live both on land and water the river swell over his bank into the lake this fish follow the stream and be see no more there be a other strange creature in nicaragua they call it like a black hog with small eye wide ear cleave foot a M.Dec.3 lib. 4 be of good stature thin haired the woman wear ring on their ear and nose with quaint ornament on their lip the lord marry as many wife as they list other man one or two they forsake change and sell their wife at pleasure they have public stew of woman and of man also in many place without any discredit yea this privilege they from follow the war the young girl have conceive eat certain herb to cause abortion their lord and priest consult of war after they have drink the smoke of i i tobacco a certain herb the woman follow their husband to the war and know how to use a bow. they all paint themselves in the war they need no head-piece for their head be so hard k k Ouiedo call these hard-head Cor^^ati that they will break a sword be smite thereon wound receive in war be the badge of honour whereof they glory much and thereby enjoy some franchise they brand their prisoner and pull out one of their tooth before they will sell their child be excellent swimmer both man and woman accustome themselves twice or thrice a day thereunto their priest be their physician and master of ceremony for which cause and because they have conference with the devil they be much esteem l l p. Cieza chron. per. p. 1.c.8 they have no temple nor house of devotion the devil they honour much which in terrible shape do sometime appear unto they as I say Cieza have hear some of they say they believe that there be one GOD in heaven to wit the sun and that the moon be his wife and therefore worship these two planet they worship the devil also and paint he in such form as he appear to they which be of diverse sort they offer bread smoke fruit and flower with great devotion any one may cut off his arm which steal Enciso with his army of spaniard seek to subdue these part use a spanish trick tell the indian that he seek their conversion to the faith and therefore discourse of one GOD creator of all thing and of baptism and after other thing of this nature less to his purpose he tell they that the pope be the vicar of CHRIST in all the world with absolute power over man soul and religion and that he have give those country to the most mighty king of Spain his master and he be now come to take possession and to demand gold for tribute the indian answer that they like well what he have speak of one GOD but for their religion they will not dispute of it or leave it and for the pope he shall be liberal of his own neither seem it that their king be mighty but poor that send thus a beg but what word can not their sword effect with the destruction of the indian the soil of Vraba be so fatten with a stream therein that in eight and twenty day the seed of cucumber melon and gourd will ripen their fruit there be m m p. mart. dec. 3.l.6 a tree in those country who leaf with the bare touch cause great blister the savour of the wood be poison and can be carry without danger of life except by the help of another herb which be a antidote to this venomous tree king n n p. Mart. dec. 2.l.4 Abibeiba have his palace in a tree by reason of the moorish situation and often inundation of his land. Vasques can not get he down till he begin to cut the tree and then the poor king come down and buy his freedom at the spaniard price Carthagena be so call for some resemblance in the situation to a city in Spain of that name sir Francis Drake take it the indian thereabouts use poison arrow the woman war as well as the man Enciso take one who with her own hand have kill eight and twenty christian they do eat the enemy which they kill they use to put in their sepulcher gold feather and other riches between Carthagena and Martha run a swift river call Rio grande which make the sea-water to give place and they which pass by may in the sea take in of this water fresh in the valley of Tunia o o Linschot l. 2 or Tomana be mine of emerald the people worship the sun for their chief God with such awful devotion that they dare not look steadfast upon it the moon also they worship but in a inferior degree in their war in stead of ensign they tie the bone of certain man who in their life have be valiant upon long staff to provoke other for the like fortitude they bury their king with golden necklace set with emerald and with bread and wine the people about Rio grande be cannibal as also about s. Martha the tunian use poison arrow and when they go to the war they carry their idol chiappen with they unto who before they enter into the field they offer many sacrifice of live man be the child of slave or of their enemy paint all the image with blood which do they eat the flesh return conqueror they hold great feast with dance leap sing drink themselves drink and again besmear their image with blood if they be overcome they seek by new sacrifice to appease chiappen they demand counsel of their god for their marriage and other affair for these consultation they observe a kind of Lent two month in which they lay not with woman nor eat salt. they have monastery of boy and girl where they live certain year they correct public fault as steal and kill by cut off the ear and nose hang and if he be a nobleman by cut off his hair in gather emerald they first use certain charm they use to sacrifice bird and many other thing s. Martha stand about fifty league from Carthagena at the foot of certain hill always crown with snow the indian p p nic. Monard c. 53 Gomar hist. gen. c. 71 here be very valorous and use poison arrow they make bread of jucca a root as big as a man arm or leg the juice whereof be poison in the island and therefore they press it between two stone but in the firm land they drink it raw and both here and there sodden they use it for vinegar and be sod till it be very thick for honey this bread be their Casavi not so good as that of maize I have see a plant of this herb grow in m. Gerard q q m. Gerard garden the picture whereof he have express in his herbal the people be abominable sodomite a badge whereof they wear about their neck a chain with the resemblance of two man commit this villainy in Gayra the sodomite be attire like woman other be shave like friar they have woman which preserve their virginity these addict themselves to hunt with bow and arrow alone they may lawful kill any that seek to corrupt they these people be cannibal and eat man flesh fresh and pouldered the young boy which they take they geld to make they fat for their table as we do capon they set up the head of those they kill at their gate for a memorial and wear their tooth about their neck for a bravery they worship r r p. Messia l. 5 c. 13 the sun and moon and burn thereto perfume of herb and gold and emerald they sacrifice slave Venezvel^ be so call because it be build upon a plain rock in the water of a lake the woman of this country paint their breast and arm all the rest of their body be naked except their privy part the maid be know by their colour and greatness of their girdle the man carry their member in a shell there be many filthy sodomite they pray to idol and to the devil who they paint in such form as he appear to they they paint their body in this sort he that have kill one enemy in the war paint one of his arm the second time his breast and when he have kill a three he paint a line from his eye to his ear and this be his knighthood their priest be their physician who be send for by a sick man ask the patient if he believe that they can help he and then lie their hand upon the place where they say their pain be if he recover not they put the fault in he or in their gods. they lament their dead lord in song in the night time make of their praise that do they roast they at a fire and beat they to powder drink they in wine make their bowel their lord sepulcher in zonpaciay they bury their lord with much gold jewel and pearl and set upon the grave four stick in a square within which they hang his weapon and many viand to eat from the cape Vela the space of two thousand mile alongst the coast be the fish for pearl discover by Christopher Columbus in the year 1498 which sail all along this coast. in s s p. M.Dec.1.lib ^ Gomar c.74 to c. 84 Curiana they receive the spaniard with great joy and for pin needle bell glass and such trifle give they many string of pearl for four pin they will give a peacock for two a pheasant for one a turtledove and when they ask what they shall do with this new merchandise of pin and needle see they be naked they show they the use to pick their tooth and to pick out thorn in their foot these indian have ring of gold and jewel make with pearl after the form of bird fish and beast they have also the touchstone for their mettle and weight to weigh the same thing not elsewhere find in India they make their tooth white with a herb which all the day they chew in their mouth chap. 2 of cumana cumana be a province name of a river call cumana a a gom. c.76 where certain franciscans 1516 build they a monastery and the spaniard be very diligent in the fish for pearl about b b p. M.Dec.7 lib. 4 that time three dominicans go fourscore mile west from thence to preach the gospel and be eat of the indian which hinder not but other of the same order found they a monastery in Ciribici near Maracapana both these order take pain with the indian to convert they and teach their child to write and read and to answer at mass and the spaniard be so respect that they may safe walk alone through all the country but after two year and a half the indian whether for their too much employment in the pearle-fishing or for other cause rebel and kill a hundred spaniard slay the friar one of which be then say mass and as many indian as they find with they which the spaniard of Domingo soon after revenge the loss c c gom. c.78 of cumana hinder their trade for pearl at Cubagua and therefore the king send james castilion to subdue they by force which he do and begin the plantation of new Calais for the spaniard to inhabit there Cubagua be call by Columbus the finder the island of pearl situate in twelve degree and a half of northerly latitude and contain twelve mile in circuit this little island be exceed great in commodity that accrew by those pearl which have amount to diverse million of gold. they fetch their wood from Margarita a island four mile to the north and their water from cumana which be two and twenty mile thence they have a spring of medicinal water there in the island the sea there at certain time of the year be very red which those pearle-oyster by some natural purgation be say to cause there be fish or sea-monster which from the middle upward resemble man with beard hair and arm the d d cap. 79 people of cumana go naked cover only their shame at feast and dance they paint themselves or else anoint themselves with a certain gum in which they stick feather of many colour they cut their hair above the ear and will not suffer it to grow on any place of their body esteem a beard man a beast they take great pain to make their tooth black and account they woman which have they white they black they with the powder of the leaf of a certain tree call gay these leave they chew after they be fifteen year old they mix that powder with another of a kind of wood and with chalk of white shell burn in manner as the eastern indian use their betele and Arecca with chalk of oyster and this mixture they bear continual in their mouth still chew it that their tooth be as black as coal and so continue to their death they keep it in basket and box and sell it in the market to some which come far for it for gold slave Cotton and other merchandise this keep they from pain and rot of the tooth the maid go naked only they bind certain band hard about their knee to make their hip and thigh seem thick which they esteem no small beauty the marry woman live honest or else their husband will divorce they the chief man have as many wife as they will and if any stranger come to lodge in one of their house they make the fair his bedfellow these also shut up their daughter two year before they marry they all which time they go not forth nor cut their hair after which there be make a great feast and very many bid which bring their variety of cheer and also wood to make the new spouse a house a man cut off the bridegroom hair before and a woman the bride and then eat and drink with much excess till night this be the lawful wife and the other which they marry afterward obey this they give their spouse to be deflower to their Piaces so they call their priest which these reverend father account their pre-eminence and prerogative the husband their honour the wife their warrant the man and woman wear collar bracelet pendant and some crown of gold and pearl the man wear ring in their nose and the woman brooch on their breast whereby at first sight the sex be discern the woman shoot run leap swim as well as the man their pain of travel be small they till the land and look to the house while the man hunt and fish. they be high-minded treacherous and thirsty of revenge their chief weapon be poison arrow which they prepare with the blood of snake and other mixture all of both sex from their infancy learn to shoot their meat be whatsoever have life as horseleech bat grasshopper spider bee louse worm raw sodden fry and yet their country be replenish with good fruit fish and flesh. this diet or as some say their water cause spot in their eye which dim their sight they have as strange a fence or hedge for their garden and possession namely a thread of Cotton or Bexuco as they call it as high as a man girdle and it be account a great sin to go over or under the same and he which break it they certain believe shall present die so much safe be their thread weave with this imagination than all our stonewall the e e P.M. dec. 8.lib.7 cumanois be much addict to hunt wherein they be very expert and kill lion tiger hog and all other fourfooted beast with bow net snare they take one beast which they call that have the sole of his foot like a french shoe narrow behind broad and round before another call Aranata which for the phisnomy and subtlety seem to be a kind of ape it have mouth hand and foot like a man a goodly countenance beard like a goat they go in herd they bellow loud run up tree like cat avoid the huntsman arrow and cast it with clean delivery again at himself another beast have a long snout and feed on aunt f f ouy call it a bear put his tongue into a hollow tree or other place where the aunt be and as many of they as come thereon he lick in the friar bring up one till the stink thereof cause they to kill it snout like a fox rough-haired which void in the excrement long and slender serpent which present die this beast stink while he live and worse now dead yet be good food to the indian they have one which will counterfeit the voice of a cry child and so cause some to come forth and then devour they the like be write of the hyena that she will call the shepherd by their name and then destroy they when they come forth they have parrot as big as raven with bell like hawk live on the prey and smell like musk great bat one of which be a physician by strange accident to a servant of the friar which be sick of a pleurisy be give over for dead because they can not raise a vein wherein to let he blood in the night a bat after the custom of that creature bit and suck he whereby so much blood issue that the sick man recover which the friar count for a miracle they have three sort of bee one whereof be little and black and make honey in the tree without wax their spider be great than we of diverse colour and weave such strong cobweb that they ask good strength to break they there be salamander as big as a man hand they cackle much like a pullet their bite be deadly I may here hold you too long in view these strange creature we will now return to their strange custom they take great pleasure in two thing dance and drink in which they will spend eight day together especial at the marriage or coronation of their king many gallant will then meet together diverse dress some with crown and feather some with shell about their leg instead of bell to make a noise some otherwise all paint with 20. colour and figure he that go worst seem best take one another by the hand they dance in a ring some backward some forward with a world of variety grin sing cry counterfeit the deaf lame blind fish weave tell of story and this continue six hour and then they eat and drink before he which dance most now he which drink most be the most complete and accomplish gallant and now beyond counterfeit drunkenness set they together in brave swagger quarrel other play the swine spew up the former to make way for other liquor and they add hereunto the fume of a herb which have the like drunken effect it seem to be tobacco this perhaps will not seem strange to some see these savage custom of drink dance smoke swagger so common with we in these day it may indeed seem strange to our forefather if their more civil more sacred ghost may return and take view of their degenerate posterity but now he must be a stranger in many company that will not estrange himself from eivilitie from humanity from Christianity from GOD to become of a man a beast of a Englishman a savage indian of a christian afiend save that he have a body in the diversify pollution whereof he have advantage and take it to out-swagger the devil these be the gull-gallants of our day to who I can wish that either their progenitor have be some cumanian indian or that they will leave this usurp gallantry to those true owner and resume spirit true english. the god of the cumanians be the sun and moon which be take for man and wife and for the great gods. they have great fear of the sun when it thunder or lighten say that he be angry with they they fast when there be any eclipse especial the woman for the marry woman pluck their hair and scratch their face with their nail the maid thrust sharp fishbone into their arm and draw blood when the moon be at full they think it be wound by the sun for some indignation he have conceive against she when any comet appear they make a great noise with drum and hallow think so to scare it away or to consume it believe that those comet portend some evil among their many idol and figure which they honour as god they have one like a saint Andrew cross which they think preserve they from night-spirit and they hang it on their newborn child they call their priest Piaces who maiden-head-rite we before mention they be their physician and magician they cure with root and herb raw sod and pound with the fat of bird fish and beast with wood and other thing unknown to the people with abstruse and dark word which themselves understand not they suck and lick the place where the pain be to draw out the evil humour and if the pain increase they say that the patient be possess with evil spirit and then rub their body all-ove with their hand use certain word of conjuration or charm suck after that very hard give they to understand that by that mean they call out the evil spirit present they take a piece of wood the virtue whereof none else know but the piace and therewith rub their mouth and throat so long till they cast all that be in their belly vomit sometime blood with the force thereof the piace in the mean time stamp knock call and gesture after two hour there come from he a thick phlegm and in the midst thereof a black hard bullet which those of the house carry and cast into the field say let the devil go thither if the sick-man recover his good die and become the priest if he die they say his time be come the piace be their oracle with who they consult whether they shall have war what shall be the issue thereof whether the year will be plentiful they forewarn they of eclipse and advertise of comet the spaniard demand in their necessity whether any ship will come short and they answer that on such a day a carvel will come with so many man and such provision and merchandise which accord come to pass they call upon the devil in this manner the piace enter into a cave or secret place in a dark night and carry with he certain courageous youth that may move question without fear he sit on a bench and they stand on their foot he cry call sing verse sound shell and they with a heavy accent say many time prororure prororure if the devil come not all this Blacke-Sanctus be renew with grievous sigh and much perplexity when he come which be know by the noise he sound loud and sudden fall down by visage and vary gesture show that the devil be enter the one of those his associate demand what he please the friar go one day with their conjure and conjure holy the cross steal Holywater and when the piace be in that distraction cast a part of the steal on he cross and conjure in latin and he answer they in his native language much to the purpose at last they demand whither the soul of the indian go he answer to hell these Piaces by their physic and divine grow rich they go to feast and sit by themselves apart and drink themselves drink and say the more they drink the better they can divine they learn these art when they be child and be enclose in the wood two year all that time eat nothing that have blood see no woman nor their own parent come not out of their cave or cell and the Piaces their master go to they by night to teach they when this time of their solitary discipline be past they obtain a testimonial thereof and begin to profess in practice of physic and divination let we bury the cumanois and then we have do be dead they sing their praise and bury they in their house or dry they at the fire and hang they up at the year end if he be a great man they renew the lamentation and after many other ceremony burn the bone and give to his best belove wife his skull to keep for a relic they believe that the soul be immortal but that it eat and drink about in the field where it go and that it be the echo which answer when one call chap. 3 of Guiana and the neighbour country both on the coast and within the land. in the year 1497. some add a year more a a p. martyr dec. 1 lib. 6. gom. part.2 cap. 84 Christopher Columbus seek new discovery after the suffering of unsufferable heat and calm at sea whereby the hoop of his vessel break and the freshwater not able further to endure the hot indignation of that now-beleeved burning-zone flee out of those close prison into the lap of that father of water the ocean for refuge he come at last to Trinidado the first land he encounter he call by that name either for devotion now that his other hope be dry up with the heat or wash into the sea by the violent shower above-boord and the less but not less dangerous which flow from his cask within or else for the three mountain which he there descry once this discovery of land so ravish his spirit by the inexpected delivery from danger as easy carry his impotent thought into a double error the one in place earthly paradise in this island to which opinion for the excellency of the tobacco there find he shall happy have the smoky subscription of many humorist to who that fume become a fool paradise which with their brain and all pass away in smoke the other be that the earth be not round like a ball but like a pear the upper swell whereof he esteem these part hence Columbus fail to and find out the peare-fishing of which Petrus Alphonsus a little after make great commodity by trade with the savage he be assail with eighteen canoas of here the sepulcher of their king and great man seem not less remarkable they lay the body on a kind of hurdle or grediron of wood under which they kindle a gentle fire whereby keep the skin whole they by little and little consume the flesh these dry carcase they hold in great reverence and honour for their household-god in the year c c gom. cap.85 1499. english guide for Guiana in the year 1595. d d sir Walter Raleigh Guiana sir Walter Raleigh have before receive intelligence of this rich and mighty empire set forth for the discovery and on the two and twenty of march anchor at point Curiapan in Trinidado and search that island which he find plentiful he take the city of saint joseph and therein Antony Berreo the spanish governor leave his ship he go with a hundred man in boat and a little galley and with some indian pilot pass along that admirable confluence of river as by the corpse dugnard unto Orenoque as great a commander of river as the emperor of Guiana of soldier and although we have before mention somewhat thereof yet this his peculiar place require some further consideration this river Orenoque or Baraquan since of this discovery call Raleana run from quito in Peru on the east it have nine branch which fall out on the north side of his own main mouth on the south side seven thus many arm have this giantlike stream to be his purveyor which be always fill his never fill mouth seem by this their natural officiousness incorporate thereunto and to be but wide gaping of the same spacious jaw with many land and break ground as it be so many morsel and crumb in his greedy chap still open for more though he can even in winter when his throat be glibbe altogether swallow these yea these force he for fear of choke to yaune his wide and to vomit out between these cleave morsel into the ocean lap so many stream and so far be it from the northern and southern extreme three hundred mile distant the inhabitant on the northern branch be the a goodly and valiant people which have the most manly speech and most deliberate say sir Walter that ever I hear of what nation soever in the summer they have house on the ground as in other place in the winter they dwell upon the tree e e king Abibeiba dwell on a tree in the country of Dariena pet. Martyr^ dec. 3. lib. 6 where they build very artificial town and village for between May and September the river of Orenoque rise thirty foot upright and then be those land overflowen twenty foot high except in some few raise ground in the middle this watery store when the cloud be so prodigal of more than the river store-house can hold whereby they become violent intruder and incrocher upon the land and not the violence of cold give this time the title of winter these never eat of any thing that be set or sow nature nurslings that neither at home nor abroad will be behold to the art or labour of husbandry they use the top of palmito for bread and kill dear fish and pork for the rest of their sustenance they which dwell upon the branch of Orenoque call Capuri and Macureo be for the most part carpenter of canoas which they fall into Guiana for gold and into Trinidado for tobacco in the excessive take whereof they exceed all nation when a commander die they use great lamentation and when they think the flesh of their body be putrify and fall from the bone they take up the carcase again and hang it up in the house where he have dwell deck his skull with feather of all colour and hang his gold-plate about the bone of his arm thigh and leg the Ar^^cas which dwell on the south of Orenoque beat the bone of their lord into powder which their wife and friend drink as they pass along these stream their eye be entertain with a pageant of show wherein nature be the only actor here the deer come down feed by the water side as if they have desire acquaintance with these newcome guest there the bird in unspeakable variety of kind and colour render their service to the eye and ear the land either in large plain of many mile bare their beautiful bosom adorn with Flora embroidery of unknown flower and plant and prostrate themselves to the eye that they may be see or else lift up themselves in hill knit their furrow brow and strut out their goggle eye to watch their treasure which they keep imprison in their stony wall and now to see these stranger the water as the grace dance with mutual and manifold embrace of diverse stream attend with plenty of foul and fish both land and water feast variety of sense with variety of object only the crocodile a creature which seem vassal now to the land now to the water but to make prey on both well-nigh mar the play and turn this comedy into a tragedy even in their sight feast himself with a negro of their company one level pass hence to cumana a hundred and twenty league to the north wherein dwell the Say^a the Assawa^ the Wikiri and the Aroras a people as black as negro but with smooth hair their poison arrow like cruel executioner do not only kill but with uncouth torment make death to be as the last so the least of their fury especial if man drink after they be wound at the port of Morequito they anchor and the king be a hundred and ten year old come a foot fourteen mile to see they and return the same day they bring they store of first-fruit and a sort of paraquito no big than wren and a * * ouy in Summar call it Bardato Armadilla which seem to be all bar over with small plate somewhat like to a rhinoceros with a white horn grow in his hinder-part as big as a great hunt horn which they use to wind in stead of a trumpet they after eat this beast Monardus f f Monard c.37 say it be in bigness and snout like a pig live under the earth as a mole and be think to live on earth they pass further till they come in sight of those strange overfalls of Caroli of which there appear ten or twelve in sight every one as high over the other as a church-tower they have sight at Winicapora of a mountain of crystal which appear a far off like a white church-tower of a exceed height there fall over it a mighty river which touch no part of the side of the mountain but rush over the top fall to the ground with so terrible noise as if a thousand great bell be knock one against another no marvel of these roar out-cry if we consider that double penalty of sense and loss which this river seem to sustain the one in that dreadful downfall bruise and break his unite stream into drop and make it foam and senseless with this falling-sickness the other in leave behind his crystal purchase further enrich with diamond and other jewel which even now he embrace in his watery arm but himself such be the course and curse of covetousness will not suffer himself to enjoy now for the monster of man there be say to be not see by our man but report by the savage and other a amazonian nation further south which Gomara think to be but the wife of some indian a thing common as you have even now read shoot and follow the war no less than their husband once about jucatan about about the river call of this great river * * p. martyr dec. 7.lib.10 and dec. 3.lib.4 call of the inhabitant Dabaiba the spaniard have name it Rio grande and the river of saint John it pass with a northern discovery into the gulf of Vraba before mention they which dwell on this river observe a idol of great note call by the name of the river Dabaiba whereto the king at certain time of the year send slave to be sacrifice from remote country from whence also be great resort of pilgrim they kill the slave before their god and after burn they suppose that odor acceptable to their idol as taperlight and frankincense say martyr be to our saint through the displeasure of that angry God they say that all the river and fountain have once fail and the great part of man perish with famine their king in remembrance hereof have their priest at home and chapel which be sweep every day and keep with a religious neatness when the king think to obtain of the idol sunshine or rain or the like he with his priest get up into a pulpit stand in the chapel purpose not to depart thence till his suit be grant they urge their god therefore with vehement prayer and cruel fast the people mean while macerate themselves also with fast in four day space not eat nor drink except on the four day only a little broth the spaniard ask what god they worship thus they answer the creator of the heaven sun moon and all invisible thing from who all good thing proceed and they say Dabaiba * * they say Dabaiba be a woman of great wisdom honour in her life deify after death to who they ascribe thunder and lightning when she be angry be the mother of that creator they call they to their devotion with certain trumpet and bell of gold the bell have clapper like in form to we make of the bone of fish and yield a please sound as they report which no doubt be a please sound and music to the spaniard covetous heart howsoever it agree with the nature of that mettle to ring in the ear one of they they say weigh six hundred * * exceed the ducat a four part their priest be enjoin chastity which vow if they violate they be either stone or burn other man also in the time of that fast likewise contain themselves from those carnal pleasure they have a imagination on the soul but know not what substance or name to ascribe unto it to which yet they believe be assign future joy or woe accord to their demerit point up to heaven and down to the centre when they speak thereof many of their wife for they may have many follow the sepulcher of their husband they allow not marriage with the sister of which they have a ridiculous conceit of the spot which they account a man in the moon that for this incest he be thither confine to the torment of cold and moisture in that mooneprison they leave trench on their sepulcher in which they yearly power mayes and some of their wine to the profit as they think of the ghost if a mother die while she give suck the poor nursling must not be orphan but be inter with she be put there to her breast and bury alive they imagine that the soul of their great man and their familiar be immortal but not other and therefore such of their servant and friend as will not be bury with they they think shall lose that privilege of immortality and the delight of those pleasant place where be eat drink dance and the former delicate of their former life they renew the funeral pomp of these great man yearly assemble thither with plenty of wine and meat and there watch all night especial the woman sing dreary lamentation with invective against his enemy if he die in the war yea cut the image of his enemy in piece in revenge of their slay lord this do they fall to drink of mays-wine till they be weary if not drunken yet after this they resume their song to his commendation with many dance and adoration when day appear they put the image of the decease into a great Canoa a boat of one tree capable of threescore oar fill with drink herb and such thing as in his life he have love which some carry upon their shoulder in procession about the court and set it down there again and burn it with all the content after which the woman fill with wine and empty of all modesty with loose hair secret not secret and variety of bacchanal gesture sometime go sometime fall sometime shake the weapon of the man and conclude with beastly sleep on the ground the young man exercise their dance and song pierce the middle of their privy member with the sharp bone of the rayfish bedew the pavement with the blood and their who be their physician and priest heal the same again in four day the have in those part magician without who advice they attempt nothing and neither hunt fish nor gather gold except the Tequenign^ or wizard think it fit to end this Dabaiban story martyr say for I will not further engage my credit for the truth that in camara which be at the head of this river there happen most terrible tempest from the east which throw down tree and house and in the last act of that tragedy be bring not by representation two foul monster of monstrous fowl such as the poet describe the harpy with woman face one of they so great that her leg be thick than a man thigh so heavy that the bough of the tree can not bear she so strong that she will seize on a man and fly away with he as a kite with a chicken the other be less and suppose to be the young one of the other corales Osorius and Spinosa tell martyr that they speak with many who see the great kill which be do by a stratagem for they make the image of a man and set it on the ground attend in the wood with their arrow till she the next morning seize on this prey and lose herself the young be never see after and happy you think not before neither but they add that the killer of she be honour as god and reward with present all q q Bot^r^ part ^^ lib. 6 these part form golden Castille and the gulf of Vraba to yield caribe or cannibal which eat man flesh and geld child to make they more fat and tender they have commerce with the devil and observe such superstition as he enjoin they they be great man-eater at the door of their house they have small court wherein be their grave in deep vault open to the east in which they bury their great man with all their wealth the curie be not far from they they have no temple nor idol they have conference with the devil they marry with their niece and sister and be man-eater they call the devil Xixarama they esteem virginity little worth in the province of s s cap. 19.and d. the devil do often appear to the indian in honour of who they sacrifice their captive take in war hang they up by the shoulder and pull out the heart of some of they in Paucora they have like devilish devotion and their priest be their oracle before the house of the chief lord be a idol as big as a man with his face to the east and his arm open they sacrifice two indian every Tuesday in the province of the devil in the province of Pozo in the house of their lord they have many idol in such resemblance as the devil have assume in his apparition and in those idol he will also speak and give answer in Carrapa t t chap. 23 they be extreme drunkard when any be sick they soon after by americus vesputius at the charge of the say king further discover the region be pleasant and wholesome the hill and valley equal agree in their unequalness the soil fat and fertile there be plenty of sugarcane a kind of balm express out of the herb Copaibas and many first-fruit which the country natural produce beside those which our Europe have communicate many sort there be of beast as a kind of swine b b which feed on grass sleep in the water Boterus which live in both element their fore-feet be short in proportion to the hinder make they slow in run and therefore be hunt commit themselves quick to the water resemble a mule but somewhat less slender snout the neither chap very long like a trumpet with round ear and short tail hide themselves in the daytime c c the spaniard leaf of tree on which it be two day in climb and as many in descend neither shout nor blow force she to amend her pace the Tamendoas be as big as a ram with long and sharp snout a tail like a squirrel of horse and sheep the man worship no god at all but be give to sooth-saying the man and woman go altogether naked be flatnosed make themselves black with the fruit Genipapi wear their hair hang from the hinder part of the head not suffer it elsewhere to grow in their neither lip wear long stone for a gallantry which be remove they seem in deform manner to have a double mouth they go together by company with great silence the wife go before her husband they entertain and welcome stranger at first with weep and deep sigh pity their tedious journey and present dry their eye have tear at command woman in travel be deliver without great difficulty and present go about their household business the husband in her stead keep his bed be visit of the neighbour have his broth make he and junket send to comfort he they be ignorant of d d they know no number further than five the rest they supply as they can with their toe and finger and if the thing number exceed they number by the toe and finger of many person assemble together Stad lib. 2 c. 29 number and letter some tradition they be say to have touch Nae and the flood under the same roof which be like a boat with the keel upward live many family they lie in net or bed hang above the ground which be usual in a great part of the indies to avoid hurtful creature they mind the day and be not careful for the morrow easy communicate what they have be very patient of labour and hunger feast if they have wherewith from morning till night and fast otherwhiles when they want three day together in swim they be miraculous skilful and will dive whole hour to search any thing under the water they believe not any reward or punishment after this life end but think that as man die so they go to the other world maim wound sick or whole and therefore bury the body with a net to lie in and food for some day think that they both sleep and eat they be excellent archer and what enemy they take in their war they feed well many day and then kill and eat they for great dainty they dwell in house scatter and separate from each other their language be almost general the same they have no law nor magistrate the woman call certain thing by one name and the man by another they have no use of three letter e e it seem otherwise by his dialogue of that language c.20 in the alphabet l f r a reason whereof some have witty give because they Americae in the year 1554. be prisoner to the tuppin Imbas and because he serve the portugal shall have be slay and devour but by God mercy he escape he be the gunner in the fort of saint Vincent and go into the wood to provide somewhat wherewith to entertain some friend than come to he become himself a prey to those men-hunter when they have take he they contend which of they have be the first taker and that controversy end he be strip naked and lead away he be give to one of their king and this victory by they be ascribe to their or idol which they say have by oracle prophesy thereof but their king be no other than the chief in every cottage which consist of one kindred and these be certain rattle as shall after appear the manner be that it get they a great name to exhibit this feast of a slay captive and therefore some that have take will credit some other friend with the gift of a captive to this solemn butchery on condition to repay he the next captive he take this be Stadius his case who be thus toss by exchange from one to another till at last he escape altogether but when he have be new take the woman come about he and one while buffet he one say this be for such a friend of i that the Peros or portugal have slay another fix on his flesh the memorial of another friend of she and then lead he with a rope about his neck almost strangle he make he also to dance in the midst of they with rattle tie to his leg but he after grow in some credit and respect amongst they and see diverse other eat while himself can not be free from fear of the like destiny the savage that they take put on a great show of resolution and little regard in seem that their tragedy support with this comfort that their friend will revenge it in time of sickness or sudden danger they will resort to he to pray to his GOD for deliverance and this conceit of his GOD which they observe in his devotion be the principal mean of defer his execution such as be mortal wound in their fight they will spend present or at least kill and dress they for a feast near at hand and one man that have live long amongst they and be desperate sick left death shall deptive they of their cheer they slay and because of his sickness hurl away the head and innards eat up the rest they take great pride in this their cruelty and when K^nyan Bebe their king have a basket full of piece of man flesh on which Nu^g in amer. a knight of Malta surname Villagagnon in the year 1555. malcontent with his estate at home sail into Francia Antarctica or the southern part of brasil under the tropic of Capricorn and pretend there to worship GOD accord to the purity of the gospel and to fortify both for the habitation of his own and for a sanctuary unto such as at home be persecute for the truth he fortify and send thence to Geneva for assistance in this his holy intent whereupon Richerius and Charterius two minister with diverse other among who be John be send and land there in the year 1577. have write his observation of these part as theuct also another of villagagnons company but as testify in many thing false the first savage that and his fellow see be the margaiate which hold friendship with the portugal and be enemy to the french and to the tovou pinambaulsy or tuppin Imbas confederate of the french and as deadly enemy to the former in the mean way they pass by the tapem^ry Paraiba Ouctacates all which howsoever they exercise hostility and mutual disagreement yet agree in like barbarous and rightlesse rite with the tovou-pinambaulsy he converse familiar about a year they be in habit of body like the europeans but strong and less subject to sickness not subject to our bodily distemper by like intemperance or vexation of mind by turbulent and distract passion of covetousness envy ambition they be all naked except sometime the old man rather to hide their disease in those part than their shame cover their privity they wear in their neither lip a h h great at one end and little at the other in their infancy it be a bone and after a green stone in some as long as one finger they will thrust out their tongue at the hole when the stone be remove pyramidal stone which bravery weigh down their lip and subject the face to great deformity some also not content with this add two other in their cheek to like purpose they press down the nose of their infant to make they flat they anoint themselves with a kind of gum which they cover with the down of feather stick thereto they wear also frontlet of feather in their ear they wear bone they which will excel the rest in gallantry and will seem to have slay and eat the most enemy slash and cut their flesh and put therein a black powder which never will be do away they use rattle of the shell of a certain fruit in which they put stone or grain and call they Maraca of which they have some superstitious conceit the woman differ from the man in nourish their hair which the man shave off before and make not those hole in their lip but in their ear wear earing of the form and bigness of a mean candle they paint also their face with diverse colour and wear bracelet of little bone of which the man wear chain or collar they will not wear clothes pretend their custom of nakedness and often wash sometime ten time in a day whereto clothes will be a hindrance and our captive woman further than the whip force they will not accustom themselves to the apparel we give they the woman make two kind of meal of certain root which they use in stead of bread which they do not put but hurl into their mouth without loss their office be also to make their drink of root slice and chew in their mouth and thus prepare boil and stir in a great pot over the fire the like drink they make of chew mayes which they call Anati the man will account it a disgrace to do these thing and that they will not taste so well they call this drink Caovin it be thick and taste like milk I have see they continue say drink this liquor three day and night together they hold it a disparagement not to be able to hold out at this bacchanal exercise which they celebrate with dance and sing especial at their beastly man-feast the woman dance apart from the man one of they report to our author that they have take a ship of the Peros or portugal and eat the man they find therein great vessel which they can not tell what it be but drink so much thereof that they sleep three day after it be likely that it be spanish wine they eat serpent and toad which with they be not venomous and lizard our author see one lizard as big as a man with scale on her back like oyster they have a kind of monkey call Sagovin of the bigness of a squirrel the fore-halfe in shape resemble a lion they have another strange beast call coaty as high as a hare with a little head sharp ear and a snout or beak above a foot long the mouth so little that one can scarce put in his little finger it feed on ants. they take i i the Brasilian Petum be neither in form nor virtue the same with tobacco as say the woman take it not Petum it be not tobacco not in pipe but put four or five leaf in another great and fire it suck in the smoke and therewith in time of war will sustain themselves three day together without other sustenance they wear this herb about their neck chap. v. of the war man-eating and other rite of the brasilians the brasilians exercise irreconciliable hostility not to enlarge their dominion but only to be revenge for the death of their friend and ancestor slay by their enemy the elder man as they sit or lie in their hang bed will make a oration of the virtue of their predecessor and of their sustain wrong and so excite the young to take arm these oration last sometime six hour their arm be club or wooden sword five or six foot long and a foot broad a finger thick and very sharp one of these man be thorough move will trouble two of our fencer their bow be as long as we the string make of the herb little yet able to endure the strength of a horse their arrow a ell long which they will shoot twice as fast as our man they have leather shield their elder man lead the rank if they may be so call which have none to marshal or order they and with great shout and show the enemy the bone of their slaine-friend they enter into a fierce battle their captive they convey in the midst of their army home to their territory and thereunto the man will not stick to give their sister or daughter to perform all the duty of a wife and feed they with the best till they redemand the same out of their flesh the man be employ if it be long before the slaughter in hunt fowl fish the woman in garden or gather oyster when that dismal day approach knowledge be give and the man woman and child assemble to the place appoint and there pass the morning in drink and the captive although he know the dreadful issue dance drink and frolicke it with the best after six or seven hour thus spend two or three of the strong fasten a rope about his middle leave his arm at liberty and so lead he up and down the village in triumph neither do he for all this hang down his head as man go to be hang but with incredible courage emblazon his own worthiness thus thus say he have I sometime bind your kindred and thy father say he to one have I devour and thy brother to another have I bouc^ned and eat and what innumerable number of you tovou Pinambausy have these hand take this throat swallow neither will the margaiate suffer this my death unrevenged then they bring he stone and bid he revenge his death he hurl they at those which stand about he whereof there be some four thousand and hurt diverse I see one say our author who leg I have think have be break by the violence of one of those blow after this come one which all this while have be hide with the a a this club they call pern^m which be consecrate to this mischief by certain ceremony of sing and paint fatal club and be not thou one of the margaiate say he and have thou not devour our kindred the other answer oh how lusty I have do it how prompt have I be in take they how greedy in eat and therefore repli the other shall thou be kill and roast on the Boucan what then say he my death shall not be b b this confidence be as well in the woman as in the man unrevenged the club end their dialogue with one blow strike he dead his wife if he have any as they sometime use to bestow on their capitue come to the carcase and spend a little time and passion in mourn but her crocodile tear be soon dry and the humour fall into her tooth which water for the first morsel the other woman especial the elder which be most cruel and greedy bring hot water and wash the body and rub it till it look like the skin of a pig then come the master of the feast which owe the captive and cut it out as ready as any butcher with we can do a weather they daub the child c c ^o Stad lib.2.cap ^9 with the blood four woman carry about the arm and leg for a show with shout and cry the trunk be divide into two part the upper part be cut and separate from the low the innards be leave to the woman which see and make broth of they call Mingau which they sup up with their child they eat also the flesh about the head the brain tongue and that which within the head may serve for meat be the child share the author of the feast have a new name add to the former for they have so many name as they have slay captive the chief of the cottage brand he on the arm with a honourable mark for the memory thereof and all that day he must spend in quiet the d d Stad l.2.c.3 be a kind of brasilians which hold confederacy with no other nation but kill all which come to their hand and that so cruel that they will cut off their arm and leg while they be alive these live in the mountain they cut they with stone and those which have trade with the christian use knife their Boucan be a grediron of four cratche set in the ground a yard high and as much asunder with billet lay thereon and other stick on they grate-wise on this they roast the flesh put fire under all the people stand about the same and every one get a little piece of he but i think I see horror express in the countenance of he that read this and every one weary of view this tragedy loathe this inhuman feast with human flesh I will therefore leave their shambles and which better beseem a pilgrim will visit their holy and holy place but alas where or what be they Maffaeus have already tell we that they observe no god and confirm the same yet show that they acknowledge a devil who they call Aygnan not that they worship he but be torment by he even in speak of he e e ler. cap.16 they tremble and the remembrance breed a compassion at amazement in the hearer a amaze passion in the speaker while he applaud our happiness free from such tyranny deplore his own misery he sometime in the form of a beast sometime in form of a bird and otherwhiles deform in some monstrous shape do grievous torment they even while the christian be in conference with they they will piteous cry out hei help Aygnan vex i nor can this be counterfeit in the judgement of any that converse with they they believe the immortality of the soul and that the soul of the virtuous that be in their fence of such as have kill and eat many enemy shall fly beyond the high mountain and be gather to the soul of their progenitor and there live in pleasant garden and perpetual dance and delicacy the cowardly ghost shall be carry unto torment by Aygnan without end they have no name whereby to signify GOD unto they but wonder to hear what the frenchman tell of the creator of heaven and earth and because they be afraid of thunder which they call Toupan they tell they that GOD be author thereof the foolish indian reply that he be then naught which will make they afraid but the fear of Aygnan make they sometime flexible to embrace the christian religion hear that this devil be inferior to the christian god. so that even in these the most degenerate of all which I have observe in this long and tedious pilgrimage there be some spark leave of religion even in the acknowledgement of a devil and of eternal reward and punishment this be further confirm by that which be write of certain magician or priest amongst they which persuade the people that they have deal with spirit that by their mean they have their root and sustenance and may by they have fortitude I say be present at one of their assembly where six hundred be gather together which divide themselves into three part the man go into one house the woman into a second the child into a three the caraibe forbid the woman and child to depart their house but to attend diligent to sing and we say he be command to abide with the woman anon the man in one house fall to sing he he he answer by the woman in the other with the same they howl it out for a quarter of a hour shake their breast and foam at the mouth and as if they have have the fall sickness some fall down in a swoon the devil in seem enter into they the child also follow in the same harsh devotion after this the man sing pleasant which cause i to go thither where I find they sing and dance in three several ring in the midst of each three or four caraibe adorn with hat and garment of feather every one have a Maraca or rattle in both his hand these rattle be make of a fruit big than a ostrich egg out of which they say that the spirit will speak and they continual shake they for the due consecration these caraibe dance to and fro and blow the smoke of Petum on the stander by say receive you all the spirit of fortitude whereby you may overcome your enemy this they do often the solemnity continue two hour the man ignorant of music and yet ravish my spirit with the delight I conceive in their song their word sound this that they be grieve for the loss of their progenitor but be comfort in the hope that they shall one day visit they beyond the hill and then threaten the Ovetacates f f ler. c.5 which dwell not far from they and at enmity with all their neighbour as swift as heart wear their hair to the buttock eat raw flesh and differ from all other in rite and language and now prophesy their destruction at hand some what also they add in their song of the flood that once have drown all the world but their ancestor which escape by climb high tree that day they feast with great cheer this solemnity be celebrate every three year and then the caraibe appoint in every family three or four Maraca to be adorn with the best feather and stick in the ground with meat and drink set before they and the people believe they eat it they minister unto their Maraca fifteen day after which in a superstitious conceit they think that a spirit speak to they while they rattle their Maraca they be exceed offend if any take away any of this provision as the french sometime do for which and deny other the caraibe lie those priest hate they exceed yet do they not adore their Maraca or any thing else Stadius g g Stad l.2.c.23 tell as you hear that they ascribe his take to the prediction of their Maraca he tell of their consecration that the h h Le^tu^ say shall receive the faculty of speech every one rattle be pitch in the ground by the steel or stalk and all of they offer to the wizard which have the chief place arrow feather and earring he than breathe Petnn on every rattle put it to his mouth shake it and say Ne Kora that be speak if thou be within anon follow a squeak voice which I say Stadius think the wizard do but the people ascribe it to the then those wizard persuade they to make war say that those spirit long to feed on the flesh of captive this do every one take his rattle and build up a room for it to keep it in where he set victual require and ask all necessary thereof as we do of God and these as Stadius affirm be their gods. these Paygi do initiate woman unto witchcraft by such ceremony of smoke dance and hundred till she fall as in the fall sickness and then he say he will revive she and make her able to foretell thing to come and therefore when they go to the war they will consult with these woman which pretend Thevet Antarct which be in France with Villagagnon agree in many of the former report he add that for fear of Aignan they will not go out but they will carry fire with they which they think be forceable against he that the Paygi exercise poison conjuration and other thing which I know not with what authority he aver against the former witness whereas Thevet sometime take in lie deserve less credit in the rest when there be any tempest in the water he say they attribute it to the soul of their progenitor and cast something into the water to appease it they have a tradition that one in habit like to the christian have long since tell their progenitor of divine matter but to so little effect as he forsake they and ever since have those bloody war continue amongst they how little the jesuite can prevail in bring the brasilians to Christianity k k maff. l. 15 piecre du jarric l. 3.a.c.22 have write somewhat and pierre du jarric a jesuite very large which be not so pertinent to our present purpose in marriage l l ler. c. 17 they abstain only from mother sister and daughter they observe no marriage-ceremony but upon consent of her friend and her own take she home it be a credit to have many wife amongst who be no Leah to envy Rachel great portion of love the husband may kill the adulteress but for their unmarried maiden they be not serupulous our author hear a woman cry in the night think she have be in some danger of devour by a wild beast but find her husband play the homely midwife to she in her travel bite off the navell-string and press down the nose the father wash and paint he they use to put to their male infant little bow and arrow into the bed and chat out their hope of the child valour in be avenge when he shall be a man upon his enemy they name their child at adventure by the name of a beast bird or otherwise as this child be call Orapacon that be bow and arrow the man be modest in accompany with their wife secret the woman have not the ordinary feminine sickness think that humour be divert in their youth see the mother cut their daughter side down to the thigh at twelve year of age but twice while he be there do he see any in private brawl or contention if such happen as they begin so they be suffer to end it if any hurt or kill other he sustain the like in his own person inflict by the kindred of the party wrong they have their proper piece of ground which they husband with their root and maize when they entertain a stranger the or goodman seem to neglect he a while and the guest sit he down silent on the bed the woman sit by on the ground and hold their hand before their eye weep with many praise that he be a good man a valiant man that if he be a christian he have bring they fine ware the stranger must endeavour in some measure to imitate the like weep gesture the be all this while whittle his arrow not seem to see his new guest till anon he come and be you come say he how do you with many term of his best rhetoric and then ask if he be hungry and if he be set his cheer before he on the ground which kindness be repay with glass comb or the like they be very kind both to their own and to such stranger as they be enleague with they will carry burden or man for the space of some mile when they need their love and hatred be in like extreme the one to their own the other to their enemy they have physician call page they use much mourn at the death of any and make a round pit bury he upright therein six hour after his death with that wealth they have in their village live some six hundred person they remove their village often which yet carry the same name Stadius m m sted l.2.c.5 say there be few village of above seven house but those house be a hundred and fifty foot long and two fathom high without Lopez Vaz write that the governor which the king of Spain send for Peru and new Spain have a custom to discover new country the licentiate Castro be governor of Peru send forth a fleet from lima which sail eight hundred league westward find certain island in eleven degree to the south of the equinoctial with a kind of people of yellowish complexion and all naked here they find hog dog hen clove ginger cinnamon and some gold. the first island they name Izabella the great Guadalcanal on the coast whereof they sail a hundred and fifty league where they take a town and some grain of gold hang up in the house they burn their town because they have in a sudden surprise kill fourteen of their man they spend fourteen month in this discovery and name they the island of Solomon that by that name man may be further induce to discover and inhabit they imagine that Solomon have his gold from thence b b bot. part. 1.vol.2 Guinea be discover by villalobos send from new Spain in the year 1543 go to discover the Moluccas the inhabitant be black of hue and witty the spaniard have coast it seven hundred league and yet can tell whether it be a isle or continent Hesselius gerardus have large set forth the petition or memorial of c c p fer. de Quir Detecti^ Incogenit^ Peter Ferdinandez de Quir unto the king of Spain about his discovery of those southern unknown land for the plantation of the same wherein he declare unto his majesty that fourteen year space he have busy himself to no small endamagement of his state and person about the same the length thereof he equal unto all Europe and as much of Asia as thence extend to the caspian sea and for the wealth and riches he call it a terrestrial paradise the inhabitant he affirm be innumerable some white some like the Mulatos and some otherwise in colour and habit of body diversify they neither have king nor law nor Arts. they be divide and war one upon another with bow arrow and other weapon all of wood they have their oratory and place of burial their bread be make of three fort of root they have variety of first-fruit almond of four sort pome-citrons apple date there be also swine goat hen partridge and other fowl and as the therefore the conqueror and conquest of Peru let we consider the country itself with such observation as we shall there find touch their religion chap. 9 of the country of Peru natural occonomical and political observation the kingdom of Peru extend a a p. de Citea part.1.c.36 seven hundred league in length in breadth a hundred in some place in some threescore in other forty more or less accord unto the difference of place quito and be the utmost city thereof the one border on Popayan the other upon chili it be not here mean of that spacious kingdom of the ingua for that reach twelve hundred league whereof this of Peru be but a part acosta b b accost libr. 3 ca. 20 number diverse strange specialty except from the general rule of nature wont course the first that it blow continual on all that coast with one only wind and that also differ from that which usual blow between the tropike namely the south and Southwest the second that this wind in other place unhealthful be heer^ so agreeable that otherwise it can not be habitable the three that it never rain thunder snow nor hail in all this coast and yet which be a four wonder a little distance from the coast it snow and rain terrible five there be two ridge and mountain which both run in one altitude and the one in view of the other almost equal above a thousand league and yet on the one part be great forest and it rain the great part of the year be very hot the other be all naked and bare and very cold so that Peru be divide into three part which they call Llanos Sierras and andes the first run alongst the sea-coast the Sierras be hill with some valley and the andes be steep and craggy mountain the Llanos or plain on the sea-coast have ten league in breadth in some part less and in some a little more the Sierra contain with equal inequality twenty league and the andes as much sometime more and sometime less they run in length from north to south and in breadth from east to west and in this so small a distance it rain almost continual in one place and never in the other in the plain never on the andes in a manner continual though some time it be more clear there then other the Sierra in the mid be more moderate in which it rain from September to April as in Spain but in the other half year when the sun be further off it be more clear the Sierras yield infinite number of vicague which be like wild goat and Pacos a kind of sheepe^asses profitable for fleece and burden the andes yield parrot ape and monkey some c c Botero report that monstrous birth do sometime proceed as by nature unwilling hand from the copulation of these barbarian and these monkey the Sierre open themselves cause valley where be the best dwelling in Peru and most plentiful of Maiz and fruit it be strange d d Cieza pa.1 ca. 72 that in the valley of Pachacama neither the high element yield rain nor the low any stream and yet there be plenty of root Maiz and first-fruit they have large and deep ditch in which they sow or set and that which grow be nourish with the dew and because the Maiz will not grow except it first die they set one or two pilchard head which fish they take with their net very plentiful in the sea therewith and thus it grow abundant the water which they drink they draw out of deep pit e e accost libr.3 ca. 21 come from the mountain to the valley they do usual see as it be two heaven one clear and bright the other obscure and as it be a grey veil spread underneath which cover all the coast and although it rain not yet this mist be wonderful profitable to bring forth grass and to raise up and nourish the seed and where they have plenty of water which they draw from the pool and lake yet if this moisture fail there follow great defect of grain and which be more worthy of admiration the dry and barren sand in some place as in the sandy mountain near the city de Loy be by this dew beautify with grass and flower insome place they water their field out of the river beyond the city of cusco the two ridge of mountain separate themselves and in the midst leave a plain and large champain which they call the province of callao where there be many river and great store of fertile pasture there f f accost ibi.c.16 Cieza p. 1.c.103 be also the great lake of which contain four score league in compass and rob ten or twelve great river of their water which they be carry to the sea but here be drink up by the way of this lake they sail in it with ship and bark the water be not altogether sour nor salt as that of the sea but be so thick that it can not be drink upon the bank of this lake be habitation as good as any in Peru. the great lake pass by a river into a less lake call Aulagas from whence it have no manner of passage except there be any under the earth there be many other lake in the mountain which seem to arise rather from spring then from raines or snowes and some of they yield Rivers at the end of the valley of Tarapaya near to Potozi there be a round lake who water be very hot and yet the country be very cold they bathe themselves near the bank for further in it be intolerable in the midst be a boil above twenty foot square it never increase nor decrease although they have draw from it a great stream for mettall-mill but to return from this plenty of water in lake to that want thereof in the plain of Peru. the natural reason which some yield of this want of rain be partly their sandy and dry quality which of themselves can yield no further exhalation then to produce those mist or dew partly the height of the hill which shadow the plain and suffer no wind to blow from the land upon they but intercept they whole with their vapour and cloud so that their wind be only from the sea which find no opposite do not press nor strain forth the vapour which rise to engender rain this seem the rather to be probable for that it rain upon some small hill along the coast which be least shadow in the same coast also where the easterly or northerly wind be ordinary it rain as in Guayaquill the south wind in other place be g g cit a^. ovid. account a causer of rain which here reign without rain as strange be the difference of season after the indian account for in the h h Cieza c. 59 their summer begin in April and end with September October begin their winter which not the absence but the presence of the sun do cause contrariwise in the plain just by in site they have their summer from October to April the rest their winter the reins in the hill be cause why they call it winter and the dew or mist in the plain so that when the reins fall most in the hill it be clear weather in the plain and when the dew fall in the plain it be clear on the hill and thus it come to pass that a man may travel from winter to summer in one day have winter to wash he in the morning and ere night a clear and dry summer to scorch he about the point of St. Helena in Peru they i i Cieza c.25 tell that sometime there live giant of huge stature which come thither in boat the compass of their knee be as much as of another man middle they be hate of the people because that use their woman they kill they and do the same to the man for other cause k k the like do Apollodorus and the poet tell of Trphon and other giant ap. Orig l.1 and Hyginus sab 152. these giant be addict to sodomy and therefore as the indian report be destroy with fire from heaven whether this be true or no in those part be find huge and giantlike bone contrariwise in the valley of l l Cieza c. 74 they have a tradition that the progenitor of the present inhabitant destroy the native people which be not above two cubit high and possess their room in testimony whereof they allege also that bone-argument concern the indian conceit of their own original we have mention their opinion of a flood and the repeople of the world by they which come out of a cave m m accost l.1.c.25 they have a other legend that all man be drown there come out of the great lake one Viracocha which stay in Tiaguanaco where at this day be to be see the ruin of very ancient and strange building and from thence come to cusco and so begin mankind to multiply they show in the same lake a small island where they fain that the sun hide himself and so be preserve n n Cieza pag. 1 cap. 103 and for this reason they make great sacrifice unto he in this place both of sheep and man they hold this place sacred and the Inguas build there a temple to the sun and place there woman and priest with great treasure some o o accost ibid. learned man be of opinion that all which the indian make mention of be not above four hundred year which may be impute to their want of writing in stead of writing they use their Quipos p p ac. l.6.c.8 these Quippos be memorial or register make of cord in which there be diverse knot and colour signify diverse thing these be their book of history of law ceremony and account of there affair there be officer appoint to keep they call Quipocamayos which be bind to give account of thing as notary and register they have accord to the diversity of business sundry cord and branch in every of which be so many knot little and great and string tie to they some red some green and in such variety that even as we derive a infinite number of word from the letter of the alphabet so do they from these kind and colour and at this day they will keep account exact of they I do see say acosta a handful of these string wherein a indian woman
