art more for ornament then necessity they have goldsmith painter potter and weaver of curious work for noble man and so of the rest no man may change the fashion use in his own country when he go into another that all may be know of what country they be for their marriage they have many wife but one be principal which be wed with solemnity and tha^n this sort the bridegroom go to the bride house and put Ottoya which be a open shoe on her foot this if she be a maid be of wool otherwise of reed and this do he lead she thence with he if she commit adultery she be punish with death when the husband die she carry a mourn weed of black a year after and may not marry in that time which befall not the other wife the Ingua himself with his own hand give this woman to his governor and captain and the governor assemble all the young man and maid in one place of the city where they give to every one his wife with the aforesaid ceremony in put on the Ottoya the other wife do serve and honour this none may marry with his mother daughter grandmother or grandchild and Yupangui the father of Gnaynacapa be the first Ingua that marry his sister and confirm his fact by a decree that the Inguas may do it command his own child to do it permit the noble man also to marry their sister by the father side other incest and murder theft and adultery be punish with death such as have do good service in war be reward with land arm title of honour and marriage in the lineage they have or post in Peru which be to carry tiding or letter for which purpose they have house a league and a half a funder and run each man to the next they will run fifty league in a day and night when the Ingua be dead his lawful heir bear of his chief wife succeed and if the king have a legitimate brother she first inherit and then the son of the first he inherit not the good as be say already but they be whole dedicate to his oratory or Guaca and for the entertainment of the family he leave which with his offspring be always busy at the sacrifice ceremony and service of the decease king for be dead they present hold he for a god make image and sacrifice to he the ensign of royalty be a red roll of wool fine than silk which hang on his forehead which be as a diadem that none else may wear in the midst of their forehead at their ear the nobleman may when they take this roll they make their coronation feast and many sacrifice with a great quantity of vessel of gold and silver and many image in the form of sheep of gold and silver and a thousand other of diverse colour then the chief priest take a the patient reader chap. 12 of their supputation of time of the feast sepulcher and other peruvian superstition before we speak of the peruvian festival time it be not amiss to take some more general view of their calendar they a a acosta libr. 6.^a.3 divide their year into so many day just as we do and into so many month or moon to make the computation of their place certain they use this industry upon the mountain about cusco there be twelve pillar set in order and in such distance as every month one of these pillar do note the rise and set of the sun they call they Saccanga by mean whereof they teach and show the feast and the season fit to sow and reap and for other thing they do certain sacrifice to these pillar of the sun every month have his peculiar name and feast they sometime begin the year in januarie but since a Ingua call Pachacuto which signify a reformer of the temple begin their year in December by reason as it seem of the sun return from Capricorn their near tropic I read not of any week they observe for which they have not so certain a rule as the sun course be for the year and the moon for the month they observe in Peru two kind of feast some ordinary which fall our in certain month of the year and other extraordinary which be for certain cause of importance every month of the year they make feast and sacrifice and have this alike the offering of a hundred sheep but of unlike colour and form accord to the month in the first month they make their first and principal feast therefore call capacrayme that be to say a rich and principal feast in it they offer a great number of sheep and lamb in sacrifice and burn they with sweet wood then they cause gold and silver to be bring upon certain sheep set upon they three image of the sun and three of the thunder the father the son and the brother in these feast they dedicate the b b knight of Peru. Inguas child put the guaras or ensign upon they and they pierce their ear then some old man do whip they with sling and anoint their face with blood in sign that they shall be true knight to the Ingus no stranger may remain in cusco during this month and this feast but at the end thereof they enter and be make partaker of the feast and sacrifice after this manner c c acosta libr. 5 ca. 23 the Mamacomas or nun of the sun make little loaf of the flower of Maiz die and mingle with the blood of white sheep which they do sacrifice that day then they command that all stranger shall enter who set affection for that this piece shall be a witness of their intention and if they do not as they ought will discover they they carry these small loaf in great platter of gold and silver appoint for that purpose and all do receive and eat those piece thank the sun and the Ingua this manner of communicate they use likewise in the ten month call coyarayme which be September in the feast call Cytua they likewise send of these loaf to all the guaca of the realm whither the people assemble to receive they to who they say that the sun have send they that in sign that he will have they honour he and the they offer a hundred sheep more of all colour and then make a feast bring Maiz from the field into the house which they yet use this feast be make come from the farm to the house say certain song and pray that the Maiz may long continue they put a quantity of the Maiz the best that grow in their farm in a thing which they call Pirua with certain ceremony watch three night then do they put it in the rich garment they have and be thus wrap and dress they worship this Pirua hold it in great veneration and say it be the mother of the Maiz of their inheritance and that by this mean the Maiz augment and be preserve in this month they make a particular sacrifice and the witch demand of this Pirua if it have strength enough to continue until the next year and if it answer no than they carry this Maiz to the farm whence it be take to burn and make a other as before and this foolish vanity still continue in the seven month they make the feast Intiraym^ and sacrifice a hundred guanaco in the cord this hunt fish present lay hold on the prey and with a skin like a purse grow behind her head grasp it so fast that by no mean it can be take from she till they draw she up above the water and then not able to abide the air she resign her prey to the fisher which leap out into the water and take it in recompense whereof they give her part of her purchase he find also in this coast water after they have run fourscore and ten mile and such a sink or channel of water in the cave the islander believe that the island have a vital spirit and that there it do breath and a hole therein be almost swallow with the whirlpool and boil of the water cloud engender of those watery conflict and darkness lay hold on his eye terrible noise as of the fall of Nilus make deaf his ear that when with labour he have get out he seem to have escape the barking of Cerberus and the obscure vault of hell. upon the top of high mountain the same Moralis see a lake three mile in compass into which many little river run without any other apparent issue in Bainoa be a lake of salt water notwithstanding it receive four great fresh river from the east west north and south and twenty small and within a furlong of the lake on the north side be two hundred fresh spring it be think to have a large intercourse with the ocean because there be shark great sea-fish which devour man in the same here be storm and tempest which seem to be the cater and purveyor for those fish in drown many diverse other lake be mention in this island one whereof partly salt partly fresh be five and twenty mile long and eight broad they be all in a large plain a hundred and twenty mile in length and breadth between eighteen and five and twenty there be another vale two hundred mile long and broad than the former thirty thousand river and brook twelve of they be very great and all which come from the west twenty thousand in number be enrich with gold. Cotobi be a plain on the top of hill so high that it be subject to the four season of the year there be also another region of the same name most barren and yet most rich full of mine otherwise unfruitful a thing common in nature that great mine undermine fertility and not strange amongst man that the great hoorder of treasure be the most unfruitful and barren in good work the gold they say be as a live tree which root in the centre of the earth send forth branch unto the uppermost face of the earth and there show forth certain beautiful colour in stead of flower round stone of golden earth in stead of fruit and thin plate in stead of leave from this island d d dec. 3 l. 4 be yearly bring four or five hundred thousand ducat of gold yearly they imagine some divine nature to be in gold and therefore never gather it but they use certain religious expiation abstain from woman delicate meat and drink and all other pleasure there be a island a little from hispaniola which have a fountain in it come by secret passage under the earth and sea and rise in this island which they believe because it bring with it the leaf of many tree which grow in hispaniola and not in this island the spaniard call the isle Arethusa the isle c c r. Hak. to.3 of hispaniola be much infest with fly or gnat who prick cause wonderful swell also there be a worm which creep into the sole of man foot and make they grow as big as a man head with extremity of pain for which they have no remedy but to open the flesh sometime three or four inch and so dig they out the gnat f f mart. dec.7.9 be so troublesome that the inhabitant do therefore build low house and make little door which they keep close and forbear to light candle nature have to this disease ordain a remedy namely certain creature call which be a kind of beetle these have four light which shine in the night two in the seat of his eye and two which he show when he open his wing the people get these and bring they to their house which there do they a double service they kill the gnat and give so much light that man may see to read letter by the light of one and many of they seem as so many candle they have but three sort of fourfooted beast and those very little now man be exhaust and beast multiply in so strange manner that one Deane of the conception carry a cow thither she be alive six and twenty year after and her fruitful generation be multiply in the island to eight hundred they be now grow wild as their dog also they kill their cow for the hide five and thirty thousand be transport to Spain when acosta return 1587. before the discovery of this island by Columbus and the spaniard these islander of hispaniola be forewarned thereof by oracle their g g mart. dec. 1.l.9 cacike and that be their king and priest report to Columbus that the father of Garionebius the present king and another cacike will needs be importunate demaunder of their Zemes or god of future event and therefore abstain five day together from all meat and drink spend the time in continual mourn the Zemes make answer that there will come not many year after unto that island a strange nation clothe beard arm with shine sword that will cut a man asunder in the middle which shall destroy the ancient image of their god abolish their rite and slay their child to remember this oracle they compose a mournful ditty which they call are^to which on some solemn day they use to sing now concern these Zemes which can foretell that which they can not avert and the superstition of hispaniola h h mart. ibid. the spaniard have be long in the island before they know that the people worship any thing but i i they worship the sun and pray to it at sunrising the light of heaven but after by further converse and live amongst they they come to know more of their religion of which one Ramonus a spanish eremite write a book and martyr have borrow of he to lend we it be apparent by the image which they worship that there appear unto they certain illusion of evil spirit these image they make of Gossampine cotton hard stop sit like the picture of the devil which they call Zemes who they take to be the mediator and messenger of the great God which they acknowledge one eternal infinite omnipotent invisible of these they think they obtain rain or fair weather and when they go to the war they have certain little one which they bind to their forehead every king have his particular Zemes which he honour they call the eternal GOD by these two name jocauna and Gua^^aonocon as their predecessor teach they affirm that he have a father call by these five name Attaberra Mamona Guacarapita Liella Guimazoa they make the Zemes of diverse matter and form some of wood as they be admonish by certain vision appear to they in the wood other which have receive answer of they among the rock make they of stone some of root to the similitude of such as appear to they when they gather the root whereof they make their bread think that the Zemes send they plenty of these root they attribute a Zemes to the particular tuition of every thing as sometime the pagan and now the popish roman some assign to the sea other to fountain wood or other their peculiar charge when the consult with the Zemes they go into the house dedicate to he and with the powder of the herb Cohobba snuff into their nostril be distract after which return as out of a trance he tell that the Zemes have speak to he and utter his revelation they say that a certain king call Guamaretus have a Zemes who name be Corochotum which often use to descend from the top of the house where Guamaretus keep he close bind the cause of his break loose be either to hide himself or to go seek for meat or else for the act of generation and that sometime be offend that the king Guamaretus have not honour he diligent he be wont to lie hide for certain day in this king village be some child bear with two crown which they suppose to be the issue of this zemes. and when this village be burn by the enemy this Zemes break his band and be find a furlong off without any harm he have another Zemes call Epileguanita make of wood be in shape like a fourfooted beast which go often from the place where he be honour into the wood when they perceive that he be go a great multitude gather together to seek he with devout prayer and when they have find he bring he home religious on their shoulder to the chapel dedicate unto he but after the spaniard come into the island he flee for altogether and can never be find whereby they divine the destruction of their country they honour another Zemes in the likeness of a woman on who wait two other like man one of these execute the office of a messenger to the Zemes that have authority of cloud wind and rain and be at command of this woman the other perform the like to the Zemes of the water that fall from the hill that be loose they may break into flood and overflow the country if the people do not give due honour to her image let we add to this relation of the Zemes of hispaniola a accident in k k mart. dec. 2.l.6 Cuba a mariner be sick be there leave on shore who recover grow into favour with the king and be employ in his war with great success against the enemy he attribute his victory to the virgin Marie who picture he have in his bosom the king by his persuasion reject his Zemes and dedicate a chapel and altar to this picture whither he and all his family resort a little before the sunset bow their head and say further they can not say they be^et the same with jewel and many earthen pot some with sundry meat some with water round about the tabernacle which they offer in stead of sacrifice as before they have do to their zemes. be demand why they do thus they answer lest it shall lack meat for they believe that image may hunger and do eat and drink they tell of this picture that be carry with they into the war as they use to bring their zemes with they into the battle this make the Zemes of the enemy turn his back yea a woman a lie or a devil descend in the sight of they all to play the Bellona for her follower and in a contention betwixt they whether the Zemes or this lady be more excellent two young man of each side be bind and whether deity shall loosen her party that shall be their god. both invoke the devil appear in ugly shape and by and by a fair virgin whereat the devil vanish do you believe it and the virgin with touch of a rod loose her man band which be find on the other adverse party be now double-bound thus can the devil transform himself into a angel of light at Loretto in hispaniola and where else soever he can be entertain the name of saint and promise of heaven shall further his hellish design they have festival solemnity in hispaniola l l dec. 7.10 to their Zemes whereunto the king summon their subject by public crier and they neat dress after their manner and paint with diverse colour of herb resort thither with their arm thigh leg adorn with shell to make music in their dance thus they present themselves before the king who sit drum at the entrance of the gate when they be to sacrifice they purge themselves first thrust down a sacred hook into their throat and by vomit empty their body after they go into the king court and all sit in a ring about the idol crosslegged like tailor and wry-necked for reverence pray that their sacrifice may be accept the woman in another place when the priest give warning fall to dance and sing the praise of their Zemes and offer cake in basket conclude with song in praise of their ancient king and prayer for future prosperity after this both sex kneel down and offer their cake which the priest receive cut in piece give to every man a portion which he keep untouched the whole year for a holy relic esteem that house in danger of fire and whirlwind that be not preserve with this reserve piece of cake they seem sometime to hear a voice from their Zemes whether by the illusion of the priest or the devil which the priest interpret by their behaviour for if they dance and sing all be well but if they go sorrowful the people go forth sigh and give themselves to fast even to extreme faintness with weep until they think their Zemes reconcile touch the original of man thus they fable there be in the island a region call Caunana where they feign that mankind come first out of two cave of a mountain call and that the big sort of man come forth of the mouth of the big cave and the least sort out of the least cave this cave they name Amaianna the great Caziba^agua before man may come out of the cave the mouth thereof be keep and watch nightly by a man who name be Machoshael who depart further to look abroad be by the sun the sight of who he be forbid turn into a stone they feign the like of other turn into tree for go so far a fish in the night that they can not return before the rise of the sun a certain ruler also call Vagoniona send one forth of the cave a fish who by the sun surprisal be turn into a nightingale which therefore in the night bewail his misfortune Vagoniona sore trouble with this loss leave the man in the cave bring forth the woman and suck child and leave the woman in a island of that Tract call mathinine carry the child away with he which be oppress with famine faint and remain on the bank of a certain river where they be turn to frog and cry toa toa as child with they use to cry for the dug and hence also come those pitiful cry of the frog in the springtime as for Vogoniona he by special privilege be not transform wander in diverse place he descend to a certain fair woman who he see in the bottom of the sea and receive of her bright plate of Latin and a kind of stone which their king great esteem another cave they have for the former tale be endless as superstition common be call jonana adorn with picture of a thousand fashion in the entrance be two grave Zemes whereof one be call binthaitel and the other Marohu out of this cave they say the sun and moon first come to give light to the world they make religious concourse to these cave as man go on pilgrimage to Rome compostella or jerusalem they have a superstitious conceit of their dead who they think walk in the night and eat the fruit Guannaba which be like to a quince and that they will deceive woman in take the shape of man make as though they will have to do with they and sudden vanish away if any feel a strange thing in his bed make doubt whether it be a dead body he may be resolve by feeling on his belly because these ghost can take all other member of man body but not the navel as some with we imagine that the devil can take the whole shape of a man only his claw except these dead man they say often meet they by the way and if a man be not afraid they vanish but if he be afraid they will assault he and many hereby have be take with the loss of their limb these superstition be leave they by tradition in rhythm and song from their forefather which it be lawful for none to learn but only the king son they sing they before the people on solemn feast play on a instrument like a timbrel their or priest instruct they in these superstition these be also physician make the people believe that they obtain health for they of the zemes. they tie themselves to much fast and outward cleanlineffe and purge especial where they take upon they the cure of great man for than they drink the powder of a certain herb which bring they into a fury wherein they say they learn many thing of their zemes. much ado they make about the sick party deform themselves with many gesture breathe blow suck the forehead temple and neck of the patient sometime also say that the Zemes be angry for not erect a chapel or dedicate to he a gro^e or garden or the neglect of other holy and if the sick party die his kinffolke by witchcraft enforce the dead to speak and tell they whether he die by natural destiny or by the negligence of the in not fast the full due or minister convenient medicine so that be profitable for they in travel and honour they as they do their zemes. when their king die they bury the best belove of their concubine with they who also have other woman bury for their attendant rel. 5 protest that it do not appear to he that christian religion have be propound in meet sort to the indian miracle he hear not of but on the contrary scandal villainy and many impiety this be the preach and conversion the romist boast of and gull our european world with muster of their miracle and thousand of their profelite which we rather pity then envy how the case be alter since that new generation of the Ignatian brood have teach especial the spaniard who they be and who they serve a better Catholicisme let Arnauldus * * Arnauld against the jesuite tell you he say that they have indeed wrought miracle amongst the indian among which he reckon convert the pagan by butcherly subvert and ^^oting they out in hispaniola by keep the husband and wife in diverse work asunder the old generation be thus wear out and a new prevent in Peru they have public place of torture within the march wherein they may put a thousand at once by torture to draw forth confession of their hide treasure such as escape hang themselves in the mountain and their wife by they with their child at their foot by their dog at land they worry they and in their pearle-fishing expose they to the raven shark themselves more dogged and shark then the brute creature by fire and sword consume twenty million of the people I will give the devil his due and therefore will not ascribe all this to those late locust the jesuite who be yet account the most cunning and zealous architect in set up the roof of that aspire spanish monarchy these and the like bloody foundation notwithstanding and therefore may be call accessory after as for the spaniard we see they by testimony of their own accuse of the same thing and how the ignatians wash their hand not from but in blood our Europe can testify what devil bring the inquisition his fair daughter much resemble his accurse presence I know not our countryman r r phil. job Hort. ap. Philips Hortop and other know to their cost but what shall we speak of the spanish cruelty to other look on their deal with each other in civil broil thus deal they with Columbus reward he with chain and send he prisoner to Spain by that way which he first of all and for Spain have discover what Roldanus and his rebellious faction do in hispaniola and in the continent martyr relate but the bloody butchery pass in Peru where covetousness which before have join now divorce the heart of Pi^arro and almagro and after that that near conjunction of the head and body of almagro s s see Gomara Apollonius Benzo etc. of these civil war in Peru. revenge in the person of all the Pi^arri which again retort the like vengeance upon the almagrist their ghost seem or some hellish fury rather to be loose on that perwian stage and to have bring like mischief to the beholder and actor in this tragedy vengeance seem to have break forth of Atabalibas tomb arm with sword fire halters chain yea the spaniard themselves offer themselves her officious vassal to become cruel executor of her bloody will in mutual execution upon themselves the awful name of viceroy governor and captain be no less subject to imprisonment and death than the poor soldier but for these civil uncivil cruelty amongst themselves they require a good orator to describe they and those former tyranny upon the indian be beyond all oratory and description thunder from heaven have need be the voice to utter such hellish and unheard-of massacre devil from hell be fit scribe with the fiery character of their infernal worke-house to register they the read whereof may astonish the sense of the reader amaze his reason exceed his faith and fill his heart with horror and uncouth passion for i I want fit word to paint they in their black colour my hand with reluctation tremble at the writing my tongue falter in the speak and whole I seem to myself surprise with distraction and not to be myself while the view of this spanish Medusa transform i into a stone the rather when I think such shall our english conversion have be if in that dismal year 1588. England have as well succeed to they as the indies or if since our catholic preacher have prevail in their powder-proiect in the year 1605. who for a temple choose a vault that their work of darkness may be do in the dark and their workhouse may be near to hell thence to borrow at hand supply of devilish device and in near familiarity to consult with the devil for word they have prepare a sulphurous breath the smoke whereof may darken the heaven the fire may rend the tremble and astonish earth the noise may make the hearer past hear and be together once those hellish Cerberi by such preach have intend there to have open the mouth of hell upon we which shall have swallow our law our religion our sun moon and morningstar the king queen and prince our fair sky of fix and well order light then shine in their great splendour of parliament-brightnesse the giant of old be say to be the son of the earth but these as they be engender of earth so have they incestuous violate that their mother whether you understand it in a literal or mystical sense and beget in her womb this hell-monster of their bloody Catholicisme they have design the time of her travel and themselves will have be the midwife the devil have bid themselves as gossip and at that open of the earth womb in her fiery travel will have send that way into the world to attend the babe all the blacke-guard of hell treason superstition atheism ignorance fire sword and all confusion in a revolution of a worse chaos then that t t the word of Moses Genes. 1 interpret without form and void Tohu and Bohu of old can have effect then shall it have be no marvel if Rome France Spain or any other have exercise tyranny or cruelty see all must have come short of the first cruelty which our english catholic have execute to open the floudgate of blood unto they and all this be the catholic cause and these the preacher or the usher rather to the preacher for the jesuite will be angry if we take from they their bloody privilege of this new Catholicisme which the devil till now he be a old and cunning serpent have never learn himself no can learn other till he have get Ignatian usher in his hellish school but whither be your pilgrim transport friend I draw near my port and leave America behind i still red with this blood now also have England in sight which as from a great height be near to a more dangerous fall and in this subject which be of the spanish cruelty not write in hatred of their nation because they be spaniard but of their pseudo-chatholike religion under show whereof they there do and here will have execute those butchery and for thankfulness to GOD for our late deliverance of which the time when I relate these thing be the return of that very u u November 5 day wherein those thing shall have be effect just demand my best testimony I have thus tell out my story and now i think I see the shore of England from which my linger pilgrimage have long detain i I hear the bell and see the bonfire with public acclamation of thankfulness for that deliverance all sing their hallelujahs and say 10 10 psal. 118.24 this be the day which the lord have make we will rejoice and be glad in it and now I see a better sight than all my pilgrimage can yield christian church without heathenish jewish or antichristian pollution a royal king true entitle desender of the faith a learned clergy wise and honourable counsellor peaceable and loyal commons in a word England present itself to my eye represent to my mind a map of heaven and earth in the freedom of body and soul yea where our subjection and service be freedom which I have not elsewhere find in all my perambulation of the world I feel myself herewith ravish and in a joyful ecstasy can but cry out y y matth. 17.4 it be good for we to be here in the true church and suburb of the true heaven here than reader let i rest i till I see whether thy kind acceptation of this will make i willing to accept another and near but hard european pilgrimage trin-uni
